HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Bleak Job Picture Darkens the Mood

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
AT face value, the first estimate of gross national product in the third quarter, released by the Commerce Department this week, implies that the recession is over: total output of goods and services, adjusted for inflation, rose at an annual rate of 2.4 percent.
But practically nobody took the number at face value. Economists noted that the gain in G.N.P. was largely a result of a slower rate of inventory cutting. Inventories declined at an annual rate of $12.9 billion in the third quarter, less than half as fast as the $27.2 billion second-quarter drop. The slower decline added $14.3 billion to G.N.P. But final sales -- G.N.P. less inventory change -- rose by only six-tenths of 1 percent, just a smidgen above the gain of three-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter. 
 Even more disturbing, economic activity slackened after the summer. Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said the economy turned "demonstrably sluggish" in recent weeks. And the Conference Board reported that its index of consumer confidence plunged 12.5 points, to 60.4, in September -- arousing fears of a double dip.
A good part of the explanation for the bleak mood of consumers and the widespread disbelief that the recession is over is the persistence of unemployment -- and, among those who have not seen a pink slip, worry about being laid off.
Some of the most prominent American companies, in both services and goods, have announced layoffs. Edward S. Hyman of the International Strategy and Investment Group noted that just in October layoffs were announced by American Express, Pacific Telesis, Hercules, Amoco, Raytheon, Westinghouse, Allied-Signal, RJR Nabisco, Boeing, United Technology, Exxon, Sears, Campbell Soup, Citicorp, A.T.& T., Amoco, I.B.M., Bell Atlantic, Rockwell, Time Inc., General Electric, Wal-Mart, Chase Manhattan, U.S. Shoe and Phelps Dodge.
The reasons may differ from company to company: Some are military contractors, caught in cutbacks; some are retailers, hurt by consumers; some are banks, squeezed by bad loans; some are publishers, hit by weak advertising; some are victims of their own acquisitiveness, deep in junk bonds or other debt and struggling to cut costs. But payroll trims are seen as a universal elixir -- though corporate layoffs boomerang, depressing consumer confidence, corporate sales and profits.
To ordinary people, the prime measure of a recession is unemployment, not gross national product. And the unemployment rate, despite the third-quarter recovery in real G.N.P., stayed like an indigestible lump in the belly of the economy. The civilian jobless rate averaged 6.8 percent in the third quarter, the same as in the second. The jobless rate was down a hair to 6.7 percent in September (well within the reach of probable error.) Unemployment data for October will be announced this morning, but economists interviewed earlier saw no reason for significant change.
For black male teen-agers seeking work, the jobless rate in September was far worse -- 40.8 percent, up from 31.4 a year ago.
Thus far, the recovery, even assuming it is still in motion, has been too slow to bring down the jobless rate. In the 1960's, Arthur Okun of the Brookings Institution produced what was known as Okun's Law: That the economy must grow at an annual rate of 3 percent just to keep the unemployment rate constant. Since the law was promulgated, the rates of productivity growth and labor force growth have slowed, and an economic growth rate of only about 2.5 percent is consistent with a constant unemployment rate.
Thus, the 2.4 percent growth reported for the third quarter was not enough to bring down unemployment, but only to hold it steady. If economists are right that the fourth-quarter growth rate will slip to 1 or 2 percent, unemployment will probably worsen, increasing the anxieties of President Bush and other Republicans about the 1992 election.
What to do to get the jobless rate down, consumer confidence up and the economy humming again? The standard remedies are monetary ease and fiscal stimulus. The Fed this week seemed to be moving, albeit gingerly, toward greater ease, but there are concerns that, with consumer and business confidence down, pushing out reserves and pushing down interest rates is like "pushing on a string," in William McChesney Martin's phrase. The huge and growing budget deficit will inhibit either big tax cuts or big spending increases.
A different approach -- and an old-fashioned one -- would be a public jobs program. This is advocated by Sar Levitan and Frank Gallo of the Center for Social Policy Studies of George Washington University. In a new study, "Spending to Save: Expanding Employment Opportunities," they argue that this is the best way to alleviate joblessness, hardship and poverty, promote the work ethic and self-reliance, provide neglected goods and services and help the economy emerge from recession.
But the economy will probably have to get much worse before Congress and the President turn to a direct jobs approach.

HEADLINE: Affordability Of Housing Up

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
A combination of declining mortgage interest rates and housing prices made homes more affordable for the average family in September than they have been in 14 years, the National Association of Realtors said today.
The group said its housing affordability index stood at 116.1 for the month, up from a revised 111.2 in August. It was the largest monthly gain since record-keeping began in 1971 and the highest since May 1977 when it measured 118.6. 
 In September last year the index was 110.2.
The affordability index measures the ability of a family in the United States earning the national median income to buy a home at the median price.
Families earning the national median income of $36,361 a year had 116.1 percent of the income needed to qualify for a conventional home loan, the trade group said.
Regionally, it was easier to buy a house in the Midwest and South based on local median incomes and prices.
A Northeast family earning $40,049 had 93.0 percent of the income needed to buy a house priced at $136,900, while in the West, a family earning $37,788 had 83.3 percent of the income to buy a $144,000 home.
A Midwest family earning $37,491 had 156.6 percent of the income needed to buy a house priced at $76,300. A family in the South earning $32,703 had 113.7 percent of income to buy a $92,000 home, the group said.
The interest rate used to calculate the index was 9.17 percent, down from 10 percent a year ago.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Mixed as Traders Await Economic Reports

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed against other major currencies yesterday as traders anticipated further cuts in American interest rates.
Gold prices were mostly lower. 
 The dollar spent much of the day moving in a narrow range as traders waited for a batch of big economic indicators due out today.
In particular, the market was waiting to see what the Government's October employment report would show.
The question was whether the report would prompt the Federal Reserve to push interest rates lower for the second time this week. On Wednesday, the central bank appeared to signal that it was easing its monetary policy when it allowed the Federal funds rate to fall a quarter percentage point to 5 percent.
The funds rate is the interest banks charge one another on short-term loans.
Other reports due today include the Government's Index of Leading Indicators and its construction-spending figures.
No one was expecting good news. "We're generally still looking at a weak economy," said Earl Johnson, a vice president with Harris Trust in Chicago. He predicted the employment figures would be soft. Then the market will be "waiting to see if the Fed takes action," he said.
The dollar is likely to fall if today's reports are negative because the currency draws support from higher or stable rates.
The British pound fell against the dollar, slipping to $1.7395 in New York from $1.7445 late Wednesday. In earlier London trading, sterling rose to $1.7445 from $1.7425.
The dollar fell against the Japanese yen. In New York, it closed at 130.75 yen, down from late Wednesday's 131.05. In Japan overnight, the dollar fell 0.05 yen to 131 yen and in London, it was quoted at 130.55 yen.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Mixed in Slow Session

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed in slow trading yesterday, as credit market participants waited for the release of October's employment statistics this morning and wondered how the Federal Reserve Board might respond.
The Fed, which was thought by many to be easing monetary policy on Wednesday, did nothing yesterday to discredit the notion that it had indeed lowered its target for the overnight Federal funds rate to 5 percent from 5.25 percent. 
 At the same time, however, analysts said movements in the Federal funds rate yesterday did not entirely eliminate the possibility that market participants had attached more significance to what took place on Wednesday than the Fed intended.
 
Intrigue About the Fed
After opening at 5 percent, the Fed funds rate traded as high as 5 5/16 percent yesterday, before drifting back down.
"There is some intrigue lingering about the Fed," said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that provides research on the foreign-exchange and credit markets.
"But I think this is going to be an academic issue, because I think the employment report is going to be soft enough so that they will show they have eased," he said.
In advance of this morning's report, the consensus estimate among Wall Street economists was that nonfarm payroll employment rose by a very modest 18,000 last month.
 
Cut in the Discount Rate?
 Doubts about the Fed lingered, but traders who seemed certain that an easing of monetary policy occurred on Wednesday said that a weaker economy might compel the Fed to reduce its discount rate to 4.5 percent from 5 percent.
"I don't think this is the last easing move we will see," a government bond trader said. "We probably will see a discount rate cut on Friday, and if not then, on Tuesday."
Anthony J. Vignola, chief economist at Kidder, Peabody & Company, has come to a similar conclusion. In releasing a revised and more dismal economic forecast yesterday, Mr. Vignola said growth over the next two quarters would likely be at half the rate that had been expected.
"The economy has deteriorated considerably over the last month or so," he said. "The extraordinary restructuring in the economy, particularly in services, is constraining employment and income growth."
 
Lower Bond Yields Are Seen
 Slower growth will allow interest rates to move lower, Kidder, Peabody's revised forecast said.
"We think that the funds rate will hit a cyclical low at 4.5 percent and that bond yields will fall to 7 percent," Mr. Vignola said.
A survey of the nation's purchasing managers originally scheduled for release today became public knowledge late yesterday. The results showed that conditions in the manufacturing sector had slipped during October. The report had almost no impact on prices in the credit markets.
Traders also tended to gloss over a report from the Fed showing that all three measures of the nation's money supply posted strong increases during the week ended Oct. 21.
 
Market for Treasuries
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds were offered late yesterday at a price of 102 13/32, down 6/32, to yield 7.91 percent, compared to 7.89 percent late Wednesday.
Prices of shorter-term Treasury notes fared better. By late in the day, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 102 27/32, up 1/32, to yield 7.45 percent. And the 6 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 9/32, also up 1/32, to yield 5.68 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were narrowly mixed. Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 4.82 percent late yesterday, up one basis point, or a hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates also rose one basis point, to a late offered rate of 4.83 percent. But one-year bill rates fell by one basis point, to a late offered rate of 4.81 percent.
 
Citicorp's Offering
 New-issue activity in the investment-grade corporate bond market was highlighted by a Citicorp two-part offering of $1.5 billion worth of new senior debt securities backed by credit card receipts.
The largest portion of the debt sale consists of $850 million of seven-year securities. The 7 7/8 percent notes were priced at $99.55 to yield 7.961 percent, 82.5 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 1/8 percent seven-year notes at the time of pricing. The remaining $650 million were sold as 6.25 percent two-year notes. They were priced at $99.87 to yield 6.322 percent, 63 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 percent two-year notes at the time of pricing.
The First Boston Corporation acted as lead manager for the underwriting. The securities are rated AAA by Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
MCI's Five-Year Notes
 In addition to the Citicorp offering, the MCI Communications Corporation offered $250 million of five-year notes through an underwriting group led by Merrill Lynch & Company. The 7 5/8 percent securities, which mature on Nov. 7, 1996, were priced at $99.84 to yield 7.664 percent, 92 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 7/8 percent five-year notes at the time of pricing. The securities are rated Baa-1 by Moody's and BBB by Standard & Poor's.
Traders in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said prices of most issues were narrowly mixed in sluggish trading.
Trading was also said to be slow in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds. Traders said prices of most widely quoted issues rose by about 1/8 of a point.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Empire State Buyer Found

 BODY:
The Prudential Insurance Company of America has found a buyer for the Empire State Building, according to a letter the company sent to a partnership holding an 84-year lease on the property.
Peter Malkin, a New York real estate investor with a substantial interest in the partnership that controls the lease, said the buyer was listed as E. G. Holdings and the sale was scheduled to be completed on Nov. 15. Which investors or institutions are represented by E. G. Holdings was not specified in the letter, Mr. Malkin said, and could not be determined yesterday. 
 Prudential declined to discuss details of the sale, and the letter did not indicate the price at which the property would be sold.
The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday that a member of the family of J. Peter Grace, the chairman of W. R. Grace & Company, had agreed to buy the 102-story building, located at Fifth Avenue and 34th, Street, for $40 million. The Journal could not say, however, who in the Grace family would be the buyer. The Grace company said Mr. Grace himself was not involved, but it would not speak for other members of his family.
Several real estate executives said yesterday that the reported purchase price was remarkably high and would be difficult to justify on strict economic terms. The building is controlled by a master lease that gives Mr. Malkin and his partners control over it and most of its income for the next 84 years.

HEADLINE: Economic Malaise Across the Midwest

 BODY:
Throughout the American Midwest, traditional home of industry and can-do optimism, a mood of hestiancy, mistrust and disorientation seems to have taken hold.
 Nebraska still welcomes travelers with a billboard saying "The Good Life," but interviews in four states suggest a deep malaise about the nation's leadership and economy. Purchases of goods from cars to combines are bring postponed.
 It is not merely that nobody believes Vice President Quayle's statement that "the country is out of the recession." It is that few perceive the Administration to have the means to revive the economy.
 Business Day, page D1.

HEADLINE: Blue-Chip Stocks Flat as Dow Falls 2.68

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks finished flat in moderate trading yesterday, but the broader market continued to show strength. The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 2.68, to 3,069.10.
Economic data relased yesterday -- like the report that factory orders were down in September for the second consecutive month -- had little impact. Investors found few incentives to buy aggressively, especially ahead of today's employment report, analysts said. 
"The traders stayed largely on the sidelines awaiting Friday's employment numbers, which some hope will allow the Fed to lower interest rates further," said Harry W. Laubsher, senior vice president and market analyst for Tucker Anthony. "Buying interest was on the shy side, with breadth and volume disappointing."
Big Board volume was a moderate 182.2 million shares, down from 200.8 million shares on Wednesday. Gaining issues outpaced losers by 904 to 725, nearly the same margin the previous day.
The New York Stock Exchange composite was up 0.06, to 216.54, with the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, slipping 0.50, to 392.46.
Trading on the American Stock Exchange was also light, with the composite up 3.13, to 387.31. The Nasdaq composite and Russell 2000 indexes both rose to record highs for the second consecutive day. The Nasdaq reached 542.98, up 1.66, and the Russell went to 184.97, up 1.62.
Earnings reports affected several stocks. Household International, a financial-services concern, fell 7 7/8, to 49 7/8, after the company said earnings would be hurt by higher loan delinquencies.
Trading in UAL, the parent of United Airlines, was stopped for a while, as the airline reported third-quarter profits that were considerably lower than Wall Street expectations. The stock fell 2, to 132 3/4.
Novell, which markets computer networks, rose 2 3/4, to 51 3/4, as it was added to the S.& P. 500, replacing Cross & Trecker, a machine tool maker being acquired. Shares of Advance Micro Devices rose sharply when the company told analysts at a meeting in California that it expected higher fourth-quarter revenues. Daniel Klesken, an analyst at Prudential Securities, increased his earnings estimates for 1991 and 1992, after the company's presentation, traders said. The stock rose 1 3/4, to close at 12 7/8.
Lotus fell 3 1/4, to 24 1/4, as some analysts downgraded the company, noting that sales of its 1-2-3 for Windows product remain sluggish and may face stiffer competition in the first quarter. Borland rose 9 3/4, to 67 3/8, on news of new-product plans, and Microsoft, was down 5/8, to 93 7/8.
First Brands, a manufacturer of home and auto consumer products, rose 1, to 30 1/2, regaining some of the losses incurred on Wednesday when it dropped more than $3.

HEADLINE: Optimism Is Blighted in the Midwest

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DOWS, Iowa

 BODY:
Across the Midwest, traditional home of industry and a can-do optimism, a mood of hesitancy, mistrust and disorientation seems to have taken hold.
Nebraska still welcomes travelers with a billboard saying, "The Good Life," but interviews with dozens of people in four states suggest a profound uneasiness about the nation's leadership and its economy. Purchases of everything from cars to combines are being postponed. 
 Take the Muhlenbruchs, whose life amid the wheat and soybean fields of central Iowa continues to offer certain virtues. "You can still yell at your husband and at least the neighbors won't hear," said Gayle Muhlenbruch. While farming is not always profitable, the land teaches hard work, husbandry and what she calls, "the plain fact that people have got to be able to help themselves."
Steadily applying such values, and shunning vacations for 20 years, Mrs. Muhlenbruch and her husband, Darwyne, prospered. They gradually expanded their farm to 700 acres from 160 and sent their two children to college. Now, however, an uneasiness has crept into their lives.
"Things are sort of floating right now, just floating," said Mr. Muhlenbruch, who is 52 years old. "You feel real uncertain. If the economy was better, I would buy a new tractor. But that can cost $80,000. So I'm waiting."
He is not alone in holding off big purchases. It is not merely that nobody believes Vice President Dan Quayle's statement that "the country is out of the recession" or that many see a "double-dip" downturn coming after the blip of confidence.
It is that few perceive that the Bush Administration has the means to revive the economy. As a result, support for the President seems muted and most people, rich and poor, urban and rural, said they had not decided how they will vote next year.
What depresses many people in the Midwest is a sense that things cannot get better in the foreseeable future. In response, many urge increased taxes on the rich, a cut in the bureaucracy, an end to what they see as pervasive pork-barrel politics and limits on terms for Congressmen. But even those suggesting such measures seem to have little conviction that a real improvement will result.
They may not understand the precise nature of the Federal deficit, but they sense that that fiscal relief is probably impossible or counterproductive.
Where consumers during past recessions looked to the President to cut taxes as a firm signal of determination to lift the economy, now they have little faith in his ability to act.
"If people thought that there was a program that could correct the situation, that in itself would improve confidence," said Richard T. Curtin, director of consumer surveys at the University of Michigan. "That is a missing element of optimism which helped end past recessions."
In Washington, "they've dug a pretty deep hole for themselves," said John Mandal, the deputy sheriff of Wright County, Iowa. "And that makes me pessimistic. The Government's no different from my family or a business. You can't keep operating in the red."
Jerry Maier, an Iowa farmer with 650 acres that are scarcely profitable, added, "We've had to tighten our belts on everything and become efficient, but the Government has just spent way beyond its means."
To help buy Christmas presents for her three children, Renee Scott of Des Moines, who works in the circulation department of The Des Moines Register, is trying to get a second job. "I fight to get ahead, yet I have to pay for Congressmen's free lunches and haircuts," she said. "If I make out a dud check I get a $15 fine, but if they write one it's no big deal. Why don't they take a look at how we live?"
 
A Dark Threat: The Federal Deficit
 The Federal deficit, $285 billion this fiscal year and headed for a record $345 billion next year, seems to loom large over the Midwest as the symbol of a profligacy and carelessness that appear beyond rectification.
But the deficit is only one of several factors that cause people to scoff at statements from economists and the Government that the recession ended in May, when the economy started growing again, albeit slowly. Growth amounted to 2.4 percent in the last quarter, less than half the growth rates generally recorded when the country emerges from recession.
Falling or stagnant property values have also undermined people's sense of their wealth. Nervousness and pessimism, meanwhile, seem to have been compounded by a conviction born of the savings-and-loans debacle and the recent Congressional check-bouncing scandal that nobody in Washington is to be trusted.
In the face of this accumulated disgruntlement, Federal reports of improved employment or consumer spending have made scant impact, even though the recession has been much harder on the two coasts than the Midwest. As Roger Brinner, the executive director of DRI-McGraw-Hill said: "Laymen are not enamored of G.N.P. numbers. The layman asks: have things gotten better?"
Many Midwesterners say no. They ask what use are the values of thrift, honesty, hard work, if Washington practises none of them. And they wonder what cause there is for optimism if, as Tim Smith of the Carter Avenue Frame Shop in St. Paul noted, "the Federal figures are all contradictory, so I get back to the basic fact my business is off 10 percent and therefore the recession is not over"?
 
An Anxious Mood In the Small Details
 In this anxious mood, small details strike people. Students like Andrea Hoagland and Kathryn Gardner at the University of Iowa see the library staff being cut. Scott Holmes, the owner of a Des Moines jewelry store, says that "when I say no to salesmen, even in this run-up to Christmas, they don't seem disappointed; they seem to expect it." Ken Neff, who runs a Radio Shack store in Wahoo, Neb., sees sales dropping 10 percent over last year's levels as farmers wait to see how good the harvest is; and Conrad Horland, an engineer in Minnesota's Department of Transportation, is alarmed by a hiring freeze.
Betty Yunek, a retired school librarian from Lake City, Iowa, said, "There are just too many gray areas in Washington as far as right and wrong are concerned." Shaking her head in indignation, she added, "I really get upset about the savings-and-loans bailouts, which are wrong and expensive."
President Bush's predilection for foreign policy forays also seems to have fostered an image of Washington extravagance as well as a sense that he is oblivious to the country's economic woes and has forgotten that, as Dennis Ott, a laborer in Warren, Wisc., put it, "you should take care of your own first."
Feelings were summed up on the radio last week by Paul Harvey, the voice of the Midwest. He spoke scathingly of Congressmen "living above the law" before declaring roundly that "the threat of bankruptcy is now greater than the threat of war."
 
Some Find Little To Complain About
 Not everyone agrees that things are so bad. Nancy Egan, who works for the St. Paul Fire and Marine Insurance Company, said she and her husband had a combined annual income of about $90,000 and had noticed no change in their lives and no complaints among their friends. "Look," she said, "I'm a white middle-class American, what do I have to complain about?"
Kari Griffin of Des Moines, a teacher, also said she felt that the economy was doing fine and that the rise in unemployment merely reflected the fact that "so many young people are too lazy to clean up and go out and look for a job."
But Mr. Harvey's statements plainly reflected an anxiety which has tended to prolong the recession by delaying spending, undermining investment and keeping people on the defensive with their eyes on their credit card payments.
For example, Joseph Giannetti, a Minneapolis photographer whose business is off 50 percent this year, said he was waiting to see films at the $1.50 movie theaters rather than going to $6 cinemas, cooking more at home, and considering abandoning his studio for a smaller one.
In St. Paul, Roger P. Chamberlain, a banker with a salary of $62,000 and total annual income of about $75,000, said he and his wife had cut their contributions to charity, refinanced their mortgage and put off buying a new car because they felt "the country will be in the doldrums for a while" and are intimidated by the cost of college education for their two children.
 
The Future Seems To Be a Colder Place
 Over all, it seems that constant reports of firings and dismissals have fed a gloomy conviction that deep structural changes are taking place, and many jobs will not return, even when the good times do. "Lean and mean is the watchword in industry," said R. James Gesell, the chairman of the small Cherokee State Bank in St. Paul, "and people feel that's not going to change."
The Cherokee bank, which has two branches and assets of about $100 million, has cut its staff to 50 from 55 a year ago and is resorting to part-time help when necessary. Its operations have been hit by the fact that demand for new loans is weak.
Mr. Gesell put his luxurious St. Paul home, set on two acres of woodland, on the market 11 months ago. He was asking $370,000, but the closest thing he had to an offer is $180,000, which he describes as attempted robbery. Because he and his wife feel a furnished home sells better, they have not moved most of their things to their adjacent new house.
"So when we have people over," the banker said, "I run back and forth with a couple of chairs."
Others adapt to the recession in more painful ways. Jim Rasmussen, a 33-year-old furnaceman in a St. Paul lead foundry, was doing fine as long as the gulf war lasted because bombs need lead and prices were high. But after the war, lead prices dropped and he was fired.
Since then, he says he has knocked on the doors of countless warehouses and factories, but "they all say they're laying off, not hiring." His unemployment checks stopped recently, and President Bush vetoed a $6.5 billion bill that would have provided additional benefits. His wife Stacey earns $6.35 an hour as a baker, but the couple is worried about food bills, concerned about their two children, aged 3 and 9, and having trouble with payments on the $36,000 house they bought last year.
"You're going to have to take a job at McDonald's," Stacey Rasmussen told her husband. "But we're getting a little old to be flipping hamburgers at $4 an hour."
As for Mr. Muhlenbruch, the farmer, he gazes out at the gently undulating farmland. "I believe in paying as you go," he said, "and the Government should have done the same."

HEADLINE: Factories' Orders Show Drop of 1.7%

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES

 BODY:
Two reports released yesterday suggested a slight slowdown in manufacturing activity, which has previously been a bright spot in the nation's wobbling economy.
A survey by the National Association of Purchasing Management, released last night, indicated that while manufacturing activity in the United States continued to expand in October, the pace of growth was slower than in the previous month. It was the first slowdown in the growth rate in the survey since January. 
 Earlier in the day, the Commerce Department announced that orders for manufactured goods dropped 1.7 percent in September, the second straight monthly decline.
As evidence of sluggishness mounted, President Bush expressed concern over the economy, saying, "It is not as strong as, obviously, we would like it to be." He continued, "I am also concerned about mixed signals on consumer confidence and business confidence. We are pleased that the stock market has performed well in recent months, but consumer confidence has slipped."
The purchasing managers' survey, a widely followed barometer of economic activity, also showed that growth in new orders, both for export and domestic shipment, was slower than it had been the previous month. And the survey showed employment continuing a 33-month decline and falling in October at a faster rate than in the two previous months.
"The economic recovery wavered in October as the rate of growth slowed to the lowest level in three months," said Robert J. Bretz, the chairman of the association. He cited specifically the weaker growth in new orders, which he said signaled "relatively modest overall growth for the remainder of 1991."
The purchasing managers' report is consistent with the latest news from the Commerce Department on factory orders, said Carl Palash, vice president and senior economist with McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei in New York.
"The reason factory orders fell so much was the big drop in defense and aircraft-shipping orders, which are highly volatile," Mr. Palash said. "The underlying non-transportation orders rose, continuing a modest uptrend. But orders aren't rising much faster than production."
And that, he added, bodes ill for employment growth. "These reports confirm other evidence that manufacturing orders are rising modestly, but not fast enough to prompt companies to boost hiring," he said. "The manufacturing sector has been the strong sector, and now it's weakening. That's why the Federal Reserve is easing up on interest rates."
There is no firm evidence yet that the Fed has actually elected to cut interest rates. But, according to The Associated Press, Marlin Fitzwater, the Presidential spokesman, told reporters at the White House today, "I don't think anyone doubts that it happened." Mr. Fitzwater added, "There could be other cuts to come."
 
Interpreting the Index
 The purchasing manager's index, which is assembled by the association, fell in October to 53.5 percent, from 55 percent in September. A reading above 50 percent indicates the economy is expanding, while a reading below that level indicates a contracting economy. Each month from February to September, the index hit a higher number than in the previous month; the October reading is the first month-over-month decline since January.
Orders for new business increased at a slightly lower rate for the second straight month, but remained at a relatively high level, said Mr. Bretz, director of corporate purchasing for Pitney Bowes Inc.
 
Divergent Trends
 The Commerce Department reported that orders for both durable and nondurable goods declined to $238.9 billion, after seasonal adjustments, from $243.2 billion in August. The report also revised the August figures to show orders falling 2 percent, steeper than the 1.9 percent decline initially estimated.
Unfilled factory orders fell six-tenths of 1 percent, the third straight decline, while shipments rose two-tenths of 1 percent, for the sixth consecutive climb. Analysts said that with shipments going out faster than orders were coming in, there could be layoffs and weaker employment in future months.
Military orders plunged 47.8 percent in September, the steepest drop in more than seven years, the Commerce Department reported. Excluding that sector, orders rose four-tenths of 1 percent. Transportation, which is also volatile, fell 14.5 percent after a 9.2 percent decline in August.
Over all, orders for long-lasting durable goods slumped 3.2 percent, to $121.5 billion. Durable orders were off 4.1 percent the previous month.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
UAL's Profit Off; Continental's Loss Thins

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
The UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, yesterday reported sharply lower third-quarter earnings and Continental Airlines Holdings Inc., parent of Continental Airlines, reported that third-quarter losses had narrowed substantially.
Both airline companies are struggling to recover from the severe downturn in passenger traffic that began in January with the Persian Gulf war, which also doubled fuel prices. 
While traffic has recovered somewhat, the increase has been anemic. Traffic in September, for example, was up only five-tenths of 1 percent over that of September 1990.
Following are details of the companies' results:
 
United Airlines
 UAL had earnings of $25 million, or $1.05 a share, compared with profits of $106.1 million, or $4.87 a share, in the corresponding quarter last year. Revenue totaled $3.23 billion, up from $2.97 billion in the 1990 quarter.
The results "were below everybody's expectations," said Kevin Murphy, an airline analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company. Most analysts had exptected earnings of $1.50 to $2.25 a share.
Stephen M. Wolf, UAL's chairman, president and chief executive, attributed the results to fare-cutting by other airlines operating under bankruptcy protection and struggling to survive. These airlines, including Midway and America West, cut fares to encourage travel and increase cash flow. But the lower fares have put pressure on the profit margins of United and other healthy airlines like American.
United tends to have more routes in areas where it competes with weaker carriers that are cutting fares, Mr. Wolf said. He said that until the fare-cutting moderated and the economy improved, United's profits would be weak. But he said he saw "some very preliminary signs that our U.S. passenger business may have begun to improve."
Mr. Murphy said there were some signs that the fare-cutting had moderated. But he added that United's third-quarter yields, or its revenue per seat, were down 1 percent. He said that during the same period, American Airlines, which is United's main competitor, showed a gain of 3.6 percent on its yields.
Mr. Murphy said American's higher yield showed it was getting higher fares for its mix of seats than United. In its third quarter, American had a profit of $70.3 million, up from $65.6 million in the 1990 quarter.
On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, UAL's stock closed down $2 a share, to $132.75.
 
Continental
 Continental Airlines Holdings, which is operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, reported a third-quarter loss of $19.7 million, substantially less than the $88.3 million it lost in the third quarter last year. Revenue remained largely unchanged, at $1.5 billion.
The airline, which plans to file its plan for debt reorganization before Nov. 28, when its right to do so expires, showed an operating profit of $25.5 million in the quarter.
Robert R. Ferguson 3d, the chief executive, said that "passenger traffic rose nearly 7 percent in this year's third quarter on a 2 percent capacity increase, while passenger revenue increased just over 4 percent due to pressure on yield as a result of the recession and weak industry demand."
Continental Airlines Holdings' stock closed up 25 cents, to $1.75, on the American Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
President Bush received conflicting recommendations from his top economic and political advisers about how the Administration should respond to the weakness of the economy. The division was over whether to answer challenges from Democrats with bold proposals or to keep on a steady economic course. [A1.] 
 The House voted to retain strict barriers on the expansion of banks into securities and other new businesses. The vote was a defeat for President Bush, who had sought more liberal rules. [D1.]
Two reports suggested a slowdown in manufacturing. The National Association of Purchasing Management said manufacturing growth slowed in October and the Commerce Department said orders for manufactured goods dropped in September. [D1.]
Democrats agreed to a new plan to extend unemployment benefits, as new claims for benefits fell more sharply than expected in the week ended Oct. 19. [A18.]
Across the Midwest, traditional home of industry and optimism, dozens of interviews suggest an uneasiness about the nation's leadership and its economy. [D1.]
 
Companies
Northrop received a blow when House and Senate negotiators blocked the purchase of new B-2 Stealth bombers and all but killed the plane's political chances to survive next year. [A1.]
Seagram will sell its lower-priced liquors to American Brands for $372.5 million. Some analysts thought Seagram was preparing to make an acquisition. [D1.]
UAL, parent of United Airlines, reported sharply lower third-quarter earnings, and Continental's losses narrowed. [D1.]
American Express appointed new senior management to run its troubled Optima credit card division and dismissed executives who it said had hidden growing account defaults. [D2.]
Rockwell International and two employees were indicted on charges of overbilling NASA for work on the space shuttle. [D3.]
An audit by regulators provides evidence that a research consortium owned by the regional Bell telephone companies overcharged them by $80 million and may have passed the overcharges on to customers. [D3.]
Borland International shares rose nearly 17 percent after it received rave reviews for several new software products. [D3.]
 
International
The White House hopes to complete a review soon of the actions of a one-time aide who represented a former Saudi official active in the criminal investigation of B.C.C.I. [D2.]
Prices are soaring in the Soviet Union before the enactment of a plan for increases in the cost of food and other necessities. [A3.]
 
Markets
Blue-chip stocks finished flat in moderate trading, but the broader market showed strength. The Dow lost 2.68 points. [D8.]
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed in slow trading, as traders waited for the release of new employment data. [D14.]
The dollar was mixed as traders anticipated further cuts in American interest rates. Gold prices were mostly lower. [D15.]
Wheat futures rebounded amid new signs of rising Soviet demand and worries about cold-weather damage to crops. [D15.]
 
Today's Columns
Initial third-quarter G.N.P. figures implied that the recession was over. But the 2.4 percent gain was largely from slower inventory-cutting. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [D2.]
While Alcoa has been retreating from an ambitious diversification plan to concentrate on aluminum, its chief rival, Reynolds Metals, has pursued the opposite tack. Market Place [D8.]
Ad campaigns for 1992 model cars are trying to rekindle America's love affair with the road. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D7.]

HEADLINE: Big Banks Set Back By House

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
Handing a defeat to the White House and the nation's largest banks and a victory to the securities and insurance industries, the House of Representatives narrowly voted today to impose significantly more restrictions on the expansion of banks into new businesses than President Bush had sought.
In a vote that essentially preserves the division of financial services that has prevailed since the Depression, the House decided, 216 to 200, to allow banking companies and securities companies to merge, but only if they keep fire walls between the activities so high that, the big banks assert, they cannot offer securities services on a competitive basis. 
 The measure, one of several main provisions in the comprehensive banking legislation, was worked out last week by two leading Democrats, Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan, the chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, and Representative Henry B. Gonzalez of Texas, the chairman of the Banking Committee.
 
Clouded Prospects
 The White House had threatened to veto a bill that included the Dingell-Gonzalez measure, and today's vote falls short of the two-thirds majority needed to override a Presidential veto. With the rapidly declining bank insurance fund in need of new money, today's vote clouds the prospects for passage of a broad bill to overhaul the banking industry this year.
Republican leaders in the House tonight vowed to seek to kill the entire banking legislation Friday; the vote is expected to be close.
A critical part of the legislation is a provision to provide a large taxpayer loan to the bank insurance fund, which has a balance of less than $3 billion. Congress is under pressure to approve more money for the fund, and that pressure could lead to passage of a stripped-down bill.
Under the measure passed by the House, banking and securities operations owned by the same company would not be permitted to share customer information, conduct joint-marketing efforts or have any financial ties like extensions of credit.
The measure would end the Federal Reserve's authority to chip away slowly at the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933, which split the banking and securities industries, by granting exemptions to large American and Canadian banks to set up new businesses that offer limited corporate securities underwriting services.
In addition, the measure would allow state-chartered banks to continue selling insurance if permitted by the chartering state, but only in states that also permit it. That would eliminate the so-called Delaware loophole, which has enabled some banks to offer insurance services nationwide.
And the measure would prohibit nationally chartered banks from underwriting insurance.
The Senate Banking Committee has approved, although narrowly, a measure that puts significantly lower barriers between securities and banking affiliates. But like the House version and unlike the Administration's, it would not permit industrial companies to own banks.
The Senate bill would also restrict the ability of banks to enter the insurance industry and includes a number of provisions for consumers that the banks have opposed. Debate in the Senate, expected within the next few weeks, is likely to be rancorous.
The House measure is a compromise by Mr. Gonzalez and Mr. Dingell to settle a dispute over whether and how to repeal the Glass-Steagall Act. Their feud had prevented legislation for overhauling the banking industry from coming to the House floor.
Supporters of the Gonzalez-Dingell compromise say the measure would grant banks sufficient new powers while keeping enough safeguards to protect taxpayers and depositors. Opponents say it is far too restrictive.
In a thinly veiled reference, President Bush said shortly before today's vote that the measure would "move banks backwards" and make them "even less competitive in the global marketplace."
"Congress must not give in to the interest groups that seek to hold back progress," Mr. Bush said at the swearing-in ceremony for William Taylor as head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, succeeding L. William Seidman. "The stakes are too high, and we cannot afford to wait any longer."
 
New Deal Legislation
 On the House floor, debate was steeped in discussion about the New Deal legislation of the 1930's that erected the barriers between the securities and banking industries. Supporters of the Gonzalez-Dingell agreement also referred frequently to the 1982 legislation that deregulated the savings and loan industry, a move that many asserted led to an estimated $500 billion bailout of the industry over the next 40 years.
"This is an historic moment," said Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, who helped forge the Gonzalez-Dingell agreement. "We don't want to tie the hands of the bankers. We want to make them competitive. But we don't want to repeat the mistakes of the 1980's."
Administration officials and banking lobbyists had fought for the motion to strike the provision, which received the support of 187 Democrats, 28 Republicans and the House's sole independent, Bernard Sanders of Vermont, and was opposed by 70 Democrats and 130 Republicans
 
Gingrich Criticizes Foley
 Visibly angered, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the second-ranking Republican in the House, said after the vote that Republicans had been tricked by House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington. Mr. Foley, he asserted, told them that the Gonzalez-Dingell compromise would fail, and so they agreed to vote to permit the debate.
A spokesman for Mr. Foley said the Speaker had made no representations.
The vote to permit the debate had the support of eight Republicans, and passed by a bare 210 to 208.
Separately, the House overwhelmingly rejected a proposal by Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, to create a "core banking" system. The proposal, which was defeated by a vote of 312 to 106, would have imposed limits on the interest rates that banks and savings institutions could pay and on the amount they could lend to a single borrower. In exchange, the institutions would be permitted to lend money in affiliated companies that could not make use of insured deposits.

HEADLINE: Mayor Wants To Freeze Tax On Property

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins wants to freeze New York City property taxes for at least two years -- and perhaps four if he can win support from the City Council and Albany for a mix of new fees to finance garbage collection or bridge maintenance, senior mayoral aides said yesterday.
But City Hall officials said the Mayor had not yet made a final decision, as he prepares his four-year plan for keeping the budget balanced, due next Wednesday. They said the plan would also call for cutting the city work force by a total of 25,000 jobs by 1995 and would count on nearly $1 billion in aid from a state takeover of Medicaid costs, roughly twice what Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has proposed to provide in that period. 
 The plan would freeze wages of city workers through next June, as previously announced, and perhaps for another year as well, while calling for a range of unspecified productivity increases to make workers more efficient, officials said. The Mayor would not cut his ambitious plans for police hiring, aides said.
 
Early Retirement Program
 The 25,000 jobs to be cut would include the thousands already eliminated from the 247,000 on the city payroll of last November. In September, the head count stood at 234,121 workers, but that number is expected to rise by 5,000 to 6,000 before shrinking again because of new hiring required in the wake of an early retirement program for senior teachers in the Board of Education.
Some senior mayoral aides still question the wisdom of a tax freeze, and even the idea's supporters said that shifting revenue or cost projections might yet make a freeze impossible but that the Mayor strongly favored it. Mr. Dinkins is struggling to close estimated budget gaps of more than $1 billion in each of the next three fiscal years, and of perhaps $250 million in the current year, which ends on June 30.
"It depends on everything falling into place," one senior aide said.
But that will be difficult since many of the proposals would require the approval not only of the Council but also of the State Legislature and the Governor at a time when economic prospects remain cloudy, Mr. Cuomo's Presidential plans are uncertain and the municipal unions are resistant to backing City Hall without assurances of no further layoffs or potential wage rewards.
In one sense, by freezing taxes, Mr. Dinkins would simply be acknowledging political realities. The City Council has vowed to bitterly resist further tax increases in the wake of two years of record increases, and leading business groups have urged a four-year freeze on all taxes. And Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, has urged a two-year freeze as one condition that might persuade him to provide a $1 billion aid package, some of which the city might use in lieu of tax increases.
 
A Broad Commitment
 But mayoral aides said Mr. Dinkins also hoped to build public support for his plan by making a broad commitment to stabilize the city's economic base in a recession. In the fiscal crisis of the mid 70's, the city froze real estate taxes for four years.
The Mayor also hopes a freeze might gain him leverage for the politically difficult idea of creating "trust funds" or new public authorities to finance trash pickups or bridge repairs through tolls, auto-use fees or residential user fees for garbage collection.
For months, a mayoral task force of business and labor leaders has studied the idea of charging tolls on the 13 East River and Harlem River bridges that are now free, to raise hundreds of millions of dollars. This week, the panel split on the issue, with business members supporting the tolls and labor leaders opposing them, so now city officials are considering raising auto registration fees, other auto user fees or gasoline taxes that could be segregated to maintain bridges.
Proposals to charge residents for garbage pickups have met resistance because fees would hit poor residents worst. But city officials have studied granting income tax credits to lessen the impact for low-income people. "We want to try to have a plan that everybody says is discussable," one senior mayoral aide said. "Some past ideas have been dismissed as D.O.A., but now it's time to stop writing the obits."
 
Meeting With Vallone
 Mr. Dinkins met with Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone on Wednesday, seeking to form a unified front for approaching the State Legislature and the Governor. Albany would have power over many of the city's proposals, from imposing the new fees or tolls to passing and accelerating Governor Cuomo's proposal to have the state assume the city's Medicaid costs in exchange for the city's surrendering some of its taxing authority.
"It was a very encouraging, upbeat meeting and it's clear we're talking the same things now: tax freeze, downsizing and a cooperative front," Mr. Vallone said yesterday. "I really very much would like to have a sensible agreement where we could stand side by side, which would be wonderful, good for the city and good for the state."
In the past, Mr. Vallone, who is from Astoria, Queens, has looked askance at creating an authority to maintain the bridges, especially if it involved tolls. He has also raised concerns about charging fees for garbage collection since it is considered one of the most basic municipal services in New York, though other cities charge for it, and commercial establishments here must already pay private haulers to take their trash away. But he stressed yesterday that the only thing he had flatly ruled out was further tax increases.
While Mr. Dinkins's hopes for the tax freeze involve the property tax, his aides said they did not expect that his plan would propose increases in any other taxes, either. But they noted that to speed the pace of the state's takeover of Medicaid costs, they might eventually have to propose some increases in the personal income tax to help finance that in the coming years.
Mr. Vallone said it was "too early to talk about anything like that."

HEADLINE: Pentagon May Give Moscow $1 Billion

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
In a novel effort to accommodate a changing world, the Pentagon is nearing agreement with Congress to transfer up to $1 billion from its budget to give the Soviet Union food and medical aid and help convert Soviet military industries into civilian projects, senior Bush Administration and Congressional officials say.
The plan, which has the support of the White House and Congressional leaders, would be incorporated in the $291 billion 1992 Pentagon budget nearing final approval in Congress. 
 Seeking to justify the use of tax money that might otherwise be diverted to American domestic needs, the plan's architects, including the Democratic chairmen of the Senate and House Armed Services Committees, contend that the investment would increase American security by helping prevent further instability in the Soviet Union.
 
'Potential for Chaos'
 "We're talking about the potential for chaos in a country with 30,000 nuclear weapons," said Representative Les Aspin of Wisconsin, the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee. "It's clearly in our interest not to allow food and medicine shortages to trigger some kind of unrest."
In a challenge to the Soviet aid proposal, however, some Republican Senators held up final approval of the conference committee report tonight, demanding that cuts in American military spending be directed to domestic concerns.
Senator Daniel R. Coates of Indiana said after a meeting of the Armed Services Committee that a "significant number of people" on the committee are demanding more time to consider the plan, which he called "potentially volatile."
"We're closing down military bases and shutting down our defense industries here, and there are people out of work, and we're providing a billion dollars of assistance across the ocean," he said.
But Senate leaders predicted a momentary impasse would not undermine the plan.
Deputy Defense Secretary Donald J. Atwood and a delegation of American business leaders are currently in the Soviet Union examining the prospects for converting Soviet military industries to the manufacture of badly needed consumer goods.
It is unclear how the gesture of tapping the Pentagon budget for Soviet aid may influence the debate over whether to make deep cuts in American military spending because of the collapse of Communism and the diminished Soviet military threat.
Pentagon aid to the Soviet Union would be separate from and in addition to other public and private American assistance currently under consideration, including increased agricultural loan guarantees and direct food aid this winter. The total amount of proposed Pentagon aid has not been determined, the officials said.
When the idea was first suggested by Mr. Aspin in August after the unsuccessful hard-line coup in Moscow, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney dismissed it as "foolish" and "a serious mistake" that could damage United States security.
Under gentle prodding from the White House, though, Mr. Cheney is now ready to relent on the condition that the Pentagon has authority to make the necessary budget cuts and to decide how the money will be spent on the Soviets, Administration officials said.
The Soviet aid package is the brainchild of the two influential leaders of the Armed Services Committees, Mr. Aspin and Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia. For the last several weeks, the two men have worked with their staffs and quietly with key Administration officials to draft a proposal acceptable to Congress and the Pentagon.
The lawmakers are putting the finishing touches on the plan, which is included in the military budget bill that House and Senate negotiators are expected to complete in the next few days.
The full House and Senate are expected to approve the compromise bill, which then goes to President Bush. Administration officials said the plan would not violate last year's budget agreement because the Soviet aid would come out of the Pentagon's budget. No Pentagon money could be devoted to domestic programs this year without reopening the budget agreement, a very unlikely possibility.
Lawmakers have suggested that the Pentagon consider a number of steps to assist the Soviet Union, including using Air Force planes to transport food and medical aid to the Soviet people this winter and to provide other help in distributing the aid.
Lawmakers have also suggested offering economic incentives to private American companies that do business with the Pentagon to invest in the Soviet Union, creating a panel of American experts to help speed American investment in converting Soviet military industries into commercial companies, and developing a United States-Soviet program to destroy nuclear and chemical weapons and clean up environmental pollution resulting from military activities.
Senator Nunn also said it was urgent to "get out in front of the explosion of technical and scientific knowledge" in the Soviet Union to prevent economic turmoil that could create a demand in potentially hostile developing countries for the thousands of Soviet technical experts.
Mr. Aspin said that the assistance program could be patterned after the Army's successful relief operation to supply food, medicine and other supplies to thousands of Kurdish refugees in northern Iraq after the Persian Gulf war. In that operation, the Army provided nearly 2,700 tons of bulk food, 200,000 gallons of drinking water and 212,000 blankets to the Kurds.
Arkady Volsky, the deputy director of the committee running the Soviet economy, has said that even optimistic forecasts put unemployment at 2 million people next year in a Soviet military-industrial complex that currently employs 7.8 million workers at 2,500 factories.
Agriculture Secretary Edward Madigan said on Wednesday that the Soviets have asked the United States for $2.5 billion in credit guarantees to purchase American farm products and an additional $1 billion in food and medical aid, but that a United States response was still in the works.
