HEADLINE: Joseph Papp, Theater's Champion, Dies

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN

 BODY:
Joseph Papp, director of the New York Shakespeare Festival and one of the most influential producers in the history of the American theater, died yesterday at his home in Greenwich Village. He was 70 years old.
He died of prostate cancer, said Richard Kornberg, his press representative. All Broadway theaters will dim their lights at 8 tonight in tribute to Mr. Papp. 
 Mr. Papp rose from a childhood in the slums of Brooklyn to found the New York Shakespeare Festival, through which he presented free Shakespeare in Central Park for more than three decades. In the 1960's, he took over the old Astor Library and turned it into the Public Theater, a huge six-theater complex in which he presented and championed the work of many young playwrights, including David Rabe, Thomas Babe, Ed Bullins, Caryl Churchill, David Hare, David Henry Hwang, Wallace Shawn, Vaclav Havel, Miguel Pinero, Ntozake Shange, Michael Weller, George C. Wolfe, David Mamet, Tina Howe and John Guare.
The Public was the birthplace of two landmark American musicals, "Hair" and "A Chorus Line," the longest-running show in Broadway history. Mr. Papp also helped build the careers of many actors, among them James Earl Jones, Meryl Streep, Raul Julia and Kevin Kline.
 
'Most Important Force'
 To many in the theater world, Mr. Papp was the most significant figure in noncommercial and institutional theater in the United States over three decades. Indeed, Bernard Jacobs, president of the Shubert Organization, Broadway's biggest theater owner, said in 1977, "Joe Papp is the most important force in the English-speaking theater today." Writing about Mr. Papp in The New York Times in September, Frank Rich called him "the only giant left in the field" and said that he had left "the New York theater an almost completely different place than he found it."
Mr. Papp took Shakespeare to the schools and to the city streets. He exercised a profound influence in bringing to the attention of the public the work of many important black, Hispanic and Asian-American playwrights and actors. He was among the first to use minority actors in major Shakespearean and other classic roles.
He had many triumphs. Three plays he produced won Pulitzer Prizes: Charles Gordone's "No Place to Be Somebody," Jason Miller's "That Championship Season" and "A Chorus Line." His plays also garnered more than 20 Tony Awards. His production of "A Chorus Line," which was directed by Michael Bennett and won a Tony as best musical in 1976, cost $1,145,000 to take to Broadway and grossed almost $150 million for his New York Shakespeare Festival. It ran from 1975 until April 28, 1990, a total of 6,137 performances.
 
Transfers, Triumphs And Disappointments
 "A Chorus Line" was a prime example of a practice in which Mr. Papp engaged often and well, one in which he was a pioneer: moving a play to Broadway from Off Broadway. In 1972, he achieved perhaps his greatest success with transferred works, winning both major Tony Awards: best play, for "Sticks and Bones," David Rabe's harrowing tale of a Vietnam War veteran, and best musical, for a tuneful version of Shakespeare's "Two Gentlemen of Verona," which starred Raul Julia and was first performed in Central Park. The next year, "That Championship Season" won the Tony for best play.
But Mr. Papp also had his share of failures and detractors. He was an outspoken public figure, and his statements were rarely intended to be diplomatic. He was quick to anger at those with whom he disagreed, or who disagreed with him. He was assailed on one hand as too avant-garde, and on the other as too commercial.
Perhaps his biggest defeat was at Lincoln Center. He ran its theater company from 1973 to 1977, when he abruptly decided to give up the job, uncomfortable with the institutional and financial strictures that came along with the post.
In recent years, many critics sensed a decline in the quality of the Public's output; at his death, he was in the middle of an ambitious project that has received mixed critical reaction, a cycle of all of Shakespeare's plays.
In May 1990, weakened by illness and seeking to attract new audiences and to infuse what he termed "fresh creative blood," he made major changes in his theater's artistic structure. In August, he named JoAnne Akalaitis, a founding member of the experimental troupe Mabou Mines, as his successor as artistic director of the Shakespeare Festival.
 
An Outsider Who Moved In
 Mr. Papp was a man of contradictions. He prided himself on being an outsider and a radical, and he was long a scathing critic of what he called "that old whore Broadway."
But as he began moving his plays uptown, and with his success of the early 1970's, from "Sticks and Bones" to "A Chorus Line," he was embraced -- and allowed himself to be embraced -- by the commercial theater.
Mr. Rich, summing up Mr. Papp's career in The Times, observed: "Paradoxically enough, he beat Broadway at its own game by reviving the lost arts of high-stakes artistic gambling and nonstop promotion that had once made the Great White Way an electrifying venue." In proving -- with shows like "Hair" -- the commercial viability of work being done by the nonprofit theater, he continued, Mr. Papp "started a complete reversal of the power equation of the New York theater."
To Mr. Papp, theater was always more than theater. "Theater is a social force," he once said, "not just an entertainment." His goal, he said, his guiding force, was to bring theater to the people and to "radicalize the environment."
He seemed to care deeply about his proteges. When one, Miguel Pinero, an ex-convict who wrote "Short Eyes," an explosive look inside prisons, was arrested, Mr. Papp went to the police station to post bail. Yet he also often fought with his writers, becoming involved in long-term disputes with Mr. Rabe and Sam Shepard.
He fought bureaucracy, unions, foundations, audiences, critics and even the City of New York. In the beginning, he successfully fought a weekly battle to obtain the money to present his park performances. Then he took on the most powerful politician in New York at the time, Robert Moses, for the right to continue his free Shakespeare performances in Central Park. He battled his playwrights, and he battled the critics.
 
Self-Made Mogul And Old-Time Showman
 One of his greatest talents was as a fund raiser, using his very public persona as a prime means of soliciting contributions. He made television commercials for the festival, affecting the swaggering stance of a self-made mogul, talking out of the side of his mouth and gesturing grandly with a cigar. He appeared in ads for the telephone company, on billboards, on the sides of telephone booths, in black tie and scarf, off for a night at the theater.
Joseph Papp was born on June 22, 1921, in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn to Samuel (Shmuel) and Yetta Miritch Papirofsky. His parents spoke Yiddish, and Yosl Papirofsky, as he was named, began to learn English only when he was old enough to play in the streets and go to school.
His childhood was spent in poverty, "surrounded by terror," he once recalled. "I got beat up regularly," he said.
His father was a trunk maker. To help the family make a living, Yosl would shine shoes, pluck chickens and, with his father, sell peanuts from a pushcart. His family would move several times a year, often in the middle of the night, because they could not pay the rent.
During World War II, he served in the Navy and had his first real encounter with the stage. "I put on shows on a flattop," Mr. Papp wrote in a 1970 reminiscence.
After the war, he went to California, to the Actors' Laboratory, which included many people from the Group Theater. After two years, he became managing director of the lab, graduating in 1948. The lab, however, split apart because of political disputes: Many of his colleagues, he wrote, were members of the Communist Party.
Back in New York, Mr. Papp began working as a television stage manager for CBS. He changed his name from Papirofsky to Papp because, he said, Papirofsky was too long to fit on the television screen during the credits. In 1954, in a church on the Lower East Side, the Emmanuel Presbyterian Church, he began staging free Shakespeare.
In 1956, he received the backing of the New York City Parks Department and its commissioner, Moses, and moved his free Shakespeare to the 2,000-seat East River Park Amphitheater on the Lower East Side. The season was produced for about $20,000, a figure that eventually expanded to the $16 million it cost to keep the Public Theater afloat in 1987. (Recession cutbacks brought the budget down to $10.5 million this year.)
That first season, there were two productions, first "Julius Caesar," directed by Stuart Vaughan, which opened on June 29, 1956, and then "The Taming of the Shrew." The casts performed without pay, and included, as the shrew, the young Colleen Dewhurst.
The next year, what was becoming the New York Shakespeare Festival Company toured the five boroughs with a mobile theater, then settled in Central Park, by West 81st Street near the Belvedere Castle, on the site that would later become its permanent summer home, the Delacorte Theater.
In 1958, Mr. Papp, who had continued working for CBS, was called before the House Committee on Un-American Activities. He denied that he had been a member of the Communist Party after June 1955, but he took the Fifth Amendment and declined to say anything about his activities before that date. CBS dismissed him, but he was reinstated after an arbitration ruling, the first person to be rehired by a television network after having been let go because of testimony before the House committee.
Mr. Papp had his famous battle with -- and victory over -- Moses in 1959. As Robert A. Caro tells it in "The Power Broker," his biography of Moses, it was Stuart Constable, Moses's top aide, who started the dispute while Moses was on vacation. What happened, Mr. Caro wrote, was this: Constable, who was politically very much on the right, found out about Mr. Papp's testimony -- or lack of it -- and became upset at the idea of a leftist producing Shakespeare for the masses. He decided that Mr. Papp would have to go and told the producer there would be no more Shakespeare unless the public was charged a fee. Mr. Papp refused. When Moses returned, he upheld his aide's decision.
The producer took the case to trial, and although a lower court ruled in favor of Moses, the Appellate Division decided unanimously that imposing unnecessary admission charges was "in violation of the public's parks rights." The season went on, free of charge, and the next year plans were made to construct a permanent theater near the Belvedere Castle site. The new theater, named for George T. Delacorte, who donated $150,000 toward its $400,000 cost, opened in 1962, with "The Merchant of Venice."
 
Expansion And Discoveries
 In 1966, Mr. Papp decided to expand. In a pioneering example of architectural recycling, he took over the landmark Astor Library on Lafayette Street in Lower Manhattan as his new headquarters, renaming it the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater. He turned the building into a six-theater complex that showed plays and classic films. He let the sun shine in with "Hair," the prototypical rock musical for the Age of Aquarius, which went on to become a major hit on Broadway. He discovered David Rabe with "The Basic Training of Pavlo Hummel."
In the mid-1970's, at the same time "A Chorus Line" was being created, Mr. Papp took over Lincoln Center Theater, while continuing at the Public and in the park. Meanwhile, "A Chorus Line" opened at the Public, moved to Broadway and became the biggest hit in Mr. Papp's career.
But at Lincoln Center attendance declined. In 1977, in his fourth and most successful season -- with productions of "The Threepenny Opera," "The Cherry Orchard" and "Agamemnon" at the Vivian Beaumont Theater and Mr. Rabe's "Streamers" at the Mitzi I. Newhouse Theater -- Mr. Papp suddenly announced that he was leaving Lincoln Center. He declared that he felt "trapped in an institutional structure both artistically and fiscally."
For the rest of the 1970's and throughout the 80's, Mr. Papp continued to produce Shakespeare and works by new playwrights, many of them dealing with social issues. Among them were plays like Larry Kramer's "Normal Heart" and Harry Kondoleon's "Zero Positive."
He also continued to transfer plays and musicals to Broadway from the Public and Central Park, sometimes successfully and sometimes not. The hit transfers included his Central Park production of "The Pirates of Penzance," which starred Linda Ronstadt and George Rose; "The Mystery of Edwin Drood," which won the Tony Award for best musical in 1986; David Hare's "Plenty," and "Cuba and His Teddy Bear," starring Robert De Niro.
Mr. Papp never hesitated in speaking out. In 1973, outraged that CBS had postponed its planned presentation of "Sticks and Bones," he denounced the network as perpetuating a "cowardly cop-out" and canceled a $7 million contract, refusing to produce the 11 more plays he had agreed to do.
Last year, outraged by obscenity restrictions imposed by Congress on recipients of grants from the National Endowment for the Arts, Mr. Papp rejected endowment grants totaling $373,000 and called the restrictions "unacceptable, reprehensible and insidious."
His relationships with his writers could be volatile. Mr. Papp and Mr. Rabe did not speak for four years after Mr. Papp, the playwright said, told him that if Mr. Rabe had not become a writer he would have been a murderer. In 1981, Sam Shepard left the Public after a dispute over the handling of his play "True West" and vowed that Mr. Papp "would never see another play of mine." Mr. Papp never did.
Many playwrights and actors, however, had an abiding love and respect for him. "He speaks from the heart," Wallace Shawn once recalled. "He has a quite amazing access to his own irrational side. So you don't get an academic response from him. You always get an unexpected response, which makes you feel that the encouragement is based on something he feels."
Despite all his success, Mr. Papp lived modestly with his wife, Gail Merrifield, in an apartment three blocks from the Public. "I help make millionaires," he once said, "but I'm not a millionaire."
Mr. Papp was married four times; the first three marriages ended in divorce. He is survived by Ms. Merrifield, who is director of plays and musicals at the Public, and by four children from his first three marriages: Susan, Barbara, Michael and Miranda. Another son, Tony, died of AIDS in June at the age of 29.
There will be a private funeral service for Mr. Papp at the Public Theater today. A public memorial service will be announced.
Mr. Papp once remarked that he loved to walk through the Public just before curtain time. "It's just a matter of touching base," he said, "letting them know I'm alive, I care. When I walk through the theater, I try to make sure the public toilets are clean, the lights are on properly. It's like it's my own place, so I have a great deal of concern for how it looks." For many years, he would show up at the Delacorte at show time almost every summer evening to watch the crowds entering the theater and taking their seats.
"When the moon is out and the wind begins to whisper," he said, "it's theater at its best. You can't beat it."
 
Prolific Impresario With High Impact
Joseph Papp brought more than 350 plays to the stage in the course of his 35-year-long career. Here are some of his major productions.

HEADLINE: Challenged by Foes on Economy, Bush Wonders Whether to Answer

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
At an unusually tense meeting in the White House this morning, a frustrated President Bush received sharply conflicting recommendations from his top economic and political advisers about how the Administration should respond to the weakness of the economy on the verge of an election year.
Toward the end of his meeting with Cabinet secretaries, other senior Administration officials, political counselors and Republican Congressional leaders, according to people who were there, Mr. Bush said that he felt as if he were in the middle of a hurricane where all he could hear was noise, and he wished aloud that those around him would give him cohesive advice instead of bickering among themselves in the Cabinet Room.
 
Answering the Democrats
 The division was over political strategy, not economic policy, over whether to answer the challenge from Democrats in Congress with seemingly bold proposals or to keep on a quiet and steady economic course.
All the advisers accept the fundamental Republican principles of a lower capital gains tax and tight reins on social spending. And with the country facing a budget deficit of about $350 billion this year, cutting taxes sharply or increasing Government spending, the steps Administrations normally take when the economy looks bad in an election year, are out of the question.
The President did not tip his hand. But he was quoted as saying that Democrats were approaching economic issues as if the political campaign had begun and that the White House needed to respond in kind.
Mr. Bush, who has been heavily criticized by the Democrats for his opposition to a bill that would extend unemployment benefits for three million Americans, today accused the Democrats of holding up the bill. In response, Congressional Democrats agreed on a new version. [Page A18.]
At the meeting, Vice President Dan Quayle and Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher were said to have strenuously argued that Mr. Bush should press hard now for a lower capital gains tax and other measures, even at the risk of losing, so the public would see that the President was fully engaged in dealing with the economy.
They were reported to have quoted public opinion polls showing that most people believe the President has not paid enough attention to the economy and that the people gloomiest about the economy are those who most blame the President for the problem.
But Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, Richard G. Darman, the budget director, and Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, argued just as strongly that the President should sit tight for the rest of the year and not risk a battle he could not win with Congress over taxes.
Democrats have the votes in Congress, they were said to have asserted, and if the President reopens tax and spending questions, Democrats will turn it to their advantage.
The White House is not the only place in town with serious splits over the economy.
Speaking at a Capitol Hill hotel today, Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic leader, compared Mr. Bush's stewardship of the economy with that of Herbert Hoover before the Great Depression, and he said the economy needed "action not just words" from Congress.
But in his office at the Capitol, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, the Speaker of the House, said he did not think action on taxes and other economic issues was likely or wise this year.
 
Risk to Bush
 The chief Senate Democrat on tax issues, Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, chairman of the Finance Committee, started much of the economic debate last week with his proposal to give families a $300 tax credit for each child. His counterpart in the House, Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, opposes that plan and any action on taxes this year.
Republican leaders in Congress are also divided. Senator Phil Gramm of Texas and Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia are determined to fight for lower capital gains taxes and more favorable deductions for individual retirement accounts. But two of the most respected Republican voices in Congress on economic matters, Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico and Representative Bill Gradison of Ohio, have argued against those proposals.
The tension in the Bush Administration and Congress reflects the consensus in political circles that the main threat to the President's re-election is the prospect of a sour economy.
This summer, Mr. Bush and his advisers felt the economy was out of the woods. The recession seemed to have ended and the country seemed to be poised for strong growth in 1992.
 
A Mysterious Relapse
 But for reasons not yet clear, the recovery stalled this fall. Some Administration economists say the forecast made in July that the economy would grow by a rather healthy 3.6 percent next year no longer looks realistic.
And Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and a strong political ally of the Administration, said in a speech at the University of Rhode Island this week that the economy was "demonstrably sluggish" and no longer had the "spark" it showed over the summer. He said he could not tell whether the slowdown would end soon or drag into next year when the political damage would be most serious.
After his meeting in the Cabinet Room, Mr. Bush spoke to a group of small-business executives who had been invited to the White House. During a photo session, the President said the economy had "turned the corner" and was "headed for recovery," but he quickly added, "I'm still concerned about the economy and that it's not as strong as obviously we'd like it to be."
Most Presidents have preferred dealing with foreign policy, where a national consensus can often be found, than economic policy, where almost all steps generate vocal opposition. But Mr. Bush has spent so much time on foreign affairs that his advisers now feel it is essential for him to be seen as coming to grips with the economy.
As a consequence, his first meeting Wednesday afternoon after he got off the plane from Madrid was with economic advisers, and on a political fund-raising trip to Texas he intends to visit a factory Friday and talk about how he plans to make the United States more competitive.
 
Last Year's Bruises
 The Bush advisers who counseled against confronting Congress over the economy had two different arguments.
Mr. Boskin, who is on leave from Stanford University, was said to have asserted that the economy would satisfactorily rebound without further action by the Bush Administration and that tax-cutting measures could lead to higher interest rates and thus be counterproductive.
Mr. Brady and Mr. Darman were said to be more concerned that the President would be badly bruised again as he was in the fight over the budget last year. Then, Democrats managed to portray Mr. Bush as a patron of fat cats who was concerned only with helping the wealthy.
Many of the scars from the budget battle remain. John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, who was criticized then for dragging the President on an unpopular course, had almost nothing to say at today's meeting. And Representative Gingrich, who was burned last year when he led the Administration charge for a capital gains tax only to have the President drop the idea, reflected some of his resentment.

HEADLINE: The Art Market;
A Crucial Auction Test: Will Prices Keep Falling?

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL

 BODY:
THE art world is holding its breath. The outcome of the next two weeks' New York auctions of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art will reflect the current state of what has decidedly been a precarious market.
Given declining auction prices, the big question is whether things have finally hit bottom. The auction houses are estimating that these sales will total $250 million, as compared to the $358 million brought in last year. 
 But even some auction-house officials admit it's difficult to predict the outcome with any certainty. "We're in such a period of stagnation, it's absolutely impossible to tell what's going to happen," David Nash, Sotheby's director of Impressionist and modern art, said recently.
Christopher Burge, Christie's president and chief operating officer, is more optimistic. "Economic recovery is not what we had hoped," he said, "but at the same time art of truly good quality is doing very well."
As always in a down market, this is a particularly difficult time for the auction houses to put together strong sales. The reason: private consignors who don't have to sell are, for the most part, holding on to their art until prices go up. Which means, if business remains slow, buyers may be able to cash in on bargain prices for what is on the block. (Impressionist and modern works in next week's sales will be on view at the auction houses this weekend.)
In addition, distress-sale merchandise is evident. In Sotheby's contemporary-art catalogue, for example, two lots are actually marked "property sold by order of the creditor." Christie's has one such notation. Other works in both Sotheby's Impressionist and modern-art sale and its contemporary-art sale are being offered by speculators who bought these pieces for top dollar at the recent height of the market and are now forced to sell because they are facing financial difficulties.
But some of the most important art that will be offered at both auction houses in the next two weeks is estate property. In fact, many of these pieces have been unavailable for years.
This season's sales begin at Christie's on Tuesday evening, with what experts say is one of the greatest private collections of Impressionist and modern art, from the estate of Burton and Emily Tremaine.
Christie's estimates the collection of 50 works, all fresh to the market, will bring more than $35 million. In order to lure the property away from Sotheby's, Christie's has guaranteed the family a minimum price, regardless of the sale's result. Though nobody at the auction house is talking, experts in the field say they believe the guarantee runs anywhere from about $28.5 million, or 5 percent below the sale's low estimate of $30 million, all the way up to $40 million. Both figures are reported to be significantly bigger than the guarantee Sotheby's offered the Tremaine family.
What with the delicate state of the market, and the memory of the guarantee Sotheby's extended last fall to paintings from the estate of the automobile maker Henry Ford 2d in a sale that badly misfired, this is a risky business indeed. "I don't like the principle of guarantees," Mr. Burge said. "But this is a two-horse race and we have to compete."
Burton Tremaine, an industrial-lighting executive who owned the Miller Lighting Company in Meriden, Conn., and his wife, Emily Hall Tremaine, began collecting this century's most important artists more than 60 years ago. The collection chronicles many of the major art movements from 1913 to the present. "The Tremaines put together a very personal collection, buying among the best of what was available," explained Michael Findlay, who heads Christie's department of Impressionist and modern art. "At the time they bought many of these paintings, the works were by no means the icons they are today."
Take Leger's "Petit Dejeuner," for example. A humorous depiction of three nude women set in a vivid, post-Cubist interior, it is now considered one of the artist's most important works. (This is a smaller and earlier version of "Le Grand Dejeuner," a painting that is at the Museum of Modern Art.) "Le Petit Dejeuner" has an estimated price of $8 million to $10 million. Another important piece in the Tremaine collection is "Premiere Disque" by Robert Delaunay, a circle of concentric colors painted in 1912. This is the initial work in a series now considered to be the first abstract paintings exhibited in Paris. Christie's estimates it will fetch $2 million to $3 million.
Art from the Tremaine Collection will also be the anchor of Christie's Nov. 12 sale of contemporary art. This is not the house's first sale of contemporary art belonging to the Tremaines. In 1988, after the death of Mrs. Tremaine, Christie's held an auction of some of the family's contemporary holdings that brought in $26 million, still a record for a single-owner sale of contemporary art.
This season's auction features many outstanding paintings, among them Jasper Johns's "Device Circle"of 1959. It is a boldly colored work that is the first of many in which Mr. Johns explores the theme of the circle. It is estimated to bring $5 million to $7 million. Another highlight of the Tremaine collection is Willem de Kooning's "Villa Borghese," on the block at an estimated $2.5 million to $3.5 million. "It sits on the cusp of his big landscapes," said Diane Upright, who heads the contemporary-art department at Christie's. "And it is one of his earliest East Hampton pastoral scenes."
In addition to the Tremaine paintings, the sale also features a group of smaller, less expensive works that Christie's hopes will appeal to a broader group of collectors. For example, it is offering a Robert Motherwell, "Spanish Elegy No. 17," estimated to bring $50,000 to $70,000; a Frank Stella, "Greek Key" ($45,000 to $65,000), and an Ad Reinhardt, "Blue Composition" ($40,000 to $50,000).
Sotheby's sales are aimed at attracting a wider group of buyers, too. "We chose the best paintings we thought would sell in the present market," Mr. Nash said. "But what is available is pretty haphazard." Leading its sale of Impressionist and modern art on Wednesday is a group of 15 pictures from the property of the Yaseen family of Harrison, N.Y. (Leonard Yaseen was an industrial real estate entrepreneur). Sotheby's guaranteed this group of pictures for a sum described by Mr. Nash as modest. The star picture in this group is Giorgio de Chirico's "Delights of the Poet," one of a well-known series that depicts eerily lighted, desolate piazzas. It is estimated to sell for $2.5 million to $3.5 million.
Also for sale are three works from the estate of Wendell Cherry, co-founder and president of Humana, a hospital chain. These include Fantin-Latour's "Still Life of Fruit and Flowers," estimated to sell for $1.5 million to $2 million; Degas's "Danseuse," a pastel over monotype estimated to bring $1.5 million to $2 million, and a large pen and ink drawing by Matisse, "Femme Se Reposant," with an estimate of $200,000 to $250,000.
Sotheby's sale of contemporary art, on Nov. 13, includes an important estate, too: nine works from the collection of Helmut Anton and Margot Kraetz of Germany, who formed their holdings of German, Conceptual and Minimalist artists in the late 1960's and the 1970's.
But what experts will be watching with special interest at that sale are the more than 30 lots belonging to the London-based advertising magnate Charles Saatchi. Though not identified as Mr. Saatchi's, these are works all familiar to collectors and experts in the field. Not only has Mr. Saatchi always been a visible personality in the contemporary-art world, he has also been criticized for selling large numbers of pieces by specific artists and in the process devaluing their work.
Also up for sale at Sotheby's is "Jubilee," an important black-and-white Johns marked in the catalogue "property of a Scandinavian collector, sold by order of the creditor." The Scandinavian collector is Hans Thulin, the 43-year-old Swedish real-estate magnate who was a big buyer at auctions three years ago but is now in serious financial trouble. The picture is estimated to sell for $4 million to $5 million, considered by many in the field as far less than Mr. Thulin paid for it at the height of the market.
For the auction houses, coming up with the presale estimates for the artworks during this buying climate has been difficult. While experts say the market is back to 1986-87 levels, everyone has a different opinion of what is accurate. "It's a moving target," Mr. Findlay explained. "It's difficult to know what's a realistic price. We do our homework and try to be fair, but we're working three months prior to the sales. If we put too high an estimate on a painting, it scares people away; if too low, they think something's wrong with it."
Much will depend on who's buying. "We won't see dealers bidding," Mr. Nash said. "They don't have the cash or the confidence. The Japanese are not in the mood at the moment either. And the speculators have completely disappeared."
Predictions are that private collectors will be buying as they did last spring. "I'm seeing old faces again," Mr. Findlay reported. "Serious collectors who haven't added to their collections in two or three years because they refused to pay the high prices are coming back."
Moreover, both auction houses report there has been institutional interest, something neither has seen for several seasons. So if prices stay low, some of this art will end up in museums, which will be much to everyone's benefit.
 
Art on View
 Starting this weekend, the art to be auctioned at Sotheby's and Christie's in New York in the next two weeks will be on view at the houses. Here is the schedule.
SOTHEBY'S, 1334 York Avenue, at 72d Street, Manhattan. Contemporary art to be auctioned on Nov. 13 is on view Nov. 9, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Nov. 10, 1 to 5 P.M.; Nov. 11 and 12, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Nov. 13, 10 A.M. to noon. Contemporary art from the Kraetz Collection to be auctioned on Nov. 13 and 14 is on view Nov. 9, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Nov. 10, 1 to 5 P.M.; Nov. 11, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Nov. 12, 10 A.M. to noon. Information: (212) 606-7000.

Impressionist and modern art to be auctioned on Nov. 5 is on view today and tomorrow, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sunday, 1 to 5 P.M.; Monday, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Tuesday, 10 A.M. to 1 P.M. Contemporary art to be auctioned on Nov. 12 is on view Nov. 8 and 9, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Nov. 10, 1 to 5 P.M.; Nov. 11, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., Nov. 12, 10 A.M. to noon. Information: (212) 546-1000.

HEADLINE: Pasta Aside, Marathon Is Still Pure at Heart

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE

 BODY:
I RUN a little; this is part boast, part confessional. Because I started all alone, 30 years ago, in combat boots, I never take personally the brie and chardonnay slurs leveled at runners by slobs. Because I dropped out to swim for 15 years, I missed the good times when running seemed political, and there was a collective joy in taking control of one's body, in believing that running could Fixx anything. Now we have the New York City Marathon on Sunday with almost 26,000 entrants running for Ronzoni and Seiko and Vermont Pure Natural Spring Water as well as for themselves. Somehow it's O.K. Perhaps this is why the Marathon is among the most beguiling of events -- beneath its dandy's clothes still beats a pure heart.
"The race itself is still pristine," says Dr. George Sheehan, the shaman of the sport. "The hype is there but you can get past it. Where you place doesn't matter. It's you and your digital watch." 
 I first met Sheehan at the Boston Marathon in 1968. He was 50, a born-again runner who had competed in college, stopped for many years to play tennis, then began running again to drain off angry energy after breaking his hand. He quickly became an Ancient Mariner, buttonholing strangers to share his wondrous revelations, his runner's highs, his intense spirituality and his uncommonly fine common sense about comfortable shoes and finding the pace and distance that fits you. He suggested to the shy that they wear ski masks when they ran.
He was a "fitness freak" then, but within 10 years his "Running and Being" (Simon and Schuster) was a best-seller, six months ahead of Jim Fixx's "The Complete Book of Running" (Random House). Sheehan now thinks that while Fixx brought millions into running, he kept many of them in the sport by validating what they were feeling.
And so, Sheehan is an accomplice, nay, an unindicted co-conspirator when Allan Steinfeld crows, as he did yesterday, that criminal imitation is the sincerest form of flattery. Steinfeld, the Marathon's coordinator, was offering another benchmark of his event's success. Bad guys were selling marathon knock-off knick-knacks. Steinfeld revealed that "SWAT teams of lawyers and police officers" would be roaming the city over the weekend to seize the illegitimate shirts and hats and bags that bore the Marathon's trademarked name and logo.
But Sheehan must be held accountable, too, for the millions of personal revolutions achieved since running became the symbol for people trying to make themselves, and in a sense their worlds, better. In a shrewd essay in last May's issue of Runner's World magazine, the writer Marc Bloom listed "Smoking Outlawed on Domestic Flights" as a historical moment in the last quarter-century of running. The social change that made such legislation possible came out of the running movement, as powerful a force in its way as the struggle for black civil rights or the women's movement at those times when it was allied with the consumer movement rather than the peddling of all those jelly-roll sneakers for terminal pronation.
Which brings us to pasta, which is where the running hard sell is today. Sheehan always liked to point out that running is an inexpensive sport populated by cheap people. I used to think he was mostly talking about himself. But since carbohydrate loading became a passion as the country began to slide into recession it seemed as though running was making cheap food chic as it once made cheap shoes trendy.
And so, yesterday, Frank Shorter, who won the Olympic marathon in 1972, unveiled his new relationship with Ronzoni and offered samples of three kinds of pasta that the company, owned by the chocolate manufacturer, Hershey, was pushing as complex enough for marathoners. And over at the Coliseum, where runners were checking in, it was possible to carbo overload on at least five different kinds of pasta being offered free, along with magazines, drinks, and fittings for shoes so complex that runners need to know the sequence in which parts of their feet hit the ground.
Is this all necessary?
"Get past it," said Sheehan, who stopped running marathons six years ago when prostate cancer treatments slowed him down to nine-minute miles. "One thing that's so special about running is the realization that the competition is within oneself, that the others are there to encourage you, pace you in the struggle within yourself and against time.
"Runners don't look around at the finish, they look at their digital watches. I was in a race recently where we were specifically asked not to look down at our watches at the end because it spoils the picture."
I am still asking the man questions after all these years: "George, what does it all mean?"
"It means we are given a 75-year warranty but we need to read the book of instructions," he said. "Diet. Sleep. Moderate alcohol. No smoking. And exercise. It's all very simple, but not easy."

HEADLINE: After Madrid, Time to Dig In

BYLINE: By Richard W. Murphy; Richard W. Murphy was Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs in the Reagan Administration.

 BODY:
With the Madrid conference ending today and Arab-Israeli bilateral talks about to begin, questions about the peace process trouble Americans.
Were the parties ready for Madrid? The Arabs and Israelis probably have not fully thought out their negotiating strategies for the next stage, but it is wrong to say they went to Madrid only because we dragged them there. They went also because they are tired of decades of conflict. 
 Arabs and Israelis alike resent the fact that years of confrontation have slowed their economic, social and political development. Many Israelis are concerned about the occupation of the territories, its effect on their building a democratic Jewish state and on their country's image abroad. Besides, the ending of the cold war has removed the incentive for Washington and Moscow to develop strategic alliances in the region. This has forced the parties, perhaps the Arabs more than the Israelis, to rethink their overall strategies.
Might the American efforts that brought them together have created a dynamic that could end up harming regional stability?
To suggest that Madrid may have set a course for war is nonsense. Whatever the outcome of the bilateral talks, there is no prospect of another war for many years. The disaster Saddam Hussein's adventuring brought Iraq reminded the Arabs and Israelis that the world will not tolerate efforts to resolve the region's rivalries militarily. Nonetheless, the military buildup continues and with it the potential for another war. Syria's purchases of Czech tanks and North Korean missiles are well-known. We can fairly assume that Israel will work to maintain its edge in nonconventional and conventional weapons.
How much more effort should America invest in behalf of an elusive Middle Eastern peace?
The U.S. and the Soviet Union will complete their formal roles as co-chairmen when the Madrid ceremonies end. To join the bilateral negotiations, both countries must be invited; such an invitation may come soon. Moscow's mediating energies will be limited. Even though Moscow retains influence in the region because of its long cooperation with Syria and the Palestinians, its contribution to the talks may well be simply good will. The burden of guiding the talks to some measurable success will fall to the U.S.
President Bush will have amply fulfilled his pledge to try to work out Arab-Israeli differences by pushing to convene the conference and start the bilateral talks. While popular at home, he faces mounting criticism for neglecting domestic policy. He surely knows that even if he appoints a special envoy to the talks, he will have to devote a substantial amount of time to the negotiating process. Would he find it worthwhile?
The developments that made possible this opening for U.S. diplomacy -- the ending of the cold war and defeat of Iraq -- ironically removed any readily apparent need for Washington to pursue an elusive Arab-Israeli peace. Still, the area remains volatile, and continuation of the Arab-Israeli conflict could eventually damage our friends and economic interests.
Even if Iran is serious about its threat to liquidate Israel, this threat can be controlled. The Egyptian-Israeli peace is cold, but it is not in either party's interest to let the treaty fall apart. Saudi Arabia is secure, and Kuwait will be back in full oil production within two years.
The basic reason for our continued role as the main mediator is that we have gotten in too far to get out. We will not be able to do the whole job, but no one can substitute for us. Our withdrawal would condemn the area to deteriorating security.

HEADLINE: Senate Fought for Six Months Over Brandeis

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You suggest (The Week in Review, Oct. 20) that one approach to end Presidential-senatorial bickering over Supreme Court nominees "might be to find nominees of such eminence that few people would dare oppose them -- senior politicians like governors or senators, or widely admired judges." You give Louis D. Brandeis, appointed by Woodrow Wilson in 1916, as an example. 
 Brandeis was neither office holder nor judge. He was in private practice, known to Americans as the "people's attorney." He invented Savings Bank Life Insurance as an inexpensive safeguard for workers' families.
He fought against municipal and national transportation monopolies, attacked the banks organized in what he called the "money trust," designed many of Wilson's progressive policies, advocated conservation of land and natural resources, and argued for women's suffrage, legalization of unions, unemployment insurance, old age pensions, industrial profit-sharing, and minimum wage and maximum hours laws. He did this for no salary, becoming the model for modern-day lawyers in pro bono work.
This list suggests why his confirmation was anything but assured or quiet. The Senate Judiciary Committee took more than 1,000 pages of testimony. Among Brandeis's louder opponents were Senator Henry Cabot Lodge; Elihu Root, former Secretary of War and Secretary of State; Moorfield Storey, former president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, and Thomas Lamont, the J. P. Morgan partner. A. Lawrence Lowell, president of Harvard, circulated an anti-Brandeis petition signed by more than 50 Boston brahmins.
He was attacked by The Wall Street Journal, The Nation and The New York Times.
Those supporting him included Walter Lippmann; Felix Frankfurter and 8 other members of the 11-man Harvard Law School faculty; Rabbi Stephen Wise; Frances Perkins, future Secretary of Labor; Charles Eliot, former Harvard president; Samuel Gompers, American Federation of Labor president; The New York World and New Republic.
Brandeis's wife had predicted that his nomination would be accompanied by a "burst of fireworks." They lasted for six months. A Judiciary Committee subcommittee voted 3-2 for the nominee. The vote of the full committee, strictly along party lines, was 10-8. He was confirmed primarily because the Democrats had a majority of more than 2-1 in the Senate.
Tumultuous battles over Supreme Court nominees are not necessarily undesirable. The Judiciary Committee and the Senate become arenas in which political differences are expressed, sometimes bitterly. Lack of disagreement may indicate only that the nominee has views that are largely unknown.
Brandeis did not appear before the committee; that was not yet the custom. It was left to other witnesses to attack and defend his character, which they did with great zest. And of course he went on to become one of the country's greatest justices.
The problem does not lie with the process. It is to be found in a committee that is unable or unwilling to ask nominees and witnesses the right questions and to insist on answers, and in a President who cynically chooses a nominee so far from the best.
 
PHILIPPA STRUM
New York, Oct. 22, 1991
 
The writer, a CUNY Graduate Center political science professor, is author of a biography of Louis D. Brandeis.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Auto Spots Focus on the Road Again

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
MANY of the advertising campaigns for 1992 model automobiles are trying an even more ambitious task than selling cars during a recession: They are trying to rekindle America's love affair with the open road.
In television and radio commercials, print advertisements and billboards, auto makers like Buick, Chevrolet, Lexus, Mazda and Saturn are seeking to restore some of the excitement and "searchlights outside the showroom" glamour that typified car campaigns in the 1950's and 1960's, when Mercury offered buyers "more of everything" and Pontiac promised drivers they would be "riding high." 
 Automobile and advertising executives say that much of their advertising during the 1980's, which played down model-year unveilings in favor of no-nonsense recitations about antilock brakes and fuel economy, dampened consumers' infatuation with cars.
"Over the past few years, automobiles have become much more of a commodity purchase," George Peterson, president of the Auto Pacific Group, a marketing and product consulting company, said in a telephone interview from his office in Santa Ana, Calif. "Manufacturers were losing sight of just how emotional a purchase of an automobile is to a lot of people."
The notion that there once was such a warm relationship between car and driver is one "that our research indicates is very much missed by today's consumer," said John Yost, senior vice president and general manager of Hal Riney & Partners in San Francisco, the agency for Saturn, a new car of the General Motors Corporation.
Hoping that "Saturn could be part of restoring some of that romance," Mr. Yost said, the car's television commercial features footage of old cars and an announcer waxing nostalgic.
"What was meant to be a hunk of metal to get you from point A to point B had become a refuge, almost family," the announcer says. "You had something special, almost magical. Isn't it time you felt that way again?" the spot ends.
In another throwback to a more romantic era, the sheet draped over cars in countless commercials and dramatically pulled away to reveal new models is making a comeback. Sheets, particularly those that flap in a breeze and then blow off, have been spotted in spots for Buick, Chevrolet, Ford, Lexus, Mazda and Pontiac.
"We're trying to create that sense of drama about the new product," said Mark Gjovik, executive vice president and group account director at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, the Pontiac agency, in Bloomfield Hills, Mich. "You can always put off buying a new car," he added, "but if there's a lot of exciting new hardware at a dealer, that's worth a look."
The agency for Lexus, Team One Advertising in El Segundo, Calif., is "really pleased with the results" generated by its sheet spot, said Skip Sullivan, senior vice president and management supervisor. He added that the findings from consumer research, as well as the response from dealers, have been positive for the spot, which uses special effects to show a sheet in the shape of a Lexus LS400 that is blown off to uncover a new smaller model, the ES300.
Thomas O'Grady, president of Integrated Automotive Resources Inc., a Wayne, Pa., consulting firm, agreed that some car ads "were somewhat boring" and that it made sense "to try to bring back the fall feeling of old days."
But in the fractious advertising world, not everyone is participating. The first campaign by Wieden & Kennedy Inc., Portland, Ore., for its new client, Subaru of America, is based on the assumption that a car is "a machine," as one print ad puts it. "Let's get rid of all the marketing glamour about the automobile, and see the car for what it really is."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Team One Advertising's television spot for Lexus uses special effects to show a sheet, shaped like a Lexus LS400, that is suddenly whipped off to uncover the auto maker's new, smaller model, the ES300. (Team One Advertising)

HEADLINE: 2d Bank Cuts Its Prime Rate

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, Nov. 1

 BODY:
The Southwest Bank said today that it would lower its prime lending rate, but analysts did not expect other banks to follow suit until the Federal Reserve cut interest rates again.
Southwest said it would cut its prime rate a quarter percentage point to 7.75 percent, effective Monday. Southwest becomes the second regional bank to reduce the key rate from the 8 percent level that has prevailed in the banking industry since Sept. 13. 
 The First Fidelity Bancorporation of Lawrenceville, N.J., cut its prime rate on Wednesday to 7.75 percent.
But no leading banks have taken similar action thus far.

HEADLINE: Water Utility of a Thousand Faces

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG

 BODY:
What a difference a decade makes.
At the dawn of the 1980's, JWP Inc. was a $40 million water utility that had lost money for eight straight years and at times teetered on the brink of bankruptcy. 
 Now, that same water supplier has metamorphosed into a $3 billion technical-services company, which instantly moved to the forefront of personal computer reselling in August when it gained control of Businessland. For JWP, it was a natural extension of its experience in installing sophisticated electrical, mechanical, electronic and pollution-control systems for high-profile corporations.
Among an eclectic list of projects, the company has created trading floors for Merrill Lynch, energy management systems for Sears, Roebuck and "clean rooms" for Hewlett-Packard's manufacturing of computer chips.
 
'Do Virtually Everything'

Just this summer, an affiliate of JWP, which is based in Purchase, N.Y., about 20 miles from Manhattan, signed a six-and-a-half-year $468 million contract to convert New York City's sludge into fertilizer pellets that will be marketed nationally.
"They'll do virtually everything but pour slab and put up walls," said David Loeb, a vice president and research analyst at Oppenheimer & Company.
The wide swath that JWP has rapidly cut through the specialty contracting fields has translated into astronomical growth; the loss of $495,000 that the company had in 1980 now seems like a faint bad dream compared with a $59.3 million profit last year.
But such rapid growth, much of it through acquisitions, has not come cheap, and JWP's debt-to-equity ratio is a steep 1.2 to 1.
 
High Receivables

Analysts say the debts are balanced by the company's high receivables, a source of cash if the company suddenly needs it.
A tougher problem has been the recession, which has hurt the equipment renovation business, maintenance contracts and computer reselling this year, analysts said.
On Thursday, the company reported third-quarter earnings of $15.3 million, or 39 cents a share, down from $16 million, or 42 cents a share. The purchase of Businessland pushed revenues up to $944.9 million, from $744.6 million.
The company's share price rose 25 cents yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, to $15.25, off its 52-week high of $23.
"It's not going to be a great year for us," said Andrew T. Dwyer, the company's chairman and president, who nonetheless expects annual profits to be up.
From Water to Computers
Still, the question remains: How could a company that continues to provide water to a quarter of Queens become the nation's largest computer reseller operating through company-owned outlets? And why would it want to?
The answers lie in a fundamental shift that the company initiated in the mid-1980's, a shift that was painstakingly orchestrated by the boyish Mr. Dwyer, who is 43 years old.
Armed with a degree in history from Yale, a law degree from New York Law School and two years of experience as a corporate lawyer, Mr. Dwyer joined the company as a vice president in 1976.
"I wasn't a very good lawyer," Mr. Dwyer said, but he was the son of JWP's chairman, Martin Dwyer Jr., who died in 1986.
JWP was born in 1877 as the Jamaica Water Supply Company, which underwent several name changes until it settled on JWP in 1986, the year its stock moved onto the Big Board.
 
Diversifying From Water

For much of its history, the company functioned primarily as a provider of water to Queens and Nassau County on Long Island. But a series of small outside ventures that the company undertook in the late 1960's -- among them lighting fixtures and prefabricated concrete -- turned sour amid the oil crisis and recession of the mid-1970's.
"It got pretty close to bankruptcy," Mr. Dwyer said.
By the late 1970's, Mr. Dwyer and Ernest W. Grendi, 45, now JWP's executive vice president and chief financial officer, began to rein in the company. After selling off JWP's money-losing ventures, sprucing up the water utility and making the overall company profitable again, Mr. Dwyer set his sights on diversification. In addition to providing services like plumbing and piping, JWP could branch out, Mr. Dwyer believed, and offer big companies, institutions and municipalities a long menu of specialty contracting services they would not ordinarily find in one place.
"We tried to identify those marketplaces where there was a need for sophisticated equipment," Mr. Dwyer said.
 
Wall Street Clients

One of the company's first targets was Wall Street, where booming securities firms found they had to retool, expand or move their offices to accommodate new technology and growing demand. JWP offered virtually everything needed to create high-technology trading floors, including the installation and maintenance of air-conditioning, wiring, telephones, data cables and computers. Salomon Brothers; Morgan Guaranty; Goldman, Sachs, and other firms have employed JWP.
Other, more diverse clients -- DuPont, Illinois Bell and Sharp Hospital in San Diego among them -- soon followed, with requests for solid-waste conversion plants, security systems and electrical networks.
As clients signed on, JWP embarked on a course of aggressive acquisitions that widened its geographic scope and expanded its services.
"The key to their success has been putting a lot of management attention into carefully developing their acquisitions," Mr. Loeb, the Oppenheimer analyst, said. "They don't overpay. They have very strict numbers regarding what an acquisition needs to contribute to JWP. And they achieve those numbers."
Forest Electric, a New York company that JWP acquired in 1986, and Dynalectric of McLean, Va., purchased in 1988, broadened JWP's electrical repertory. University Industries of San Diego, which JWP acquired in 1988, helped it gain a foothold on the West Coast and offer more extensive mechanical services. And Drake & Scull Holdings, a British electrical and mechanical company that JWP acquired in 1989, brought international exposure.
 
A Natural Step

Because JWP was increasingly called upon to set up computer systems, selling computers to its clients seemed like a natural outgrowth, said James R. Ryan, vice president of investor relations. To that end, the company in 1990 picked up Neeco Inc., a reseller of desktop computer systems based in Canton, Mass., and gained control of Businessland of San Jose, Calif., in August of this year.
The new computer unit that the company has created, JWP Businessland Inc., will have sales of about $1.8 billion worldwide, mainly in the United States, making it the largest reseller of computers operating through its own outlets. The Computerland chain has sales of about $3 billion, mainly through franchisees.
JWP now counts 21,000 employees in 195 offices, compared with 400 employees in 5 offices in 1980. Company officials and analysts swear by JWP's decentralized style of management, which allows many of the company's acquisitions to maintain their identities under the close scrutiny of the home office.
 
'They Watch Very Closely'
 "They look over the shoulder of the people who run their companies," said Carey Tharp, a senior analyst at H. G. Wellington & Company. "There's a lot of decentralization, but they watch very closely."
If JWP has a weakness, Mr. Tharp said, it is its lingering susceptibility to a sluggish economy.
"Some of the environmental business has been postponed because municipalities don't have the income," Mr. Tharp continued. "And margins on the smaller contracts on the West Coast and in the East are lower because the bidding is tougher."
"But," he added, "for a company of this nature to have flat earnings in a recession is pretty darn good."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Next Computer To Cut 30 Jobs

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Next Computer Inc. said it would lay off about 30 people, or 5 percent of its work force. Most of Next's 600 employees are based at the company's headquarters in Redwood City, Calif. Next also has a manufacturing plant in Fremont, Calif.
Steven P. Jobs, Next's founder, chairman and chief executive, said in a telephone interview that the layoffs were because of a rethinking of Next's business plan that focuses more on corporate customers creating their own software programs rather than using off-the-shelf products.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Citibank Names Head Of Foreign Debt Panel

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Citibank, the largest American bank lender to Latin American countries and the leader in negotiations to reorganize those countries' debts, yesterday named Mike de Graffenried chairman of the bank's debt-restructuring committee.
Mr. de Graffenried, 42 years old, will replace Robert A. McCormack, who moved to a new position in the bank to help resolve its problems with commercial real estate loans. 
 The appointment comes as bankers, led by Citibank, are negotiating with Brazil on a package of financial options covering about $40 billion in medium- and long-term debts. Brazil has already begun to make cash interest payments that will cover about $2 billion of its $8 billion in interest arrears, with the remainder of past-due interest to be covered once the country and banks agree on a broader debt package.
Analysts expect the solution for Brazil to be somewhat similar to that worked out for other countries, where bankers have accepted a package that allows them to choose among making new loans, accepting a market rate of interest on a reduced amount of existing loans, or accepting a below-market interest rate on the existing loans. The packages also include various mixtures of United States Treasury zero-coupon bonds and financial assistance from international organizations to guarantee some principal and interest payments.
Mr. de Graffenried, who speaks Spanish and Portuguese, is no stranger to the debt talks. After the Mexican loan default in 1982, he joined the Citibank debt-restructuring team led then by William R. Rhodes, now a bank vice chairman, and was deeply involved in earlier loan agreements with Brazil and Argentina. After a tour of duty as Citibank's senior officer in the Persian Gulf region, he returned to New York and the debt-restructuring group.
"In the 1980's, there was a real sense of crisis, and living moment to moment," Mr. de Graffenried said in an interview yesterday. Currently, he said, the most heavily indebted countries are past the liquidity crises that threatened their ability to pay for imports and interest on their loans.
He noted that the economic rebound in Mexico, Chile and Venezuela, which followed internal changes and debt restructurings, could make negotiations easier "by showing other countries that there is a benefit to be derived."
What the solution will be in the cases of Brazil and Argentina, the two largest remaining debtors, remains to be seen. Mr. de Graffenried declined to comment on the current state of negotiations with Brazil. Talks with Argentina, which owes banks about $25 billion but has been making partial interest payments of $60 million a month, could begin later this year.
Mr. de Graffenried lives in Westport, Conn., with his wife, Pilar, and their 15 year-old son.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in Heavy Trading On Gloomy Economic Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar plunged in heavy trading yesterday as new economic reports showing the economy has continued to decline prompted a broad selloff.
Gold prices were mixed. On the New York Commodity Exchange, bullion for current delivery settled at $355.60 an ounce, off $2.50 from Thursday. Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $355, down $2.70. 
 "The dollar is sitting on its lowest levels in quite a few months based on a continued, clearly weak economic picture," said John McCarthy, chief dealer at ABN-AMRO Bank N.V.
In a much-anticipated report, the Labor Department said the unemployment rate climbed one-tenth of a point to 6.8 percent in October as factory and construction workers suffered enormous layoffs.
A separate report showed the Government's chief economic forecasting gauge, which is meant to project economic activity six to nine months from now, declining for the first time in eight months.
Analysts expect the data will prompt the Federal Reserve to provide a new round of interest rate cuts in an effort to revive the sputtering economy. Such a move would be bearish for the dollar since lower interest rates make dollar-denominated securities less valuable to investors.
The dollar broke through the criticial technical and psychological support level of 1.6580 German marks, which prompted even more selling.
"With prospects of continued pressure on interest rates in the U.S. and with firm interest rates in Germany, the mark zoomed against the dollar and other major currencies," said Ronald Holzer, chief dealer at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago.
Analysts said the belief that the Bank of Japan will move soon to trim interest rates there tempered the dollar's decline against the yen somewhat. But the dollar settled sharply lower against all other leading currencies.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 130.74 Japanese yen from 131.00 yen at Thursday's close. Later in London, it fell to 130.20 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 129.73 yen, down from 130.75 yen on Thursday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7490 from $1.7445 late Thursday. In New York it cost $1.7675 to buy one pound, more expensive than Thursday's $1.7395.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.6445 German marks, down from 1.6715; 1.4435 Swiss francs, down from 1.4680; 5.6215 French francs, down from 5.7130; 1,233.75 Italian lire, down from 1,252.50; and 1.1201 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1230.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Browning-Ferris Fills A Long-Vacant Position

 BODY:
Browning-Ferris Industries, the Houston-based waste disposal company, said yesterday that Bruce E. Ranck had been named president and chief operating officer. The posts had been vacant since John E. Drury left in January.
Mr. Ranck, 42, has spent 21 years at the company. He had been performing many of Mr. Drury's former duties as executive vice president in charge of North American solid-waste operations. 
 "Mr. Ranck's experience and knowledge will be critical to B.F.I. during this time of transition," said William D. Ruckelshaus, the former administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency who is the company's chairman and chief executive.
Mr. Ranck takes over a company that has endured grim and embarassing economic news in recent months.
In September, Browning-Ferris said its fourth-quarter earnings would be down 38 cents a share from the previous quarter -- which had already been considered low. A month earlier, the chief financial officer, R. John Stanton Jr., sold 60,000 common shares, about half his holdings.
Browning-Ferris officials have attributd the company's shaky economic performance to the recession. But analysts have noted that most of its competitors were not affected by the downturn.
But Mr. Ranck sounded a positive note in a statement yesterday. "B.F.I. is a strong, solid company, with good managers at every level of its operations," he said.
Browning-Ferris's shares fell 37.5 cents each yesterday, to $17.75, just above their 52-week low, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Mr. Ranck received a bachelor's degree from Michigan State University in 1970. He lives in Houston with his wife and five children.

HEADLINE: Treasuries Mixed in Reaction to Jobs Data

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The October employment report received a mixed reception in the credit markets yesterday, as prices of shorter-term Treasury notes improved but bond prices fell.
Immediate reaction to the report was positive, as traders bought securities after the Labor Department said non-farm payrolls contracted by 1,000 jobs and the unemployment rate rose one-tenth of a point, to 6.8 percent. 
 But concern about next week's quarterly refunding auctions -- a worry compounded yesterday by a sharp drop in the dollar on foreign exchange markets -- and disappointment that the Federal Reserve Board did not immediately respond by easing monetary policy ultimately persuaded market participants to sell securities.
"There is a good deal of reluctance to buy in front of the refunding," one government bond trader said. "And while prices of shorter-term maturities are higher, there is some concern that if the Fed doesn't move again those securities may be too expensive."
At a series of auctions next week the Treasury intends to sell a total of $38 billion worth of new 3-year and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds.
Concern about the market's ability to absorb such enormous amounts of securities almost always leads traders to turn cautious beforehand.
Yesterday's sharp drop in the dollar compounded those worries, analysts said, because a weaker dollar makes it less likely that foreign investors will be interested in buying significant amounts of the new securities.
Although the Fed chose not to push short-term interest rates down for the second time this week, most analysts said the weak employment statistics make such a move very likely.
But they said they were surprised that those same factors -- new evidence of economic weakness and a likely policy response from the Fed -- did not cause bond yields to fall yesterday.
"We may be at the stage in the cycle where further Fed easing doesn't guarantee lower bond yields," said William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. "Whatever the causes for it, bonds lost buying support when they moved to higher prices."
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 102 6/32, down 1/4 of a point, to yield 7.93 percent, compared with 7.91 percent late Thursday and 8.04 percent on Oct. 25.
Among note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 102 25/ 32, down 3/32, to yield 7.46 percent. But prices of the 6 7/8 percent five-year notes rose by 3/32, to 100 21/32, to yield 6.71 percent. And the 6 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 22/ 32, up 1/8 of a point, to yield 5.62 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates continued to decline.
By late in the session, three-month bills were offered at a discount rtae of 4.74 percent, down 8 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by 7 basis points, to a late offered rate of 4.76 percent.

HEADLINE: Dow Drops 12.75 on Program Selling

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks fell in heavy trading yesterday after a late series of program trades and a weak bond market pushed prices lower. The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 12.75 for the day, at 3,056.35, but it was up 51.43 for the week.
Many investors stayed on the sidelines, awaiting a cut in the discount rate after the Labor Department reported that employment had declined, contrary to expectations. 
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 206.5 million shares, up from 182.2 million on Thursday. Losing issues outnumbered gainers by 845 to 772.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 1.14, to 391.32, and the Big Board composite was down 0.53, to 216.01. The American Stock Exchange composite fell 0.46, to 386.85.
On the Nasdaq, the composite index was off 2.05, to 540.93, while the Russell 2000 was off 0.35, to 184.62.
 
11 Trading Programs
 Program selling emerged early. Birinyi Associates tracked "a healthy amount" of such transactions -- 11 trading programs throughout the day. Their combined effect pulled the Dow down about 29 points.
A sluggish report on jobs and a decline in the Index of Leading Economic Indicators spurred hopes that the Fed would quickly ease credit, but when it became apparent that it would not happen yesterday, stock prices fell.
Gene J. Seagle, director of technical research for Gruntal & Company, said the economic reports made the pressure being exerted by President Bush for lower rates more likely to be successful.
Another indication of a discount rate cut is the money supply, which a Federal Reserve report on Thursday showed was increasing, something it had not done in a while, Mr. Seagle added.
"A probable cut in the discount rate, plus awful returns for investors with certificates of deposit and money funds, should set the stage for a new high on the Dow, with a thrust through the 3,100 level," Mr. Seagle said. He added that the Treasury's quarterly refunding next week "could also enhance the chances of a rate cut."
Shares of American International fell 1 1/8, to 86 7/8, after the insurer reported lackluster third-quarter earnings linked to its property and casualty operations. Traders said analysts at Dean Witter and Alex. Brown lowered their 1991 and 1992 earnings estimates.
Immune Response was up 1/4, to 59 1/2. The stock had risen 6 1/8 on Thursday because of a regulatory panel meeting to discuss how to measure the effectiveness of AIDS vaccine trials. The biotechnology company, in a venture with Rhone-Poulenc Rorer, is conducting clinical trials of an AIDS vaccine.
American Home Products rose 1 3/4, to 75 1/4, after Barbara Ryan, an analyst at Prudential Securities, raised her 1991 and 1992 earnings estimates. She cited the company's strong third-quarter earnings and new contraceptive and arthritis drugs.
The Food and Drug Adminstration's approval of Syntex's Ticlopidine, a product that reduces the risk of fatal and nonfatal thrombotic strokes, moved the stock as high as 46 1/4 yesterday before it closed down 1/8, to 45 5/8. The stock had risen 1 3/8 the day before. Traders noted that analysts at Merrill Lynch and Smith Barney were repeating their buy ratings.
On the strength of its higher fourth-quarter earnings, Ralston Purina stock rose 2 1/8, to 52 5/8.
Technology stocks were among the most active issues yesterday, with Intel up 1 1/4, to 41 7/8, and Borland Intertnational up 2 3/8, to 69 3/4. Novell, on the other hand, lost 1 1/2, to 50 1/4, and Dell Computer fell 2 1/4, to 22 5/8.

HEADLINE: Indicators Index Falls a Tenth of 1%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
The Commerce Department reported today that its Index of Leading Economic Indicators turned down one-tenth of 1 percent in September, the first drop in eight months. It had been flat a month earlier.
The indicators are the Government's chief barometer of future economic activity and are intended to forecast the economy over six to nine months. Thus, the drop heightened fears of renewed recession. 
 "The next six months do not present a pretty picture for the economy at all," said Allen Sinai, an economist for the Boston Company. "Rather than a recovery, it's looking more like a double dip or the extension of a recession that might never have ended."
 
'Flirting With a Double Dip'

"It's clear we're flirting with a double dip," Larry Meyer of Laurence H. Meyer & Associates, a St. Louis economic forecasting company, said. The indicators are "flattening out, telling us the economy has lost any sense of upward momentum," he continued, adding, "It's moving sideways."
Three consecutive declines in the index are considered a fairly good sign of an approaching recession, although the index failed to predict the last contraction. It did not start turning down until August 1990 -- the month after the recession began.
In September, 6 of the 11 forward-looking indicators in the index were negative.
And Lawrence Chimerine, senior economic counselor for DRI-McGraw-Hill, a Lexington, Mass., forecasting service, said the five components that made positive contributions did not "show any sign of strength right now."
"Over all, it's a flat environment," Mr. Chimerine said.
 
Housing, Manufacturing Weaker

Most analysts concur that the economy, after spurting last spring and summer after the Persian Gulf war, has tailed off. Both the housing and manufacturing industries, which had paced the recovery, have weakened in recent months.
Consumer spending, which represents two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, remains sluggish, and today's Labor Department report on growing unemployment is not likely to stimulate any activity.
"Not only is income falling, but everyone else is worried about their jobs, and that's a devastating combination," Mr. Chimerine said.
The biggest negative in the index of leading indicators was a shrinking money supply, which the Federal Reserve watches closely as a sign of economic growth. The Fed is believed to have nudged short-term interest rates down earlier this week in an attempt to stimulate economic expansion.
 
Other Components

Other negative components were declining orders for new plants and equipment; falling prices for raw materials, which indicate slack demand; a shorter average workweek; rising claims for unemployment insurance, and lower stock prices.
Positive contributors were an increase in building permits, rising orders for consumer goods, improving consumer confidence, an increase in unfilled orders and slower delivery times, which also suggest increasing orders.
The various changes left the index at 145.4 percent of its 1982 base of 100. The index has risen 2.8 percent in the last six months, wiping out a 1.2 percent loss during the previous half-year.
