HEADLINE: Jobless Rate Rises to 6.8%, as Economy Stalls

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Underscoring that the economic recovery has slowed to a near standstill, Labor Department figures showed today that payroll jobs failed to rise in October and that the unemployment rate edged back up to its August level of 6.8 percent.
Although the report was only modestly worse than expected, despite sharp job losses in manufacturing, retail trade and construction, economists said it added to fears that the midyear rebound had stagnated. 
 "You're just not getting any follow-through to the recovery we saw in the spring and early summer," said Edward F. McKelvey, senior economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "The economy is dead in the water."
 
'Back Into Recession'
 Congressional Democrats were quick to seize on the report. Senator Paul S. Sarbanes of Maryland, chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, said it indicated that the economy "is heading back into recession."
Party leaders renewed efforts to win approval of legislation to extend jobless benefits by up to 20 weeks for those who have exhausted them. House Democrats failed to get their bill past the committee stage, though, even though the Administration endorsed it hesitantly. Still, leaders of both parties said they felt a bill providing extended benefits could be passed soon. [Page 49.]
Today's employment figures also prompted the White House to make one of its strongest pleas yet for the Federal Reserve to ease monetary policy again.
Mr. Bush, whose advisers are reported to be offering him conflicting advice on how to spur the economy, called for lower rates in an interview with a Houston television station. And the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, traveling with the President on a campaign fund-raising trip to Texas, said that "lower interest rates always have been a good way of stimulating the economy."
In a separate report, the Commerce Department index intended to predict the course of the economy turned negative in September, albeit by a slight one-tenth of 1 percent, the first decline since January. Spending on construction, on the other hand, posted an unexpected and sizable gain for the month.
The Federal Reserve, which earlier this week presided over a reduction in the overnight lending rate among banks, did nothing further today, but analysts continued to anticipate a cut in the discount rate and possibly other easing steps. The central bank's main policy-setting body, the Open Market Committee, meets on Tuesday to plot strategy through mid-December.
"I don't really see what's holding them back," commented Daniel Friel, economist at the NCNB Corporation in Charlotte. He said the economy had lost so much momentum that national output in the fourth quarter might show no gain at all after rising at a 2.4 percent pace in the July-September quarter. Mr. Friel said he was particularly concerned about manufacturing and construction, two sectors that typically lead the economy out of recession.
 
Factory Jobs Drop
 Factory jobs dropped 32,000 last month after a 31,000 loss in September, a combination that erased advances posted in July and August. The October decline was concentrated in durable goods, including machinery, electronic equipment, transportation equipment, instruments and primary metals.
Jobs in retail trade fell by 47,000, the biggest since April, as seasonal hiring for the holiday season by department and variety stores fell short of expectations.
And in construction, which enjoyed a small gain in September, 29,000 jobs were lost last month. The industry has now shed 10 percent of its jobs since May 1990 and the unemployment rate for construction workers has climbed over this period to 16.2 percent from about 10 percent, said Janet L. Norwood, commissioner of labor statistics.
On the brighter side, however, service jobs advanced for the sixth straight month, with a 101,000 gain -- divided among health care, business and other services -- that largely offset declines elsewhere. Though there is stagnation in key sectors, said Douglas P. Handler, economist at Dun & Bradstreet, "there are pockets of strength."
Over all, payroll jobs eased by 1,000, in contrast to modest anticipated gains ranging between 15,000 and 35,000.
 
Rate for Women Rises
 According to the department's survey of households, employment fell by 198,000 last month, but because of a decline in the labor force the ranks of the jobless swelled by 140,000, to 8,582,000. The unemployment rate for adult women rose three-tenths of a point, to 5.8 percent, after declining in September, while the jobless rate for adult men was unchanged at 6.4 percent, the report also showed.
A total of 2,537,000 workers had been jobless for 15 weeks or more during the Oct. 6-12 survey week, 175,000 more than in September.

HEADLINE: House Panel Fails to Clear Benefits Bill

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
House Democrats stumbled today and failed to get their new bill for extended unemployment benefits out of the House Ways and Means Committee, even though the Bush Administration endorsed it hesitantly.
But Congressional leaders of both parties and the budget director, Richard G. Darman, said they felt a program could be agreed on early next week, and that a bill providing benefits to about three million people out of work more than half a year could be passed soon. 
 Today's disagreement in the committee, which grumbled over lack of advance notice of a Democratic leadership decision to push the $5.5 billion bill forward with a new financing mechanism, was plainly a setback to the hopes of Democratic leaders to retain a partisan advantage on the issue.
"The legislation is more complicated than we anticipated," said Representative Dan Rostenkowski Democrat of Illinois, the committee chairman, after several members from both parties had complained that they did not know how the financing would work.
Democratic leaders had hoped to finance the extra unemployment benefits in large part by speeding up payments from upper-bracket taxpayers who expected sharp earnings increases from one year to the next. Some committee members complained this would be unfair to taxpayers who did not know how their partnerships, mutual funds and other income would work out.
This was a major shift by Democrats who had twice before sought to pay for extended benefits by raising the deficit, the chief reason cited by President Bush for killing those measures. The new proposal was devised by Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas and chairman of the Senate Finance Committee.
 
Estimated Tax Payments

His proposal to increase estimated tax payments by many taxpayers with incomes over $50,000 would require them to estimate, and make payments on, the income they expect to earn in a given year. Under current law, they can estimate taxes based on the previous year's income if that is more advantageous to them.
Outside the committee room, several Republicans said they favored the idea. "It's just paying your taxes on time," said Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the House Republican leader.
Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the Republican whip, said, "It seems to me that's not unfair."
Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas and the Senate minority leader, said on the floor that he liked the idea.
Mr. Darman, the budget director, told reporters "we were not opposed in principle to more rapid tax collection." But he said a few more days' time would be helpful to the Administration in seeing just who would be affected by the change, and to make sure it did not "accidentally hit a whole lot of people you don't want to hit."
The sharpest opposition came from Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the ranking Republican on the Ways and Means Committee, and President Bush's own Congressman. He said the plan was unfair to people who could not estimate their income accurately, and did not affect merely the rich, because "50 percent of the tax returns that are expected to be affected are under $200,000."
Mr. Rostenkowski said he did not know what he would do on Monday, but said he could move forward with the Bentsen plan if a few questions were answered. Reflecting the view of most party leaders on Capitol Hill, he said, "I think we ought to do something."
Mr. Darman and Lynn Martin, secretary of Labor, both chided the Democrats for seeking political advantage in quick action today. A news conference trumpeting the Democratic bill had to be canceled after Mr. Rostenkowski halted the committee meeting without action.
But Mr. Darman told reporters the Administration could offer several plans that involved modest variations on what the Democrats were proposing, and they could be worked out if the Democrats wanted.
Mr. Dole was even more insistent on the chances of an agreement. He told the Senate: "It can be done in an hour. The differences aren't that great."

HEADLINE: Your Taxes;
I.R.S. Audit Rate Continues to Drop

BYLINE: By Robert D. Hershey Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Although the Internal Revenue Service gets huge amounts of information on interest, dividends and other income from banks, brokers and others, the chance of a taxpayer's being subjected to an audit continues to shrink. The service managed to scrutinize only 80 individual returns in every 10,000 last year, down from 92 in 1989.
Despite the flood of Forms 1099 that curb opportunities to underreport, the I.R.S. frets about compliance. Increases in work load that have outstripped resources and the ever-greater complexity of the tax law -- amended more than 100 times since 1980 -- are two of the biggest problems, it says.
"The number of returns filed, particularly business and corporate returns, has increased, while staffing has hardly grown at all," the I.R.S. stated in its annual report. 
 Examinations last year produced recommendations for $22.3 billion in additional tax and penalties. But what the I.R.S. calls its rate of audit coverage, which was 2 percent for individual returns in 1980, continues its long decline. Last year's drop, to eight-tenths of 1 percent, was the fifth in a row since a 1985 uptick. Audits of corporate taxpayers, however, edged up last year.
The audit rate, affected by many factors, has considerable geographic variation. By region, audits per 10,000 individual returns were highest in the Southwest (108) and in the West, including Alaska and Hawaii (101). In the rest of the nation, the figure drops to between 59 and 79, while for international filers it is only 48.The number of delinquent accounts in the agency's active files grew almost 9 percent, to more than 3.5 million, although this jump was less than the 13 percent surge in delinquent accounts during 1989.
One element of the I.R.S. report, though, is relatively stable over the decades. Last year, the cost of collecting each $100 was 52 cents, the same as in 1965. In the interim, the cost ranged from 40 cents in 1969 to 56 cents in 1976.
Total revenue collected grew 4.2 percent last year, to $1.1 trillion, somewhat below the consumer inflation rate of 6.1 percent.
 
Deduction Denied

In a case that could affect artists and other taxpayers who donate works to charity, the United States Tax Court this week upheld the I.R.S. in denying The San Francisco Chronicle a $2.9 million deduction for giving its clippings library, reproduced on microfiche, to the California Historical Society.
The court held that the clippings, which dated back to the earthquake year of 1906, were not the kind of property that could be subject to capital gains and that therefore any deduction was related to the cost of producing them. But the production cost -- more than $10 million -- had been written off as annual business expenses, and so the cost basis was zero, the court held.
Judge Theodore Tannenwald Jr. said it might be that this type of material should qualify for capital-asset treatment when donated to charity but that such qualification would have to be determined by Congress.
 
Footnotes
 *Employees who pay for child care while they work are allowed to take a child-care credit on their tax returns or to take advantage of an employer-provided benefit -- dependent care accounts, in which up to $5,000 of compensation may be set aside annually on a pretax basis. But beginning with 1989 returns, it had to be one treatment or the other, not both. At nearly all income levels, workers are generally better off using dependent-care spending accounts rather than the child-care tax credit, A. Foster Higgins & Company, a benefits consultant, has calculated. Tax savings from the dependent-care account, now offered by about half the employers, are especially big if the taxpayer has only one child and expenses exceed the $2,400 limit for one dependent under the tax credit. The accounts may be used for day care, preschool tuition or other expenses in caring for a dependent of any age.
*By tightening the rules governing interest allocation for figuring foreign tax credits, the Tax Reform Act of 1986 made it less attractive for American companies with sizable overseas operations to issue debt. In response, many of these concerns relied more heavily on preferred stock, according to a study by Julie H. Collins and Douglas A. Shackelford, accounting professors at the University of North Carolina. Small or weak companies tended to be hurt most seriously by the law because of limited access to the market for preferred.

HEADLINE: New York Area Unemployment

 BODY:
Unemployment in New York City rose in October to 8.5 percent from 7.7 percent in September. This rate was considerably higher than the national rate of 6.8 percent reported yesterday.
The jobless rate also jumped somewhat in New York State to 7.2 percent from 6.8 percent and in New Jersey, to 6.8 percent from 6.2 percent. 
 "The October figures do not indicate any marked change in the unemployment situation as compared to recent months," said Jesse Benjamin, deputy regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the bureau's regional commissioner, noted that New York State's unemployment had risen from 5.5 percent in October 1990.

HEADLINE: Gloom Seems to Deepen For Allentown's Jobless

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALLENTOWN, Pa., Nov. 1

 BODY:
Shirley George survived the first three rounds of layoffs at the Unisys Corporation's branch office here. But not the fourth.
"I figured I'd get it sooner or later," said Mrs. George, 52 years old, who kept the company's records and archives. "Let's face it: Unisys is unloading a lot of people. It's going to catch up with you eventually." 
 National unemployment figures inched up another notch in October after rising steadily for the last few months. Cities like Allentown, which enjoyed a renaissance of investment and job growth only a few years ago, are feeling the pain of the sluggish economy. The downturn has refused to go away, and despite Government reports heralding the start of a recovery, albeit an anemic one, things seem to be getting worse here.
 
'A Big Dose of Reality'
 Many people laid off in recent weeks said they had thought they would make it through the recession with their jobs intact. "You think everybody's expendable but you," said John Phillips, who earlier this week lost his job as a district manager for the Pepsi-Cola Company, a position he thought was untouchable. "It's a big dose of reality. Feels very weird to be walking into an unemployment office for the first time."
The Allentown unemployment rate was hovering right at the national average of 6.8 percent in September. Yet people who have lost jobs since summer agreed, in a series of interviews, that the outlook for work had grown much bleaker in recent weeks, and they seemed to accept it grudgingly as an inevitable symptom of a regional, and national, illness.
"I know this winter's going to be very tough," said Joe Recker, 33, who last month lost his job as a production operator for the Stroh Brewery Company, where he worked for 12 years. "But the brewery has seen its sales drop. I don't like it, but I can't argue with them over it."
 
Recalculating Family Finances
 With children ages 8, 6 and 3 to worry about, Mr. Recker and his wife, Carolyn, have been recalculating their finances since he received his layoff notice. Mrs. Recker is considering a part-time job in a bridal shop to supplement her pay as a full-time day-care worker.
"It's a matter of being one of the survivors," said Brian Gimson, general manager of Ceramet, a machine parts maker that laid off 22 people out of its 150-member work force this year. "Everyone is forced to look at themselves a little harder, to see where they can pare down."
At the Allentown branch of the Pennsylvania Job Center, where those who have lost work can apply for Government benefits and sift through a computerized listing of new jobs, one of Mr. Gimson's former machinists, Cliff Mangan, pointed to a bulletin board with job postings. In August, when he first started looking at the board, he said, there were usually two or three sheets posted, but in recent weeks, he has not seen a single one. The board remained starkly empty today.
 
Data May Hide Some Jobless
 Allentown's director of community development, Don Bernhard, said that although the local economy had not changed much over the last year, he thought the number of people who had exhausted their 26 weeks of unemployment benefits was growing. "There's a growing sense that more people are out of work than the figures indicate," Mr. Bernhard said. "Those people are falling off the table." Statistics released on Thursday marked another drop in the area's overall employment, down 2,100 jobs, to a total of 318,100.
Last year, Allentown, a city of about 100,000 on the eastern edge of Pennsylvania, about 50 miles north of Philadelphia, was ranked at the very bottom of a list of 300 metropolitan areas compiled by Money magazine. The cities were judged on their desirability as places to live, based on criteria including crime, weather and pollution, housing and jobs.
Rankings aside, the sleepy town of stately, well-attended churches remains safe by urban American standards: only five murders were committed in the first half of the year, fewer than a single day's average in New York City.
Historically, the city's economic backbone consisted of heavy industry -- Mack Truck and Bethlehem Steel were among the largest employers -- until those operations scaled back, moved away and closed in the 1970's and 80's. The pop singer Billy Joel even titled a song "Allentown" in 1982 when plant closings lifted unemployment to almost 12 percent.
Then came a vigorous revival in the late 1980's, when light industrial and other companies were attracted by the area's stable and reliable work force. The jobless rate dipped below 4 percent in 1989. A transition to service-oriented and light industry was aided by an influx of businesses from neighboring New Jersey, where labor and housing costs are higher.
"Three, four years ago, it was on fire," said Laurin Fegley, 23, whose four years as a car salesman ended with a layoff in May. "Everything was moving; you could sell anything. But now people aren't spending what they once did. Companies aren't doing anything differently. The entire region is just moving slower."
The current recession is swamping the service sector as well. A senior executive at Merchants Bank, which since last year has laid off 200 of its 1,000 employees in 50 state branches, maintains that the layoffs resulted not from a lack of business but from the need of its parent, the First Fidelity Bancorp of Lawrenceville, N.J., to consolidate its staff by cutting payrolls.
The executive, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, described the layoffs as part of a broad push for productivity. "Everybody's hurting," he said. "This softness of the economy is lasting much longer than we expected, and it's causing problems because of its duration."
A sneeze by one of the area's major industries, for example, can still induce a cold. The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, which is based in the area and has a large steelmaking operation on the Lehigh River, this week reported an unexpectedly large $61 million loss for its third quarter, and plans for a joint venture with British Steel are expected to eliminate about 2,000 administrative and plant jobs.
"Bethlehem Steel affects everyone in the Lehigh Valley," Mr. Bernhard said. "You just can't ignore it."
Next to many of those sharing his three-hour wait to see an employment counselor at the Pennsylvania Job Center, Mr. Phillips, 32, who is single and ready to move elsewhere in search of a new job, is philosophical about his fate. "Companies have to save money, just like everyone else," he reasoned.
Jim Moyer, a 49-year-old machinist who was laid off two weeks ago after 30 years with his company, said some of his friends were accepting the inevitability of a lower salary in a new job. He himself hesitated last week before turning down a job that offered $6 an hour, compared with the $16 an hour he had been earning.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Payroll jobs failed to rise in October, and the unemployment rate edged back up to its August level of 6.8 percent, Labor De partment figures showed, reflecting an eco nomic recovery that has slowed to a near standstill. Although the report was only mod estly worse than expected despite sharp job losses in manufacturing, retail trade and construction, economists said it added to fears that the midyear rebound had given way to stagnation. [Page 1.] In Allentown, Pa., some of the faces behind the layoff notices. [49.] 
 House Democrats failed to get their bill for extended jobless benefits out of the Ways and Means Committee, even though the Bush Administration endorsed it hesitantly. But leaders predicted a program would be agreed upon early next week. [49.]
The Senate derailed an energy bill, effectively defeating the Administration's plan to open an Alaskan Arctic wildlife refuge to oil drilling to reduce dependence on foreign oil. Congressional officials predicted an energy bill would get to the floor this year. [37.]
The stage was set for a vote on comprehensive banking legislation as early as Monday, as House Democrats repelled a White House attempt to kill the package. [37.]
The Index of Leading Economic Indicators slipped 0.1 percent in September, the Commerce Department said. It was the first drop in eight months, and heightened fears of renewed recession. [49.]
Construction spending increased 1.1 percent in September, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $406.5 billion, up from $402.1 billion in August, Commerce said. It was the third straight rise. [49.]
A former White House aide who represented a leading B.C.C.I. figure committed no ethics violations, the White House said. [24.]
 
 Companies
CBS Inc. announced its largest quarterly loss ever, $169.1 million, reflecting write-offs of its costly commitments to televise Major League Baseball and the National Football League. [37.]
R. H. Macy & Company said its losses narrowed in the fourth quarter to $72.3 million from $80 million a year earlier, and that sales increased slightly for the first time in many months. [37.]
Bombardier Inc. said that it had entered negotiations with the Ontario provincial government to acquire a stake in Boeing's money-losing de Havilland aircraft unit. [39.]
 
 International
A vast deregulation of the Argentine economy was announced by President Carlos Saul Menem in an attempt to reverse decades of Government intervention and protectionism. [3.]
 
 Markets
Stocks fell in heavy volume after a late series of program trades and a weak bond market pulled prices down. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 3,056.35, down 12.75. Many investors were awaiting a hoped-for cut in the discount rate. [40.]
Shorter-term Treasury notes improved but bond prices fell as traders had a mixed reaction to the October jobs report. [40.]
The dollar plunged in heavy trading on the economic reports. Gold prices were mixed, with bullion for current delivery at $355.60 an ounce, off $2.50, on the Comex. [46.]
Soybeans rose sharply amid expectations of Soviet food aid and supply worries. Grain futures also settled mostly higher. [46.]

HEADLINE: Oakland Journal;
Blaze Hones a Sense of Community

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 1 -

 BODY:
The deadly firestorm that scorched the hillsides of Oakland has turned a middle-sized city into the sort of place where neighbors gather for potluck suppers and trade gossip outside the post office.
With more than 3,000 residences destroyed and 5,000 people left homeless, the ordinary webs that bind neighbors have been unraveled. But the families who lived on the burned ravines and ridges overlooking San Francisco Bay have found new ways -- some might say old ways -- of keeping in touch. 
 Without a permanent address or a telephone number, they communicate on bulletin boards that have sprung up overnight all over this city of 372,000 people and flock to neighborhood meetings that have taken place virtually every night since the Oct. 20 blaze.
Without a back fence to talk over, they pass the time of day at the corner store or at a new community assistance center here, a teeming warehouse where all manner of rebuilding difficulties are supposed to get solved.
The need to congregate is manifest in many ways.
On one charred block, a single home remains, and so that is where residents gathered for a potluck. At a community center, there was a spaghetti feast for hundreds of people who wore name tags with arrows pointing up or down to signify whose houses were saved or destroyed.
This week, children returned eagerly to schools that had been closed in the fire-scarred neighborhoods, and were thrilled to be reunited with friends. For some, the books and pencil cases in their desks are their only remaining possessions.
People are also reaching out with messages on ad hoc bulletin boards that have become ubiquitous here: at markets, on telephones poles in charred neighborhoods and in The Oakland Tribune, which dedicates one page each day to fire victims seeking help and donors offering it.
Victims, for the most part, are looking for scattered friends, lost pets and housing. Donors are offering anything and everything, including trucks to haul debris, massage treatment, grief counseling, strollers and pianos.
The premier bulletin board is at the Chimes Market, in the heart of the Rockridge neighborhood, and the postings there are a chronicle of kindnesses great and small.
"Many cats seen at Lake Temescal mixing with the wild ones. Could yours be there?"
"Room available in lesbian household."
"This dog is still alive," with a photo attached. "Are you looking for him?"
Similar notices also hang at the assistance center, where booths have been set up by the Federal Emergency Management Administration, the Internal Revenue Service, the State Department of Motor Vehicles, the local utility companies and an array of legal and social service agencies.
When fire victims are not at the center seeking answers to a daunting list of questions, they go up to the hills where their homes once stood and pick through the debris, which covers about two and a half square miles.
For now, the landscape is all white ash, blackened trees and sepia chimneys. But wildflower and grass seed has already been sown to prevent erosion, and within a week, if there is a bit of rain, the hills will begin sprouting orange poppies and purple lupine.
When night falls, the fire victims flock to neighborhood meetings where they share information and bombard the Mayor with questions about building permits, liability insurance, debris removal and the like.
Sometimes Mayor Elihu Harris is received warmly and other times with catcalls and expletives. He is so tired that his eyelids droop and his speech slurs. Usually, the early hostility of the audience is cooled by the meticulous presentation of Oakland's city manager, Henry Gardner, who offers his home telephone number as an expression of concern.
The majority of people at the meetings say they plan to rebuild, which seems more a function of economics than sentiment. Most homeowners are insured for full replacement costs, and they would walk away with far less money if they sold their lots and bought houses elsewhere.
When the fire victims step to the microphone with questions for officials, they identify themselves by where they lived and whether they intend to stay.
"I used to live and expect to live again at 5895 Grizzly Peak Boulevard," said Garrett Gruener, who organized a meeting on Wednesday at the Claremont Hotel, which was attended by 500 burned-out residents.
But not everyone is that certain.
"My name is Gil Chasin and I live at 30 Vincente Place," said another young man. "I mean I lived at 30 Vincente Place. I mean I live at. . . ." His voice trailed off in confusion. He stammered out several more verb tenses. Then he shook his head and fell silent.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Many burnt-out residents of Oakland, Calif., have found new ways -- some might say old ways -- of keeping in touch. A woman read messages posted on a bulletin board outside a market near the fire area; Some messages left by victims of the fire ask for aid in finding a lost cat, while others offered rooms for rent to those left homeless. (Photographs by Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSH ADOPTS PLAN TO ATTACK CRITICS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Nov. 1

 BODY:
As White House advisers fret about the sour economy and the voter discontent it has stirred, President Bush is solidly fixing the blame for both on official Washington, and especially on its Democratic majority in Congress.
The strategy, urged on Mr. Bush for weeks by some of his leading political advisers, surfaced unexpectedly Thursday night in Houston, and the President repeated his attack on Democrats in a talk here tonight. 
 The President's shift in tactics came after months of near silence on critics' charges that he is neglecting the economy and other domestic issues. It also followed a turbulent White House meeting on Thursday morning at which Mr. Bush's political advisers urged him to tackle the economic issue head on, while his budget director and chief economist urged him to take a lower-key approach.
 
Fire-Breathing Assault
 In Houston that night, Mr. Bush transformed what had been billed as a 10-minute pep talk to Republican loyalists into a 50-minute fire-breathing assault on Congress's ethical and intellectual flaws.
Before a crowd of wealthy Republicans, he repeatedly condemned Congressional Democrats as "old thinkers" and "small-bore" partisans who were blocking what he characterized as his agenda of fresh solutions for the nation's ills.
Then, with Mr. Bush and Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, sitting nearby, Vice President Dan Quayle called for two-term limits on all United States senators. Mr. Gramm is serving his second term.
Mr. Bush repeated that performance tonight in Dallas, where he spoke to another $1,000-a-head audience contributing to his still-unannounced re-election campaign.
 
'Problem Is in the Congress'
 "The problem is in the Congress of the United States and the liberal Democrats that control it," Mr. Bush said tonight to a hotel ballroom filled with Dallas Republicans. "Those old guys that control the subcommittees haven't had a new idea in 30 years."
Mr. Bush said he "had been kind and gentle" to the Congress but had ended up "a javelin-catcher" at the receiving end of Democratic attacks. "I can't wait to be a candidate when I decide to be one and take this to the American people," he said. "They're tired of it; they're sick and tired of it.
"Why do you think the American people are so fired up about term limitations? Because they've wised up; they understand it. And I'm going to fight for that, too, all next year," he said to wild applause.
The President has sharply criticized Congress before, most notably in a Washington speech last month after the seamy battle over Judge Clarence Thomas's confirmation to the Supreme Court. But his remarks this week have easily been the most bitter and most partisan in recent memory.
 
Pledge to Fight Critics
 In an interview with a Dallas television station today, the President suggested that, his patience exhausted, he was reacting to a stream of unfair attacks from Democrats seeking political gain out of the recession.
"I've been kind of a shock absorber for highly partisan criticism," he said, "and I'm not going to do that anymore. I'm going to say when a guy takes me on in a demagogic way, I'm going to hit him right back."
The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said today that Mr. Bush's attack on Thursday had not been planned, but was a spontaneous departure from the less strident speech that he had been prepared to deliver.
But both Democratic and Republican political strategists said today that they saw a larger meaning to Mr. Bush's tactics at a time when public revulsion against entrenched government is running high.
"Whichever side gets to decide who's the Establishment has a leg up" in the coming Presidential campaign, one Republican adviser said.
In that political race, this adviser said, "the Democrats started earlier, but Bush has a lot more material to work with."
 
Casting Bush as Insider
 Democrats are already hammering the economic and domestic policy themes in this fall's campaigns, casting Mr. Bush and Republicans as the Washington insiders who are responsible for a national malaise.
As challengers in 1980, Mr. Bush and Ronald Reagan rode a similar wave of discontent with incumbent Washington into the White House. But after 15 years in Washington and a decade as a symbol of Republican control of Government, Mr. Bush faces a much tougher task in casting himself as an outsider battling the capital's bureaucratic mess.
But Mr. Bush also has substantial ammunition for this battle. Public confidence in Congress as reflected in polls has dipped markedly, and a series of legislative debacles -- from influence-peddling by the savings-and-loan industry to check bouncing and the Thomas hearings -- has painted an even darker image of incompetence and corruption.
Notably absent from Mr. Bush's remarks, at least for now, is any indication that the White House plans new initiatives to deal with the economy.
Democratic strategists in Congress professed today to be undisturbed by the President's new bluntness. To the contrary, they said, Mr. Bush's change in tone suggested that his critics were hitting a soft spot in the President's political armor.
"Here's a man who is towering in the popularity polls, who's 23 to zip in the veto contest in Congress, and he sounds defensive and excited," one Democratic adviser said. "I think he's scared stiff on the economy and he's in a big fix as to what to do about it."

HEADLINE: Foreign Doctors Flocking to Rescue Long-Shunned Areas of Dire Poverty

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WELCH, W.Va.

 BODY:
Few doctors want to build a practice or make a home in a place like this. An economic sinkhole whose coal-mining jobs have been vanishing, Welch is a remote Appalachian outpost filled with the very poor and the very sick.
Heart attacks, breathing disorders, diabetes and depression are the doctor's daily diet, and the county hospital has had little luck luring doctors even from West Virginia's own medical schools. 
 So Welch imported doctors like Siva Prasad from India, Piayon Kobbah from Liberia, Godfrey Chithambo from Malawi, Dale Barnes from the Bahamas, and Cecelia Bella, Julito Sultan and Andres Rago, all from the Philippines.
 
Many Come From India
 Fifteen of the 19 doctors on the staff of the state-owned Welch Emergency Hospital, the only hospital serving a three-county population of 115,000, are immigrants. "We'd be pretty dead without them," said Stephen Shride, the hospital administrator.
So it is throughout much of rural America, where people are 10 to 15 years older, on average, than those in cities and where people have access to less than half as many doctors per capita. Graduates of foreign medical schools, more than 90 percent foreign-born, make up a fifth of the nearly 600,000 physicians practicing in the United States, according to the American Medical Association. About 25,000 come from India, the biggest source.
No one seems to have tallied the numbers working in rural areas recently. "It's higher than one would expect," said Dr. David A. Kindig, a professor of preventive medicine at the University of Wisconsin in Madison who in 1971 founded the Public Health Service's National Health Service Corps.
Dr. Kindig did a study a few years ago of foreign graduates working in communities of fewer than 10,000 people and found that their numbers doubled from 1975 to 1985, to a point where they represented 15 percent of the communities' physicians. The figure is probably closer to 20 percent now, he said. In a later survey, Dr. Kindig found that 75 percent of the physicians intended to stay in the communities.
 
Cutbacks in Program
 More and more American-born physicians shun the primary care work that the communities need most: family practice, pediatrics, internal medicine, obstetrics and gynecology. They choose instead the higher status, better pay and narrower scope of the specialities practiced in metropolitan areas, which also offer access to large communities of doctors and better equipped hospitals.
In the 1970's through the mid-1980's, the Public Health Service dispatched thousands of Americans a year for stints in underserved areas in return for Government scholarships to medical schools. Federal budget cuts all but halted the program, with fewer than 50 such doctors sent out a year in the late 1980's. The program has been revived, but on a much smaller scale.
Like American doctors, most foreign-born doctors cling to the metropolitan areas, particularly in the Northeast and in Ohio, Illinois and Florida, where they go for hospital residencies and internships. But more and more have been moving beyond the cities, in part because recent changes in the immigration laws, intended to help communities that cannot find American doctors, make working in rural areas a condition for remaining in the United States. Heavy recruiting by desperate communities and a desire to escape discrimination by urban American doctors are also factors.
Under the immigration laws, a foreign doctor in this country for medical school, an internship or a residency must return to his home country for two years when his studies are finished. But if he is offered, and accepts, a job in one of the 2,100 areas the Federal Government has designated as medically underserved, the two-year requirement can be waived and he can apply for permanent residency in the United States.
The foreigners also tend to settle down and raise families in the communities. Encountering less professional discrimination, which, they say, most often takes the form of belittling their methods and judgment, they say they have more opportunity in rural areas. Typically, they earn $80,000 to $200,000 a year -- less than they would make in bigger cities, but easily enough to provide higher standards of living than those they left at home.
Among states with largely rural populations, West Virginia has the highest concentration of immigrant doctors. One of every 1,750 people of the state is a graduate of a foreign medical school, as against one in 25,163 in Idaho, with the fewest.
 
Where Infirmities Abound
 And in West Virginia, few places illustrate the importance of foreign doctors to rural communities better than Welch, and few offer so rich a laboratory of rural people's infirmities. Dr. Prasad, 42 years old, came to Welch to start a practice in internal medicine two years ago. "Mr. Shride contacted me to see the hospital," he said. "My wife liked the place. I did not apply anywhere else."
"I see just about all the patients," Dr. Prasad said. "They come with breathing problems and chest pains. Most of them smoke. You see a lot of diabetes, hypertension and kidney failure problems. They have poor knowledge of nutrition."
Among his patients, the most common meal is biscuits soaked with a gravy made of flour, milk, lard or grease from the frying, and salt and pepper. Goodson's, the only supermarket around, runs $12.99 specials for 25-pound tubs of Valleydale lard, and it's a very popular item, as an ingredient and as a medium for frying.
"I have seen heart attacks here with people under 40," Dr. Prasad said. "It's their dietary habits and smoking."
 
Settling 30 Miles Away
 The Prasads have settled in the slightly more affluent town of Bluefield, 30 miles away, and put their sons, 13 and 14, in the local schools. Rather than take a paying job, Dr. Prasad's wife, Santhi, a cellular biologist, works on their sons' schooling.
"Two hours every night, math and science," Dr. Prasad said. "She is very devoted to that."
Dr. Barnes, 37, the chief of staff, comes across as much more American than the other doctors, no doubt because his parents, teachers in Seventh-day Adventist schools, moved from the Bahamas to Detroit when he was 7. He is a graduate of the Loma Linda University medical school in California, where he was in the top 10 percent of his class, and did a residency in internal medicine at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn.
Dr. Barnes was sent to Welch four years ago by the Public Health Service. Although not a citizen, he qualified for a Federal scholarship in medical school and in return was assigned here. He completed his obligation two years ago, and as an unmarried man in a town barren of most amenities, he said he would rather be elsewhere.
He said he has been staying on until the hospital can recruit a new chief of staff. But Mr. Shride said a sense of mission seems to hold Dr. Barnes here, too: "9 o'clock, 10 o'clock at night, his car is still here."
 
Reasons to Be Depressed
 Dr. Barnes sees all the maladies Dr. Prasad does and cites the same causes: smoking and diet. A reason the habits persist, he said, is the hopelessness of the area. "There is a lot of just plain depression," he said. "When you're on call regularly, you get two or three suicide attempts a week."
Dr. Rago, 47, who has worked in or near Welch as a family practitioner for 16 years and is also an American citizen, said his fees for examinations range from $25 to $45, but many patients pay nothing. "If they can't pay, what can you do?" he said. "They say, 'You can bill me.' You don't have any choice. You cannot say, 'I won't see you.' "
Among patients, the one recurrent complaint is the English spoken by some of the doctors, a problem the doctors try to deal with. "They'll look real hard at your face, and they can tell if you can't understand," Cathy Smyth, a payroll clerk, said. "If they see you don't understand, they'll repeat it real slow."
 
Questions of Color
 Billy Mullin, 45, permanently disabled at the age of 32 by black lung disease, the scourge of coal miners, was sitting on a bench outside the hospital one recent day, having a cigarette. He said his disability check came to $1,800 a month. "I had a heart attack in February," he said. "They took care of me like a baby. But I could hardly understand their language. The nurse, she tell me what he said."
Patients, most of whom are white, say they are not troubled by putting themselves in the hands of doctors who mostly are not white.
"When people in West Virginia see somebody different, they seem not to be threatened," Dr. Prasad said. He said some people are amused by the red dot, a bindi, that Mrs. Prasad wears on her brow in the tradition of Hindu wives.
But bigotry does crop up. Dr. Barnes, who is black, recalled the departure of a partner in a practice the two had here. "He was a light-skinned black, and he had a lot of patients who assumed he was white," Dr. Barnes said. "When he left, people asked if he could recommend another white doctor."
Still, the doctors say they are more readily accepted in Welch than in big cities. "You find discrimination in big medical centers where there are residency programs," said Dr. Bella, director of the pathology lab.
And when immigrant doctors move from one state to another, licensing boards often demand more paperwork of them than they ask of Americans, even after the immigrants have been admitted to practice in other states.
"They find they are discriminated against by state licensing boards, and sometimes they are," said Dr. Roy Schwarz, senior vice president for medical education at the American Medical Association. "The quality of these physicians is about the same that it is for U.S. graduates."
Graduates of foreign medical schools must pass a medical exam to work in the United States, and about a quarter of the 20,000 or so who apply each year a year do. Then they must apply for residency assignments in American hospitals.
The doctors here wrestle with the moral issue of serving American communities, however impoverished they are, instead of ones at home. Dr. Bella and her husband, a doctor from whom she is now separated, have moved back and forth, working in both the United States and the Philippines. She said she preferred Welch, in part because she found it a better place for raising her 9-year-old daughter.
Dr. Rago and his wife, a registered nurse, hurried back to the Philippines for two weeks to help the victims of the eruption of the Mount Pinatubo volcano in June. But after 16 years in Welch, he said, he considers himself a thoroughly rooted American.

HEADLINE: Kentucky Race for Governor Leaves Voters Yawning

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FRANKFORT, Ky., Oct. 31

 BODY:
Democrats have had an electoral stranglehold on the Kentucky governorship for the past 20 years, and 1991 does not appear to be the year Republicans will break that hold.
If the polls and pundits are correct, the Democratic candidate, Lieut. Gov. Brereton C. Jones, will sweep past his Republican opponent, Representative Larry J. Hopkins, in Tuesday's election. The incumbent, Wallace G. Wilkinson, a 49-year-old Democrat, is barred by state law from succeeding himself. 
 But Mr. Jones's expected victory, no matter how sweeping, is not likely to mask the ennui, frustration and deep-seated cynicism about politics and politicians that the poll takers have found this year in Kentucky's electorate, as well as in much of the nation's.
 
'A Really Sorry Campaign'
 Indeed, at the start of the final weekend before the election here, many voters seem more than sated by a campaign in which the candidates have generally ignored public issues in favor of attacks on one another over the handling of personal finances.
"It's been a really sorry campaign," said Kim Blackburn, a pet shop manager in Lexington. "This state has all kinds of problems, especially economic problems because of the recession, but all we've heard is a lot of personal attacks by the candidates. I don't know who I'll vote for. It's hard to get your heart into it."
Mr. Hopkins, 58 years old, has spent much of the campaign suggesting that Mr. Jones might be a tax evader because the Lieutenant Governor, one of Kentucky's leading horse breeders, has refused to make public his tax forms.
Mr. Jones, 52, has said repeatedly that he has paid all his taxes. But Mr. Hopkins continues to demand that his opponent make public his tax returns, and wonders aloud why they are being withheld if there is nothing to hide.
"Can you trust him?" he asks voters. "It's an indication of character."
 
32 Overdrafts in One Year
 Mr. Jones, for his part, has spent much of the campaign recalling that Mr. Hopkins, who has represented Kentucky's Sixth Congressional District in the state's Bluegrass country since 1978, was one of the House members recently found to have written overdrafts on the House bank, 32 checks in his case.
Mr. Hopkins says the bank never actually processed the checks; thus, they did not "bounce." But Mr. Jones is not satisfied.
"How many people do you know who have bounced 32 checks in one year that didn't go to jail?" he asks voters.
Both candidates are regarded as political moderates, and both have themselves expressed concern about the negative tone of the campaign. Like many candidates around the country, they have talked about a need to change the campaign system.
Mr. Hopkins has called for limits on the number of terms elected officials can serve. Mr. Jones has said that if he is elected he will impose a new code of ethics on executive branch officials "within 60 seconds of my taking the oath of office."
 
More Interest in Lottery
 But to many Kentucky voters, the talk of campaign reforms and government ethics has a hollow ring.
So little has been said by the candidates about such pressing issues as rising health care costs, neglected schools and economic development in Kentucky's chronically depressed mountain regions that many Kentuckians are talking less about who will win the governor's race than who will win Saturday's state lottery, worth nearly $40 million, and which thoroughbreds will run off with the $10 million in Breeders' Cup purses offered the same day at Churchill Downs.
State election officials report a sharp falloff in voter registration, and expect a low voter turnout on Tuesday.
In several debates, Mr. Jones and Mr. Hopkins have explored the major issues facing the state, though not in great depth, and have showed that they have some significant differences, though not a large number.
Mr. Hopkins has said he favors more limits on abortions, but he has not been explicit. Mr. Jones would leave the decision on whether to have an abortion to the mother, at aleast in the early months of pregnancy.
Mr. Hopkins favors right-to-work laws on the ground that they would encourage more industries to move to Kentucky. Mr. Jones is much more pro-labor, saying, for example, that he would give state employees some bargaining rights.
 
A Focus on Personality
 "Basically, this has not been an issues race," said Penny Miller, a political scientist at the University of Kentucky who has written several books about the state's politics.
"That's often true of Kentucky races," she added. "Personality tends to count more. The problem with this race is that it has gotten too personal. A lot of people are just plain turned off."
Both President Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle have visited Kentucky in an effort to give Mr. Hopkins's campaign a lift. But the latest poll, made public on Thursday by The Louisville Courier-Journal, showed Mr. Jones leading Mr. Hopkins 52 percent to 27 percent, with 22 percent undecided.
The poll takers interviewed 529 adults whom they considered likely to vote. The poll, conducted by telephone on Oct. 24-28, had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.
Mr. Hopkins tried to play down the poll results in an appearance this morning at one of his campaign offices in Lexington. "The poll that really counts, the mother of all polls, will be on Tuesday," he said.
Mr. Jones, appearing at a rally Wednesday night in Louisville, anticipated the results of the poll, telling cheering supporters that some good news was coming his way, and shouting, "We're going to give Larry Hopkins the whipping he deserves!"

HEADLINE: Mexican President Outlines Program for Changes

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 1

 BODY:
President Carlos Salinas de Gortari unveiled plans today for Mexico's continued transformation in the second half of his term, promising sweeping changes in agriculture, in education, and in the distant relations between church and state.
After three years in which he has concentrated on modernizing the economy and laying the groundwork for free trade with the United States, Mr. Salinas turned in his annual State of the Nation address to themes of social change. 
 "A great dividing line" still holds the country apart and holds it back, he said. "That line is poverty."
Mr. Salinas acknowledged "certain deficiencies" in the electoral system put in place for the congressional and gubernatorial elections on Aug. 18, which his Revolutionary Institutional Party won by a landslide. The party later surrendered two of the six state governorships it won because of opposition charges of fraud.
 
Interrupted by Jeers
 But as he called for dialogue with the opposition parties to help improve the process, the President was interrupted by the jeers of their representatives. And even before he had arrived in the Chamber of Deputies to speak, opposition leaders took the same podium to protest low wages, official human rights violations, and the Government's control of political resources and electoral appeals boards.
"It is not enough, sirs, that we be equal before the law if we are not equal in the face of authority," said a leader of the conservative National Action Party, Diego Fernandez de Cevallos.
Much of Mr. Salinas's two-hour address was a vigorous defense of Mexico's market-oriented economic policies. For the first half of this year, he noted, economic growth approached 5 percent on an annual basis. The 11.9 percent inflation in the first nine months of 1991 is the country's lowest in 16 years, he said.
Mr. Salinas did not mention the possibility of fixing the peso to the dollar, and several Government officials have said in recent days that the possibility appears increasingly remote. He brushed off Mexico's growing current account deficit as an inevitable consequence of greater private investment and the need for imports. Despite the imbalance, he noted, foreign-ex change reserves had risen as of Thursday to the highest in Mexico's history, nearly doubling in one year to $16.71 billion from $8.415 billion a year before.
 
Government Program Criticized
 Some economists have criticized the Government's busy privatization program as a transference of resources that has not significantly improved the lot of impoverished Mexicans. Real minimum wages, according to an economic consulting firm here, fell in September to their lowest level since 1980. But Mr. Salinas said today that profits from the sale of government enterprises would increasingly be channeled to social programs.
Focusing on the system of communal lands that was established over a 30-year period after the Mexican Revolution, Mr. Salinas argued that the country should shift its emphasis from the redistribution of farmlands to their productivity. While not spelling out his plans precisely, he indicated that he would allow peasant farmers to join with outside investors. Government officials said the new policy would also allow the farmers to lease their lands for the first time.
"In the past, land distribution was a path of justice," Mr. Salinas said. "Today it is unproductive and impoverishing."
In an effort to improve the notoriously poor quality of Mexican education, Mr. Salinas said he would decentralize the present system, giving new resources to the states so that they could administer the schools. A senior official said this would allow the Government to break the stranglehold on change that the giant national teachers' union has been able to maintain by bargaining as a single unit.
Taking up his inaugural pledge to address the 130-year-old split between the Mexican state and the Roman Catholic Church, Mr. Salinas called for "reconciling the definitive secularization of our society with effective freedom of religion."
While insisting on the continued separation of church and state and of secular education in public schools, he somewhat obliquely suggested a new willingness to give churches legal status, to allow them to own property, and to improve relations with the Catholic hierarchy.
The Mexican primate, Ernesto Cardenal Corripio Ahumada, later pronounced the President's comments "magnificent."

HEADLINE: Dutch Study Is Issue in Euthanasia Vote

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS

 BODY:
As the voters in Washington State consider whether doctors should be allowed to end the lives of terminally ill patients who have asked to die, people on both sides are bolstering their arguments with a new study from the Netherlands, where euthanasia is illegal but widely tolerated.
Opponents of the measure, which appears on next Tuesday's ballot, say the Dutch study shows that unless euthanasia is strictly forbidden, some doctors will kill patients without their consent. Supporters say it shows that such fears are greatly exaggerated. 
 The report, commissioned by the Dutch Government and published in early September, was summarized in the Sept. 14 issue of the British medical journal The Lancet.
Through interviews with doctors, examination of death certificates and other methods, the study showed that about 2,300 deaths a year, or 1.8 percent of all deaths in the Netherlands, were deliberately caused by doctors acting on their patients' orders.
And it found that 1,000 more people were put to death by their doctors without their consent, despite professional and judicial guidelines limiting euthanasia to people who explicitly and repeatedly ask for it.
In all the deaths cited in the study, doctors killed patients by lethal injection or gave them a lethal mixture of drugs to drink.
To Deborah Senn, a Seattle lawyer who is a leader in the movement for a yes vote in the Washington referendum, the Dutch study "really rebuts the argument" that euthanasia is "out of control in the Netherlands."
But Dr. Carlos E. Gomez, a physician and public policy analyst whose own study of euthanasia in the Netherlands, "Regulating Death" (Free Press), has just been published, says the study shows that the Dutch "have already done what was worst feared."
 
'Boundary Area' Cited
 Richard M. Doerflinger, an official in the Secretariat for Pro-Life Activities of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, said the number of patients killed without explicit requests in the Netherlands would be the equivalent of more than 17,000 people killed each year without their consent in the United States.
Mr. Doerflinger noted that the extent of euthanasia in the Netherlands would be almost doubled if 2,500 cases in what the Dutch researchers called "a boundary area" -- where painkilling drugs were administered with an intention of bringing on death as well as reducing suffering -- were counted.
According to the study, in 30 percent of the deaths where doctors accepted the risk of shortening a patient's life by administering high doses of painkilling drugs, they listed bringing on death as one objective. In an additional 6 percent of the cases, doctors said causing death was their chief objective.
Dr. Gomez said he saw no difference between giving high dosages of painkillers with a deliberate intent to kill and the study's category of euthanasia accomplished with clearly lethal drugs.
 
Little Difference Seen
 Reached by telephone in the Netherlands, Dr. Johannes J. M. van Delden, a researcher of the study who wrote the Lancet article, agreed that the difference was slight.
"It is not up to me to say whether these cases are euthanasia or not," said Dr. van Delden, who is associated with the Center of Bioethics of Utrecht University and the Health Council in The Hague. "If you want to call it euthanasia, please do.".
Dr. Richard Fenigsen, a retired Dutch physician and outspoken critic of euthanasia who is now in the United States, contended that the study should have also listed as euthanasia many of the deaths caused by high dosages of painkillers or decisions to forgo or halt life-prolonging treatments. By his definition, 19.4 percent of deaths in the Netherlands should be considered euthanasia.
But Ms. Senn said, "I think the opponents are playing with the numbers." She noted that in more than half the cases in which patients were killed without their explicit request, the patients had become mentally incompetent after earlier expressing some general wish for euthanasia if their suffering became unbearable.
Ms. Senn, who recently visited the Netherlands and talked with health officials there, said the study showed that the practice was "self-limiting."
 
Abuse by Doctors Doubted
 "Everything I hear is that doctors in Holland find this a very draining experience," she said. "It is illogical to think that doctors will abuse the practice."
The study found that Dutch doctors agreed to fewer than a third of 9,000 explicit requests every year from patients who expressed a desire to die or to be assisted in committing suicide.
Because economic pressures are often suggested as a potential cause for abuse of euthanasia, Ms. Senn said it was significant that the study showed the absence of economic considerations in decisions about euthanasia.
By contrast with the Netherlands, Ms. Senn added, the Washington State measure stipulates that no patient could be killed unless the request was written and signed before two witnesses, and that two doctors had to agree that the patient was terminally ill with less than six months to live.
But Dr. Gomez said the Dutch study illustrated the fragility of any guidelines. "I was told up and down that under no circumstances could patients be euthanized without their consent," he said.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Musings Cast Pall Over Race

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's public hand-wringing about whether to seek the Presidency has slowed but not frozen the pace of the just-formed Democratic primary field, fund-raisers and campaign aides said this week.
The candidates' travels have picked up as the six major Democratic candidates have taken their campaigns to New Hampshire, Kansas, Florida, Iowa, Georgia, Maine and Arizona in the days that the New York Governor continued to tantalize political insiders with talk of the Presidency. 
 Most of the candidates have said they are unaffected by Mr. Cuomo's musings. But other Democrats have noted that some big-money contributors are holding out on committing themselves as long as Mr. Cuomo's candidacy remains a possibility.
"You have to run your own campaign," said Robert Farmer, the former Democratic Party treasurer who is now raising money for the campaign of Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas. "You can't be looking over your shoulder to see what other people are going to do."
But he added that money has been harder to pry loose in some political circles, particularly in New York, where many prominent Democrats have ties to Governor Cuomo.
"That doesn't mean that if you have some friends they won't stand up for you," Mr. Farmer said. "But if you have mutual friends, it kind of freezes you."
 
New Pall Over Campaign
 Whether the candidates will admit it, Mr. Cuomo's return to the circle of speculation casts a new pall over a campaign that had already been slow to start.
That sluggish start has had something to do with the activity of the announced candidates themselves. Senators Tom Harkin of Iowa and Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, for example, are sidestepping joint appearances at events that would have been mandatory in the more heated campaign four years ago. In addition, Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia has just returned to the stump on a regular basis, more than a month after announcing his candidacy in Richmond.
Some Democrats appear to welcome the possibility of a Cuomo candidacy. Aides to Mr. Clinton, for example, are convinced that the presence of a liberal Northeasterner in the race will set Mr. Clinton further apart in voters' minds as a moderate Southerner.
Others hope that Mr. Cuomo's presence will lend sufficient weight to the Democratic field to force President Bush into a defensive position if the economy stays sluggish.
Paul Tsongas, the former Senator from Massachusetts, is one of those. "To beat George Bush, you have to win a nomination that has value," he said at a news conference on Thursday in Concord, N.H. "Whoever wins with Governor Cuomo in the race will have the necessary momentum against George Bush."
 
Different Conclusion
 Republican operatives see a similar advantage, but have reached a different conclusion. Where anxious Democrats see stature in a Cuomo candidacy, Mary Matalin, the chief of staff for the Republican National Committee, said the White House saw a "flawed record" that they could exploit. Mr. Cuomo, the Republicans say, is a clearer target than other Democrats.
Mr. Cuomo's indecision has clearly sent more tremors through the Democratic field than the ruminations of that other famous undecided Democrat, the Rev. Jesse Jackson. Mr. Jackson -- who has run twice and is expected to announce his plans for 1992 at a news conference on Saturday -- had already been counted out of the race, even by many of his own supporters, well before Governor Cuomo expressed his renewed interest.
And Mr. Jackson's decision, some veteran fund-raisers noted, would have more of a political than financial effect on the race. Since Mr. Jackson never traveled the traditional fund-raising route in his two national campaigns, few money-raisers have felt compelled to remain neutral until he makes a final decision.
The story is different for Mr. Cuomo, who is widely considered able to raise large sums of money with relatively little effort.
 
'Sense of a Diminished Field'
 If Mr. Cuomo ultimately decides not to run, he may have caused more damage than he intended. Strategists in both parties speculated that by raising expectations that he would enter the race, Mr. Cuomo instantly reduced the standing of the declared candidates.
"He has added to the sense of a diminished field," said Rich Bond, a Republican who worked in President Bush's 1988 campaign and is still close to the White House.
But on the campaign trail Democratic candidates will admit to no such thing. To concede that Mr. Cuomo is a significant threat to their nascent campaigns would be catering to the notion that the Democratic Party's chances without him would suffer.
And for now, they see no reason to go on the attack.
Edmund G. Brown Jr., the former California Governor who announced his candidacy two weeks ago, said he would welcome Mr. Cuomo. "Sure, let him come in," he said on the Cable News Network call-in program "Larry King Live." "Why not?"
Democratic strategists remain unsure of whether the perceptibly slowed campaign can be attributed to Mr. Cuomo, a slowed economy that has hobbled fund raising or disenchantment with the declared Democratic field.
"I think money is going to be slow this year for 100 reasons," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic strategist who is not aligned with any of the Democratic candidates. "And if some contributors whose pockets aren't that deep can blame it on Cuomo, I wouldn't be surprised if they did."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Harnisch Presses His Face Up Against the Window

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Pete Harnisch of the Houston Astros was one of the most consistently effective pitchers in the National League this year, and he might be one of the most pained this winter. Because of the timing of the demotion of the Phillies' Rod Booker to the minor leagues last July, Harnisch will not be eligible for salary arbitration.
Booker's effect on Harnisch is a result of the 17 percent solution to the 1990 spring training lockout. 
 The key to the settlement was the compromise that granted salary-arbitration eligibility to the senior 17 percent of the players who have been in the major leagues between two and three years and had at least 86 days of service in the most recent season. Prior to the settlement, three years of major league service were necessary for arbitration.
The economic advantage of being eligible for arbitration is obvious from last year's results. The initial 17 percent group -- 14 players -- nearly tripled their collective salaries, receiving a 196 percent raise. The year before, players who had between two and three years in the majors saw their salaries jump only 20 percent.
Harnisch, whose 2.70 earned run average was the fifth best in the National League, made $275,000 in 1991. He missed out on the 17 percent group by one day because of Booker, a reserve infielder for Philadelphia .
The Phillies designated Booker for assignment on July 18. They sent him outright to their Scranton minor league team five days later. If they had waited one additional day, Booker would have emerged from the season with exactly three years of major league service, making him eligible for arbitration without being part of the 17 percent group.
Had Booker gained that day, Harnisch would have been the 15th and last player in the 17 percent group. Harnisch has 2 years and 135 days of service. Joe Girardi of the Chicago Cubs and Kirt Manwaring of San Francisco were the last players to make the group, each with 2 years and 140 days.
The others who qualified are Chico Walker and Dwight Smith of the Cubs, Greg Litton of the Giants, John Habyan of the Yankees, Bill Spiers of Milwaukee, David West of Minnesota, John Marzano of Boston, Greg Myers of Toronto, Junior Felix of California, Gary Thurman of Kansas City, Ken Hill of St. Louis and John Costello of San Diego.
In another development, the Cardinals picked up the option in Ozzie Smith's contract, meaning they will pay him $2 million next season.
The Twins gave Junior Ortiz a $50,000 buyout instead of a $520,000 salary in 1992. Toronto offered Candy Maldonado salary arbitration, meaning he cannot become a free agent.
Ten players filed for free agency, bringing the total to 67. Yesterday's filings included Orel Hershiser and Jay Howell of Los Angeles, Alejandro Pena of Atlanta, Glenn Davis of Baltimore and Tom Candiotti of Toronto.

HEADLINE: Auto Safety vs. Fuel Economy: Questions of Size and Design

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER

 BODY:
Big cars are usually safer in crashes than small cars, highway statistics indicate. But tests also suggest that the safety of any car, large or small, is a very relative affair. That may be the real issue in the current debate over car size and safety.
This week, some advocates of safer cars accused Federal Department of Transportation officials of unfairly manipulating a crash test that was subsequently seen in a television commercial. 
 The commerical, in which a large car smashes head-on into a small one and crushes it, was paid for by the Coalition for Vehicle Choice, an auto industry group. Car makers oppose a Senate bill that would raise average fuel economy standards from 27.5 miles per gallon today to 40 miles a gallon in 2001, contending that the move would result in smaller and more dangerous cars.
Some advocates of the fuel economy measure, which was introduced by Senator Richard A. Bryan, Democrat of Nevada, accused Federal highway officials this week of suppressing, among other things, data that showed that the smaller car's driver would have survived the crash. Government officials deny they rigged the test or suppressed data.
 
Fundamental Questions
 "This is all a red herring and a game they are playing," said Jerry Ralph Curry, the administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.
But histrionics aside, the debate does raise some fundamental questions. For example, just how important is a car's size to occupant safety? Are other factors like design and safety equipment just as vital? Can fuel economy be increased without causing more highway deaths?
It's a pretty elementary proposition that when you crash a 4,200-pound car into one weighing 2,400 pounds, as Mr. Curry ordered, that the bigger car is going to come out the winner. And predictably, that is just what happens on the highway: insurance industry records give large cars a higher safety rating.
The reasons are simple. A large car has more metal to crush, absorbing energy in a crash, and more interior space, shielding occupants, said Charles Hurley, a spokesman of the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety in Arlington, Va.
"The pattern is unmistakable," Mr. Hurley said. "Large cars offer more protection." But these days, large vehicles, with wheelbases of 110 inches or more, account for only 14 percent of all cars on the road. And Federal statistics show that as the large cars become smaller and small cars larger, the importance of size decreases sharply as a safety factor.
In 1990, for example, occupants were killed at the same rate -- 2.1 deaths per 10,000 vehicles -- in compact cars, with wheelbases of 95 to 99 inches, and in smaller midsize cars, with wheelbases of 100 to 104 inches.
Perhaps more important, accident reports collected by the insurance institute show a wide variance in the safety of different models within the midsize class and large midsize class, with wheelbases of 105 to 109 inches. In 1988 through 1990, for example, the Buick Century and Toyota Camry had the lowest rate of occupant injury claims relative to all other vehicles. But two other cars of similar size -- the Hyundai Sonata and Nissan Stanza -- were among those with the highest injury claims.
As a group, midsize cars were safer than smaller cars when insurance claims are used as a guide. But some small two-door sedans outperformed some larger two-doors. For example, during the 1988 through 1990 period, the Ford Probe and the Plymouth Colt and Dodge Colt had higher safety ratings than larger two-doors like the Chevrolet Beretta, Chevrolet Cavalier and Pontiac Sunbird.
William Gardner, the head of crashworthiness engineering for Transport Canada, a Government agency, said that among vehicles of similar size, a car's design is the critical factor.
"It could depend on how well a seat belt fits an occupant," Mr. Gardner said. Other important factors include the energy-absorbing characterictics of a vehicle's front end.
 
Seat Belts and Air Bags
 A part of the confusion surrounding the current debate is the changing nature of car safety. In the past few years, the overall rate of highway deaths has fallen, during a time when the presence of smaller cars has grown. A major reason for this improvement is the increased use of seat belts. And as more cars are equipped with air bags, highway safety is likely to improve even more.
The General Accounting Office issued a recent report that found that the trend toward smaller cars has had virtually no effect on highway safety. Even Mr. Curry, the Federal official, said that he was at a loss to predict what safety improvements would mean for highway safety.
"I couldn't in any way tell you what will be the final result on America's highways based on these changes to cars," he said.
Cars can get better gas mileage in two ways: through technological improvements or reductions in size. But just how far those changes can go without sacrificing safety remains the issue. And that is what is being overlooked as the debate over the Bryan bill grows more bitter.
"There is very little middle ground here right now," said Mr. Hurley of the insurance institute, which opposes the Bryan bill on safety grounds.
