HEADLINE: With Allowances, Every Parent Differs

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
Rina Pianko of Manhattan, a homemaker with three sons, believes that children should get an allowance because it teaches them what money is and how to manage it.
"But the allowance should be flexible from year to year as a child's needs change," she said. "This is really teaching them about themselves." 
 Ms. Pianko's views are similar to those of many parents, who give allowances for two basic reasons: to provide children with money for some of the things they want, and to help them learn about spending and budgeting.
Of course, not all families give regular allowances, preferring to give spending money to their children periodically, or not at all. But for many Americans, allowances are a part of family life.
A recent survey by Teen-Age Research Unlimited, a research company in Northbrook, Ill., showed that 33 percent of youngsters between age 12 and 19 receive a regular allowance. The younger the teen-ager, the greater the likelihood that he or she gets an allowance.
The Rand Youth Poll, a market research company in New York that does an annual survey of teen-agers, reported that boys aged 13 to 15 received an average allowance of $15.25 a week last year, while girls of the same age received $16.90. Boys age 16 to 19 averaged $27.20 and girls age 16 to 19 averaged $28.80.
 
Watch Your Symbolism
 The way an allowance is given may be as important as the dollars changing hands. As Kenneth O. Doyle, a professor of psychology at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis, put it: "I think people have to look at money less for its market value and more for its symbolic value. If a parent gives grudgingly, that's conveying something to the kid."
Specialists in the field of children's finances say parents should decide whether the child must perform certain chores in order to get an allowance, whether the allowance will be given in advance in special situations and whether the child should be required to save part of the allowance.
"An allowance is a way to help a child become financially responsible," said Steven L. Sanders, who conducts financial education programs in schools for Citibank Mastercard and Visa. "And it can be done without beating someone over the head."
Some experts think that to give a child autonomy, an allowance should have no strings attached. Neale S. Godfrey, chairwoman of the Children's Financial Network, a New York company formed to teach children about money, sees value in linking an allowance to jobs around the house.
"It's essential for children to be able to see that you work for pay," she said. "And if children want to earn extra money by doing optional chores, like cleaning the TV screen or the windowsills, you should make that available to them."
On the other hand, Marsha Ann Miller, a trustee of the Fund for Economic Education, established by the American Bankers Association, said an allowance ought to be separated from chores, which children should be assigned to do regularly.
"I'm not going to withhold the money because you didn't make your bed, since the expectation is that you are going to make your bed," she said. "I don't see money as either a reward or a punishment, but rather a way to instill in a child a positive view of what money will do."
There is also a strong difference of opinion among the experts about giving advances to children who run short of money before the next allowance day. Some adamantly oppose letting a child borrow on the next week's allowance, while some say advances are permissible under certain conditions.
In the first camp is Harold Moe, an author of "Teach Your Child the Value of Money" (Harsand Financial Press, 1990).
"No advances," he said. "An allowance is the heart of teaching children about money and by its very nature is planned by parents to help children make decisions."
But Mr. Sanders of Citibank disagrees. An advance should be given, he said, as long as it is used as a learning experience.
"If a kid borrows a dollar, the kid should take on a small interest rate and give back $1.10 or $1.20," he said. "The concept is that money is not free when it is borrowed."
Many of those who study allowances say that a portion of the money should be saved for long-term goals. Dr. James U. McNeal, a professor of marketing at Texas A & M University, said that setting limits on how an allowance can be spent "not only teaches about money and money management, but also about marketplace behavior; children should be told to save a part of their allowance for high-ticket items."
Ms. Godfrey, who is also the author of "The Kids' Money Book" (Checkerboard Press, 1991), goes even further, asserting that once a child is 7 or 8, he or she ought to save part of the allowance, give some of it to charity and divert some of it to what she called taxes.
"You have to teach kids at a very young age the concept of taxes," she said. "The kids should pay taxes to the family and help the family save for something."
A key issue with allowances, of course, is the amount, but there is no consensus because of the wide variations among families and family income. The amount should depend not only on the child's age, the family's income and its philosophy concerning allowances, but also on the affluence of the community where the family lives. What's more, the amount can change if the rules change.
For example, Linda Barbanel, a New York psychotherapist, recommends that parents start giving an allowance of $1 or $1.50 a week when a child is 6 years old and raise it by a couple of dollars at every birthday.
"The needs are greater as the child gets older, so give a little extra as discretionary money," she said. "The allowance is the first step toward financial management."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Neale S. Godfrey, author of book on children's finances, suggests encouraging saving. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Soviet Upheaval Has Little Impact On Spending Bill for U.S. Military

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
House and Senate negotiators today approved a $291 billion military budget bill for the 1992 fiscal year, making few changes in the Pentagon's spending plans outlined a year ago before the collapse of Communism in the Soviet Union and the diminished Soviet military threat.
The compromise bill for the year that began Oct. 1 represents a 2 percent decline after inflation from last year's military budget and follows the path that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney announced last year to cut Pentagon spending by about 20 percent over five years. 
 The spending plan now advances to the full House and Senate, which are expected to approve it next week and pass it along to President Bush for his approval. Mr. Bush is expected to sign the measure.
 
Influence of Soviet Upheaval
 The dramatic upheaval in the Soviet Union had some influence on the compromise agreement that lawmakers hammered out in private meetings over the past two months. It prompted negotiators to adopt a plan to transfer up to $1 billion from the Pentagon's budget to humanitarian aid and economic assistance for the Soviet Union to help avert chaos there.
And it helped deal a crippling blow to the Stealth bomber, the radar-evading aircraft originally designed to defeat Soviet air defenses and bomb nuclear missile silos. Each plane costs $865 million -- another big drawback.
But lawmakers say the abortive Soviet coup along with Mr. Bush's plan to eliminate thousands of battlefield nuclear weapons and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's decision to reciprocate caught Congress near the end of a budget year, unwilling or unable to reopen last year's budget agreement to make deeper cuts in military spending.
The rallying cry of lawmakers now is, "Wait until next year!" Democrats and Republicans predict that the lessening Soviet threat, pressing domestic spending priorities and the political imperatives of a Presidential election year will force Congress and the Administration to renegotiate last year's budget agreement to permit the shifting of Pentagon funds to domestic needs. The agreement stipulated that through the 1993 fiscal year, money could not be shifted from military ledgers to other spending programs.
In the first stage of this reassessment, the House Armed Services Committee will soon begin hearings to gauge the impact of the disintegration of the Soviet Union and how that alters American military requirements.
 
Lingering Parochial Interests
 Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who is chairman of the Armed Services Committee, said today's action "continues an orderly, prudent build-down responding to a reduced threat in the world."
Representative Les Aspin, the Wisconsin Democrat who is chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said that the compromise ushered in a "basic realignment in the way we think about defenses."
While the brokered agreement does demonstrate Congress's desire to adapt to changing threats, it also reflects lingering parochial interests and an institutional inertia to shift military strategies overnight.
Lawmakers endorsed ground-based defenses against accidental or limited ballistic missile strikes from hostile third-world countries. But they also agreed to buy four more F-117 warplanes the Air Force says it does not need, and lawmakers refused to cut reserve troops in their home districts as deeply as the Pentagon wanted.
"There's enough in this bill to keep everyone happy, but there's not yet strong evidence we've entered the new world," said Gordon Adams, director of the Defense Budget Project, a nonpartisan research organization here.
A spokesman for the Pentagon, Pete Williams, said that Mr. Cheney was reserving comment on the compromise pending a review over the weekend.
 
Abortion Provision Dropped
 Lawmakers dropped a provision that would allow abortions in United States military hospitals overseas after President Bush threatened to veto the entire military spending bill if it contained the measure.
The conference committee's report offers a detailed guide for military programs for coming fiscal year. Money will have to be appropriated for the programs in a separate bill. House and Senate negotiators are scheduled to begin the appropriations conference on Nov. 12.
Legislators lifted a 43-year-old ban on women flying combat aircraft. Navy officials said that female aviators could be flying carrier-based combat planes by next summer. Female pilots now fly several combat aircraft, including Navy A-6's and A-7's, but only in training roles.
The Soviet aid proposal, which would allow Air Force planes to transport food and medicine to the Soviet people this winter and offer economic incentives to private American companies to invest in Soviet businesses, touched off the only real disagreement in the conference's waning hours.
The plan's two main architects, Mr. Nunn and Mr. Aspin, argued that American security interests are served by preventing further economic turmoil in a nation with more than 30,000 nuclear weapons.
Some Republican senators expressed outrage today that the United States would send Pentagon savings to the Soviet Union when budget deficits and other domestic problems at home begged for more attention.
"If the Soviet Union needs money to clean up their environment and reform their military, let them stop producing the missiles and submarines that directly threaten us," said Senator Robert C. Smith, Republican of New Hampshire.
Mr. Cheney sent a letter today to Senator John W. Warner of Virginia, the senior Republican on the Armed Services Committee, saying the Administration "would not oppose" the plan.
 
Fortunes of B-2 Damaged
 The changing Soviet threat clearly damaged the B-2's fortunes. The compromise effectively blocks the purchase of any new planes beyond the 15 Congress has already ordered and authorized the spending of $1.8 billion for new parts for aircraft that may never be built.
Negotiators set aside $1 billion for a single new B-2 this year, but the aircraft, built by the Northrop Corporation, would have to satisfy several technical milestones and then pass a second vote in Congress before the money would be released.
The Administration had much better luck with its other top military priority, the scaled-back version of the "Star Wars" missile defense system that President Ronald Reagan initially proposed in 1983.
The compromise calls for $4.15 billion to establish a single ground-based ballistic missile site near Grand Forks, N.D., by 1996 or whenever the technology is capable. The Senate had wanted $4.6 billion, $600 million lower than the Administration's request, but much higher than the House's $3.5 billion version.

HEADLINE: Martinelli in Yonkers, Halpin in Suffolk

 BODY:
Tuesday's elections offer two hotly contested suburban races.
For the first time in 50 years, residents of Yonkers, N.Y., having replaced the city manager form of government, will select a mayor with stronger powers. That's a chance to end years of political turmoil. 
 Since 1984, a state Emergency Financial Control Board has monitored the city's finances. The fiscal problems were compounded in 1988 when a majority of the seven-member City Council resisted a court order to build 1,000 units of moderate- and low-income housing to overcome racial segregation.
Construction of 200 units is finally under way. And Federal District Judge Leonard Sand will consider allowing Yonkers to build fewer than the remaining 800 units. Yonkers needs a mayor who can move various factions toward compromise.
The Republican-Conservative, Peter Chema, is a businessman who has served as Council majority leader and opposed the housing order. His efforts to appear more moderate ring hollow. The Democrat, Terence Zaleski, a lawyer and a former teacher, has been a conscientious State Assemblyman for four years but lacks political maturity.
We support Angelo Martinelli, a businessman running as an Independent after losing to Mr. Chema in the Republican primary. Mr. Martinelli, who served as Mayor of Yonkers for 12 years, lost office in 1987 when he urged compliance with Judge Sand's order. He has the stature and skills to pull people together.
In the contest for Suffolk County Executive, we recommend the incumbent, Patrick Halpin, over his opponent, Robert Gaffney. Mr. Halpin, a Democrat, has weakened his candidacy with offensive campaign tactics. But in a county saddled with an irresponsible legislature and a recession, he has provided level-headed leadership.
He is therefore preferable to Mr. Gaffney, the Republican and Right to Life candidate. Mr. Gaffney is an amiable but undistinguished State Assemblyman who offers few realistic ideas for coping with eastern Long Island's distressed economy.

HEADLINE: Coming Back;
The Business of Business

 BODY:
Political leadership alone can't do it. Managerial discipline alone can't do it. For New York City to work its way back from the present economic slump, it needs the help of business leaders, as leaders and as individuals.
The 1970's fiscal crisis was impossible for business leaders to ignore; the city faced bankruptcy. When Gov. Hugh Carey asked for help, he got it. The 1991 crisis is less acute yet no less a crisis. It presents itself in the form of troubled schools, crime and drugs, snarling panhandlers, pitiable homelessness, slipping services and, worst, in glib pessimism. 
 In fact, more business people are probably giving more public-spirited service than ever. And many businesses consider public participation to be a routine responsibility. But these are not routine times. They call for a greater commitment by more businesses and a greater willingness by the Dinkins administration to accept help and advice.
Much of today's civic involvement by businesses began in the last crisis. David Rockefeller, then chairman of Chase Manhattan Bank, led in creating the New York City Partnership of 175 chief executives. A recent Partnership proposal, to consolidate economic development agencies, has been adopted; others are pending. The Partnership also urges predictability, arguing that business cannot flourish unless taxes are stabilized.
The Partnership helped create another private sector group last year -- the Mayor's Management Advisory Task Force -- that has already produced valuable proposals for managing Medicaid costs and East River bridge tolls, and has helped fill city management positions.
Individual corporations already provide much direct financial and volunteer aid. Schools Chancellor Joseph Fernandez invites business ties, not just dollar contributions. Some 60 companies provide mentors, tutors and equipment. Booz, Allen & Hamilton analyzed the Board of Education's operations, pro bono, and made proposals for saving $20 million a year. Volunteers from Coopers & Lybrand help out at three Bronx high schools; the accounting firm rates employees on community service.
Another boost comes from self-taxing Business Improvement Districts to clean up commercial neighborhoods, like the Grand Central Partnership and the one in Times Square. But smaller nonprofit neighborhood service agencies need support.
Alas, the pool of corporate talent has shrunk since the 1970's. Some giants like General Electric and Union Carbide have left for suburban headquarters, the daily lives of their executives and employees no longer ruffled by the city's distress. Out of sight, out of mind.
Those who remain could be doing much more. Public service could be built into the career ladder. Executives facing early retirement might be encouraged to donate time to the city. It would certainly help if one or more towering business figures rallied others to such involvement.
At the same time, the bridge between the public and private sectors runs two ways. The Dinkins administration has frustrated more than a few businessmen who feel they are talking to deaf ears. Business partners can help only if there is mutual willingness to hear, and act.

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
The Right Questions

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

 BODY:
From the public address system of the number 1 train came the voice of civility. "Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen," said the voice, "and welcome to the Broadway local. I don't know whether you're interested in this sort of thing or not, but the number 2 and 3 trains may be boarded just across the platform. In fact, downtown transfers are on the house. Our final destination is South Ferry. This involves closing the doors." The woman to my left snapped out of her commuter fugue state and laughed.
A soothing voice of civility on the subway -- it was wonderful. And weird. Just a few stops south, four men were on trial, charged with another sort of subway story, the one that included the brutal murder of a tourist from Utah a year ago. The voice of civility continued to come over the P.A., faintly British, so at odds with the usual sullen crackle of the speakers. But it was difficult not to think of blood on the station floor. This is what it is like to be a New Yorker, to have to stop and constantly acknowledge pain. 
 Sometime in the coming week Mario Cuomo may decide whether he is running for President or not. The entire business of Presidential politics, so fitful and ill favored this time around, has ground to a screeching halt, waiting for Mario. If he Godots, if he never arrives on the stump, he will become somehow irrelevant in that way politicians become irrelevant when their time for the Presidency has passed, irrelevant in the way George McGovern and Teddy Kennedy are irrelevant.
This would be a waste. Mr. Cuomo has many liabilities, among them the fact that he is a son of the city that much of America thinks of as Depravity 'R' Us. This could be one of his great advantages. Pain 'R' Us, too. Mario Cuomo, the orator, the grocer's son, would be good at acknowledging pain, at asking feelingly, "Are you better off than you were four years ago?"
The voice on the national public address system says the economy is improving, but almost 1 in 10 Americans are relying on food stamps, a record number. When the President refused, between boating and golf at Kennebunkport in August, to declare the budget emergency that would have extended unemployment benefits, it seemed clear that he doesn't have a clue about what it's like living in America, the America without the rambling family vacation home. His fellow Americans were taking vacations in the above-ground pool bought with the '86 bonus, seeing chlorine as a luxury item. One sad story of depleted savings and downsized hopes after another -- that's what's happening outside the inner circle of the silver spoons.
There's a lot of talk going round about how Mr. Cuomo will face difficulties if he runs. He will have to answer for the budget deficits and cuts here in New York State, for his stands on capital punishment and abortion. He will say that the economy is in a mess, instead of trying to pretend that things are improving. He will not run from his unpopular positions, unlike George Bush, who tailored his stand on abortion to suit the prevailing winds.
The Governor will evoke, not deny, the fact that we have become a people who anticipate downward mobility for our children. That fear is a turning point in the American psyche. Some Republicans are gleeful about the ascendancy of Mr. Cuomo, the urban ethnic with the vocabulary of a theologian and the face of a mournful hound. The glee is premature. No one could better suggest that the two highest elected officials in this country are men who believe privilege is a christening gift.
Mr. Cuomo may be vulnerable to attack on everything from his ethnicity (now we may see how the Republicans really feel about our tired, our poor, our Italian-Americans) to New York's economy.
But let's not look at his vulnerability in a vacuum; let's not pretend he would be challenging Abe Lincoln. Clarence Thomas. Family leave. John Sununu. Unemployment benefits. Willie Horton. The gulf war. Iran-contra. Above all, the economy. The soothing voice is seductive, especially when things are as bad as they are today. But in George Bush's case, it is the voice of a man who knows no more about hard times than he does about hard questions. This election should encompass both. The President has plenty to answer for if only the right person asks. The right person is Mario Cuomo.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Taxpayers Raising Banner of Revolt

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It was refreshing to hear about groups like the New York City Chamber of Commerce calling for a four-year freeze on all taxes on businesses and property owners in the city (news article, Oct. 8). In Connecticut, the cry against a new state income tax is reminiscent of the Boston Tea Party two centuries ago. 
 The message sounded in New York City and Connecticut is not unique. Taxpayers all across the country, and especially elsewhere in New York State, are disgruntled.
Last year, the New York Farm Bureau pushed for state fiscal reform. Our farmer members believe that whether you are a farm family in rural New York or you are a someone in business in New York City, your overall tax burden is exorbitant, and reform is long overdue.
We also pushed for serious mandate relief and fair but equitable spending reform. In addition, we are working on the national front to reform a fiscal beast that is even more out of control.
Common sense needs to be brought back into governmental fiscal matters, at the local, state and national levels. The shift in taxpayer attention toward spending restraint and to saying no to more taxes should be a clear signal to government leaders that the old spend and tax days have reached their twilight. MARK F. EMERY
Director of Public Relations
New York Farm Bureau
Glenmont, N.Y., Oct. 11, 1991

HEADLINE: Land Swap on Ballot Helps Adirondacks Area

 BODY:
To the Editor:
On Nov. 5, New Yorkers will be asked to vote on an amendment to the State Constitution critical to safety at a small airport in the Adirondack region. The Piseco Airport, in Arietta in Hamilton County, is the only airport serving the southern Adirondacks, its permanent residents and more than 55,000 seasonal visitors. 
 Unfortunately, trees on state land near the runway are growing into the flight path, forcing aircraft to dodge and dangerously shortening the runway's usable length.
The amendment, Proposition 2, would authorize the state to convey 50 acres of forest land to the Town of Arietta in exchange for at least 53 acres of wild forest land of equal or greater value. If this exchange is approved by the voters, it would still require further approval of both the State Legislature and the Governor to insure that it is fair and equitable.
The Piseco Airport plays an important role in search and rescue missions, firefighting, acid-rain monitoring and providing emergency medical transportation that is vital to this remote and rural area, whose nearest resident doctor is 60 miles away. It is also vital to the region's economy, almost wholly based on tourism.
Proposition 2 is an important matter of safety and economic vitality to the residents of the southern Adirondacks.
 
ANTHONY J. CASALE
Member of Assembly, 113th Dist.
Albany, Oct. 31, 1991

HEADLINE: THE MIDDLE EAST TALKS;
Excerpts From Baker-Pankin Remarks: 'They Have to Turn a Page of War'

BYLINE: Reuter

DATELINE: MADIRD, Nov. 1 --

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a news conference today by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Foreign Minister Boris D. Pankin of the Soviet Union about the Arab-Israeli peace talks. Mr. Pankin's comments were translated by his interpreter.
 
PANKIN'S STATEMENT
 It is a pleasure to be able to come here to share my views and impressions of the conclusion of the plenary session at the . . . Palace. The whole world has been following closely the developments in Madrid, which is quite understandable because Middle East means a lot from the point of view of human culture and, in terms of today's realities, also from the point of view of economics. 
 Over the last few decades we have heard -- we didn't hear much upbeat reporting from the Middle East. Rather, it was reporting on hostages and other bad things. But still today, despite all odds, I think that we can feel optimistic, because the convocation of this conference is good news, as it is good news that for the first time throughout the Middle East conflict, the main parties to that conflict have gathered in the same room. And it's good news that the main topic of discussion was peace, although the participating states have different views of how this movement toward peace is to be accomplished.
 They have various views as to the priorities, but still all of them, overall, have come to share the conclusion that they have to turn a page of war, and the Soviet Union and the United States, as co-chairmen, see their task in having this page of war turned as soon as possible. That was the logic that motivated our joint action during preparations for the conference and at the conference itself. And we decided to follow the same logic, following the conclusion of the plenary session that has just been completed.
 The task of the next phase is to develop, negotiate process in bilateral and multilateral groups. I thank you.

 
BAKER'S STATEMENT
 Let me make a quick statement . . . before we respond to your questions. Let me repeat what I said in my just-concluded speech to the conference that this conference, I think, represents a start, an important start, particularly because no peace is possible if the parties are unwilling to meet face to face.
 For the most part, I think what we've seen here in Madrid is what you might have expected in a public forum in advance of negotiations. We saw, I believe, some posturing. I know we saw the staking out of some maximalist positions. This is something that I have been saying for some time I thought you should expect.
But I also think we saw some of the emotions that are felt so keenly by all sides to this conflict. The bottom line is that now the real work of peace must begin. The direct bilateral negotiations, I have said before, I think are the forum for that work, and I think it's, as I said in my remarks to the conference, now up to the parties to begin that effort. . . .

 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 Q. Mr. Secretary, you've also been saying in the days preceding the conference, and I think the President as well, that there might very well be interruptions. Well, we've just had an interruption of about two hours. Could you share with us please some sense of what you were doing in that period, who you were meeting with, who the -- the notion I suppose is either the Israelis, the Syrians or both are reluctant to moving ahead and causing you some logistical problems. Could you enlighten us a little?
 A. The problem, to the extent that there is one, Barry, relates to what again I said in my remarks, and that is the inability of the parties to agree on the venue or location for the bilateral negotiations. And I was working with the parties during that recess in one final effort to see if we could bring them together and see agreement reached. And I was working as well jointly with the minister here with a host of different people.
 It is the view of the co-sponsors, as we both expressed in the conference, that the bilateral negotiations should begin here in Madrid as soon as possible. That is our position. We are ready and we hope everybody else will be.
 
Site of Talks
 Q. Some of us understood that there really had been no dispute, certainly no complaint from Israel, about beginning here. We're interested in knowing where the actual face -- past the throat-clearing stage, where the true negotiations will take place. Is there an agreement to have real negotiations in Madrid or is that still open?
 A. I've told you what the position of the co-sponsors is. I think that there are some who are prepared to begin in Madrid rather quickly. I am going to continue to refuse to try and negotiate these things out in a public way.
 We are continuing, as I said in my remarks, to consult with the parties as we move forward here over the course of the next couple of days.
 
Aid for Progress
 Q. What are your ideas on linking development aid to progress achieved at the negotiating table? And what other options do you have to keep the process going? . . .
 A. . . . Linking development aid to progress in negotiations -- that is not something that we have taken a position on. We are in favor of seeing bilateral negotiations on the issue of peace, and multilateral negotiations on regional issues such as economic development and that sort of thing, arms control, economic development. We're not suggesting any formal linkage between those two processes.
 
2d Phase Dispute
 Q. (through a translator) . . . Mr. Shamir repeated his invitation to the Arab delegation to hold the second phase in the Near East. And then is Israel the main foe of having the second phase take place in Madrid, sir?
 A. Let me say that I'm not going to play the game out here, and I don't think my colleague is, of trying to negotiate this matter in public. It will serve no useful purpose for me to stand up here and say this is the position of X, that is the position of Y. What we are saying, we're telling you what our position is, which is that we think these bilateral discussions should begin here in Madrid as soon as possible. PANKIN: I agree with you.
 
Shamir's Departure
 Q. Secretary Baker, could you tell us please if the early departure of Prime Minister Shamir exacerbated the problem in determining where the bilaterals would be held? And can you tell us also when you knew that he would have to be leaving early on Friday?
 A. In no way did it exacerbate the problem. And we have known since before we left for Madrid that the Prime Minister wanted to return in time -- wanted to leave in time to get back to Israel for the Sabbath. We put out a statement here -- if I'm not mistaken, over the course of the past 48 hours -- that explained that, and this, that is why that we started as early as we did this morning at 8 o'clock.
 
Mideast Arms Deals
 Q. (through a translator) Can you tell us whether you consider the possibility of introducing . . . [inaudible] moratorium on arms supply to the region?
 PANKIN: Indeed, this was one of the items of the eventual agenda of multilateral negotiations, and we will have to agree on the start of these negotiations and the process of contacts between the delegations once we completed this stage in the conference.
 
U.N. Resolutions
 Q. Mr. Baker, the press has been very, very polite with regard to you, and they always say that you never start anything without finishing it. I've seen you in Geneva with the Iraqis, and you've told them that you have 12 U.N. resolutions that have to be put into effect, and they were put into effect. And now I ask you, are you actually going to achieve this phase? You're going to sit down with the Israelis and say, "I have hundreds of U.N. resolutions that must be put into effect"? This is my question for Mr. Baker. My other question for Mr. Pankin. In President Gorbachev's speech, he said the Israeli-Arab conflict is one of the hangovers or holdovers of the cold war. Do you think this is true? And also another question for Mr. Baker. Are you going to begin talks with the P.L.O. when there are no more reasons for such dialogue?
 BAKER: I'll answer the first question you asked me, and then the Minister will respond to the question you directed to him. I will sit down with any of the parties that wants us to sit down with them, and indeed the co-sponsors will sit down with any of the parties that want us to sit with them, including Israel, and work as hard as we know how for a comprehensive settlement for the Arab-Israeli conflict on the basis of U.N. Security Council Resolutions 242 and 338. That happens to be the terms of reference of this process that we have initiated, and we will continue to do everything we can to serve as a catalyst to move that process forward, and that, of course, would involve implementation of those resolutions.
 PANKIN: I consider that all those things in the conflict, including the most severe things in the conflict, are really relics of the cold war that are brought forth in the very widest sense. In the period when people couldn't find or weren't able to find ways of finding dialogue and negotiations to protect the rights of each other and their peoples by fair means, equitable means . . . Here, for instance, between the Soviet Union and the United States right now we have new relations when we publicly stated that we are no longer in a state of confrontation but now in a mode of friendship. Look at how much has been done in the recent past. New processes of solving conflicts.
 We, for instance, signed on to very important documents vis-a-vis Cambodia. Now after decades we have begun a process, a peace process on the Middle East. This is what I wanted to answer in regard to this question, and that's, I think, what the President of the Soviet Union had in mind.
 
A Game of Chicken
 Q. . . . Without getting into the details of who wants what in this squabble over the venue, why do you think it's taking place? Do you think this indicates that the parties are somehow having second thoughts about going ahead, so they're just using the symbolism of this to hide behind? Or do you think they're just playing sort of a high-stakes game of chicken over it and it's going to get Settled?
 BAKER: Well, I don't know. I think I've said before that we anticipated from the very beginning that none of this would be easy, and it hadn't been for seven or eight months. And I don't think what we're now witnessing is a whole lot different, frankly, from some of the differences of opinion that existed in the past over modalities or procedural questions. But the fact of the matter is, and I said this in my remarks to the conference, I think it will be extremely difficult for people to understand if parties do not -- if they should decide not to participate in bilateral negotiations on the sole basis that they don't like the place where the negotiations would be conducted.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Text

PUB-DATE: November 3, 1991

SECTION: Section 6; Page 34; Column 5; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 4111 words

HEADLINE: Steven Soderbergh: The Sequel

BYLINE: By Trip Gabriel; Trip Gabriel is a frequent contributor to this magazine. His last article, "The Psychiatrist Who Pleaded Insanity," appeared in May.

 BODY:
JUST BEYOND THE SET, extras cast as office clerks circa 1919 come and go. Women sweep by in floor-length wool dresses, while men lumber out of costuming in stiff-front shirts and mutton chops. In the purposeful, hectic half-hour before filming begins, all the 100-odd members of the cast and crew appear seriously busy, save for the director, who stands, hands jammed in pockets, looking happily useless. Steven Soderbergh has never commanded such a large cast. In fact, he says, "I've never been into double digits before."
The $12 million budget for this film, "Kafka," although modest by Hollywood standards, is many times what was spent on "Sex, Lies and Videotape," Soderbergh's acclaimed 1989 debut, which a number of critics called the best first feature of the decade. Produced in obscurity in Soderbergh's hometown of Baton Rouge, La., it became a sacred text of the video-literate generation, its title entering the language and its success setting off a feeding frenzy for Soderbergh's talents. Shot for just $1.2 million, it recently passed the $100 million mark in worldwide earnings. 
 The result is that Soderbergh has been able to fly all the way to Prague to make "Kafka," as well as to attract a cast that includes Sir Alec Guinness and Joel Grey and is headed by the Oscar-winner Jeremy Irons, who says he came out of a showing of "Sex, Lies and Videotape" and declared, "I must work with that man."
This is what real money buys: a huge set recreating an insurance office where 54 clerks hunch over manual Remingtons. To enter the set is to step from a workaday sound stage into a cavernous, marble-columned room that seems to have stood for 100 years. Perched in a doorway, Soderbergh is like a toy maker who has set down a marvelous windup device and stepped back to observe. "The amazing thing is, I said, 'Let's do this' eight months ago, and then, whoops, they're serious. Somebody went to a lot of trouble to make this to my specifications."
There is something earnest and gee-whiz about Soderbergh. His wire-rim glasses, gangly frame and close-cropped hair suggest a precocious boy-mathematician with a Ph.D. He is dressed more conservatively than anyone on the set -- sport jacket, white oxford-cloth shirt, black penny loafers -- as if he were trying to look the part of someone older and more authoritative.
Yet there's no doubt Soderbergh is in control of his movie. Many around him remark on how little he equivocates when designing a shot or addressing actors. Based on the admittedly autobiographical "Sex, Lies and Videotape," with its alienated lead character, one might have expected a halting, neurotic director, unsure of what he wants. But Soderbergh is easygoing and natural. He betrays little hint of the extraordinary pressures placed on a young director with a previous hit, pressures that generally fall into two categories: the assumption that the director is a genuis and will easily duplicate the success, or the temptation to label the first film a fluke and its director an impostor. Soderbergh's manner indicates he has not succumbed to either. In spite of a pronounced streak of self-deprecation, he seems to have no doubt that he deserves all that has come his way, that it's absolutely right that he is making an eagerly awaited second film with an illustrious cast, while still only 27 years old.
SHOT PRINCIPALLY IN black and white, "Kafka" is a strange and unexpected movie, more reflective of Soderbergh the perfervid film buff than a thematic extension of "Sex, Lies and Videotape." Whereas the first film was a CAT scan of intense, up-to-the-minute relations between the sexes, "Kafka" is a period murder mystery with touches of horror. With its baroque Prague backdrops and expressionistic images, the film intentionally evokes old German horror movies, like F. W. Murnau's "Nosferatu." It was written by Lem Dobbs, something of a legend in Hollywood for his imaginative but often unfilmable scripts.
The title character is based less on the real Franz Kafka than on the confused and paranoid antiheroes he created. It's as if Kafka had awakened to find himself in one of his own nightmarish fictions. (To eliminate any vibes of undergraduate pretense, Soderbergh ruled that anyone on the set using the word "Kafkaesque" would be fined 10 Czech crowns.)
By day, Kafka works as a drone in a faceless insurance office; by night, he haunts Prague's famous Bohemian cafes, or holes up in his garret, scribbling short stories no one will publish and tortured letters to his father. When a co-worker is mysteriously murdered, he investigates and stumbles onto a conspiracy linking officials at the insurance company with a body-snatching enterprise operating out of Hradcany Castle, the seat of the Czech Government.
Pursuing the trail, Kafka encounters bomb-throwing anarchists and a man who has been transformed by Frankensteinian experiments into a human hyena. He is eventually led to the castle itself, where the movie takes a sudden leap into a brave new world presided over by a mad scientist. The movie might be described as a cross between "The Third Man" and "Brazil," with the eerie nighttime street scapes of one and the Orwellian overtones and retro-futuro look of the other.
All this represents so big a departure from the naked naturalism of "Sex, Lies and Videotape" that audiences may wonder if the same person directed both movies. And now, after a series of reshoots, "Kafka" bears even less resemblance to Soderbergh's first film. Working from Dobbs's original screenplay, which Soderbergh had read and admired years earlier, the director initially revised some scenes to show Kafka as incapable of connecting romantically with the woman he desires, played by Theresa Russell. Impotence was a major theme in "Sex, Lies and Videotape." "It became kind of a joke between us," says Dobbs, who also wrote the screenplay for "The Hard Way," starring Michael J. Fox. "He'd say, 'Leave the sexual anxiety scenes to me.' "
The material was duly filmed last autumn in Prague, but during the course of editing early this year, Soderbergh decided the romantic dysfunction scenes didn't work. They injected a confusing subtext into the story. In May, cast and crew reassembled in London for two weeks of reshooting, thus removing the last thematic traces of "Sex, Lies and Videotape." Soderbergh admits to having made a sophomore director's mistake. "I tried to force a relationship between Jeremy's character and Theresa's character the moviecould not support," he explains. "I'd made this one feature, and that approach was all I knew."
In the two years since the nearly unprecedented success of "Sex, Lies and Videotape," Soderbergh's career has not been without setbacks. The "Kafka" reshoots, almost 20 percent of the film, have delayed the film's release until the first week of December. Soderbergh had once planned to follow "Sex, Lies and Videotape" with a different film, "The Last Ship," a post-nuclear-war story set on a destroyer. But after several unsatisfactory screenplay drafts, he decided to abandon the project. Soderbergh is aware that audiences want to group him with Woody Allen, Barry Levinson or Spike Lee -- writer-directors given to semiautobiographical films that chronicle distinctive milieus. But he has been frustrated in his attempts to come up with a second personal film on contemporary relationships. "I guess after 'Sex, Lies,' I'm just not anxious to make films that are nakedly about my life or my experience," he says. "Right now, I have a desire to look outward instead of looking inward.
"You know, 'Sex, Lies' was the sum total of years of experience. It's only been two years since then. I'm not sure I know enough new things to generate another feature. I guess I'm not finding myself very interesting at the moment."
IT TOOK ONLY A SINGLE screening of "Sex, Lies and Videotape" to make Steven Soderbergh an overnight success. One day he was working as an anonymous van driver at the Sundance Film Festival in Park City, Utah, where the film was first exhibited; then a rave review, the first of many, appeared in Variety, unleashing a fusillade of telephone calls from industry lights. Sydney Pollack and Robert Redford were on the phone, each wanting to produce his next movie. The actress Demi Moore took Soderbergh to lunch at the Ivy, a Hollywood hangout, and asked him to work on a film with her. Executives at Columbia, Universal, Warner and Paramount all encouraged him to bring future projects to their studios.
At the 1989 Cannes Film Festival, Soderbergh became the youngest director to win the Grand Prize. One jury member, the playwright Peter Handke, compared the film to the work of Chekhov. "They took me outside to shuttle me over to the press tent, and these photographers were pushing in and screaming," Soderbergh wrote in his journal. "It was like Elvis has left the building! Sometimes, it just hits me all of a sudden, what happened, and I can't believe it."
Cannes is notorious for hyping young film makers, but "Sex, Lies and Videotape" lived up to expectations upon opening, generating extraor-dinary word-of-mouth and celestial praise from critics. "I don't remember ever seeing such acclaim for a first film as he got," says Lem Dobbs, who suspects one reason may have been the dearth of serious new film makers in the 80's. "You used to have waves of talent, whether it was the Nouvelle Vague from France in the 60's or when you had the young Bogdanovich, Scorsese and Coppola all at once in the 70's. Now, there hasn't been a wave in so long that Steven Soderbergh became a one-man wave, and everyone went disproportionately crazy."
The assured camera work and the exceptional performances from unknown actors suggested a mature director in mid-career; it was as though Soderbergh had sprung fully formed from the head of Francois Truffaut or Yasujiro Ozu. But he hadn't really come out of nowhere. Despite his youth, Soderbergh had already logged years of experience making short films.
"The turning point was the summer of '75, when 'Jaws' came out," Soderbergh recalls. At the time he was 12. "It was the first time I started thinking: 'Somebody made  this! This didn't just appear spontaneously.' " He bought "The Jaws Log," a movie tie-in book that chronicled the director Steven Spielberg's five-month ordeal filming the movie in the waters off Martha's Vineyard. "I was just obsessed with it," Soderbergh says. "I had this dogeared copy, with certain passages marked, which I'd carry around in my back pocket. I began to understand you could have a job doing this."
While in high school, Soderbergh enrolled in an animation class at Louisiana State University, where his father was dean of the College of Education. There he was drawn into the orbit of several undergraduate film makers who were working out of an abandoned chemistry lab. "He had an amazing encyclopedic knowledge of film," says Paul Ledford, one of the older students. "Lots of people could name a film's star and director, but he knew the names of the cameraman and the writer, and he could recite lines."
In those days, Soderbergh wore his hair in a kind of blond Afro and was skinny enough to fit into the back seat of Ledford's Fiat Spider. Along with another friend, they haunted the movie houses of Baton Rouge. "Movie theater people got to know us," Ledford says. "We'd always sit as a threesome in the middle of the front row. Opening weekends in the summer, we'd figure out how to see all five films in town in one day. We were hungry to see everything. Steven saw 'Jaws' 27 times. He can recite 'Jaws.' "
Ask Soderbergh today, and he will tell you that his favorite movie is still the one that excited him as a 12-year-old. This claim may seem odd, coming from a writer-director who made his mark with a small, low-budget film about sexuality and deceit, bereft of bloodshed and mechanical monsters. Yet Soderbergh really does love "Jaws." An avatar of the generation of mall rats who viewed the Hollywood epics of the 70's over and over, he keeps a rough count of the number of times he's screened "Star Wars" (eight), "American Graffiti" (low teens) and "Apocalypse Now" (high teens).
"Sex, Lies and Videotape" demonstrated the precocious visual fluency of a young director who was already confident enough to ignore convention. "So many things in that movie go against the rules," says Walt Lloyd, the cinematographer who shot both "Kafka" and "Sex, Lies and Videotape." For example, Lloyd says Soderbergh is not afraid to "cross the line," that is, when shooting the reverse angle of a conversation, he'll place the camera on the opposite side of an imaginary line connecting two characters. "In film school, they tell you not to do that -- you can't cross the line," says Lloyd. "I've shot with a lot more experienced directors and said, 'This is a great opportunity to cross the line.' All of a sudden it's a 15-minute discussion about breaking the rules."
Yet Soderbergh's gifts are clearly more than technical. Unlike his hero, Spielberg, who seems unable to treat adult situations and themes without sentimentality, "Sex, Lies and Videotape" is a movie for grown-ups. The Oscar-nominated script portrays its characters with the dense specificity of a novel. Soderbergh, a self-taught writer who never took a screenwriting course, probably owes his talent to a voracious reading habit as a teen-ager, when he consumed novels, science fiction and The New Yorker. He also repeatedly saw such character-driven movies as "Carnal Knowledge," "Annie Hall" and "Manhattan." "Steven started doing short films about problems people were having," says Ledford, who has worked as a soundman on both of Soderbergh's features. "They'd make people laugh but dealt with situations we all faced, like talking to women at a young age."
Soderbergh graduated from high school in 1980, a uniquely focused 17-year-old. Possessed by the desire to make movies, he concluded that a college education would be a time-consuming detour, and headed for Southern California to plunge into the life. Once there, he encountered nothing but roadblocks. The only jobs he could find were nether-world-of-Hollywood menial -- a cue-card holder, a game-show scorekeeper. Discouraged, he returned to Baton Rouge, but had to settle for a job as a coin-changer in an arcade. In his spare time, he made a humorous short about waiting for his big Hollywood break called "Rapid Eye Movement."
He eventually landed a job with a video production house, and for the next two and a half years built his technical skills. Meanwhile, he wrote a half-dozen screenplays and searched for the financial backing to produce them. At one point, he took $7,500 of his own savings, gathered a small group of film-making friends and made "Winston," a short about sexual deception that clearly prefigured the future. Resolving to give Hollywood one more shot, he made plans in late 1987 to set off by car to the Coast. Then, in an eight-day burst -- in a bedroom of his parents' Baton Rouge house, on the road and in the Los Angeles home of a friend where he had crashed on the couch -- he wrote the first draft of "Sex, Lies and Videotape."
WITH ONLY minimal prodding, Soderbergh is willing to discuss the autobiographical origins of his first movie, tracing them to a year in his life when he was "behaving badly" -- just like his character, John, a callow lawyer cheating on his beautiful, repressed wife, Ann, with her lubricious sister, Cynthia. Although the director had a steady girlfriend, he was also seeing other women and lying to all concerned. "It was very complicated, very complicated," Soderbergh says. "I was spinning too many plates on sticks. I thought I would have a heart attack, that the amount of lying would catch up with me."
Eventually, Soderbergh confessed his transgressions to his girlfriend, and then, like his character Graham, he sold off most of his possessions and hit the road. In the movie, Graham is impotent, a condition he attributes to a time when he was a pathological liar. Disgusted with his past, he has commited himself to always telling the truth, which proves rather startling when the intimate details emerge. Graham's few worldly goods include a camcorder that he uses for a "personal project" -- taping women talking about their sex lives. What these women cannot, and will not, say to others, they freely confess to Graham's camera. In a highly erotic movie that contains no nudity, talk turns out to be the biggest turn-on of all.
It would seem that both of these male characters, John and Graham, are based on Soderbergh's experiences -- though he swears there was never a camcorder in his life. In fact, all four characters in the movie are autobiographical. "It was like cutting up my personality over a period of time into four parts and building a character based on each," he says. "I certainly went through a period like Cynthia, where I didn't really give a damn what anybody thought and left a trail of human wreckage behind me. And then there was also a period not long after that when, like Ann, I was very down on anybody who did that. And certainly for a long time I was in this Graham mode of trying to strip things down and simplify. I had too much stuff. I'd got involved with too many people. I had a desire to clean out."
Speaking in his hotel suite in Prague, Soderbergh lies stretched full-length on a couch. Though he has been living in these rooms for two months, they are almost bare of personal possessions. Just like his alter ego, Graham, here is Soderbergh, trailing few personal effects and camped out on a couch. The prone state he prefers is, of course, the position one assumes when talking to an analyst. Soderbergh says that during his period of philandering, he briefly visited a psychotherapist but quit after three sessions. "I just lied to the therapist," he says.
Instead, he seems to have designed his own treatment, one that requires him to speak as openly as he can, as often as he can, even to casual acquaintances. Like Graham, Soderbergh describes himself, in the language of Alcoholics Anonymous, as "a recovering liar." Despite the rush of celebrity following "Sex, Lies and Videotape" that included some 350 interviews, he has not adopted the studied blandness -- or retreated behind the mask of stock phrases -- so typical of Hollywood personalities. Jeremy Irons sounds almost alarmed when discussing this aspect of Soderbergh's nature. "He's terribly open," Irons says in his Oxbridge accent. "If you ask him, he'll tell you anything."
Indeed, it is all but impossible to make Soderbergh squeamish with a question. Asked what caused him to be unfaithful, he recalls the insecurity he feltabout his looks. "When you have profound feelings of self-consciousness, you want to prove that you can be attractive to somebody by force of your personality," he says. "But once you've done it, that person ceases to be interesting, and you move on."
Soderbergh's doubts about his physical appearance caused him, in part, to bail out of Hollywood as soon as he got the chance. "You walk down the street and see these amazing-looking people," he says. "I've always felt very out of place there physically." After "Sex, Lies and Videotape" became a hit, Soderbergh piled his possessions into a 1960 Rambler and drove cross-country to Charlottesville, Va., where he had lived for a few years as a boy. There, he bought a 40-acre farm and married Betsy Brantley, an actress he had met while doing preliminary casting for "The Last Ship." The couple had a daughter last winter, and Soderbergh is happy to be living with his new family thousands of miles from what he considers the superficialities of the film colony.
Looking to the future, he says his third movie will be another surprise -- a comedy about the founding of the National Football League, based on a script written by his brother-in-law, Duncan Brantley, and Rick Reilly, both writers for Sports Illustrated. "If I end up doing this movie," Soderbergh says, "based on the three films I will have made, no one will ever be able to predict what I'll do next."
 "TURNOVER!" BARKS the British assistant director.
"Kamera!" echoes the Czech translator for the benefit of local crew members.
The "Kafka" production has come this chilly night to old Prague, to a dark, twisting street lined with baroque houses whose facades are thick with scrolls and curlicues. The walls are sooty and crumbling from all the lignite coal that is burned to keep the city warm. High above Soderbergh, cast and crew looms Hradcany Castle, sitting atop a massive rock and bathed in green light. The castle is a maze of interconnected Government buildings, a city within a city that suggests corridors receding to infinity and spiral staircases out of an M. C. Escher print.
In tonight's scene, two short bowler-hatted men spring from a doorway to frisk Kafka and drag him away. The action is both sinister and comic. Soderbergh quickly sets up the scene so that the camera will cover the action in one continuous shot. He films economically, thanks to an ability to envision how each frame will fit into the finished whole.
Besides his technical virtuosity, Soderbergh also has a reputation for being an actor's director. "Sex, Lies and Videotape" made stars out of four previously little-known or lightly regarded actors: Andie MacDowell, James Spader, Laura San Giacomo and Peter Gallagher. "He loves actors, which is a very nice thing, because not all directors do," Jeremy Irons says. "Some directors consider actors nothing but things that get in the way before the editing happens."
Yet to be on a Soderbergh set is to discover a paradox: his work with actors is low-key and unassertive. He offers no drama coaching, demonstrates no line readings, engages in no lengthy discussions of characters' motives. Most of his instructions are technical, such as when to pause under a light.
Before the camera rolls, Irons and the two bowler-hatted officials (played by Simon McBurney and Keith Allen) rehearse their lines. When Irons is accosted and his pockets rifled, he plays it weary and put-upon. Discussing his motivation, he says to Soderbergh: "It's not so much my rights I want. I want some answers." Soderbergh nods laconically.
After a second run-through, the director says, "It just needs to go really fast."
Another run-through. Soderbergh asks that a phrase of dialogue be dropped. "One more time," he says quietly, standing a few feet away and listening with his head bowed in contemplation. The actors repeat their lines; the director nods noncommitally.
The camera rolls again and Soderbergh, almost invisible amid all the activity, watches through a small video monitor. At this point the scene is almost in hand. Soderbergh says little else until, six takes later, he has two he likes. "We're wrapping fools," he announces at 4 A.M., the night's work concluded.
HALF AN HOUR LATER, the "Kafka" cast and crew tumble in from the cold and take up seats at the too-bright lobby bar of the Hotel Forum. The director sets the tone of any movie shoot, and Soderbergh's lack of pretense has trickled down on this one. It has become routine for nearly the entire company, actors as well as grips, to drink together after the day's shooting. Since it is close to dawn, the hotel bar is otherwise empty. At the far end of the bar, Jeremy Irons, wearing a silk scarf and knee-high leather boots outside his pants, is talking to one of the English grips. Closer to Soderbergh, Stuart Cornfeld, one of the film's producers, holds forth about the night's subfreezing temperatures. Winter has arrived a month early in Prague. Every setup and takedown is requiring extra time, slowing the production schedule.
But with all the talk of of adversity, Soderbergh, whose nose is still red from the chill, perks up. He recalls an episode from "The Jaws Log," the battered book that became his film-making bible.
"Whenever things are going slowly, I think about Spielberg out on Martha's Vineyard," he says. "I just can't conceive of the pressure he was under -- a 55-day schedule that balloons to 155 days and a budget that goes from $3.5 million to $8 million. They're out there getting 30 seconds of usable footage every three days because Bruce kept breaking down. His eyes kept crossing. That must have been just gut-wrenching."
Bruce, of course, was Spielberg's mechanical shark. And suddenly Soderbergh realizes that, compared with directing a cross-eyed mechanical shark, he has it pretty good.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 35; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1466 words

HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY;
Introducing the Poor to the Middle Class

BYLINE: Vicki Goldberg's book "The Power of Photography: How Photographs Changed Our Lives" has just been published.

 BODY:
In the 30'S, when the documentary impulse ran rampant across the nation, the Federal Government compiled the largest photographic record ever made of rural -- and some urban -- life in America. From 1935 to 1943, the Historical Section of the Resettlement Administration and the Farm Security Administration produced something like 80,000 prints and 200,000 unprinted negatives.
These images, which influenced "The Grapes of Wrath" (both book and film), remain the chief source for the country's vision of the Depression. Dorothea Lange's "Migrant Mother" and Arthur Rothstein's "Dust Storm, Cimarron County" have achieved iconic status; much of Walker Evans's finest work was taken for the F.S.A. 
 The project left a legacy as significant as its enduring images: this was the first time an American administration had employed photography as a prime player in what was essentially a Government propaganda campaign. The Resettlement Administration was established to help the "submerged third" of the nation that was overwhelmed by rural blight. Congress resisted many New Deal measures because of their supposedly socialistic cast; F.D.R.'s Administration hoped to enlist popular support by showing urban Americans how urgent the need was.
 A new show at Neikrug Photographica, "Farm Security Administration . . . A Time for Celebration" (224 East 68th Street, through Nov. 16), approaches the F.S.A. from the photographers' point of view. The gallery asked Esther Bubley, John Collier, Jack Delano, Carl Mydans and Louise Rosskam to chose their own favorites; Mrs. Rosskam and Mrs. Arthur Rothstein selected work by their late husbands; the rest of the pictures were Neikrug's choice (open from 1 to 6 Friday and Saturday, and at other times by appointment: 288-7741 or 288-7742). The refreshing result is a parade of familiar subjects in less familiar guises, a useful reminder of how broad the archive is.
 Here are the families on the road with their life histories tied up in a sack, the unemployed men by the closed-up cafes, the old couples without a full set of teeth between them, the diners and gas stations and bargain stores, the houses crowded with children and peeling paint and little else, that the F.S.A. stamped on the national memory. Here too are the few shining, middle-class exemplars -- men with polished, high-laced shoes or spanking-clean children in little plaid fedoras -- that rounded out the F.S.A.'s presentation for the middle-class audience it was aimed at.
 But the migrating family is not by Lange but by Mydans, the gas station not by Evans but by Russell Lee (it looks like an Evans taken a few hundred feet back), and most of the familiar scenes are to some degree unexpected.
 Sadly, the show has no dates or titles for any work but Delano's. You might guess that Lee's picture of an Asian child with I.D. tags was taken during the 1942 Japanese relocation program, or that the elderly men snapped by Lange, one with his chin jutting out from his scrawny neck and a tight-lipped look of dogged defiance, were tenant farmers on relief, but it surely would help to know.
 During the 30's, photodocumentary was considered the most reliable and objective means of reporting; even literature tried to imitate the dispassionate thoroughness of the camera. But photographers are neither entirely objective nor always reliable, nor is there to this day any agreement on the role of esthetics in reporting. Clearly there was none then, and some of the F.S.A. photographers leaned hard on art.
 Delano favored slightly stagy setups for group portraits that suggest a notion of family disjunctions to match our own: two children stand close to the lens and regard it boldly while the other members of the family stand back, lost in the tedium of being photographed, contemplating the interiors of their own minds. Ed Rosskam has a strong formalist bent: in his picture of a black neighborhood in Chicago, the flat expanse of a brick wall takes up much of the surface, giving way to a slice of street where three boys at play punctuate the open space of the sidewalk.
 Walker Evans's picture of a sharecropper's kitchen, one of many instances in which Evans turned a poor wooden shanty into an interior by Vermeer, points up the way style affects perceptions of poverty. Scholars have determined that Evans cleared the kitchen table of all distracting objects, moved a crock onto the cupboard, and positioned his camera in such a way that it disguised the layout of the house.
 The result was a cool and affecting beauty that presumably mirrors not only a stylistic preference but Evans's own sanguine view that there was beauty even in these hard lives, and hope for a more orderly existence. The compassionate optimism of so many of the F.S.A. photographs was not created solely by Government decree.
 For the belief was abroad in the land that with sufficient will, technology and the proper kind of Government intervention, even the problems of the Depression could be licked. The New Deal was based on this assumption, and it in turn fostered the feeling that something was being done, that what was broken would be fixed. The F.S.A. photographs generally show people who are down but not out, penniless but still full of fight, because that was what Roy Stryker, director of the program, wanted to see, and what the photographers wanted to see, and what the audience wanted too. In a sense, the 30's was an age of faith.
 In images of abject misery, like Lange's woman with a dirty child by a tent or Delano's mother and child on a pallet resting on four chairs, there is no hint that the subjects have brought this on themselves by drink or bad character. They are victims who deserve sympathy. Congress was not altogether happy with the populist sentiments of the F.S.A. pictures, which some thought socialistic, even communistic. (Even two or three decades later, Congress briefly considered destroying the file because it did not put the country in a properly advantageous light.)
 At least by 1938, and increasingly after the war began, Stryker asked his photographers to show a more positive side of the program; some of the photographs at Neikrug may reflect that. But coded in all the images is a sense that everyone was in the Depression together and if luckier folks only knew about the plight of those less fortunate they would naturally be moved to help. Stryker said that the F.S.A. was meant to introduce Americans to Americans.
The Federal Government does not sponsor any such photographic programs today. Photographers do portray the contemporary "submerged third," sometimes for news organizations, sometimes with the assistance of nonprofit organizations, infrequently with local government support. Times have changed. New Deal programs are in disrepute, faith is in short supply, the sense of community is shaky, and Americans are much less willing to meet the Americans in this kind of picture.
A strong book like Stephen Shames's recent "Outside the Dream: Child Poverty in America" does not flinch from showing drug abuse, domestic violence, and interiors that more closely resemble a town dump than anything by Vermeer.
 But if the present Administration has not chosen to follow Roosevelt's lead in presenting the poor, it has improved upon his lessons in the uses of communication. It was Roosevelt who first harnessed radio to politics in his fireside chats, Roosevelt who first let a magazine photographer take "candid" rather than posed portraits of him, and Roosevelt who allowed the F.S.A. to link photography to political policy. The Bush Administration, which knows how to suborn images to its own purposes, took control of a large-scale visual documentary project and turned it into propaganda for the Presidency: the photographs and TV coverage of the gulf war.
 This time around the Government did not hire the photographers but co-opted them. This time the photographers may not have shared the Administration's sentiments but were restricted from recording anything else. And this time the Government seems to have used the visual record in part to distract attention from just the kinds of economic problems the F.S.A. photographers diligently recorded in hopes of curing them.
 F.D.R., who had many newspapers lined up against him, had to hope some of the media would use the F.S.A. images the way they were intended. Last month, as Saddam Hussein was resisting the peace provisions, ABC showed a film called "Heroes of Desert Storm," which mixed actual film of Patriots and Scuds with staged scenes of battle to recount America's triumph. It was introduced by none other than the President himself. Neither Roy Stryker nor Franklin D. Roosevelt understood the image game that well.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
New Flights To Caribbean

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
AIR fares to the Caribbean this winter will be little changed from last year, and airlines will offer almost the same number of seats. What has changed, however, are the many new flights to Caribbean destinations and greater accessibility for travelers who do not live near such traditional Caribbean gateways as New York and Miami.
Delta Air Lines will begin nonstop service from Atlanta to St. Thomas on Dec. 15, the start of the high season to the Caribbean. Continental Airlines has tripled, to 30, the number of cities -- including Denver and Cleveland -- that will feed passengers onto its 34 weekly Caribbean-bound flights from Newark. And Northwest's schedule this winter includes the Detroit-Boston-Bermuda flight that it inaugurated last May. 
 In addition, next month Key Air, which has long flown charter flights for Club Med and other tour operators, will inaugurate 10 scheduled charter flights a week from Savannah, Ga., to the Caribbean -- four to Jamaica and two each to Aruba, St. Maarten and Freeport. Savannah's city fathers are so pleased, according to Carlisle Vason, Key's director of sales and marketing, they are building a $1 million airport hub complete with Caribbean motif and its own customs and immigration facilities.
"I have a feeling that the increase in flights from 'off-line' cities may be the wave of the future for the Caribbean," said Marcella Martinez of the Caribbean Tourism Organization in New York. "If you want to increase tourism to the Caribbean, you cannot do it primarily out of the Northeast gateways."
Some airlines have realized as much for several years, as witness Northwest's four-year-old daily flight from Minneapolis to Montego Bay, Jamaica, for example, or T.W.A.'s longtime direct flight from St. Louis to San Juan. .
Even the financially troubled Pan American professes to see a potential savior in the Caribbean, a region it dominated for years. Since Delta recently bought 45 percent of Pan Am, along with most of its European routes, Pan Am has to concentrate on the Caribbean and Latin America.
"We'll continue to go to 16 Caribbean locations, mostly with nonstops from Miami and New York," said Jeff Kriendler, a Pan Am vice president. "But while we're selling the Caribbean along the Eastern Seaboard, Delta will be selling the region for their flights and ours in cities like Dallas, Cincinnati and Salt Lake City."
 
Deterrents to Visiting
 The Caribbean is already accessible to many Americans, of course. Almost 11.5 million people flew there from the United States last year, according to the Department of Transportation, up from 10.7 million in 1989 and almost 8.8 million in 1985. But airline officials say the increase would have been much greater had it not been for the Persian Gulf war, which gave many potential airline passengers the jitters, and the weak United States economy. Sixty-five percent of the Caribbean's visitors are Americans, Ms. Martinez said, so a weak American economy badly hurts the Caribbean.
As the weakness in the economy continues, airlines are not raising fares above last year's levels. T.W.A.this fall is offering a low fare of about $250 between New York and San Juan. Continental's autumn round-trip excursion fare from Newark to St. Maarten is $383. Key Air's New York to Aruba round-trip fare is $379. Delta's fare from La Guardia to Nassau is $344 round trip. All these fares require advance purchases, midweek departure and a Saturday overnight; generally they are nonrefundable. These fares rise after Dec. 15, the start of the high season.
The dominant carrier in the Caribbean these days is American Airlines, which flies 74 daily flights, including 36 nonstops. Next month the airline will inaugurate a daily nonstop from Miami to Aguadilla, P.R., but most of its flights from the mainland are to San Juan, which has been American's Caribbean hub since1986.
From San Juan, continuing passengers have a choice of several regional airlines, including American Airlines' affiliate, American Eagle, which has 94 flights a day to 14 Caribbean destinations. Another regional carrier, LIAT Ltd., owned by 11 Caribbean governments and based in Antigua, flies to 26 islands. Having overcome difficulties with its on-time record, the carrier is considered greatly improved of late by American travel officials. Last spring it opened its first United States sales office, in New York, in hopes of doubling the 150,000 North American passengers it carries each year. LIAT has two "explorer fares": $169 ($199 in July and August, December and January), with a maximum of three stopovers, valid for 21 days. And a $357 year-round fare, valid for 30 days, gives unlimited travel to any of its 26 destinations. The cheaper of the two fares must be purchased in the United States, the other can be purchased anywhere in the Caribbean.
With its ambitious schedule to Miami, Atlanta and Toronto, B.W.I.A., the carrier owned by Trinidad and Tobago, is much more than a regional airline. This winter it will inaugurate the only nonstop from New York to Trinidad, five times weekly, and direct service six times a week to Tobago, with stops in Barbados, Grenada and Trinidad. (Since Tobago enlarged its runway by 50 percent last spring, making it accessable to wide-body aircraft, visitors no longer have to change planes in Trinidad.) But with flights to more than a dozen islands, the 51-year-old carrier is the Caribbean-based airline best known to Americans by far. Other carriers include Windward Island Airways, Air B.V.I. and Air Guadeloupe.
 
New Flights
 Lots of new flights, in addition to those of B.W.I.A. and Delta, are scheduled for this winter. T.W.A. will add a fourth daily flight from New York to San Juan. Air Jamaica will have eight flights a week from Atlanta to Jamaica, up from five flights most of last year. And Minerve, the French airline, will begin charter flights next month between Kennedy Airport in New York and Martinique and Guadeloupe in the French West Indies.
ALM Antillean Airline pulled out of New York last spring, but now flies to Aruba, Bonaire and Curacao four times a week from Atlanta, as well as most days from Miami.
Air Jamaica has also modified its schedule from New York so passengers can arrive by midday.
Like European-bound passengers last summer, tourists are still waiting until the last minute before booking flights and packages. While that probably reflects economic uncertainty, some carriers say it also reflects the hope that air fares and Caribbean hotel rates will fall. But that is unlikely, they say, since air fares have already fallen over the past few years when adjusted for inflation.
Among the many package fares available are: Pan Am's all-inclusive three-night package from New York to Puerto Plata, Dominican Republic for $634 per person. Delta's "dream vacation" packages to St. Thomas (as low as $579 per person for three nights), St. Croix ($599) and St. John ($849). Air Jamaica's three-nights in Jamaica from $409 (without meals) to $755 per person (all-inclusive).
Many of those package fares are offered by travel agents, while some agents have put together outstanding packages of their own.
