HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By Terrence P. Neilan

 BODY:

On the Trail of Ellis Peters
Q. We are big fans of Ellis Peters, the medieval mystery writer who bases her stories in Shropshire, England. Are there any tours of Shropshire with an Ellis Peters connection? -- Lisa and Kirk Werner, Morris Plains, N.J.
A. The British Tourist Authority in New York says it is not aware of any organized tours, although local travel agents may well put together tours of their own. 
 The authority does, however, offer something that would appeal to all Peters fans: a free brochure listing four driving tours of Shropshire based on the Peters works. The brochure, "Brother Cadfael Car Trails," is named for her books' main character, a medieval monk.
The first tour, "The Hermit of Eyton Forest Trail," covers 25 miles in the heart of Shropshire, passing through many of the places mentioned in "The Hermit of Eyton Forest." Peters fans will recognize such villages and hamlets as Atcham, Leighton and Wroxeter, as well as the market town of Much Wenlock.
The second tour, "The Marches Trail," covers 31 miles in the border country with Wales. Many of the scenes from "Dead Man's Ransom" are set there. The area is rich in such local crafts as pottery, jewelery and knitwear. The third tour, "The Hugh Beringar Trail," covers 30 miles of villages, parish churches and market towns in north Shropshire. It also features scenes from "Dead Man's Ransom" and is named for one of the book's characters, the Sheriff of Shropshire.
The fourth tour, "The Virgin in the Ice Trail," is the most scenic. It covers 54 miles and passes through the rollings hills of south Shropshire as well as the market towns of Ludlow and Bridgnorth. Much of the trail is featured in "The Virgin in the Ice."
The brochure is available from the British Tourist Authority, 40 West 57th Street, New York, N.Y. 10151; telephone (212) 581-4708. It can also be obtained in Shropshire at tourist information centers in Ludlow, Shrewsbury, Oswestry and Whitchurch. Included with the brochure is a four-page pamphlet listing accommodations in areas covered by the tours.
 
24 Hours in Seattle
 Q. My wife and I will be arriving at the Seattle airport in late November around 9 P.M. and will leave by ferry about 24 hours later. Without renting a car, what is the best way to spend about 24 hours in Seattle? -- W. P. Johnson Jr., Old Greenwich, Conn.
A. The heart of Seattle has trendy cafes, spectacular mountain views and a giant open-air farmers' market, all within easy walking distance in the downtown area. But be aware that many of Seattle's hills rival San Francisco's, especially in the areas most frequented by tourists. A bus that makes the 35-minute journey from the airport costs $1.
For sightseeing, a free bus rolls through downtown every 10 minutes, making stops at all the attractions. Among the most popular sites is the Pike Place Market, covering about three city blocks. The market, which is open every day, has 105 farm stands, 220 stands offerings crafts and about 300 selling clothing, antiques and foodstuffs. Pike Place is also famous for its fish market.
From the market you can hop a bus to Pioneer Square, the city's historic district. It has antique shops, art galleries, cafes, drugstores and nightclubs. You might also drink a latte (espresso with steamed milk, a popular Seattle beverage) at the popular Grand Central Bakery. The Elliott Bay Book Company is the place for browsing.
For a panoramic view of Seattle and the Olympic and Cascade Mountains and Mount Rainier, try the 520-foot observation deck at the Space Needle, built for the 1962 World's Fair.
To get to the needle, take the Monorail, which is also a leftover from the World's Fair. The Monorail can be boarded in the downtown shopping district. The less-than-a-minute ride costs 60 cents.
 
The Indianapolis 500
 Q. Could you please tell me how I can get tickets to the Indianapolis 500 next year and the names of agencies to contact for places to stay. -- Ginny Burke, Sayville, L.I.
A. Next year's Indianapolis 500, the 76th, will be held from May 22 through 25. The following tour operators are among those offering tickets and land packages:
Grayline of Indianapolis, 9075 North Meridian Street, Indianapolis, Ind. 46260, (317) 573-0699, offers three-day packages that include accommodations at Quality Inn Suites or the Radisson Plaza. Packages include reserved seats at the race, tickets to the race parade the day before, breakfast and a box lunch on race day and transfers. Rates range from $765 to $1,160 per person in double occupancy.
Tickets and Travel, 1099 North Meridian Street, Suite 155,Indianapolis, Ind. 46204, (317) 633-6406, sells a package with three nights at the Courtyards by Marriott, reserved seats at the race and parade, transfers and daily Continental breakfast. Prices are $725 per person.
Regal Sports Vacations, 3029 West 39th Street, Suite 3011, Indianapolis, Ind. 46208, (317) 291-9500, offers packages at luxury hotels (Westin or Hyatt Regency), first-class (Sheraton), business class (Signature Inn) or economy (Days Inn). Rates range from $595 to $1,095. Packages include a choice of reserved race seats and either a ticket to the parade or the drivers' meeting, which is held in Gasoline Alley.
 
Austro-Hungarian Expo
 Q. Where can I find information on the Austria-Hungary Expo for 1992-93? -- Magdi Biro Fischer, Anaheim Hills, Calif.
A. The Expo planned for two sites, one in Vienna and one in Budapest, was to have been held in 1994. But for two reasons -- one ecological, the other financial -- it was canceled. Budapest pulled out because of a lack of money. Vienna had a referendum on the fair and most voters objected to devoting open space to the venture.
 
Springtime in Bogota
 Q. My son will be attending the University of Bogota, Colombia, all next year. What information can you give me about the weather and the type of clothing he should take? -- R. Gillen, Warwick, Mass.
A. Bogota, in the words of The Times Books World Weather Guide, is truly the city of the perpetual spring. Nights are cool but never really cold and frost is unknown. Sunshine averages from three to five hours a day thoughout the year, with the days feeling warm but never really hot.
Remarkably, there is only a four-degree variation between the lowest average daily maximum temperature (64, in July) and the highest (68, in February). Precipitation is at its highest in October (6.3 inches).

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Livingston Plaza;
Designed for a Dozen, but One Tenant's Enough

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
DESIGNED for as many as a dozen tenants, Livingston Plaza, the newest office building in downtown Brooklyn, wound up with only one occupant, the New York City Transit Authority.
But that suited the developers, Cohen Brothers Realty Corporation and Starrett Housing Corporation. After all, the Transit Authority did more than take all 600,000 square feet; it bought the whole building, at a reported profit to the developers of $12 million. The agency is using Livingston Plaza to house some 2,500 workers who had been dispersed through downtown Brooklyn. Headquarters remains at 370 Jay Street. 
 Did the deal amount to a quasi-public body bailing out a private real estate enterprise?
"It was a case of something that wouldn't necessarily have happened without us," said Frederick S. Harris, director of real estate for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. "But nobody said, 'Help these guys.' Quite the opposite. The city seemed interested in having us go to other projects.
"There is no question that our annual cost is more than if we had stayed in our various spaces, but it's quite clear that the annual cost will be better than it would have been if we had simply upgraded our leased space."
The building itself, core and shell, cost about $95 million, Mr. Harris said. To complete the interior work, another $25 million was needed. It amounted, he said, to an effective rent of less than $20 a square foot.
The argument for purchasing a building was that the Transit Authority, using tax-exempt bonds in the transaction, would ultimately be liable for lower debt service than it would be as a tenant absorbing the cost of the higher-interest conventional financing taken out by its landlord.
"The basic building and tenant package ended up at $200 to $210 per rentable square foot," Mr. Harris said.
"And that was for a fully equipped building -- everything up to the marker boards on the wall," added Robair A. Reichenstein, the deputy real estate director at the M.T.A.
The Permanent Citizen's Advisory Committee to the M.T.A. took no position on the project, said its associate director, JoAnn Katzban. Neither did the Straphangers' Campaign, another watchdog group.
But State Senator Franz S. Leichter, a Manhattan Democrat, criticized the deal as long ago as March 1989, when he said: "Acceptable cheaper space is available elsewhere to satisfy legitimate space demands. And there is absolutely no reason why the T.A. has to have a brand new building."
Many employees have already moved into the 12-story, trapezoidal structure, which has massive, turreted corners; gleaming, piston-like columns and alternating bands of dusty gray and charcoal gray tiles. The "plaza" of Livingston Plaza is a triangular apron filled with three- to four-foot-high islands that double as planters and seating coves.
Helmut Jahn of Chicago was the architect. The interiors were by the Manhattan architectural firm of Gruzen Samton Steinglass.
The story of Livingston Plaza is that of two initiatives in downtown Brooklyn, originally separate, that converged in the late 1980's.
In July 1985, Cohen and Starrett were designated developers of an office building on a city-owned block bounded by Livingston, Smith and Schermerhorn Streets and Boerum Place. They were to lease the parcel from the city for 99 years and the structure was to be completed in 1988.
"The original plan was to develop the site in such a way as to be attractive and economic for back-office users from the financial-services industry," said Charles Steven Cohen, president and chief executive officer of Cohen Brothers. With rents in the low to mid-$20's, the building was to position itself as an alternative to New Jersey, in particular.
Of course, as of October 1987, all bets were off that involved financial-service concerns.
At about the same time, Mr. Harris was moving to consolidate the authority's "significant tenancies" in downtown Brooklyn. This included 200,000 square feet in an old garment factory, 25 Chapel Street, at Flatbush Avenue Extension. Among its drawbacks, transit officials said, was that elevators would catch on fire, rain poured on to desk tops and pigeons roosted in unoccupied floors, all while four mortgage holders fought among themselves following the disappearance of the landlord.
THE M.T.A. issued a request for proposals, prepared by Gruzen Samton Steinglass and Pattison Partners. It stated that the Transit Authority needed more than 400,000 square feet of space near 370 Jay Street, and specified such criteria as floor sizes, ceiling heights, floor load capacities, column spacing and power requirements.
In November 1987, responses came from the Cohen-Starrett partnership, as well as the developers of the Metrotech complex, Albee Square Mall and two adjoining buildings on Jay Street that were to be renovated.
The Cohen-Starrett partnership was "aggressive on price from the beginning," Mr. Harris said, and its building was closest to 370 Jay Street. Since the overall project had already gone through the city's land-use review procedure, it was left pretty much intact. "We couldn't change a species of tree in the plaza," Mr. Harris said.
While the turreted layout created some problems for the interior architects, Michael A. Kazan of Gruzen Samton Steinglass said it was "by and large a very good building, ideally sized and located for the T.A."
But the partnership was not without problems, Mr. Harris noted. "The T.A. was having a long, drawn-out battle with the Cohens on the quality of their subway work in their building across from Bloomingdale's," he said, meaning 750 Lexington Avenue, between 59th and 60th Streets, which was also designed by Mr. Jahn. (Today, Mr. Cohen dismisses the incident as "a small thing that had to be worked out.")
MORE critically, the Livingston Plaza parcel was deemed too desirable by City Hall, Mr. Harris said, in that it would probably succeed on its own, without a large municipal tenant.
"They thought that this was the one building that would get built on spec," Mr. Harris recalled. "We got a year on hold where we went through a political interchange over the best site. The one site the city really wanted us to go to was Atlantic Terminal, which hadn't even submitted a proposal."
That debate lasted until the end of 1988, after which intense negotations began with the developers that led to an agreement in November 1989. The ground lease on the city-owned parcel was revised at this time.
In September 1990, $200 million in bonds were issued by the Transit Authority, with yields between 7 and 8 percent. Among the buyers was Cohen Brothers Realty. Under the agreement, Mr. Harris said, payment was not made until unfinished construction items amounted to $500,000. That was a powerful inducement to the developers to build the structure quickly.
"They had a conventional construction loan from Chase and their interest was roughly $30,000 a day," Mr. Reichenstein said. "That meant it wasn't really worth arguing a lot."
With the end in sight at Livingston Plaza, perhaps the biggest challenge faced today by Cohen Brothers is finding tenants for the 100,000 square feet at 3 Park Avenue that were abruptly vacated two months ago when the Family Media magazine publishing concern shut down without warning. The 41-story tower, between 33d and 34th Streets, has a total of 600,000 square feet.
At 750 Lexington Avenue, about 80,000 of 340,000 square feet are vacant, Mr. Cohen said. There are lesser vacancies at the Crystal Pavilion, 805 Third Avenue, a 550,000-square-foot building at 50th Street; 475 Park Avenue South, a 340,000-square-foot building at 32d Street and 3 East 54th Street, a 200,000-square-foot building.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Livingston Plaza office building in downtown Brooklyn, where the New York City Transit Authority will fill all 600,000 square feet. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New York Ranks High in Housing Bias

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
IN the largest study of housing discrimination ever completed for the Federal Government, researchers have concluded that the problem is more prevalent in New York City and its suburbs than in any of 24 other major metropolitan areas across the United States, particularly for the Spanish-speaking minority.
The study coincides with a rapid increase in fair-housing complaints to regulatory agencies in the New York area. Taken together, the new findings from both Federal and city agencies suggest that housing discrimination has persisted, and perhaps become more common, despite a succession of laws enacted in the 1980's to prevent it. 
 In a small number of cases, the discrimination has come in its most virulent and obvious forms, involving harassment of minority tenants.
"I adjusted to this society long ago, and I never expected this," said Francisco Caballero, a 73-year-old native of Puerto Rico, who, according to court records, awoke to find the wall behind his three- room, $319-a-month apartment in Astoria, Queens, spray-painted with the images of a Ku Klux Klansman, a cross and a stick figure dangling from a noose.
In a case that has been appealed to the New York State Surpreme Court, he and three other tenants of the Astoria building in June were awarded $22,500 in damages from their landlords, a family of immigrants from Greece.
More often, according to civil rights lawyers and other experts, the techniques are more subtle.
"People no longer stand at the front door and say, 'Go away, I don't rent to blacks,' " said Phylliss Spiro, director of the Open Housing Center, a nonprofit New York City group that helps discrimination victims gather evidence against landlords, home sellers and real estate agents. "They smile very politely and say, 'What a shame, we've just taken a deposit from someone else.' " In the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development study, "testers" -- groups of three that included whites, blacks and Spanish-speaking people -- posed as prospective renters or buyers to see if they were treated differently when making similar requests.
IN the New York area, the testers found that Hispanic people experienced some form of discrimination 61 percent of the time when trying to buy and 53 percent of the time when trying to rent, houses or apartments. The problem was less severe for them in all other cities studied.
For New York-area blacks, discrimination was experienced 44 percent of the time when they tried to buy and 40 percent of the time when they attempted to rent. In only three other cities -- Chicago, Dayton, Ohio, and Macon, Ga., -- was the incidence of discrimination against blacks higher. "For blacks, the New York area is about as bad as any place in the country, and for Hispanics, it is easily the worst," said Margery Austin Turner, senior researcher for the Urban Institute, a nonprofit group in Washington, which conducted the study with analysts from Syracuse University.
In all, 3,800 visits were paid to real estate agents and rental brokers in 25 cities during the spring and summer of 1989 to measure various forms of discrimination ranging from outright rejection of minority applicants to unequal requirements for security deposits. The project was paid for with $2 million in Federal funds.
While their broadest conclusions were released in September, the researchers last month provided a more detailed analysis at the request of The New York Times, comparing the 25 metropolitan areas.
"New York came out the worst, or nearly the worst, more than any other place in the study," said John Yinger, a professor of economics at Syracuse University, who directed the project. He said there was no basis for historic comparison because the only similar study, conducted by H.U.D. in 1977, did not try to assess the problem of discrimination against Spanish-speaking people, and used different methods.
But regulators in New York City said their discrimination caseload has increased sharply.
The New York regional office of H.U.D., in an analysis separate from the Federal study, said its complaints of housing discrimination in New York and New Jersey nearly doubled in the fiscal year that ended last June 30, to 936 from 481.
The two states, with only 10 percent of the nation's population, now have 20 percent of its housing discrimination cases under investigation, the agency said.
In New York City, the Human Rights Commission, which is responsible for enforcing local fair-housing laws, said it brought 22 cases of discrimination before an administrative law judge in the last fiscal year, and reached judgments against landlords and home sellers in every one. During the 1980's, the agency typically brought about 10 cases a year.
The increase comes at a turbulent time for racial and ethnic relations, when memories of violent strife are fresh in neighborhoods like Crown Heights and Bensonhurst in Brooklyn and Howard Beach in Queens. City officials said that there was no proof of a link between these incidents and housing discrimination but that they were convinced it exists.
"The issue in these communities is turf -- who belongs and who doesn't -- and housing discrimination is at the core of the problem," said Rolando Acosta, deputy commissioner for law enforcement for New York City's Human Rights Commission.
Nor is the problem confined to neighborhoods that are poor, segregated or have a history of tension.
"This is the last place I expected this to happen," said Weldon Turner, a 31-year-old lawyer and stock trader for Salomon Brothers, the securities firm, whose case was resolved by the Human Rights Commission in June.
According to the court record, Mr. Turner, who is black, and his wife, Sharon Friedman, who is white, were denied a $1,895-a-month rental apartment on West 80th Street just off West End Avenue because of his race, even though they had offered the landlord two months' rent in advance and two additional months' rent as a security deposit. The building is in an integrated neighborhood that ranks among Manhattan's most expensive.
Their case, like that of Mr. Caballero, was ruled on by the Human Rights Commission, which ordered the building's landlord to pay them $10,500 in damages. The ruling is being appealed.
Housing analysts, attorneys and advocates of the poor point to a host of reasons why housing discrimination persisted in the 1980's and may be increasing in the 90's.
The economic boom and acute housing shortages of the 80's, while enriching landlords and home sellers, also made it easier for them to discriminate against some applicants, according the Craig Gurian, chief counsel of the Human Rights Commission's Law Enforcement Bureau. That was because demand was so strong that they were able to find other tenants or buyers quickly, he added.
Economic expansion in the last decade also meant that the incomes and aspirations of many minority families were rising, leading them to seek housing in neighborhoods previously dominated by white, middle-class and affluent residents, sometimes creating tension. Now, with the region's real estate market in a deep slump, discriminatory practices may be becoming more pervasive because black, Spanish-speaking and other minority people are finding bargains in more attractive neighborhoods.
Shifting immigration patterns may have also played a role. While New York and its suburbs have always attracted disparate ethnic groups and nationalities, the influx during the 80's was led by diverse and sometimes antagonistic groups -- Dominicans, Haitians, Koreans, Chinese, Iranians, Syrians, Greeks and Soviet Jews.
"Some of these groups came without the support networks and sources of capital that previous immigrants had developed," said Robert Lake, a housing analyst and associate professor at Rutgers University's Center for Urban Policy Research. As a result, he added, some of the new immigrants have been "particularly vulnerable."
The problem was underscored in June and July by a series of fire bombings of the Fillmore Real Estate agency in Canarsie, a predominantly Italian and Jewish neighborhood in southeast Brooklyn.
The agency, under a court order to stop "racial steering" -- the practice of showing minority applicants only those homes on blocks already dominated by minorities -- had been showing black applicants its full range of listings.
The case of Mr. Caballero attracted less notice, but also resulted in violence. Court records show that after the spray-painted figures appeared on his wall in October, 1986, a series of confrontations ensued with his landlords, Irene, Matheos and Steven Vizentinis, themselves recent immigrants from Greece.
Ultimately, in 1988, Mr. Caballero's 35-year-old nephew, Hector Rodriguez, who shared the Astoria apartment, was beaten bloody, and the two men moved out.
In their response to the Human Rights Commission investigation, the Vizentinis family said their disagreements with Mr. Caballero and his nephew did not involve racial or ethnic bias. According to the court record, they offered various intepretions of the painting on their tenants' wall -- that it represented a street lamp in Paris, a chandelier or a "silly puppet."
Some of the increased recent caseload before the government agencies results from broader and more vigorous laws against discrimination that were enacted in the 1980's. Lawyers say that the public is gradually learning its rights under the laws, and complaints are rising.
CHIEF among the recent laws are the 1988 amendments to the Federal Fair Housing Act, which accorded disabled people and families with children the same level of protection that had previously been provided racial, ethnic and religious minorities. The amendments came two years after New York City broadened its own local laws to prohibit discrimination against lesbians and gays, who are not covered by Federal statutes.
The city laws were amended further in September. Landlords with two-family houses, who had previously been exempt from most of the local fair-housing regulations, are now fully covered. All landlords and real estate agents named in discrimination cases must now respond in 30 days, faster than previously required.
To detect and combat discrimination, government agencies and nonprofit groups have crafted a powerful weapon through the expanding use of "testers" or "auditors." Typically, teams including a white, black and Hispanic tester, all of them neatly groomed, polite and articulate, visit real estate offices, landlords or mortgage lenders separately to see if they are shown the same properties, offered the same terms and treated equally.
Although the tactic has been used for more than a decade, it has become far more widespread since the late 80's.
TESTERS were also used in all 3,800 visits conducted by the Urban Institute and Syracuse University in its study for the Federal Government. By conducting such a large study, and applying statistical analysis to the results, the researchers said, they were able to document the incidence of subtle forms of discrimination and distinguish random episodes from those that are systemic across the nation.
Among the findings were that 8 percent of the black and Hispanic applicants across the nation who responded to advertisements of homes for sale were told they were no longer available, even though the same homes were later offered to white applicants. Among those applying for rentals, 12 percent of the Hispanic and 15 percent of the black applicants experienced similar discrimination.
The study also assessed the prevalence of more subtle forms of discrimination. It found, for example, that 23.9 percent of the black applicants and 24.6 percent of the Hispanic applicants received less favorable treatment than whites when they applied for rental housing, as measured by such variables as the amount of the security deposit required and whether an application fee was required.
Testers have also been used extensively by the New York City Human Rights Commission, which says it conducted more than 10 tests, each involving a large group of realtors or landlords, in Midwood, Kings Highway, Canarsie, Bay Shore and other Brooklyn neighborhoods in the late 1980's.
Officials of the commission declined to release the results in detail, but said that the tests, and a resulting suit, led to the court order against the Fillmore agency in Canarsie that prohibits it from racial steering. The commission said it is now conducting widespread testing of rental and sales practices in several neighborhoods, but it declined to say where.
One case that demonstrates the effectiveness of using testers in gathering evidence against an individual landlord is the one involving Mr. Turner and Ms. Friedman.
According to the court record, the couple said they responded to an advertisement in The Times for the apartment in October 1988 and made an appointment with Joan Green, who was then its tenant and was planning to move. After they inspected the apartment and decided they wanted it, they were repeatedly blocked by the landlord, Louis Schwartz, in their effort to sign a lease or even make out an application.
Despite repeated entreaties, in which Mr. Turner offered to pay two months' rent in advance and put down two months' additional rent as a security deposit, the court testimony showed, Mr. Schwartz continued to stall. A week after the couple's first visit to the building, the Human Rights Commission, which had been contacted by them, sent out testers to try to rent the apartment.
The testers, a white couple approximately the same age as Mr. Turner and Ms. Friedman, told Mr. Schwartz they had an 11-year-old son. They were offered the apartment. When Mr. Schwartz produced a lease for them to sign, they produced a subpoena for him to appear in court.
In his defense, Mr. Schwartz told the Human Rights Commission that he had not taken a rental application from Mr. Turner and Ms. Friedman because it was his policy not to use them. He also testified, according to the court record, that he did not accept security deposits in advance.

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles

 BODY:

GLASNOST BALLET
The First International Glasnost Ballet will perform this evening at 7:30 in the Shubert Theater in New Haven. Artists from the Bolshoi Ballet of Moscow, the Kirov Ballet of St. Petersburg, and the National Ballet of Prague, cohered into a new company, will dance excerpts from "Giselle," "Swan Lake," "Raymonda" and other classics. Following this performance the company will embark on a tour of 50 cities across the country. 
 Ticket prices range from $20.50 to $50, and dress circle seats at $100 include a post-performance champagne reception. Call the box office, 562-5666, for reservations.
 
MOM-STYLE COOKING
 Another first taking place in Hartford Friday through next Sunday is the First Great American Meat Loaf Contest, tapping into current interest in economical food and nostalgia for mom's cooking. The event will also benefit Hartford's Foodshare food bank; visitors are asked to bring donations of canned goods.
Professional chefs from the area will cook their specialty meat loaves for two public taste-offs and judgings Friday and Saturday from 11:30 A.M. to 2 P.M. in the Center Court of the Civic Center. Admission will cost $1 or a donation of canned goods.
Saturday night at 8 P.M. a party will begin in the Skywalk Restaurant on the Civic Center's second floor for which the admission charge will be $35. Included in the price are comestibles of the 60's: pigs-in-blankets, cheese and crackers, and fluffernutter sandwiches. The main course will be meat loaf with mashed potatoes and green beans, or chicken a la king. Videos of the 60's, dancing, memorabilia exhibitions and Hula Hooping will be among the many diversions provided in four party rooms.
On Sunday from 10 to 6 the Skywalk area will be given over to meat loaf tastings, art, poster and memorabilia exhibitions and videos. Admission will be $6, $4 for children and free for children under 5.
 
PAINTINGS ON DISPLAY
 William McCloy's paintings, on view at the Slater Memorial Museum in Norwich through Nov. 24, reflect the powerful influence of John Steuart Curry, whom he served as an assistant on major murals. Mr. McCloy's massive figures with meticulously drawn musculature and mythic faces, while reminiscent of Curry, are distinctive and arresting in their own right. The pieces on exhibition are portraits, self-portraits, still lifes and social commentary.
After a long career as an art teacher in several universities around the country Mr. McCloy retired from his last post as chairman of the art department at Connecticut College in 1978. He will give a talk about his work Wednesday at 5:30 in the Lyman Allyn Museum of Connecticut College, 625 Williams Street, New London. Admission is free.
The gallery, on the campus of Norwich Free Academy, is open free of charge weekdays from 9 to 4, and weekends from 1 to 4.
 
HOUSATONIC BENEFIT
 Advance reservations are required for the Housatonic Valley Association's auction next Sunday at the Litchfield Inn. The highest bidder will win six days and five nights in the designer Diane von Furstenberg's apartment on the Left Bank in Paris.
Other prizes include a story hour for children presided over by Meryl Streep and a tour of NBC with Tom Brokaw. Among items to be auctioned is a set of 10 handpainted nesting dolls from Russia. Proceeds will aid the association programs to protect the Housatonic River and its watershed.
The festivites, including a champagne reception, begin at 2 P.M., and tickets are $25. A patron's brunch is available at 1 P.M. for an all-inclusive fee of $100. Call 672-6678 for more information.
 
TURKEY TIME
 Talking turkey is Rick Rodgers's forte. On Friday, from 7 to 10 P.M. he will conduct a cooking workshop at the Silo in New Milford that is based on his book, "The Turkey Cookbook."
Thanksgiving and any dinner will be enriched by his recipes for a meal consisting of Creole shrimp spread on herbed toast, three-mushroom bisque with port and tarragon, roast turkey with wild rice, pecan and cranberry stuffing, green beans with pancetta and rosemary, and Drambuie gingerbread with pumpkin cream. The fee is $50. Call 355-0300 for reservations.
 
ARCHITECTS' VALUE
 Those who can, buy; those who can't or don't want to, renovate. And David E. Austin, partner in the Southport architectural firm of Austin Patterson Associates, said those who renovate without hiring an architect do so at their peril.
"Why Hire an Architect?" is the subject of a talk he will give on Friday from 9:45 to 11:30 A.M. at the Darien Community Association, 274 Middlesex Road. He will discuss the various functions that an architect performs on a renovation, and how an architect can save the owner thousands of dollars and inestimable grief. His lecture will be accompanied by slides, and admission will be $2. Call 655-9050 for more information.
 
AFFIRMATIVE ACTION
 Pressures on black people in the professions are to be discussed by Stephen L. Carter tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. in Madison. His new book, "Reflections of an Affirmative Action Baby," forms the basis for his talk, which will cover his successes and his frustrations, the benefits and costs of affirmative action to him personally, and the divisions over the issue among black Americans.
Mr. Carter is a professor of law at Yale and he will speak at R. J. Julia Booksellers Ltd., 768 Post Road. Admission is free but reservations are required. Call 245-3959.
 
REFORMATION MUSIC
 The Brass Ring Quintet, the Bethesda Festival Chorus, a 17-piece orchestra and soloists will perform a program of music from the Reformation today at 7:30 P.M. in the Bethesda Lutheran Church, 305 St. Ronan Street, New Haven. It is the first in a series of concerts planned by the newly formed concert choir, and it includes works by Bach and Heinrich Scheutz. The Brass Ring, formed a decade ago by Yale music students, is currently in residence at the Hartt School of Music at the University of Hartford.
Admission will be by donation, and proceeds will benefit Columbus House, a shelter for homeless men in New Haven. Call 787-2346 for more information.

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
Rising Vacancy Rate Troubles Westport

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
ON Saturday afternoons the Jaguars and BMW's cruise Westport's busy Main Street, and seemingly recession-proof shoppers browse through Barney's, Laura Ashley and dozens of chic specialty shops where rents have retained their lofty levels of around $55 a square foot.
But along the Post Road a different story unfolds, a tale of empty stores and failing shopping plazas. 
 "It's a two-tiered system," said Marc Nevas, a commercial real estate agent. "Away from Main Street we have around 40 stores vacant compared to 12 in past years."
Far worse off is the office market: 40 percent of office space scattered around town -- 800,000 out of a total of 2.4 million square feet -- is empty. The vacancy rate is the highest in Fairfield County.
"We've never done anything to attract business," said Lois Schine, a Westport resident for 40 years and president of the local Chamber of Commerce. "We have always been a residential community. The quality of life is what brought companies here."
That kind of thinking, while still prevalent in some quarters, is challenged by the realization that prolonged commercial stagnation can lead to higher residential taxes. At a time when even affluent homeowners are economizing, residential property already is heavily taxed. Only 21.5 percent of the communty's taxable property is commercial, the rest is residential.
"Homeowners will not be affected until 1995," said Peter Wolgast, executive assistant to the First Selectman, "when a revaluation takes place. If we still have significant commercial property vacant, it will have a much lower value and therefore lower assessment. That will put a heavier burden on residences."
An effort to determine public support for filling empty offices was made by the Chamber of Commerce last month through a survey done by the Westport office of Yankelovich Clancy Shulman. It indicated that the tax mix could shift by 1995 to 84 percent residental and 17 percent commercial. A typical $500,000 home taxed currently at $5,219 could pay $7,793 by 1996, allowing for inflation and adjustments in assessments.
Mailed to 3,000 households with registered voters, the survey drew 1,000 responses. It contained statistics tracing a rise in commercial vacancies from 22 percent in 1987 to 40 percent, or 16 percentage points above the county average. Average office rents declined from $29.92 in 1987 to $18.21, and property values dropped from $200 a square foot to $93. In 1986, 21 buildings were sold; so far this year, three have been sold.
While 70 percent of the respondents supported the recruitment of businesses to fill vacancies, the absence of specific proposals for doing so generated some skepticism. "We are suffering from the same economic malaise that has beset the entire country," said the First Selectman, Douglas Wood. "I don't think we should try to predict four years into the future. The chamber survey did not ask whose problem it is, nor did it lead to any conclusions about what should be done."
THE town is receptive to business, he emphasized, but he added that "we will not offer financial incentives and we have no plans for any kind of tax abatement," a policy echoed by Ms. Schine at the Chamber of Commerce.
"People we surveyed want the tax base broadened by encouraging businesses to fill up the empty space," she said. "They are not willing to pay increased taxes or put up with reduced services resulting from buildings remaining empty."
The survey also created apprehension among those who believe that it paves the way for commercial tax breaks that would increase taxes for homeowners and encourage future development. Sidney Kramer, a lawyer who is president of a group called Save Westport, said, "We have been fighting commercialization for 10 years, and there is still plenty of room to do a lot of damage."
While town zoning has tightened to restrict commercial development mostly to the Post Road, an additional 280,000 square feet could be built. "The purpose of the survey," Mr. Kramer said, "was to ask for a tax break, to allow the chamber to state that public opinion favors concessions to entice businesses into town. We are overbuilt by 40 percent. That's the developers' problem, and the alternative to higher taxes is to lower rentals at the landlord's expense."
A shrunken daily work force has many retailers feeling threatened. Robert Hertzel, owner of Klein's Stationery on Main Street and president of the Downtown Merchants Association, complains that his office supply business has gone down by 20 to 30 percent in the last four years.
"There are fewer people coming into Westport," he said. "The barbers have fewer customers and there are fewer patrons in the restaurants. Fewer houses are being sold." He estimates that the number of employees coming into town weekdays has declined by 3,000 in the last four years.
COMPARED to the major office centers of Stamford, Norwalk and Greenwich, Westport's commercial market is viewed by many realtors as boutique in style.
"It's attractive only to smaller firms," said Al Remsen, executive vice president of William Pitt Real Estate in Stamford. "The typical corporate office tenant shies away from that type of location in favor of a full service office setup."
The 385,000-square-foot Stauffer complex on 54 acres off Exit 18 of Interstate 95 was vacant for three years, badly skewing Westport's vacancy rate. Last month leases were signed for 33,000 square feet by American International Group, a New York reinsurer, and for 113,000 square feet by Phibro Energy of Greenwich, a crude-oil trader. That will drop the vacancy rate to 34 percent.
Another positive sign is the impending renovation of an empty 36,000-square-foot building at 55 Post Road West. Stuart Longman, head of the DLM Construction Company in Norwalk, bought it in June from Mutual of New York for $3 million, a bargain at under $85 a square foot.
A block from Main Street, it is "on a site comparable to Fifth Avenue and 57th Street," Mr. Longman said. A skylighted atrium, a granite and onyx lobby and a new brick exterior in keeping with surrounding buildings are planned.
"We will make it into a triple-A building and rent it at $14 a foot, the bottom of the Westport scale," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The 36,000-square-foot office building before the renovation. (Alan Wanzenberg, Architect )
 
Drawing: Rendering of 55 Post Road West after renovation in Westport, Conn. (Alan Wanzenberg, Architect)

HEADLINE: Florio Counterattack Carries Risks

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
GOV. JIM FLORIO'S name isn't on the ballot in Tuesday's legislative elections, but if there were any doubts about his importance to the outcome of the voting, the Governor cleared them up during the last two weeks by joining the campaign debate.
The Governor's $2.8 billion tax program, enacted last year, has angered voters and raised the hopes of the Legislature's Republican minority, which is looking to wrest control of the State Senate and the Assembly from the Democrats for the first time in 20 years. Democrats currently have a 23-to-17 majority in the Senate and a 43-to-37 edge in the Assembly. 
 Since only Democrats voted for Mr. Florio's program, Republican candidates have been running under their party's banner, talking about the tax package and frequently mentioning the Governor by name. Many Democrats are running without their party's label and act as if they have never heard of taxes or anyone named Florio.
His aides deny that the Governor is angry about the way the campaign has played out, saying he understands the game of politics. But Mr. Florio has directed some of his sharpest comments at those Democrats who are trying to win election by distancing themselves from the decisions they made a few months ago.
In a speech at a Mercer County Democratic fund-raising event, the Governor told the Democrats to "get off their knees" and become "javelin throwers instead of javelin catchers." Mr. Florio pushed for a defense of his tax program, which was enacted in response to a growing budget deficit and which provided money for property tax relief and school aid.
Last week in Essex County, Mr. Florio said the Democrats were in danger of changing the party's symbol from a donkey to a chameleon by their apparent eagerness to look and sound like their Republican opponents.
The Governor told 800 Democrats who attended the county organization's annual pre-election rally that people who were suffering in the current recession should "send a message" to President Bush by voting against Republicans on Tuesday. He also pictured the Republicans as a party that encouraged bigotry by accepting David Duke, a former Ku Klux Klan leader and a candidate for governor of Louisiana, as a member.
Mr. Floro's decision to step into the campaign so aggressively at a time when Democratic candidates were trying to avoid having to defend his, and their, program carries a certain amount of political risk, but it also changed the tenor of the campaign and took away the Republican advantage of being on the attack with no one firing back.
Stephen A. Salmore, professor of political science at Rutgers University and a Republican consultant, was delighted by Mr. Florio's decision. "I'd like to give him money to go on television," Mr. Salmore said.
But, while he said he believed that the Governor's lack of popularity would not enable him to rally his party's candidates in the election, Mr. Salmore said that "to try and write his political obituary would be ridiculous." Mr. Florio's term is not up until 1993 and, Mr. Salmore said, "Two years is a long, long time."
The members of the Legislature will be on the ballot in 1993 with the Governor, and if Republicans capture control on Tuesday, they, as well as Mr. Florio, will have to tell the voters what they have done. "Florio's a counterpuncher, and he'll have the Republicans to do battle with," Mr. Salmore said. "Right now he has no one to battle with."
Richard W. Roper, executive director of the Council on New Jersey Affairs at Princeton University, said Mr. Florio had made the right decision to stand up for his programs. "He doesn't have anything to lose," Mr. Roper said. "The Democrats aren't helped by being quiet since the public holds them largely responsible for what has happened anyway."
Mr. Roper said the public's anger over the tax program has stood in the way thus far of any broad acceptance of the need for new tax revenue. But, as time passes and the financial problems New Jersey faced last year are showing up elsewhere, Mr. Roper said, there is a chance for a greater level of understanding.
"Clearly, New Jersey is not alone in that boat, and fiscal problems are showing up in other states in the Northeast and around the country," he said. "It's likely that the public will conclude at some point that while the action taken by the administration was something they did not prefer, it may have been necessary."
 
'Typical Florio Aggressive Move'
 Jeff Michaels, executive director of the Republican State Committee, said Mr. Florio's decision to step out in front on the tax issue when most members of his party were running from it "is a typical Florio aggressive move that appears to be timed to try to reverse the momentum of our campaign."
Before he suddenly entered the fray, the Governor's recent public appearances had been devoted to publicizing law-enforcement initiatives, like promoting the rights of crime victims, Mr. Michaels said, indicating that Mr. Florio had been following advice to divert the public's attention from the tax issue.
Steve DeMicco, executive director of the Democratic State Committee, said the Governor was simply "standing up for something he feels very strongly about." He said Mr. Florio had obviously wanted Democrats to do what some candidates had already begun to do: talk about the benefits of the programs financed by the increases.
"I feel fine having the Governor reminding people of the benefits of the program," Mr. DeMicco said. "Something might happen from it, and it can only be good."
Jon Shure, Mr. Florio's spokesman, said, "The Governor felt the need to communicate strongly with the public about the reasons for the program." Mr. Shure said Mr. Florio believed that if the public wanted to elect Republicans it would do so without voting for Democrats who were trying to look like Republicans.
"This isn't about tax votes, since Republicans voted for tax increases in the 1980's," Mr. Shure said. "They saw the same problems we did in the 1990's, but they made a political decision to say to the Democrats, 'You provide every vote for the taxes' and we'll run against them." Thus far the Republicans have been getting "a free ride" by not being forced to say how they would have met the state's fiscal problems, he said.
 
Republican Attack on Tax Program
 The Republicans have been saying that the Governor's tax program was the wrong solution to a problem created in large part by the recession and that it has exacerbated the economic downturn by creating higher unemployment and business failures. The Republicans have promised to roll back the state sales tax to 6 cents from the 7 cents it was pegged at in the Governor's program and to make up the $500 million that the rollback would cost by cutting spending.
The Democrats argue that such economies do not exist and point out that a looming budget deficit next year makes the Republican promises unrealistic.
Both parties have concentrated much of their spending in 7 of the 40 state legislative districts where the resignations of incumbent lawmakers, a realignment dictated by the 1990 census or demographic changes have changed once strong districts for either party into virtually open seats.
 
Closely Watched Races
 Among the most closely watched races are those in the Fourth District in Camden County and some surrounding towns, where Senator Daniel J. Dalton, the Senate majority leader, decided not to seek re-election; the 10th District, chiefly in Ocean County, represented for 18 years by Senator John F. Russo, a former Senate president and Democratic gubernatorial candidate, who also decided to retire, and the 14th District in Mercer County, where Senator Francis J. McManimon, a 20-year Democratic veteran of the Legislature, the last 10 years in the Senate, is facing a strong challenge.
Others are the 13th District in Monmouth County, where Senator Richard Van Wagner, a Democratic Senator since 1983 and an Assemblyman for 10 years before that, decided not to seek another term, and the 18th District in Middlesex, where the Democratic incumbent, Senator Thomas H. Paterniti, was defeated in the Democratic primary in June.
Also, the 30th District, a new central New Jersey district created to reflect population changes noted in the census, and the 38th District in Bergen County, where the Democratic incumbent, Senator Paul J. Contillo, who has served six years in the Assembly and eight in the Senate, is campaigning on his refusal to vote for Mr. Florio's tax program.
Joan M. Haberle, the New Jersey Secretary of State, estimates that 48 percent of the state's 3,677,766 voters will go to the polls on Tuesday. This translates into a turnout of 1,765,326 voters.

HEADLINE: More Towns Regulating Yard Sales

BYLINE: By ALBERT J. PARISI

 BODY:
IN communities throughout the state, garage and yard sales are so numerous that traffic comes to a halt and sidewalks take on the appearance of a bazaar, with knickknacks, haggling customers and, for the more industrious, even refreshments.
But in recent years a growing number of municipalities have begun to regulate or to enforce existing regulations on such sales. The new regulations take a variety of approaches, often in combination with one another. Some require permits, others limit the number of sales a homeowner can hold in a year and still others restrict how many days they may last. 
 Officials say the new emphasis on regulation and enforcement is less a matter of raising revenue for municipalities than an attempt to keep residents from turning yard sales into a sideline business that creates hardships for neighbors.
"In recent years, because of the popularity of garage sales due to recessionary economic times, we've seen many towns adding to or dusting off existing ordinances and vigorously enforcing them," said William G. Dressel Jr., assistant executive director and chief lobbyist for the New Jersey State League of Municipalities. The league is a Trenton-based nonprofit lobbying agency that represents 562 of the state's 567 cities and towns.
Mr. Dressel said the league had monitored some 50 towns where regulations were currently in place.
"The pressure is on many towns to get after those who are using garage sales as a means of carrying on an unreported business, and the best tool at a municipality's disposal to protect its safety concerns are such regulations," whether extensive or minute, he said.
Valerie G. Thompson, the clerk of Highland Park Borough in Middlesex County, offered an explanation for the tougher stance on yard sales that was also expressed by other officials. "Here there was a great concern that it was getting out of hand and that something needed to be done,"she said.
She said some people were "taking advantage of the popularity of garage sales" and holding them on weekends regularly, prompting complaints from neighbors who were fearful of either strangers' roving the neighborhood or traffic congestion. The borough limits households to no more than two garage sales a year, and each requires a permit with an accompanying $10 fee.
 
Blocking of Driveways Prohibited
 Ms. Thompson said applicants were responsible for making certain that sidewalks and neighbors' driveways were not blocked by those attending the sales. 
"We strictly enforce it to the extent that if a police officer sees the sale going on, he'll ask to see their permit," she said. "If they don't have one, we'll ask that they get one and pay the fee after the fact. You have to allow for a little leeway."
Noncompliance is punishable by fines ranging from $25 to $100 or 10 days in jail.
In Passaic, permits were adopted for similar reasons. "It just got to the point where we were getting so many complaints that we needed to have some kind of regulations," said Joan A. Koterba, the assistant city clerk.
The city generates little in permit fees; licenses are $5 an applicant, with a surcharge of $2 a person for those contributing items to a sale who are not family members. Passaic's main thrust in the passage of the 1985 permit law "was to get a handle on those who wanted to turn garage sales into an ongoing business," Ms. Koterba said.
In Passaic, residents are limited to two sales a year and are not permitted to post sale signs on utility poles or trees other than those on their own property. Even at that, they must remove such signs within 48 hours of the sale's end.
In Princeton Borough, residents are forbidden to post signs on utility poles, and signs put on trees must be promptly removed at the completion of the sale.
In Hackensack, the Bergen County seat, yard sales have become a common sight from the early spring through late fall for those seeking to clear out basements and attics of duplicate anniversary presents or old and worn items taking up needed space. Eugene Duffy, the city's director of community affairs, said that permits for garage sales were not required but that city ordinances limited residents to no more than one garage sale a year.
 
'Kind of Tough to Enforce'
 "It's kind of tough to enforce, and we've really had no need over the years," Mr. Duffy said. "If we charge, say, $15 a permit per sale, then we have to assign someone in City Hall to keep track of it all, pull that person away from other duties and who knows what else."
He said that in recent years a "few complaints have been raised" by neighbors against neighbors over repetitive sales and "we've had to have a word with people to remind them that there is a law."
"The most complaints we've gotten really concern traffic tieups when your next-door neighbor holds a sale and someone winds up parking and blocking your driveway," Mr. Duffy said. Sometimes, he said, those who complain hold a garage sale the next week to "get even."
In some towns, permits are viewed as a deterrent to a neighborhood's taking on the character of a flea market.
In Hopewell Borough, in Mercer County, local officials became concerned in 1986 when some families began holding garage sales regularly on weekends.
"We noticed that a few people would buy stuff in bulk at other garage sales and then pretend that they were holding their own yard sale," said Hilary R. Fortenbaugh, the borough clerk. "A yard sale is one thing; a private business is another."
 
Limit of Two Sales a Year
 She said the borough passed a law requiring a $15 permit and a limit of two sales a year for a family. "For the most part, it solved the problem," she said.
But some of the borough's 1,968 residents chose to hold sales without permits because they felt the fee was too high, she said. Since enforcement might have been difficult at best and stood the chance of creating animosity among neighbors, "we chose to keep the limit and lower the fee to $3 for the first sale and $5 for the second," Ms. Fortenbaugh said.
Since the fee was reduced in 1989, "we're issuing more permits than ever and people are actually paying for them instead of ignoring them," she said. The money from the fees, she said, is put into the borough's general fund.
"If we make $100 a year, that's a lot," she said.
While the state's Office of Taxation is clearly aware of the concerns that have prompted permit requirements, it is bound to the understanding that garage sales are run under a tax-exempt status known as "casual sales."
"Receipts for casual sales by law are tax exempt and it is assumed that garage sales" are run occasionally and not as an ongoing business, said Kenneth D. Munn, an office spokesman. "That's not to say that if someone privately sells a car or a boat that it's not taxable, but garage sales are not considered in the same category as, say, a vendor in a flea market who has a permanent space on a regular basis and must be registered to collect sales taxes."
 
An Annual Townwide Sale
 Instead of regulation, officials in New Milford, a middle-class Bergen County community of 16,000, have favored a different tack on garage sales. They have unofficially approved that residents take part in a once-a-year, townwide lawn sale that is sponsored by a local charitable group. The event involves hundreds of families throughout the town.
Dianne Rothweiler, the borough clerk, said there had been few or no complaints in recent years of any one family's holding multiple sales or taking advantage of the lack of regulations.
Some merchants who have benefited from the increase in yard sales are less than enthusiastic about increased regulation.
Elliott Hulick of Dayton, who runs an antiques business in town, says permits are nothing more than a municipality's capitalizing on a family's effort to generate added income.
"Fees and permits are ridiculous, and as far as I'm concerned, it's just the town's way of holding out its hand and demanding a piece of the action," he said. "We pay enough taxes, whether we live here or do business here. To demand more is absurd."
 
Keeping the 'Glut' Down
 But David Dutch of Hopewell, who also operates an antiques shop, says permits are a "good idea which I have no problem with because it keeps the glut down in the area when it comes to these kinds of sales."
He said an occasional yard sale of his merchandise in front of his home enabled him to move merchandise that might not get the same kind of exposure in his shop.
"People are looking for bargains and I price them accordingly; otherwise I'd need a warehouse to store stuff that might accumulate," he said.
Regulation or no, Ulrich C. Knoepflmacher, a professor of English literature at Princeton University who is an avid garage sale shopper, said the lure of the sales would continue to be the occasional bargain, particularly in tough economic times.
"A while back at a sale, I found a Victorian-style china bowl at a wonderful price, still in its original box," he said. "It looked like the owner had gotten it as a Christmas gift and left it unopened, so for a few dollars someone got rid of some clutter and I got a great deal."

HEADLINE: CRAFTS;
Provocative Quilts Stand Out in a Dignified Show

BYLINE: By BETTY FREUDENHEIM

DATELINE: MORRISTOWN

 BODY:
THE craft exhibition of the New Jersey Arts Annual looks spectacular in the spacious new gallery of the Morris Museum. At last, individual works are given ample room. Strong pieces do not intrude on the message or style of subtler works; some large works have an entire wall to themselves.
There is a strength and dignity to this show that should silence forever that tired old question, "Is it art or is it craft?" Who cares about picayune semantics? Here are artistic expressions in wood, fiber, metal, glass or clay, well made and well displayed. 
 In a time of economic uncertainties, it is reassuring to find harmonies in the crafts of the 90's. Some set forth shapes and hues adopted from nature. Other works are rendered in pure black and white, using this stark contrast to emphasize patterns rather than to dazzle the eye.
And the brightly colored items no longer feature those glaring Day-Glo tones that were so common in the 80's. Here vivid coloration sings out with joy, while muted tones express deeper chords.
The artists in the show all live or work in New Jersey. A juror selected work by 39 craft artists; 26 others were invited to participate. Michael W. Monroe, curator in charge at the Renwick Gallery of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, was the juror.
"The works that I have included are ones that have strong visual qualities combined with the technical skills necessary to the realization of those creative ideas," he said. "The exhibition reflects a wide diversity of expressions."
How true. Only the specified geographic requirements make this a regional show. There are no set styles or techniques to identify local origins.
The quilts are truly provocative. Leah Kaspar's "Cathedral" has the lyricism of a stained-glass window at Chartres. The underlying architectural structure is there, but instead of leaded lines and Gothic glass in vivid hues of scarlet or blue, this Burlington artist has stitched together bits of cloth that were printed with violet and mossy green patterns. Somehow this translation from one medium to another is successful. Her hues present the quiet luminosity of a church window on a misty day.
The eight-pointed stars in "Shades of Night" echo a traditional quilt pattern, but Judy Dales of Boonton Township has turned the regular repeat into a sparkling sky. Her stars become scintillating explosions of color, like fireworks sending out particles of brilliant lights.
"Chromium Web," by Merrill Mason of Jersey City, is composed of square-cut pieces of cloth, sewn together in checkerboard fashion. The seams are barely visible because the fabric is covered with phototransfers that could have come from black-and-white snapshots of a trash dump.
The overall pattern is as helter-skelter as its source. Here and there, lines of a Venetian blind or round cooking pots provide rhythmic repeats. Textures predominate in the broken bits of steel, rags and a broken umbrella. Surprisingly, the artist added small green patches woven with metallic threads. They introduce the only color on this quilt.
"Memoirs of Certain Mountains," a quilt by Rita Erickson of Montclair, looks like a Japanese woodblock print of a volcano with lava flowing down one side and fiery smoke issuing from the top. The exact motif recurs nine times in regimented rows. Close examination reveals tiny blossoms on the pale green background and rocky hillsides. What an intriguing balance of precise design, flowery fabrics and implications of disaster.
A master potter, Albert Green of Westfield, is represented by a square platter, a tall jar and a tea bowl. His distinctive sea green glazes are crisscrossed with two or three calligraphic black lines. This work speaks of an Oriental approach that combines a meticulously planned creation with a touch of the unexpected. A seemingly casual drip of glaze or a few scattered dots unify all the other elements.
"Neck Pot," by Carol Townsend of Burlington, has the grace of a well-thrown pot, while its surface becomes an abstract desert scene. There are hints of a river's passing through mountains and deep ravines. At the top, encircling the neck, are the dark clouds of an impending storm. Broad swaths of gold may be reflected light on the still waters.
Sy Shames's porcelain vessel is paper thin and pure white. The gently undulating curves suggest a female torso: a breast, maybe two, perhaps the whole rib cage. His works have subtle curves, but his hints are few. This Basking Ridge artist turns vessels into sculpture. If they were used to contain bouquets of flowers, the work would take on a decidedly surrealistic air.
"Chrysalis," by Steven B. Levine of Dayton, is named after the pupa stage of a butterfly, but the shape also parallels the sleek lines of a jet airliner. This work is an amalgam of walnut and cherry blocks, turned on a lathe; the surface has a sensuously smooth polish. How to display a pointed cylinder so that it maintains its upward thrust? Mr. Levine's solution was a wooden stand reminiscent of an old-fashioned umbrella holder.
Carol Rosen of Califon creates assemblages from bits of wood that formerly served as parts of machines or tools. Her "Gestural Construction VII" is a disk with nail holes, scratches and screws still intact. These details add to rather than distract from the peppered surface. Hung alone on a stark white wall, the piece seems to revolve in place with its inner circles suggesting a secondary turning motion.
Perhaps Renaissance nobles once sported daggers in the shape of Jan Palombo's small pins. The three by this Paterson jewelry maker are gold and silver; the "handles" are encrusted with bright stones.
"House Key Pin," by Marjorie Simon of Highland Park, mocks practical key chains. Her "keys" take the forms of miniature monoliths and Noguchi-like sculptures. The holder looks like a Viking cap with a keyhole smack in the center. Don't try to figure out the symbolism; it's fun to wear jewelry that invites questions.
Overcrowded display cases are the one shortcoming of this show. One contains 13 objects, including jewelry and other media juxtaposed with three long wooden "Strumstick" instruments by Bob McNally of Rockaway. This confused melange conflicts with the delicate intimacy of "Pine Barrens Botanical" by a Mantua artist, Paul Stankard. In the center of his small glass block floats a miniature re-creation of a botanically correct wild plant, complete with blooms and roots.
The show runs through Nov. 24. The Morris Museum, at 6 Normandy Heights Road in Morristown, is open Monday through Saturday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and Sunday from 1 to 5 P.M. Admission is $2 for adults and $1 for children and the elderly.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
A British Play Called ECC Group

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
Andrew H. Teare, the group chief executive of Britain's ECC Group, is a solid kind of gentleman, a burly veteran of the building materials industry. Since taking over in 1990 at the flabby ECC, formerly English China Clays, he has put the company through a rigorous slimming that caught the eye of the investing community. The stock of ECC, the world's largest producer of kaolin, the white clay used to coat and brighten paper, has risen 38 percent since the beginning of the year.
Mr. Teare won many hearts after he arrived from the Rugby Group with his move to keep ECC's dividend steady, using both savings from the restructuring and a reduction in capital spending. He also promised, despite a fall in demand, not to cut prices. In paper coatings and fillers, ECC seems to have the product quality and market dominance to hold or push up prices. 
 He has cut employment, especially in England, where he said ECC "was run on Colonial lines." He has shed unprofitable divisions and is phasing the company out of the housing business. ECC is now concentrating on clay and other industrial minerals with a minor in building materials.
The question is whether the stock has any growth left in it, in light of the doubts about the economic recovery in the United States and the slowdowns in Europe and Japan, all leading markets for ECC.
The stock closed on Friday at 480 pence in London and at $24.50 for its American depository receipt, which represents three ordinary shares and which is traded over the counter. Those prices are just 100 pence and $4 below the company's record highs.
Some analysts in both England and the United States are still enamored with ECC and Mr. Teare's leadership. They see a company that has cut costs and is ready to rebound when sales pick up with the economy. Even some who would not buy the stock now still applaud the changes in structure and culture at ECC and the savvy purchase of the Georgia Kaolin Company last year for $353 million.
But these analysts fear that the stock's high price, combined with a uncertain outlook for paper and advertising and the dismal state of construction, puts the company off limits for now. Advertisers are major users of the paper ECC coats with clay from Cornwall and Georgia.
The analysts are worried that price increases for kaolin and other paper-coating materials will be delayed further into 1992 or 1993, a possibility even some of those buying ECC acknowledge. With the recession and the cost of restructuring, ECC's earnings per share have plummeted two-thirds and even optimists do not expect ECC to retake those heights before 1993.
"We are still buyers both short- and long-term," said David Taylor of Robert Fleming Securities in London. "But it is harder to suggest to people that the stock is going to put on another pound."
Donald A. Pattison, an analyst at C. J. Lawrence in New York, countered: "The paper industry business here and abroad stinks. They are a long way from showing record earnings again."
ECC can be an interesting opportunity for American investors. It is a foreign stock, which adds diversity to a portfolio. But it is also a company with a significant stake in the United States with its purchase of Georgia Kaolin. The company's production of kaolin is now about 60 percent in Britain and 40 percent in the United States. "Within 10 years it will be 40-60," Mr. Teare said. "We are turning this more and more into an American-based company."
But in the United States the A.D.R. is very thinly traded. There are days when there are no trades, and this means it can be difficult and expensive to trade. The A.D.R. has risen only 25 percent this year because the rally of the United States dollar relative to the British pound cut the gains.
The debate over the stock centers on the outlook for the economic recovery in Europe and the United States and the health of the paper and advertising industries. If one is confident about this outlook, then the company could close in on its former level of profitability in 1992.
But if the confidence is not there, then the stock may have had its run for now. If earnings fall short of the most optimistic projections, the price-to-earnings ratio is higher than the averages of the market as a whole and the industrial-materials sector. This makes other recovery-play stocks look more attractive.
Mr. Teare himself still expects the recovery but thinks it is six months off. "There is no real pattern to it at the moment," he said.
But this apparently has not dampened the enthusiasm for the stock. Even as the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, last week called the recovery here "demonstrably sluggish" and the October employment data showed more weakness, ECC's stock in London and the A.D.R. in New York both rose about 5 percent.
Richard Rae of Hoare Govett in London is a fan of the stock for both the short and long term. But he does concede that if ECC jumped to 510 pence a share in a hurry, he "would not be surprised to see a lot of sellers" taking profits.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
For the Bond Market, Heaven Can Wait

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:
As Dante saw it, purgatory was no vacation spot. There, the greedy were consigned to a mountain ledge, with "weeping people everywhere, lying outstretched and face-down on the ground."
Many lost souls are paying a price for the avarice of the 1980's. No one -- not the banks, the Government or the Federal Reserve -- is able to recharge the economy. A fading recovery and Fed easing have failed to make long-term capital much cheaper, an essential for strong growth. But many bond investors and analysts are optimistic that this will happen, ignoring the sizeable risks. 
 Last week, the Fed's bard, Alan Greenspan, tried talking long-term rates down. He chose his own poetic image, "a 50-mile-an-hour head wind," to decry bank stinginess and account for an economy that is going nowhere. The voracious credit demands of the financially prostrate Government help explain why, even after the Fed nudged short-term rates down again on Wednesday, the yield on 30-year Treasuries has gone to 7.93 on Friday from 7.79 percent on Oct. 1.
And who is buying the Treasury's wares these days? The bankers. Of $194.4 billion in Treasury borrowing from January through September, the banks bought about a third, perhaps double the typical ratio. Uncle Sam, it seems, is practically the only guy who can satisfy the banks' flinty credit committees.
Individual investors are also rushing into bonds, with brokerage firms coaxing them to seek higher yields than C.D.'s or money market funds offer.
But bond buyers are jittery. Two weeks ago, mere talk of tax cuts, potentially inflationary, immediately added 30 basis points to yields.
And bond investors are paying more to hedge their positions. Over the last two weeks, options prices have reflected a 10 percent rise in the expected volatility of 30-year bond yields through April.
Those ready to have a party any time yields slip below 8 percent forget what happened when a slowing economy brought the long bond below 7.6 percent in March 1987. "People were chasing yield without any insight into the downside of bonds," said Ian A. MacKinnon, who heads Vanguard's fixed-income funds. A flare-up of inflation propelled the rate to 8.7 percent a month later, as buyers stampeded into shorter maturities. "They all blew out the door at the first sign of a rise in rates," he said. The next significant drop in bond yields came in October, when the stock market crash made a recession seem certain. 
Now, lower interest rates are giving stock market investors the courage to ride the high, foaming surf of an expected recovery in earnings -- the same recovery they have been betting on since the winter. But now even some bond market bulls are beginning to fear that their slow- or no-growth case for lower interest rates conflicts with the case for a recovery strong enough to revive earnings. Souls in purgatory may be bound for paradise, but few know how soon.
