LENGTH: 2828 words

HEADLINE: Retailing's Wistful Christmas Dream

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
The 20-odd days between Thanksgiving and Christmas were once a magic time for America's retailers. Merchants could count on selling most of their goods at the full retail price and producing as much as half of their profits for the entire year. The pre-Christmas sale was anathema. Shoppers so improvident as to have waited until the last minute were punished with empty shelves. Absolutely no markdowns until December 26. And measured year to year -- with an occasional blip from a recession -- revenues marched ever upward, often posting double-digit growth.
It's been at least four years since retailers enjoyed such a traditional Christmas. Some in the industry contend the glory days ended back as far as '84. 
 Data are inconclusive about exactly when the problems began, but merchants are certain that their Christmas experience is growing steadily bleaker. This year will be no exception. In fact, it could be even worse because of a triple whammy: a short selling season, the dregs of a recession and a debt-ridden consumer.
The real pessimists say things may be even worse than that. Some merchants and retailing analysts have begun to wonder whether the very nature of Christmas as a commercial enterprise may be changing. If they are right, merchants of all stripes, particularly the big department stores, will have to alter their approach to the holidays in years to come. What changes might be involved, however, no one seems to know.
Retailing experts blame their woes on the confluence of two trends.
One is the changed mood of the 1990's, a sort of minimalist backlash to the excesses of the 1980's. Many people simply intend to spend less on gifts for the holidays, and studies of buying habits indicate this shift has been underway since at least 1989. If anything, consumer torpor could accelerate the trend this holiday season.
The other trend is the rise of the mass merchandisers, discounters and outlet stores. They have forced department stores to monkey with their pricing schemes, thus teaching buyers that there is no such thing as paying full price -- just wait and the item will soon be on sale.
 
Who Fills the Stockings?
 "It's not that consumers' stockings will be empty," said Philip Johnson, president of Leo J. Shapiro & Associates, a consumer research company based in Chicago. "They'll be filled by Wal-mart and Toys 'R Us instead of Bloomingdale's and Marshall Fields."
Patrick M. Dunne, who teaches retailing at Texas Tech University in Lubbock, says merchants have trained the consumer to expect sales every day. "So why should they expect anything different at Christmas?" he asks.
Carl Steidtmann, vice president and chief economist of Management Horizons Inc., a consulting firm in Columbus, Ohio, likens consumers' fondness for product promotions and markdowns to addictions in general. "It's very difficult to break them of that habit," he said. "Promotional activity is like a drug."
As consumers have learned to extend the price waiting game, the result in the last two or three years has been nervous merchants ever quicker to cave in on prices, enshrining the pre-Christmas sale as a means to entice consumers into the store before the last moment and persuade them to open their wallets. Last year, for example, Sears, Roebuck and Company began its traditional post-Christmas clearance sales in early December, forcing other merchants to slash their prices. And the year before, highly leveraged retailers, worried about cash flow and the need to service their debts, began cutting prices in late November.
"For the consumer, this only came to reinforce and more deeply instill the notion that they should expect discounting, early discounting and deep discounting," said Richard Curtin, director of the University of Michigan's Consumer Survey Research Center.
"It's possible that Christmas from now on will be like this, with lots and lots of sales," said Mr. Johnson of Shapiro & Associates. "And there's no reason for the consumer to think that's a bad thing -- they spend less money and still get what they want."
But something more than mere bargain hunting may be afoot.
Alice Bird McCord, senior vice president of the National Retail Federation, a trade group in New York, sees a linkage between Christmas shopping changes and population shifts, such things as time constraints on the individual and the growth in the number of working women. But the most important factor, she said, is changing consumer values.
Shoppers are older and better informed, Ms. McCord said, and they're applying their knowledge and experience to purchasing. "They tend to be more practical. They are less easily convinced by promotional devices, and they are more likely to buy fewer, better quality items," she said. "The Christmases when you saw an item like a Pet Rock or something frivolous or outrageously expensive selling out are over."
A monthly study of consumer sentiment by Shapiro & Associates found that 44 percent of those surveyed in September said they planned to spend less on Christmas this year than last. By last month, the figure had risen to 47 percent. Although Shapiro & Associates won't release data from all their sentiment surveys, which run back to the early 80's, they say the Christmas spending sentiment trend has generally been bleak since 1989.
Some analysts think the American public's movement toward quality and value and a turning away from conspicuous consumption is related to the growing awareness of environmental issues and other concerns, like unemployment, corporate downsizing and an increasing focus on family rather than self.
"As it is in every business cycle, you're talking about an aversion to past values, in this case away from the flashy, Rodeo Drive, labels-as-status values of the 80's," said Isaac Lagnado, president of Tactical Retail Solutions, a New York consulting firm. "Skepticism as a value is getting to be very acceptable."
Analysts say the booming business cycle in the 80's masked the development of this new breed of consumer, which caught retailers unaware. Cynthia Cohen Turk, president of Marketplace 2000, a consulting firm in Coral Gables, Fla., said consumers will loosen their grip on their pocketbooks once the economy improves -- but not to the point they did in the 80's.
"This is a very discriminating consumer, and that is not going to change when the business cycle picks up again," Ms. Turk said. "They won't tolerate lousy service, old stores, and shoddy merchandise, no matter what it's price is."
Pleasing this new consumer at Christmastime has puzzled many retailers; some even confess to being bereft of bright ideas.
"You have so many people selling the same merchandise that price is almost the only thing that drives sales," said Frank Doroff, executive vice president and general merchandise manager of Bloomingdale's. "It becomes a matter of who has the cheaper price."
The extent this has become a problem for department stores is evident in a survey of 1,000 people by Tactical Retail Solutions. The firm found that 75 percent of those questioned felt department stores put high prices on merchandise just so they could mark them down and advertise a sale. And 80 percent said that although they might be unable to find the same merchandise in a discount store like Syms or Dress Barn, they nevertheless could find a satisfactory alternative at a lower price.
Such attitudes have caught department stores like Macy's, Nordstrom and Bloomingdale's between the high costs of offering ambiance, presentation, service and inventory and the necessity of competing with discounters. Many of these chains are still struggling under heavy debt loads they assumed in buyouts or to fend off takeovers. The unfortunate result, many retail analysts say, is that store executives have had to focus on the financial aspects of the business and neglected to cultivate its theatrical elements, which have traditionally driven retail operations, particularly at Christmas. Instead of striving to stock merchandise sold by no one else or generate clever promotions to draw shoppers, stores began relying on markdowns to generate cash flow.
But, paradoxically, though they aren't struggling under massive debt, discounters see plenty of difficulties ahead. Most, like K Mart and Toys 'R Us, are counting mostly on price and volume to save their Christmas season. Toys 'R Us, for example, is bringing out a catalogue for the first time this year, and it is filled with discount coupons worth $173. (To obtain one, a customer must visit the store.)
K Mart is placing its bets on cordless ratchets, drills and screwdrivers; home security devices, and in-line rollerskates (better known as Rollerblades), but the company will be happy with Christmas sales only "moderately better" than last year, said Orren F. Knauer, vice president for investor relations.
A few brave souls are experimenting with new approaches.
The Hartmarx Corporation, which operates Wallach's, Barrie Pace and Hart, Schaffner & Marx, among others, mailed a video Christmas catalogue to 150,000 of its best customers. The company hopes the video will stand out from the mass of catalogues in the mail and capture weary shoppers' attention.
"We think the real risk in our business is staying static," said John Eyler, chairman and chief executive of Hartmarx's specialty stores division.
Other retailers have sought to soften their image of pricey exclusivity. For the first time since its founding in 1978, the Sharper Image, which specializes in glitzy high-tech items, is stocking items costing less than $50. "What I realized was that we had tremendous foot traffic in the stores but most items were too expensive for the people coming in," said Richard Thalheimer, founder and chairman of the company. "So we went looking for innovative, unusual, fun items priced between $16 and $29."
Neiman Marcus began two years ago to devote some of its catalogue pages to gifts for less than $50 and less than $100. The strategy is to attract cost-conscious customers who might have thought Neiman's was out of their range.
Neiman's hasn't moved away from big ticket items, but some of the whimsical glamour is absent. The premier "his and her" item in their catalogue this year is not a Chinese junk or a pair of camels, as in the past. Instead, it is the civilian version of the military's LTV Hummer, the boxy vehicle used in the Persian Gulf war to replace the Jeep. The price: $50,000. Neiman executives are quick to point out the gift's utilitarian nature as a recreational vehicle.
"In the past, the more outrageous the idea for a his-and-hers gift was, the better," said Bernie Feiwus, president of Neiman Marcus's mail order division. "Utility wasn't part of the equation. This year it was."
But most merchants seem wary of making bold new efforts, preferring to rely on the tried and, until recently, true. Many will try to outdo one another with lavish window decorations, install a Santa Claus somewhere on the ground floor surrounded by fake snow and mount Christmas trees festooned with thousands of gilded ornaments and glimmering lights.
"I think the whole industry could probably use some innovation and creativity," said Mr. Doroff of Bloomingdale's. "The Christmas business has become so promotional that you don't focus on unique and different offerings because you can't afford to take markdowns on that sort of merchandise."
Many retailers and industry consultants admit to a lack of ideas about how to get the industry out of the box it has pushed itself into. Those that do have a prescription offer a straightforward approach: stick to your guns on price or else find a way to offer goods that no one else has and provide some other exclusivity, like selection or service or high quality. "Instead of giving the customer what he wants at the right price the first time, they give the customer something that may not be exactly what he wants -- maybe it's not the right size or the right color because they don't have it in stock -- but it's cheap," said Marvin J. Rothenberg, president of Marvin J. Rothenberg Inc., a retail consulting firm based in New Jersey.
"They fail to understand that these value-conscious customers are not just looking for low prices, that they'll pay full price as long as they have the goods they want."
But many of the large department stores now lack the financial stability to gamble on the exclusive merchandise that might become the next Cabbage Patch doll and rack up large profits -- but might equally well flop.
They also are reluctant to risk funds on deep inventories. Indeed, this year many stores are carrying tight inventories, hoping to reduce the need to take pre-Christmas markdowns if stock isn't moving fast enough. They have learned that once one store chain begins a pre-Christmas sale, the stampede is on. But reduced inventory, of course, further reduces the stores' ability to immediately offer a customer exactly what he wants -- at a higher price.
"What retailers need to do is get back to a more traditional pricing structure," said Ms. McCord of the National Retail Federation. "But once you've gotten on the sales train -- and we've been on it for a while now -- it's very, very hard to get off."
Even Mr. Curtin of the Consumer Survey Research Center, who is generally more optimistic about merchants' prospects than the merchants themselves, said an attempt to hold the line on holiday markdowns would most likely lead to a showdown with customers that few retailers have the fortitude to weather.
"It will only take one retailer in a region to break the ranks, and then the consumer will win," he said.
 
 
 
LEARNING A LITTLE DISCIPLINE
 Retailers are counting on lean inventories to save them from the markdown malady that has afflicted recent holiday selling seasons.
Federated Department Stores Inc., for example, plans to stage roughly the same number of discretionary promotions -- sales designed to build traffic in stores -- as it has in the last three Christmas seasons. But the company's president, James M. Zimmerman, warned that inventories are so tight that stores are likely to sell out of merchandise before markdowns are needed.
K Mart is also practicing inventory discipline, said Orren F. Knauer, vice president for investor relations, holding open options to buy merchandise from suppliers without actually committing itself to taking delivery.
"Inventory plans throughout the industry are so conservative that if sales go better than planned, they'll be sold out awhile before Christmas," said Daniel D. Barry, a retail analyst at Kidder, Peabody. "I think you'll see an unusually low level of markdowns."
Recent history, however, has demonstrated that tight inventories do not guarantee against panic sales. In the months before the 1986 holiday season, stores were also bragging about inventory control. But by Dec. 20, with few shoppers showing a willingness to spend, many stores started slashing prices. "Hopefully there will be a little better discipline this year," Mr. Knauer said.
 
 
 
GIDGETS AND GADGETS TO TEMPT THE SHY CONSUMER
 The Sharper Image, a chain of gadgetry emporiums, has spent all year preparing for this Christmas. Richard Thalheimer, the company's founder and chairman, took one look at last year's abysmal holiday sales and decided something had to be done. "People were tired of looking at the third-generation answering machine," he said. "We had to get out of that rut."
But getting out of the rut is what so many merchants seem to fear. "Most merchants nowadays want to wait to see somebody else prove an item will sell," Mr. Thalheimer said. "I couldn't afford to do that."
So he sent his buyers in search of unusual items. They came back with liquid gel insoles for shoes that sell for $19.95 and a $119 thermometer that takes a person's temperature in one second after it is touched to an ear. And he started selling some clothing, like a quilted silk bomber jacket for $139.95 and handknit woolen fisherman's sweaters for $149.95.
Mr. Thalheimer knows that next season other retailers will use the results of his retail experiments. This year, he sold more than 200,000 mugs filled with a liquid gel insulator that freezes to keep drinks cool. Mass merchandisers like Walmart and K Mart soon introduced the same mug at prices lower than the Sharper Image's $12.95.
The mass merchants' action will eventually force him to eliminate the mugs from his shelves, Mr. Thalheimer said, at which point he will try to entice the consumer with some other must-have gadget.
"Specialty stores have that kind of responsibility to experiment and try new things, but when times are tough, everybody just pulls in their wagons and plays it safe," he said. "Fortunately for us, we couldn't even afford to do that. If we had, I believe we would have gone out of business."

HEADLINE: Business Diary/October 27 - November 1

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Getting Salomon Managers to Think of the Shareholders 

If Warren E. Buffett, the interim chairman of Salomon Brothers Inc., is right, the firm's problems are due to an overly generous compensation scheme. In a letter to shareholders, Mr. Buffett said the securities unit, which illegally bought too many Treasury bonds, earned only about 10 percent on its equity capital, not a stellar showing. But "106 individuals who worked for the unit earned $1 million or more," he wrote. He told shareholders bonuses would be scaled back when the current plan runs out. The firm will offer stock, not just cash. That would encourage executives to think of the shareholder. Other firms might copy that. But some others think the plan is dubious. "When the current bonus plan pays out on Dec. 31," said Graef S. Crystal, author of "In Search of Excess," "Unless there is recession on the Street, there is likely to be a hemorrhage of talent." A few defections may be part of the plan.
 
 
Chrysler Starts to Look Better
 
When a car company loses $82 million in the third quarter, it usually signals that something big -- like sales -- has fizzled. Investors walk away. But this is no ordinary quarter. In fact, it is no ordinary year. Analysts predict Detroit's Big Three will lose $5 billion before it's over. That made the Chrysler Corporation's bleak numbers look good last week -- at least by comparison. "In the market we're in today, holding losses to $82 million is an outstanding performance and clearly reflects the efficiencies we've gained by restructuring Chrysler," said Lee A. Iacocca, Chrysler's chairman. Wall Street agreed. Part of Chrysler's performance came when it sold its half interest in Diamond Star Motors to the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation of Japan for $99.75 million. Its stock -- which had been languishing -- rose $1.625 to $12.75 on the announcements and closed the week at $12.50.
 
 
Time Warner's Japan Connection
 
Last week, Steven J. Ross, the chairman of Time Warner Inc., made good on a promise to find foreign partners. The Toshiba Corporation and C. Itoh & Company of Japan said they will invest $1 billion in Time Warner. That gives the companies a 12.5 percent stake in a limited partnership called Time Warner Entertainment and cuts some of Time Warner's $8.8 billion in debt. Perhaps most important, the deal gives Time Warner opportunities in Japan. "Beyond valuation, the goal is to create a strategic partnership to get distribution in Japan," said Harold J. Levy, vice president of Arnhold and S. Bleichroeder Inc., an investment bank in New York.
 
 
Boeing Has a Hit on Its Hands
 
Although it has never flown, the Boeing Company's mid-sized 777 is already a hit with the airlines. Last week Japan Airlines ordered 20 of the new twin-engine jets. The order is valued at $2 billion and comes two months after a $3.6 billion order from British Airways. Six airlines have now signed up to fly the plane.
 
 
A Computer That's Still Growing
 
Last week the Thinking Machines Corporation unveiled its latest number-crunching supercomputer. It's a monster. The massively parallel machine -- so called because it divides up problems among a number of simple processors -- snaps together like a set of Legos. It can stroll along with 32 processors, or roar with 16,000. Each chip can be connected to four math-processor chips. That makes the CM-5 one of the few supercomputers that can grow. Although most customers are research labs, the American Express Company said it would take two CM-5's, but was mum about what it would do with all that power.


Burying the B-2
 
The Northrop Corporation received a blow from Congress last week. Northrop makes the B-2 Stealth bomber. The B-2's mission is now moot since it was designed to sneak past Soviet radar defense with its load of bombs. Congress made it difficult for the Pentagon to order any more B-2's this fiscal year beyond the 15 being built. Each plane costs $865 million.


Extra Innings, but Not Revenues
 
Two years ago, CBS bet heavily on baseball. It paid $1.06 billion for the right to show major league games. But it still lost money last year. This year (aside from the weekend of the Clarence Thomas saga) the fans tuned in to the World Series as never before. Minnesota and Atlanta cooperated by going seven games, three with extra innings. That brought CBS $35 million in extra revenue since more commercials could be shown. Game seven scored 32.1 ratings points -- impressive since each point represents 921,000 homes. But CBS still lost $169.1 million in the third quarter, its worst ever.
 
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Moscow's Man of Action
 
When he addressed the Congress of People's Deputies in Moscow, Boris N. Yeltsin, President of the Russian Republic, said it was time to act "decisively, sternly, without hesitation." He told the highest assembly in the Russian Republic that he intended to lift most price controls (not vodka) at the end of the year. He also said he would accelerate the privatization of agriculture and some light industries and that he would stop financing the central Government's ministries -- excluding the military, transportation and energy. The central Government is what President Mikhail S. Gorbachev runs. It sounded as if Mr. Yeltsin had a plan. It also sounded as if he recognized how much disruption the leap into a market economy would cause. The Congress approved the proposals 876 to 16.


Trading Barbs
 
Last week Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, talked tough to the European Community. She admonished it for the generous way it continues to subsidize its farmers. She said Europe's farmers were "killing the land." That part -- killing the land -- was in response to assertions by European officials that the Bush Administration does not care about the environment. The Europeans want rules banning trade that harms the environment, something Ms. Hills would rather not see.


A New Leader for Japan
 
1Last week it became official. Kiichi Miyazawa was chosen as Japan's next Prime Minister. Mr. Miyazawa is more than an adept politician. He once was Finance Minister and before that represented Japan in important trade negotiations with the United States. Though he is thought to want better relations with Washington, when it comes to trade he still must wrestle with powerful interest groups at home. "He is superbly qualified," said Jeffrey E. Garten, managing director of the Blackstone Group. "But it is still not clear what freedom of action he will have."
 
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
The Littlest Rebound
 
Economists are still puzzling over the results. The economy expanded by an estimated 2.4 percent in the third quarter, according to the Commerce Department. That increase, though meager, was the first positive showing in a year. But those gains did not come from the sectors economists are very fond of; they came from shifts in inventories. "Inventory changes up or down are no basis for sustained growth," said Robert Ortner, the author of "Voodoo Deficits." Sustained growth comes from capital spending. "As rebounds go, this is puny," he said.


Sheepish Consumers
 
Right now, the consumer is more lamb than lion. The Conference Board's Index of Consumer Confidence tumbled in October to a nervous 60.4, down from 72.9 in September. The index was a self-confident 100 in 1985. The fall in confidence is important since jittery consumers don't spend. Last month's reading was the worst since the 1981-82 recession.


Negative Foreshadowing
 
It wasn't exactly a leap, but it was worrisome just the same. Unemployment rose to 6.8 percent in October, up from 6.7 in September, the Labor Department said last week. "That suggests a negative fourth quarter," said Alan Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Company. There was also a fall in the Commerce Department's Index of Leading Indicators. The index, which is used to forecast the economy six to nine months in the future, fell 0.1 percent in September, the first drop since February. "That suggests a negative prognosis for the first quarter," he said. "I read these numbers as recession threatening," he said.


The Price of Pot-Smoking
 
Economists are fond of building mental models of how the world works. If demand falls, they say, prices usually tumble. But if demand stays down, prices often rise to compensate for lost economies of scale as sellers go out of business. That is the way the market works. But what about the underground market? Demand for marijuana is down sharply, according to a report from the National Institute on Drug Abuse in Washington. Yet prices are higher than ever. What cost $20 an ounce a decade ago, sells for $800. The high prices suggest pot has lost its allure. "If it goes up much more I'm going to stop smoking," one smoker told The Times.
 
The National Association of Purchasing Management said its monthly survey showed the pace of growth slackened in October. The survey fell to 53.5 from 55 in September.

HEADLINE: Technology;
Mining Deep Underground for Energy

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Across vast areas of the world, Government scientists say, it should soon be possible to drill a hole in the ground and harvest energy that is abundant and environmentally benign. This is not oil or gas, but heat.
Researchers at Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico are seeking to tap the heat within the earth, which comes from earth's molten core or from radioactive decay and which geologists say dwarfs the energy content of oil, coal or natural gas. 
 By the end of this month, after a decade of work, they hope to begin producing usable quantities of heat in the form of hot water, from the bedrock 12,000 feet under Fenton Hill, N.M. Water heated deep within the earth will be brought to the surface and used to make steam.
One enthusiastic backer, Stewart Udall, a former Secretary of the Interior, said in a recent letter inviting energy specialists to a conference on geothermal heat that the technology is so promising that "at first blush, it might seem to be a product of science fiction speculation."
The energy to be harvested in New Mexico is from hot dry rock, which is different from a technology already in commercial use using heat from underground. Several companies take heat from the wet rock in Rocky Mountain and Pacific Coast states to make electricity, by tapping into water that has seeped into rock that holds heat from the earth's core. But that water exists in only a few places.
By contrast, after spending more than $160 million in Federal money on research and tests, Los Alamos researchers are convinced that hot dry rock is found almost everywhere, if the well is deep enough.
In many places, they say, the temperature gradient between the surface and the rock below is large enough so the depth of the wells is easily within the ability of existing drilling technology. In about 2 percent of the land mass of the United States, according to Los Alamos scientists, the gradient per kilometer is greater than 45 degrees centigrade (or about 125 degrees Fahrenheit per mile), making hot dry rock practical if the electricity can be sold wholesale for 9 to 10 cents a kilowatt-hour.
That price is not currently competitive with natural gas or coal plants, but it might be if credit were given for the fact that the generating system creates no carbon dioxide, the combustion product believed to cause climate change, or other pollutants. The New Mexico test site has a slightly higher thermal gradient -- 65 degrees centigrade per kilometer -- and will bring up water at 240 degrees centigrade. Getting water that hot from a site with a smaller gradient would simply mean drilling deeper. Water not hot enough to make steam for electricity would still work well for heating homes, running factories and for meeting some needs in an electric plant.
Even if a gradient of 60 to 70 degrees is required, vast parts of the western United States qualify, according to researchers.
If the energy of the earth's crust could be economically tapped, the resource base would be hundreds of times larger than any now in use, according to a study published by Los Alamos in 1989.
The standard measure of energy consumption from all sources is one quadrillion British thermal units. A B.T.U. is the amount of energy needed to raise the temperature of one pound of water by 1 degree Fahrenheit, and a quadrillion is a "1" with 15 zeroes. The United States consumes about 80 quadrillion B.T.U.'s annually, from coal, oil, gas, nuclear power and all other sources, but the estimated energy potential of hot dry rock nationwide is 10 million quads, the study found, more energy than this country uses in thousands of years.
The Los Alamos study, which referred to the process as "mining heat," noted that many underground resources are not fully recoverable. "However, even if only 0.1 percent or 0.01 percent of the accessible hot dry rock resource base is ultimately extracted, the impact on the U.S. energy supply would be far-reaching," it said.
Mr. Udall, who is chairman of the Center for Resource Management, a nonprofit organization in Salt Lake City that studies energy and environment issues, is organizing a conference next month to share information with government officials, utility officials, environmentalists and others on the potential of hot dry rock, with Los Alamos as a co-sponsor. Among the benefits he points out is that the system has no waste. The water that carries the heat from underground is re-injected through the other well, forming a closed loop.
The Los Alamos test involves twin 12,000-foot wells, one for injecting water, the other for retrieving the hot water for steam. Drilling is a challenge, because by definition the rock is hot. Also, the target material is hard rock, not the softer sedimentary rock oil drillers go after. This makes the work cumbersome and costly.
The reward at the bottom is rock that is very hot but also very solid. Technicians inject water at very high pressure, to open up fractures in the rock, through which the water flows. "People tell me they're less than a millimeter," said David V. Duchane, the program manager for the Los Alamos geothermal energy program. But no one is sure. "Remember," he said, "no one has ever been down there."
So far the rock has not behaved exactly as expected. The original plan was to drill the ends of the two wells near each other, pump water into one and wait for it to flow to the other. But when the water was pumped in at pressure high enough to open fissures in the rock, at 2,700 pounds per square inch, the water went off in its own direction, probably following natural stress lines. Drillers had to move the bottom of the second well to find the water. Next time, said Mr. Duchane, they will drill the first hole, create the reservoir, locate it through micro-seismic tests and then drill the second well into it.
Another problem, especially in the arid West, is that in an earlier test the system seemed to lose excessive amounts of water. Some of the water seemed to bleed away, but most, Mr. Duchane said, was probably absorbed by microcracks in the rock. "That can't go on forever," he said, predicting that at some point losses would drop to a small amount.
Hot dry rock plants could be useful in balancing electric systems through the hours of the day, say backers. In years to come, many analysts expect windmills and solar cells to provide an increasing portion of electric power, but those sources are notoriously intermittent and must be complemented with plants that can start or stop quickly, a capability nuclear plants and most coal plants lack. Hot dry rock plants could alter output quickly.
Outsiders are watching the experiment carefully. "It's not a sure thing, but it does have potential," saidDr. Evan E. Hughes, a project manager at the Electric Power Research Institute, a utility consortium in Palo Alto, Calif. "Hot dry rock could be big enough to supply virtually all the electricity we need."
But the price must be competitive, he said, and "no one's going to believe it until they've seen it done." It will probably take more than a single test to demonstrate, Dr. Hughes added.
John R. Bailey, a geologist in Tulsa, Okla., who is a consultant to O'Brien Energy Systems, a geothermal company, also believes hot dry rock has large-scale potential. Existing geothermal plants already produce energy for electricity and for everything from heating greenhouses to drying potato chips, he said, and hot dry rock is far more widespread.
Successful fields at the moment, said Mr. Bailey and other experts, rely on having several production wells and a single well for re-injection. Thus the pair of wells at Fenton Hill will not represent the economic questions fairly.
With natural gas at historic low prices, any new technologies face a stiff hurdle. But "if there were another energy crisis, this would be economically possible in the East," Mr. Bailey said.
For example, he said, the Adirondack mountains in New York could be suitable, and lots of water is available there. "Ultimately, you can get hot dry rock almost anywhere, if you're willing to drill deep enough," he said.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Nobody Loves an Equity

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
IndividuaL investors' equity holdings, including both common stocks and mutual funds, have dropped as a percentage of total assets in the last 20-plus years.
Experts say the trend is fueled by several forces: the stock market collapses of 1969-70, 1973-1974 and 1987; high yields on money market funds and bonds in the late 1970's to early 1980's; soaring real estate values that competed for dollars, and the growing domination of institutional investors. 
 But the withdrawal by investors has been overdone, advisers say. Investors who shy away from stocks get "only limited exposure to the form of investment which has provided the best total return over long periods of time," said H. Bradlee Perry, chairman of David L. Babson & Company, a mutual fund and investment advisory group in Cambridge, Mass. Indeed, with interest rates plummeting and the stock market rising, there was a modest gain in equity holdings in the first half of this year.

HEADLINE: CAMPUS LIFE: Rutgers;
Asian Americans Organize Against 'Silent' Stereotype

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.

 BODY:
Though the 5,100 Asian and Pacific Islander students at Rutgers University constitute, at 11 percent, the largest minority group, they are often referred to on campus as the silent minority.
"It's the Confucian ethic of restraint," said Bertrand Wang, a senior in Asian Studies from East Brunswick, N.J. "Mind your own shop, and never speak out against your elders." 
 But now, Rutgers' 12 Asian interest organizations are trying to convince members to speak out -- and with a single voice.
"Many Asians on the college campus are lulled into thinking that racism, because it exists mostly in the subtle form of stereotypes, doesn't need to be battled," Mr. Wang said. "Letting people get away with it is saying it's all right."
In interviews, Asian students also recounted a handful of incidents in which they or their classmates had been verbally or physically assaulted; few of these incidents, they said, have been reported to the Rutgers administration.
 
'Just Want to Communicate'
 "All we want is a voice," Mayank Gupta, a senior from Dayton, N.J., studying computer science and mathematics. "We're not militant. We're not gangs. We just want to communicate." Mr. Gupta is president of the 300-member Association of Indians at Rutgers.
For Asian students, the new vehicles of communication on campus are the Rutgers Asian American Coalition for Equality and a campus newspaper, Common Interest.
"I really wish more Asians would voice their opinions, admit to discrimination," said Ellen Keng, a sophomore in business from Morristown. "This paper is their vehicle."
But speaking as one will not be easy for a community that has rarely acted in its own behalf, a community comprising Asian Indians, Japanese, Chinese, Pakistani, Filipinos, Koreans, Cambodians, Vietnamese, Hmong, Laotian, Thai and other ethnic groups.
"Many join the Asian student groups for their active social agendas," said graphics editor Edward Chao, a senior from West Windsor who is majoring in electrical engineering.
 
Soul Searching and Cliques
 Peter Li, a professor of Chinese who is also author of the book "Understanding Asian Americans: A Curriculum Resource Guide," noted a tendency for Asian Americans to form cliques in college. "In high school, we try to be as American as possible," Professor Li said. "We adopt the slang, mimic the hair." But in universities, he said, "For Asian Americans, the soul searching that often accompanies the college years causes them to grapple with feelings of ambivalence about their origins."
Asian students for whom English is a second language are "ostracized by the English-speaking majority -- white, black or Hispanic," said Chi-Lin Shih, a professor of Chinese, who said that the feeling of exclusion further encourages them to isolate themselves from other students.
Ching-I Tu, a professor of Chinese and department chairman of East Asian languages and cultures, said he felt "the bond is there for students; otherwise, they wouldn't seek to learn their cultural origins, their heritage, through college classes."
There is a year-old East Asian languages and cultures department at Rutgers. But the department offers only Chinese and Japanese language and culture courses, leaving many Asian students feeling forgotten.
 
Competing Ethnic Groups
 And though membership flourishes for the various student groups, Siraj Hasan, a junior in accounting from Karachi, Pakistan, said it is difficult to attract attention when "all the cultural events tend to run together, and each group tries to outdo the other." Mr. Hasan belongs to the 68-member Pakistan Students Association.
Ethnic groups themselves must contend with internal divisions, said Ada Chiu, a senior in economics from Kowloon, Hong Kong. Ms. Chiu, who is president of the 300-member Chinese Students Organization, noted, for example, that among Chinese students, many different dialects are spoken and many different regions of China are represented.
Mr. Gupta said he perceived a similar problem within the Indian organization. "But we find a common language," he said.

HEADLINE: CAMPUS LIFE: Connecticut;
Campus Outgrows Its Need for Dairy But Not for Milk

DATELINE: STORRS, Conn.

 BODY:
University of Connecticut students will no longer be drinking milk from the university's own dairy herd come the middle of this month, when the creamery is due to close.
UConn announced on Tuesday that it will close the only milk processing plant at a New England university. Karen Grava Williams, a university spokeswoman, said the plant would be closed because it no longer serves as a laboratory for agricultural students and is in financial difficulties. 
 Closing the creamery, which processes the milk from UConn's herd of 80 cows, has been debated since April 1989, when state inspectors cited 50 health code violations. Inspectors criticized unsanitary conditions in the dairy and the antiquated equipment used in a process that has become far more automated.
But Thomas J. Tighe, university provost, finally decided to close the dairy because it had accumulated a $500,000 deficit, and to keep it open would require renovations and new equipment totaling more than $2 million, Ms. Williams said.
"If there was an academic need, we would have tried to find resources elsewhere," she added.
 
Building to Be Renovated
 The State Legislature had approved $2.8 million for renovations to the building that housed the creamery in the budget for the fiscal year ending next June. University officials said the money would still be used to renovate the building, which also houses classrooms, laboratories and the Dairy Bar, a shop famous statewide for its homemade ice cream and a popular attraction for visitors to campus. The Dairy Bar will remain open.
The creamery delivers milk and other dairy products, like butter and sour cream, to UConn's cafeterias and other state buildings, including prisons and training schools for the mentally retarded.
UConn students say they are worried that closing the dairy may mean that the university and they will pay higher prices for milk. "I would think it would be more expensive getting it off campus," said Timothy S. Paris, a sophomore mathematics major from Shelton, Conn.
Gerald N. Weller, head of the student commissaries, said he was unsure if having to go to dairies outside the university would result in price increases, but that he would begin talking with local milk vendors.
The concern for price increases stems in part from the economic troubles that have plagued the state and the university recently. Students felt the creamery's closing was another signal of decline at a university that has been forced to lay off employees and reduce services because of cuts in state financing.
"Generally it's a sign that the university is underfunded," said Gregory P. Jack, a senior psychology major from Hamden, Conn.
 
Will Still Get Ice Cream
 Melissa K. Labbe, a junior music education major from Ellington, Conn., said, "Basically, we're going very downhill." She added: "There's not a whole lot we can do about it, as long as we still get ice cream."
Students will still get ice cream because the ice cream from the Dairy Bar is not made with cream from the milk processing operation. Indeed, the bar will be expanded with a larger sales room that will offer student-made and student-grown products, like sausages from the university farm and apples from its orchard, when they are available, Ms. Williams said. UConn, which was founded as an agricultural school in 1881, will maintain its herd of 80 cows and will sell their milk to another processor, Ms. Williams said.

HEADLINE: Earning One's Keep

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In response to my letter ("Keeping the Government Out of Housing," Oct. 6) Muriel C. Hayman correctly points out that I am "not old enough to remember the G.I. Bill" ("Low-Interest Loans to Lower-Income People," Letters, Oct. 20). I am a senior economics major at the University of Maryland at College Park and came to the United States from Somalia barely seven years ago. 
 However, the G.I. Bill wasn't an earlier version of the current welfare system; it was a program to reward men and women who fought to save Western democracies.
There are now attempts to bring back some form of paid volunteerism, such as the bill offered by two Democrats, Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia and Representative David McCurdy of Oklahoma. It would send high school graduates to do public service helping the elderly, participating in literacy programs and tutoring inner-city children. Upon completion of the service, the students would be given $20,000 in vouchers -- not cash -- for college tuition or a down payment on a house. Although attacked by free-marketeers, it still has advocates in some conservative circles.
There is a difference between government paying those who earned a reward by serving their country and those who feel entitled to aid without doing public service.
It is time that America does away with the culture that promotes free lunches.
 
ABDUL RAHMAN ABDI
Greenbelt, Md., Oct. 20

HEADLINE: Look Inward, World Bank

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Running Aid in Tandem With Reform" (Forum, Oct. 20) rightly emphasizes the need for reforms involving market incentives and development of "market-friendly" institutions supported by foreign finance. 
 But Vinod Thomas, the author, also admits that "when aid programs are poorly designed, they allow recipients to postpone -- or totally avoid -- difficult policy changes." Yet the reasons for what might be called the past preponderance of non-success -- and the relatively few success cases -- are never dealt with. I suppose the reader is to conclude that if the symbiosis between reforms and financing doesn't work out, it must be due to the failure of the recipient country to treat the program "as its own, rather than as a foreign imposition."
Surely there is more to it. One possible cause of failure extends to the behavior of the donor/creditor agencies, including Mr. Thomas's own World Bank. At least part of the problem resides with such agencies' felt need to keep lending even when recipients' actions don't warrant it. Bluntly put, as long as meeting some sort of informal lending levels overcomes the insistence on high quality, donors may undermine their own objectives by permitting recipients to pursue inappropriate policies.
The World Bank is all too often unwilling to act like a bank at the outset -- to wait until the recipient proposes a serious, long-term program of reform. It is also not often prepared to cease lending if mutual understandings are violated. This is, of course, not lost on would-be recipients and is a major reason why structural adjustment packages have often deteriorated into ritual dances while the money kept flowing.
While donors are asking for policy reforms in the third world and Eastern Europe, little attention is paid to the sociology and operating behavior of their own institutions.
Achieving success in linking policy change with foreign financing may require institutional and policy reforms from donors as well as recipients.
 
GUSTAV RANIS
New Haven, Oct. 23
 
 The author is the Frank Altschul Professor of International Economics at Yale University. He has served as assistant administrator for program and policy in the Agency for International Development.

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
By Definition, an Automobile Is . . .

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
WE were having our usual disconnected conversation the other night. About birds and bushes, about people we knew and computers. And, of course, about cars. We talked technology, and I remembered a friend who is generally a smart fellow but who knows NOTHING.
This is a guy with a doctorate in psychology. And, listening to him some time back, he allowed as how his car was driven by only one wheel. Huh? Well, sure, he said. Has to be. Because the outside wheel goes faster in a turn. 
 I stayed calm and sort of alluded to differentials and how those simple devices allow driven wheels to travel at different speeds on the same axle, but I don't think he got it. And I knew then that people, even very savvy people, often are buffaloed by fairly low technology.
So we set out, the other night, to come up with a sort of glossary, and I offer it here, as is and thoroughly incomplete. If you have your own puzzlements, though, you can join the conversation by dropping me a line at 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Maybe we can do more of this:
Analog/Digital -- The difference between a vague round clock and one that wakes you at exactly 7:14 A.M. In car terms, it generally means the difference between a dash with real needle-instrument gauges and one that shouts at you in ice-blue numbers. Right-thinking people prefer analog.
Antilock brakes -- Forget airbags. Antilock braking systems are the most important safety advance since seatbelts. Wheel sensors send a message of impending lockup to the car's on-board computer, which then pumps the brakes faster than the fastest foot. The result is quicker stops without skids, and the major advantage of ABS is that the wheels do not lock and a driver retains steering control.
Breakerless ignition -- Also known as electronic ignition, it does away with the adjustable and perishable breaker points in the old-fashioned distributor. Means lots less expense for tuneups and extends the life of sparkplugs.
Climate control -- Pioneered by General Motors, the system uses a thermostat to combine heat and air-conditioning to maintain a preset interior temperature.
Coefficient of drag -- Streamlining has become more important with the need for better fuel efficiency. An important measure of any car's ability to slip through the air is its drag coefficient, which takes into account its frontal area and overall smoothness. Today's average car has a Cd. of about .32. Experimental vehicles are much lower.
Displacement -- Formerly measured in cubic inches, now expressed in liters. It is the total volume of the space inside the engine's cylinders that is available for combustion. A liter represents 61.025 cubic inches.
Electronic suspension -- A system that changes the ride and handling qualities of a car. Generally, there are two settings, normal or "touring," and "sport." The normal setting is good for cities and potholed streets. "Sport" makes the car stiffer and better on twisty roads. Some cars push the electronic envelope by using sonar waves to "read" the road and instantaneously readjust suspension settings.
Fuel injection -- You know about this. But, for the record, it replaces carburetion as the way to get gasoline into the cylinders. Generally, a microprocessor reads the accelerator angle and the needs of the engine and adjusts the spray of fuel to create an optimum fuel mixture. Also known as EFI, or electronic fuel injection.
Intercooler -- Generally used in conjunction with turbocharging. The idea is to cool intake air with a separate radiator, because cooler air is denser air. And the denser the oxygen charge in the combustion chamber, the more power there is in the explosion of the fuel mixture.
Load leveling -- When Cadillac tried this in the late 50's, there was a serious glitch: Put the car on a lift, and it went crazy trying to find the ground. Modern technology has fixed the problem, and today's luxury cars use their computers to determine load and readjust their springs.
Multivalve technology -- Conventional powerplants breathe through one exhaust valve and one intake valve per cylinder. In the 1950's, hot rodders "ported" their engines to increase the area around the valves and alleviate the natural emphysema. But modern engineers have gone the hot rodders one better by using two valves for intake and two for exhaust, simultaneously increasing power and efficiency.
Overdrive -- High gear has traditionally been 1:1, which is to say that a transmission output shaft turns one time for each turn of the crankshaft. Overdrive, which decreases power but is suitable for highway cruising, means even higher gearing, providing increased fuel economy.
Rack and Pinion -- A steering system that moves a toothed bar with a gear on the end of the steering shaft. More precise than conventional recirculating-ball systems, in which steering motion is transmitted by steel balls placed between a worm gear and a nut.
Supercharger -- A windmill, driven by a chain or belt hooked to the crankshaft, that packs more air and thus a denser charge into the combustion chamber. This is old technology, picked up and improved today by Ford and Buick. Turbocharging increases power in the same way, although the air pump is driven by the flow of exhaust gases.
Traction control -- The reverse, in a sense, of antilock brakes. The same wheel sensors note imminent slip, and the computer cuts power from the engine.
Zero-to-60 -- You know about this, too, but it is one of the standard measures of acceleration and never mind the Double Nickel. These days, 10 seconds is average to slow, and a leisurely diesel will reach 60 miles an hour in the mid-teens. Probably the fastest production cars were the muscular Corvettes and Carroll Shelby's 427 Cobra, which hit 60 m.p.h. in just over 4 seconds. Try that with power to one wheel.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The supercharger, on top of the engine, packs a denser fuel mixture into the combustion chamber. This is Buick's V6. (General Motors)

HEADLINE: Sunday Dinner;
Spots Where the Wine List Is a Good Match for the Food

 BODY:
In today's economy it is difficult for restaurants to stock large inventories of wine. This may not be a bad turn of events, because it has forced many restaurants to rethink wine in relation to food. The result has been smaller but more thoughtful lists. Here are three restaurants in Manhattan where both the food and the wine lists are good.
 
Chin Chin
 216 East 49th Street, (212) 888-4555 -- This may be the best-looking Chinese restaurant in town. It is near the summit when it comes to food, too. The cooking cuts across various ethnic borders, and while most dishes are full-flavored, few are seriously spicy. If you like wine with Chinese food, the selection here is impressive and exceptionally well chosen. Prices are more than fair, starting at $14. 
 Among appetizers on the current menu are crispy fried squid, vegetable duck pie with crepes, chicken soong in lettuce pocket and cold noodles tossed in a hot sesame sauce. Main courses include Peking duck, shredded chicken with garlic sauce, crispy sea bass and crispy orange beef.
Appetizers are $4 to $12, entrees, $13.50 to $19.50. Sunday dinner is served from 5 to 11 P.M. (Review, May 3, 1991.)
 
Les Halles
 411 Park Avenue South, between 28th and 29th Streets, (212) 679-4111 -- It is not easy to absorb all the interior details at Les Halles. A little tiled butcher shop is up front, and just behind is the bar. The lofty space here has a Parisian feel with elaborate wood molding, off-white walls, tulip sconces that cast soft light and tables draped in butcher paper. Charcuterie posters and black and white photos adorn the walls.
Patrons come here for the gutsy French cooking. As for the wine list, it is a delight, not only for its sensible prices but also for delectable little-known country wines like Bourgueil ($16), Chateau Aiguilloux from Cahors ($15) and Vidal-Fleury from Vacqueyras ($21).
For appetizers, you might start with the frisee aux lardons (chicory salad with bacon and Roquefort croutons), onion soup or warm sausage served with lentils. For entrees there are grilled flank steak with a shallot sauce, lamb shank with couscous, pigs' feet and moules mariniere (steamed mussels with white wine).
Appetizers are $5 to $7.50; entrees, $12.50 to $22. Sunday hours are noon to midnight. (Review, Feb. 15, 1991.)
 
Sarabeth's
 1295 Madison Avenue, near 92d Street, (212) 410-7335 -- This cheerful spot is almost too cute to be taken seriously as a restaurant, with its country cupboard at the entrance, cream-toned wallpaper, pastoral American paintings on the walls and capacious baskets of dried flowers. Yet there is nothing juvenile about the food.
The American menu is sophisticated and well focused. Sarabeth's also offers a limited but quality American wine selection that is well matched to the food and reasonably priced.
Starters on the current menu include cream of tomato soup; marinated goat cheese with roasted sweet peppers, black olives and toasted nut-raisin bread; Caesar salad and rigatoni with grilled tomatoes, chicken sausage, zucchini and arugula.
Among main courses are grilled salmon with lentils, caramelized endive and a warm ginger vinaigrette; grilled tuna caponata with roasted potatoes; herbed linguine topped with a stew of squash, tomato, ginger and fried ricotta cheese; chicken potpie and seared duck breast served with duck tortillas, green rice and avocado.
Appetizers are $4 to $6.75; entrees, $14.75 to $20. Sunday dinner is from 6 to 10 P.M. (Review, Aug. 24, 1990.)
This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times, and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current.

HEADLINE: Military Spending Binge Got Us Into This Mess

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Republican Party line points proudly to the country's "longest peacetime expansion" during the Reagan-Bush decade of the 1980's. The intended point is that the second longest economic expansion of the post-World War II period was achieved without the stimulus of a wartime buildup, as occurred during the Vietnam War era, when the longest expansion was recorded. 
 But a graph of United States military spending in dollars of constant purchasing power, published in the Sept. 28 issue of The Economist, and based on Commerce Department and Office of Management and Budget figures, makes it clear to anyone not wearing Republican-tinted glasses that the spending bulge above the trend line for 1980-90 is about twice that for 1965-75.
Moreover, since real gross national product did not double between 1970 and 1985, the relative-size argument doesn't wash either.
Of course, it is a blessing that there was no shooting war in the later period, but does that matter to the economy? If the Republicans are going to claim that spending on shooting wars imparts a greater economic stimulus than spending for military hardware that doesn't fire any shots in anger, how do they explain why the outbreak of the Persian Gulf war brought about our recession? Because it was fought at nearly zero marginal capital cost and expenses were covered by passing the hat among our allies?
As the most significant events of the last 45 years are taking place in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, about all the United States can do, because of the debt piled up during the Reagan years, is offer advice on how to privatize industry and pray for market miracles.
 
LARRY COLE
Natick, Mass., Oct. 16, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Wearing Thin;
Facing a Tide of Voter Anger, Politicians Look to Channel It

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AMERICA is in a sour mood. The unemployment rate is rising, the Index of Leading Economic Indicators is slipping, and everyone seems to be thoroughly disgusted with the powers that be, including Congress and, increasingly, the White House.
It should be a dream scenario for Democrats, who have been shut out of the Presidency for more than a decade and who, until recently, had been all but counted out of the race again in 1992. Instead, there is a sort of low-grade policy panic setting in as elected officials of both parties seek to gauge the depth of the public's anger and formulate a palatable and convincing set of solutions. 
 Both parties are struggling under the weight of the recession, which has added a slate of economic woes to the general disenchantment with Washington's brand of insider politics that first began to make itself felt during the 1990 midterm elections.
But the discontent is more complex than the polls can convey. Across the country, the sense that the nation is on the edge of bad times colors daily life.
In the Midwest, farmers who have saved and worked hard for years remain uneasy that everything they have gained could slip away at any moment. In New Hampshire, the first primary state, workers are striking at paper mills and knitwear factories. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation recently seized five failed banks.
And even in relatively affluent areas like Montgomery County, Md. which has come to depend on white-collar Government-related jobs, middle-class county workers staged a sit-in last week to protest imminent layoffs and other budget cuts.
Such are the scenes of frustration among American voters, further fueled by a nagging feeling that the last people who can be trusted to fix their problems are the very politicians they have elected to office.
"People are unhappy," said Alan Rosenthal, the director of the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University. "The political system has gotten a bad rap with the S. &L.'s and the problems with the states, and people feel insecure. The American idea that progress is inevitable is being challenged."
As a result, voters are weighing extreme alternatives. Witness the Louisiana electorate, which has given David Duke, a former grand wizard of the Ku Klux Klan, the chance to become its next governor in a runoff election on Nov. 16.
On another front, the movement to limit terms of elected officials, which first surfaced in 1990, has caught fire again. Term-limitation legislation covering state and local offices has been introduced in 45 states this year, and probably a dozen states will consider measures next year that would specifically limit the terms of members of Congress.
A big test comes Tuesday, when the voters of Washington State decide on a measure that would apply term limitations retroactively. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington, who would be affected, has said such a law would be unconstitutional.
But it would certainly send its message. It matters little that many of those joining the new "populist" bandwagon include corporate interests like those that are financing the Washington term-limitation initiative, or politicians like Edmund G. Brown, who opposed term limits when he was California state party chairman but now, as a Presidential candidate, favors them.
Clearly, when the public is in a rotten mood, it can only help a politician to be an outsider, or to profess to be one. This is a tougher sell for the three candidates -- President Bush and Senators Bob Kerrey and Tom Harkin -- who work in Washington.
"Being outraged does help, but only as long as you channel that anger," said an aide to Mr. Harkin. "People don't want someone up there just shaking their fist."
Mr. Bush has chosen to be the insider's outsider, battering away at Congress and blaming it for the worst of the country's ills. Some members of Congress have helped to make it an easy target for Presidential barbs and for general resentment as a privileged group. By abusing special checking priviledges and practically institutionalizing the free lunch for themselves, legislators have called attention to the rarified level of special treatment that they enjoy.
But some in the White House understand that blaming Congress is only the political half of what must ultimately be an economic solution. The trouble is, the Republican leaders in Congress and President Bush's advisers cannot yet agree on how best to reverse their slipping fortunes. Some advisers would have Mr. Bush tough it out and depend on the economy to rebound. Others have said he must present his own economic package, starting with a capital gains tax cut.
Another insider-outsider is Mr. Harkin, who, as the chairman of an Appropriations subcommittee, is a Senate leader. But he has traveled the country crafting a "populist" insurgency, announcing his candidacy in an Iowa cornfield in his shirt-sleeves and denouncing traditional leadership and Mr. Bush by using a common barnyard epithet.
But the battles are being fought this year on several other fronts that are far distant from the traditional Presidential fields of Iowa and New Hampshire. The National Conference of State Legislatures has found that states were forced to raise taxes to balance their budgets to the tune of $16.2 billion in the 1992 fiscal year, the largest dollar increase ever and the largest increase as a percentage of state budgets in 20 years.
A veteran Republican member of the Maryland State Senate, Howard Denis, said he has never seen it this bad. And his consituents are hurting. "People are in the doldrums," he said. "Whether they're planning a vacation or going out to dinner or buying a house, I think people are in a deep depression not only about the state of the economy now, but the prognosis for the future."
Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey, whose popularity plummeted when he raised taxes immediately upon taking office last year, is among the governors who have sought to link the behavior of the insiders in Washington and painful steps taken by state officials at home.
 
Blaming Bush
 In a speech intended as an effort to keep the legislature in Democratic hands -- a prospect that appeared to be fading by the minute -- he urged New Jersey Democrats to get up off their knees and blame Mr. Bush for the state's economic troubles.
But other state officials see appeals for Federal help as futile. Gov. Michael J. Sullivan of Wyoming offered a common plaint at a Washington forum on health care costs last week. "We are a bit like a swimmer being washed down the river with no boat," he said of declining Federal support for state-run programs.
And Mayor Raymond L. Flynn of Boston, who is president of the United States Conference of Mayors, has mounted an offensive along similar lines. In a letter mailed to each of the announced Presidential candidates on Friday, he chastised the entire political establishment for failing the suffering cities. "Frankly, I am stunned by the lack of urgency that the Washington Democrats and Washington Republicans have toward our national recession and its impact on working families," wrote Mr. Flynn, who is a Democrat.
With his comments, Mr. Flynn joined the dizzying circle of what Mr. Rosenthal of the Eagleton Institute calls the "politics of blame."
"I think voters are ready to blame everybody who comes into their sights," he said.
Mr. Duke in Louisiana has touched the chord of discontent and, in the process, rattled the national Republican Party by seizing on their best themes to do so.
By contrast, Senator Harris Wofford, a Democrat who was appointed to serve out the term of the late Senator John Heinz, a Republican, has staged a remarkable comeback in Pennsylvania. He has used outsider politics to tar his Republican opponent, former Gov. Dick Thornburgh, who was until recently President Bush's Attorney General. In the process, Mr. Wofford has closed a 40-point gap in the polls.
Such strategies are not entirely without substance. To their credit, some candidates have also promoted issues that appear to be uppermost on voters' minds, including welfare dependency and health care costs.
"Some people have an image of voters as a group of mad dogs foaming at the mouth," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic consultant. "That's not what this is about. People are frustrated. They want people to pay attention to them, and they want a lot of help."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Amid Histrionics, Arabs and Israelis Team Up to Lose An Opportunity

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: MADRID

 BODY:
After three days of talks, the first ever between the leaders of Israel, Syria, Lebanon, Jordan and the Palestinians, a question mark still hangs over the Madrid peace conference: Was it history in the making, or just histrionics? The early assessment is that it may have been a little bit of both.
First, the bad news. The conference itself -- the speeches delivered by the parties -- became an incredible lost opportunity. This was the first peace conference broadcast live, around the world, and most importantly, to the countries involved. It was an ideal chance for Arab and Israeli leaders to reach out to their opponents' publics and try to reshape attitudes. Instead, they mostly reached out and poked one another in the eye, proving that they were not ready for prime time. 
 Even worse were the exchanges between the Syrians and the Israelis. This peace conference may have actually set back their relations. The public remarks by Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa of Syria were seen by many as anti-Semitic and demonstrated what a closed, dark room Syrian society really is. In his speech, Mr. Sharaa dwelled upon what he saw as the dual loyalties of American Jews and on the lovely life of Syria's decimated Jewish community, and he offered the most skewed interpretation of Zionism.
"The claims invoked by Israel for the migration of world Jewry are not sanctioned by any legal or humanitarian principle," he declared in a speech broadcast live in Israel. "If the entire world were to adopt such claims it would have to encourage all Christians to emigrate to the Vatican and all Muslims to Holy Mecca."
 
'A Regular Day'
 Watching Mr. Sharaa's spokesman carefully pick out non-Israeli reporters to ask questions at a news conference was chilling. Any notion that Syria had come to Madrid because of "new thinking," or for any other purpose than to make peace with Washington, was dispelled by his performance.
Yitzhak Shamir was scarcely better. His opening address was larded with the sort of propagandistic, anti-Palestinian, cliche-ridden lines normally reserved for late-night radio debates between Israelis and Arabs. Mr. Shamir's performance raised serious questions about whether he or his generation of the Likud party can ever bring themselves to reach a lasting accommodation with the Palestinians. After the first day of talks, a reporter asked Mr. Shamir how it felt to finally sit down face to face with all of Israel's Arab adversaries. He answered: "It was a regular day."
Nor was the conference uplifted by the performance of the Egyptian Foreign Minister, Amr Moussa. To put this conference together the United States had to reunite the Arab world, with its lowest common denominator politics, after it was fractured by the gulf war. Egypt demonstrated at this conference that it is much more interested in reasserting its leadership over this reunited Arab world, by hewing closely to the cautious Arab consensus, than it is in really being a bridge between Arabs and Israelis.
 
No Mention of Sadat
 Mr. Moussa did not miss an opportunity to bash Israel and did not take a single opportunity to tell his fellow Arabs in public that it was time for them to reach out to Israel the way President Anwar Sadat had. In fact, Mr. Moussa did not once mention the name of the Egyptian President who made peace with Israel. Instead, after a day of Arab speeches which heaped vitriol on Israel, and Mr. Shamir's speech which heaped it right back, Mr. Moussa declared: "We have listened to some passionate speeches which manifest how a change in attitudes is badly needed. I address Israel mainly. . ." More than a few Israelis at the conference remarked that if that is the sort of fairness Israel can expect from an Arab country it already has peace with, why bother with the others?
So much for the bad news. Perhaps the conference's most important achievement was forcing the Palestinians to finally get their act together. Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d -- by telling the Palestinians that they could not be represented in Madrid by Yasir Arafat and the usual Palestine Liberation Organization officials, and by telling them that they could not come without agreeing to discuss with Israel only self-rule in the occupied territories -- compelled the Palestinians from the West Bank and Gaza to develop their first coherent peace strategy addressed directly to Israelis.
Of all the conference participants, the Palestinian representatives, Hanan Ashrawi, Faisal Husseini and Haidar Abdel-Shafi, offered the only discernible signs of new thinking. Dr. Abdel-Shafi called on Israelis "to abandon mutal fear and mistrust, approach us as equals within a two-state solution and let us work for mutual benefit and well-being." The P.L.O. has never been able to articulate such clear-cut peace overtures to Israel, because of its internal divisions and its preoccupation with how it will look in inter-Arab politics. Only Palestinians from the West Bank and Gaza, who live with Israelis, could have carried such a message. A joke going around the conference hall was that the note Mr. Shamir slipped to an aide as Dr. Abdel-Shafi spoke on Friday, read: "We made a big mistake. We should have let the P.L.O. come."
It was striking that at the Palestinians' news conference, their spokesman, Albert Aghazarian, pointedly called on Israeli reporters, and he did so by name: "Dan Avidan, Israel Davar newspaper, you have the next question." Whether the Israelis and Palestinian representatives hold bilateral negotiations in Madrid or Washington, in public or in secret, it seems that they will find each other, and they will start to talk.
Intra-Palestinian politics may never be the same after this meeting. The West Bank Palestinian representatives here have had too much international news media attention, too many meetings on their own with the American Secretary of State and taken too many personal risks to come, to ever go back to the old days of taking a back seat to the P.L.O. But as the Palestinian saying goes: "One day honey, one day onions." When the spotlight is gone, they will have to face that the balance of power is so much in Israel's favor that the Government -- particularly this Israeli Government -- will offer them little. The Palestinian delegation here had lots of internal divisions and it is not clear they will be able to maintain their coherence in the more mundane, difficult days of negotiating alone with Israel and making real concessions. The conference raised expectations that are unlikely to be met soon -- if at all. There will be days of onion aplenty down the road.
Finally, the Soviets' behavior at this conference highlighted what everyone already knows: they are no longer a superpower. Mikhail S. Gorbachev, supposedly a conference co-sponsor, used his speech not to exort Israelis and Arabs to make peace, but to appeal that the world pay more attention to his economic problems. It is something that Israelis and Arabs should note. The end of the cold war made this conference possible, but also irrelevant, in the global strategic sense. Without the competition with the Soviets in the Middle East, and with no oil shortages, American interests there are minimal. The Arabs might be wise not to mistake the energy Washington put into this conference -- a spillover from the gulf war -- for a permanent committment of energy.
But therein lies Mr. Baker's dilemma. If this conference demonstrated anything, it was that these parties, when left alone, will accomplish nothing. The only way Mr. Baker could get agreement on even the shape of the table was by simply deciding what he thought was fair and imposing it. So it will be when it comes to making peace as well.
Mr. Baker is caught between American strategic interests, which will draw him away from the Middle East, and Arab-Israeli habits, which will demand his constant involvement in the Middle East.
These conflicting impulses were evident in Mr. Baker's closing remarks, in which he wavered between vowing that the United States will "provide encouragement, advice, recommendations, proposals to help the peace process," and his last word to the parties: "If you do not seize this historic opportunity, no one will blame anyone outside your region. The continuation and success of this process is in your hands."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, left, sitting across the table from the joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation at the Middle East peace talks in Madrid last week. Next to Mr. Shamir is the Lebanese delegation. (Agence France-Presse)
