SECTION: Section 4; Page 4; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 955 words

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Poland's Politicians Gather Few Votes And Less Trust

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG

DATELINE: WARSAW

 BODY:
Through the 45 years the Communists held power in Poland, people survived by divorcing themselves from what happened in public life. What they read in the censored newspapers, what they watched on the state-controlled television, or what they heard from their national leaders all belonged to the sham reality of "Oni" -- "Them.". Everything that really mattered, from personal life to political agitation, happened outside the established political system -- in the home, the Roman Catholic Church or the clandestine Solidarity movement.
The resulting cynicism toward politicians has proven more pervasive than the cathartic enthusiasm that swept away the Communist regimes of Eastern Europe in 1989. The idea of "Oni" lives on, and many people have come to view their elected government with the disdain once reserved for the Communists. Consider the results of Poland's parliamentary elections last week. Just two years ago, this country turned out to chase the Communists from power in elections overwhelmingly won by candidates from Solidarity. This time nearly 58 percent of the electorate stayed at home, and of the more than 100 parties that competed, none won more than 12 percent of the vote. The prospect of forming a governing coalition proved so insurmountable that President Lech Walesa offered himself as prime minister. 
 As leaders of the half dozen major parties began negotiating to build a coalition and choose someone other than Mr. Walesa as prime minister, many said the most worrisome development was that so many people hadn't bothered to vote. They took no comfort from comparisons with the United States, where a voter turnout of less than 50 percent in a legislative election is no surprise; here, it is widely agreed that Poland's pioneering economic reforms require the broadest possible social consensus.
 
'They Have No Hope'
 "People are very disappointed, they have no hope, and they don't believe any kind of politicians," said Jan Litynski, a member of the Democratic Union, a center-left party emerging from Solidarity. The party won 12 percent of the vote, narrowly outperforming the former Communists and a parade of parties representing peasants, Catholics, nationalists, and a center-right faction stemming from the Solidarity movement.
Public opinion surveys indicate that the nationwide angst stems mainly from the country's economic reform program, which has filled the stores with goods and stirred vigorous growth in the private sector but has also led to an unemployment rate of 10.5 percent, and the threat of further layoffs in collapsing state-run industries, in a land where jobs had been a constitutional right.
The endless hours of waiting in line for bread or meat that characterized the Communist years is gone, but so too is the web of subsidies that kept prices artificially low. Although standards of living have dropped less than 7 percent, a majority of people believe their family's economic situation will worsen in the next 12 months, according to public opinion polls. In an October poll by the Public Opinion Research Center, only 20 percent expressed unqualified support for the Government's economic approach.
This roughly matches the election results, in which the Liberals led by Prime Minister Jan Krysztof Bielecki and the Democratic Union, headed by former Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, together won 20 percent of the vote. Their parties were most closely associated with continuing the current approach.

 
Little Explaining
 One explanation for the dissatisfaction with politicians is that the first two post-Communist Governments, those led by Mr. Mazowiecki and Mr. Bielecki, did little to explain to the public exactly why dismantling the Communist economy was proving so painful.
At the giant Ursus tractor works, for example, the election last Sunday was followed by a meeting at which layoffs were announced. More than a dozen interviews on election day with workers at this former Solidarity stronghold revealed frustration and anger, even though the Government has intervened to keep most of the factory alive. Few felt their votes would make a difference.
The old habit of seeing the country's established government or industrial institutions as "Oni" has left a considerable legacy. Millions of Poles still feel a sense of entitlement to steal from the company or to work at half speed.
And in the Communist system, success was not in any way correlated to hard work or ability; it was based exclusively on who you knew, and getting rich was simply a matter of finding the right "uklad," or scheme. The few who got ahead through these strategems were deeply resented by the "masses."
These days, both foreign investors and the emerging new class of entrepeneurs are viewed with suspicion. Many see capitalism as a more efficient form of "uklad" in which a privileged few earn obscene amounts of money. The fact that some of Poland's new rich are former Communists who started their businesses by stealing state property has not helped. Nor has a spate of financial scandals, which earlier this year included the arrest of several senior banking officials, including the president of Poland's national bank.
Despite their grumbling, however, Poles have generally tolerated the economic reforms and Mr. Walesa said this week it was up to the Government to keep them going by energizing the apathetic voters. "This 60 percent of the electorate also supports reform, but they do not like our political involvement," Mr. Walesa said in an interview with the Warsaw daily Rzeczpospolita. "By not voting, they called upon us: Take up our problems, the problems we live with; otherwise we are not in this game."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Polish President Lech Walesa offering himself as prime minister after parliamentary elections last week. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
From Japan, New Ways To Sell Yet More Cars

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
Not long ago some of America's top trade negotiators tracked down the head of General Motors Corporation's Saturn project -- the high-tech car that was supposed to undo Detroit's bad habits and take the Japanese down a notch -- and asked a loaded question: Why wasn't G.M. selling its sporty, low-cost car in Tokyo?
After all, they pointed out, the United States, under pressure from the Big Three car makers, has turned autos into the season's No. 1 trade issue with Japan. Cars and car parts, more than two-thirds of the swelling trade deficit, will be high on the agenda when President Bush arrives here later this month. The Saturn would be a great way to reverse the image of American car makers in Japan, they said. 
 "What we ran into was an attitude that we hear all the time from our own manufacturers," one frustrated trade negotiator said. "You know, 'We'll export when we are done filling the American market.' Only by then, it will be a four-year-old car. And the Japanese will laugh."
More than a decade after Japan and the United States began wrestling over cars -- after tens of thousands of American auto workers have lost their jobs, after Japanese plants have sprouted throughout the Midwest, after the utilitarian, $10,000 Toyota Corolla has given way to the luxurious, $45,000 Lexus -- Tokyo and Detroit are talking past each other more than ever. Nowhere is that clearer than at the world's premiere car exhibition, the Tokyo Motor Show, held every two years. And the 1.5 million visitors streaming through -- most take the train, because you have to be crazy to drive in Tokyo -- are learning that the visions of the automobile emerging from Japan and America are dramatically different.
 
Imagining the Future
 The Japanese makers have used the show to fantasize about the "personal car," centerpiece of an anticipated era in which the roads will be filled with an array of distinctive autos -- futuristic Batmobiles, back-to-the-40's coupes, hydrogen-powered getabouts. Many of these cars, now just prototypes, will not make it to the highways for years, if ever. But they point in a direction that is unmistakable. "If we have learned anything in the past few years," said Yoshio Nakatani, the general manager of Toyota's Americas Planning Division, "it is that people do not want to drive a car just like their neighbor's."
Rightly or wrongly, Detroit is still driving in a different direction -- still aiming at Henry Ford's ideal of mass production of family cars. A G.M. executive, walking through the Tokyo show on the day after the company announced a $1.1 billion third-quarter loss, said the Japanese technology was impressive, but he dismissed the cars as "very much made for niche markets."
To the Japanese, that is exactly the point: In coming decades, the whole auto market will be a series of niches. And they are already organizing themselves that way. At Mazda's plant in Hiroshima, three or four wholly different models come down a single production line; the robots select different parts depending on what car is being built next. Such "lean production" allows even low-volume cars to be profitable, but it is still not the way Detroit does things.
In addition, no American car makers have yet to build a full design center in Japan, where many believe the center of auto design has moved. The Japanese, however, are deliberately moving their design activities out of Japan. "What we want to do is create a series of largely independent companies that design and develop cars for different regions and cultures," said Nobuhiko Kawamoto, Honda's president.
The day is not far off. Honda designed its station wagon in America for Americans (it has been a disappointment so far), and next year it plans its first all-European model. Nissan turned a series of "retro cars" -- specialty models reminiscent of America in the 50's -- into a huge hit in Japan, but so far it has not tried to sell them elsewhere. This year Toyota has a wide Camry for Americans, a narrower one for Japanese. Its Avalon was designed in California. The industrial irony is clear: Buyers seem to want an American look wrapped around a Japanese chassis.
 
Electric Cars?
 Japan's auto makers, though, have an Achilles' wheel or two of their own. Their move to big luxury models has eroded their fuel economy ratings. It has also begun to undercut one of their own favorite myths: That their luxury models are aimed at taking market share from German, not American, auto makers. With Japan's share of the American market now just short of 30 percent, such claims look ridiculous.
Moreover, Japanese auto companies are not yet the environmental visionaries that their public relations staffs insist they are. While a few are working on recyclable car parts, they have been slow to develop electric cars. "We will beat them to the market," said Gary W. Dickinson, who heads some of G.M.'s big technology projects, referring to its forthcoming electric car.
Such victories for G.M. may be hollow if the world's biggest auto maker doesn't begin to take the world's second biggest auto market seriously. Which takes one back to the Saturn. The problem with fulfilling the American market first is that it perpetuates a mind set in American factories that exporting is what one does with cars that are left over. More important, by not challenging the Japanese in their own market, G.M. loses a chance to determine how competitive the Saturn really is, against the best players on the block. If it did, Detroit might see a lot of things happening here -- new designs, new consumer tastes -- before the Japanese take it by surprise, once again, in America.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Why Older People Are Richer Than Other Americans

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
The cherished idea that life gets a little better for each succeeding generation of Americans is being challenged anew by economic research suggesting that if present trends persist, only the best trained will continue to prosper while other Americans remain stuck at current standards of living or fall behind.
The notion that some Americans will be the first generation to live at a lower level than their parents has emerged as a campaign theme for some Democratic presidential candidates. More important, it seems to be gaining ground as an issue in public opinion polls. In a New York Times/CBS News poll taken last month, 52 percent of respondents said the next generation will be worse off than today's. In March, the number was half that, 26 percent. 
 "When you ask about generations coming up, it depends on who in that generation you are asking about," said Claudia Golden, a Harvard economist, "and at no time in our history has that 'who' question mattered more. The college-educated person is doing better than before, and is also in a position to do extraordinarily well. But if you are looking at a high-school graduate not going on to college, entering the job market for the first time, particularly if he is African-American, his future is not very good."
Although intergenerational wealth issues are a relatively new field for researchers, there is some evidence that this economic generation gap is rooted in two trends: the inability of many young families to buy a home -- often the primary means of amassing and retaining wealth -- and flat or declining incomes for a broad range of workers.
As a result, wealth, which is defined as assets after debt has been subtracted, has been accruing mostly in the hands of those middle-aged and older. Figures from a 1986 Federal Reserve Bank survey, published last May by Robert B. Avery of Cornell University and Arthur B. Kennickell of the Federal Reserve in Washington, show that in 1983 households headed by someone under 35 had an average net worth of $45,700; three years later that figure had slipped to $38,600. At the same time, households headed by those 65 and older increased on average from $208,000 to $218,000. All age groups under 55 grew poorer on average; all groups over 55 grew richer.
In 1963, according to the same survey, households headed by those over 65 made up 19 percent of the population and owned 26 percent of the wealth; in 1986, that group represented roughly 21 percent but its share of wealth had grown to 33 percent, while that under 35 -- the baby-boomers -- had increased from 18 percent to 23 percent, yet remained at 6 percent for its share of the wealth.
Private homes represent a large part of each generation's net worth. For older Americans, who bought their first homes in the 1950's and 60's, long ownership equals equity. Today 85 percent of homeowners 65 or older own their homes outright, debt free, according to David Weil, a Brown University economist.
But ownership rates among young adults are falling. Those rates have increased since 1973 only among households headed by those 55 or older, from 76 percent to 80 percent in 1990, according to a recent survey by the Joint Center for Housing Studies at Harvard. They stayed even over that period for those 45 to 54, but slipped from 51 percent to 44 percent for 25 to 34 and from 23 percent to 15 percent for people under 25.
 
'Losing Absolutely'
 The problem is that housing prices have sharply risen above the rate of inflation, while incomes, in constant dollars, have not kept pace for many people. Frank Levy, a University of Maryland economist whose study, "The Economic Future of American Families," did much to spark the economic generation-gap debate, has shown how incomes spiraled for men ages 45 to 54, working full time, from 1948 onward.
In 1948, this group had a median income of $16,702 in 1989 dollars. By 1958, incomes had risen to $23,400, an increase of 20.7 percent. Ten years later, in 1968, their wages had climbed to $28,400, a 40 percent increase over the decade, and by 1978, to $32,500, up another 14.4 percent. Yet by 1988, this group's wages had stagnated. Productivity per worker had also stalled, Dr. Levy said.
When the broad range of incomes was rising, even those who at the lower end of the scale improved their lives, Dr. Levy said. "If the underlying trend in wages is rising, then you can lose relative to other people but still be better off than you were," he said. "But if the underlying trend is flat, as it is now, then when you lose relative to other people, you are also losing absolutely."
The losers are those with marginal educations in a specialized work force. Dr. Levy, whose work has been picked up by the Presidential campaign of Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, pointed to research showing that wages and employment have risen for college-educated production workers while falling for the semi-skilled and unskilled. But if the future belongs to the college-educated, as Dr. Golden of Harvard suggested, it belongs to relatively few: the proportion of high school graduates who earned bachelors degrees has been constant at about 25 percent for years.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
When Chainsaws Pare the Hills of Ancient Trees

 BODY:
Not counting Alaska, only about 5 percent of the virgin American forests that existed when the first iron axes arrived on Leif Ericson's ships still stand. Many of the last ancient trees have been spared only by a celebrated diversion, the Fish and Wildlife Service's decision in 1990 to protect a little bird called the northern spotted owl.
That ruling infuriates Washington and Oregon loggers whose jobs are threatened -- the bodies of spotted owls have been found nailed to road signs. But like the snail darter in Tennessee and the delta smelt in California, the last 3,000 pairs of owls were fading bit players in world ecology until they became the symbol of their habitat and the legal tripwire for rescuing it. They can only survive in the mix of 300- to 1,000-year-old trees, fallen logs, dead snags, new seedlings and rich forest floor that characterizes old-growth forest. 
 Some feel that relying on cute or exotic animals to save the day obscures the huge environmental and economic stakes involved in the old-growth battles. The real issue, environmentalists say, is that an irreplaceable treasure is being sawn down for the short-term gain of timber companies and the politicians who support them in the name of saving jobs, and that thinly disguised Government subsidies to the timber industry are encouraging this.
"We're trying to avoid this 'endangered species of the month' parade -- we can't expect the Endangered Species act to carry all the weight," said Representative Jim Jontz, an Indiana Democrat who has introduced bills to ban selling Federal timber below cost and to protect old forests. "We need an 'endangered ecosystems' approach."
Ancient forests were cut in the 1980's at the rate of 70,000 acres a year. They cannot be recreated simply by replanting and waiting.
Harvesting now commonly means clearcutting patches of 40 to 640 acres, burning the cut limbs and debris and reseeding. This practice eliminates decaying trees, a fertilizer source. Unshaded soil heats up, killing microbes that help new trees take root. Replanting with rows of prime lumber conifers then produces not a replacement forest but a mere tree farm, which supports few species. One hard storm can wash off generations of topsoil, wiping out seedlings, smothering fish eggs in spawning streams and making the water too shallow and warm for the 20-pound trout of the Northwest.
Almost all the old-growth forests that remain are in the hands of the Forest Service, the Federal Bureau of Land Management, the states of Washington and Oregon or small timber lot owners.
It is these forests that produce the highest profits for timber companies. Lodgepole pine in the dry eastern Rockies may sell for $25 per 1,000 board feet, but Japanese buyers are paying nearly $750 for the same amount of Douglas fir from the rainy Cascades if it's fine enough for the exposed-beam construction of traditional houses. Largely for that reason, a quarter of the logs cut in the Pacific Northwest are exported.
 
The Beauty of the Wood
 The price difference is in the wood's strength and beauty. The grain of thick old trees is knot-free and as compelling to stare at as fire is. The beams made from spruces, ponderosa and sugar pines, and silver and Douglas firs will dry without warping and carry heavy loads. But exporting raw logs from Federal land is illegal, and there are many domestic buyers. Sitka spruces become guitars. Rot-resistant redwoods become decks and picnic tables. Incense cedars, whose smell repels moths, become closet lining, fenceposts and pencils. Seven-foot-thick red cedars are split into shingles.
For decades, timber companies fought to keep the public trees from being cut because it depressed the price of their own timberland. But by the late 1980's, the companies had cut virtually all their old growth, and regional Forest Service administrators now say that timber state Congressmen are pressing them to sell trees faster than the public lands can sustain.
The companies argue that people want high-quality lumber, and remind environmentalists that the national forests were set aside, like Europe's, to be harvested regularly. Some timbermen refer to the old forests as overmature thickets where fine trees are allowed to rot and jobs could be created instead.
Another push to cut has come from Wall Street. Corporate raiders spotted undervalued forests acquired in railroad-building days. The Maxxam Group of Houston, for example, bought the Pacific Lumber Company of California and logged its redwoods to pay off the debt.
But the most economically irrational attack on ancient forests is not in the Northwest, but in Alaska. There, environmentalists say, despite the Tongass Timber Reform Act of 1990, two mills owned by the Louisiana-Pacific Corporation and a Japanese consortium are paying as little as $3 for 500-year-old sitka spruces -- a wood so light and strong that Howard Hughes used it in his gigantic Spruce Goose airplane -- and grinding them into pulp, something that can be made from any ten-inch tree farm specimen. The Forest Service is losing 75 to 95 cents on every dollar it spends for forest upkeep.
Meanwhile, Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. is planning to convene the "God Squad," a panel of Federal officials empowered to grant exemptions to the Endangered Species Act and to ask it to allow 44 sales of old-growth Oregon timber halted by the spotted owl ruling.
But companies, fearing that the future will get bleaker, are aggressively developing wood substitutes. Oriented-strand board, a new plywood, can be made by fusing glue-covered strips of sawmill waste or trees like aspen. More walls are being built of thin steel 2-by-4s, not pine ones. And companies are even importing the Japanese technology that helps foreign sawmills pay so much more for exported American old-growth -- thin, laser-guided saw blades that get more planks from a log.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
How Most of the Public Forests Are Sold to Loggers at a Loss

BYLINE: By Donald G. McNeil Jr.

 BODY:
In 1905 Gifford Pinchot, America's first national forester, assured Congress that if it would place the national forest reserves under his direction in the Department of Agriculture he would have them running at a profit within five years. He went so far as to say that he would not even need the $1 million a year he was given for research and promotion.
The National Forest Service has never made good on Mr. Pinchot's promise. Last year, Congress gave it $550 million to pay for growing and selling timber. F. Dale Robertson, the present chief, reported that its "net revenues" from timber sales for 1990 were $629 million. 
 But a growing chorus of tree-smart economists are challenging timber policy, not on environmental grounds but as business propositions. They are producing cash-flow analyses that conclude that the Treasury is losing up to $200 million a year on timber and, by conventional business wisdom, ought to stop.
Congress held hearings last week on a bill introduced by Representative Jim Jontz, an Indiana Democrat, that would phase out all money-losing sales over five years and aid towns whose sawmills were forced to close.
But the question remains: why sell the national forests at all? There is no timber shortage. There are more trees in the United States than there were in 1920.
Three historic changes are responsible. Oil and gas heat replaced fireplaces and stoves that used to burn 400 cubic feet of wood per American per year; cars, trucks and tractors replaced the nation's 50 million horses and the one-third of all agricultural lands that fed them; advances in seeds and fertilizers mean the nation's crops are being grown on about 400 million acres, the same amount under cultivation in 1920. On the rest, trees grew again.
The national forests have no lock on the timber market. About 72 percent of United States timberland is privately owned.
Trees, like most other crops, grow best on land that is warm, wet and flat. Most Forest Service land, by contrast, is mountainous, dry and cold, the land neither homesteaders nor railroads wanted. It is nearly as impractical to farm timber there as it would be to farm tomatoes. Trees grow slowly, roads are expensive, fires are hard to fight and small towns may lose their watersheds or tourist trade when the forests are logged.
But publicly owned trees are cut because the Forest Service sells them so cheaply that loggers would be foolish to say no. It builds roads, pays rangers, absorbs the risks of fires and insects, then sells at a loss.
Historically, the Forest Service has set minimum bids without figuring in its own costs -- a normal part of a business's profit calculation. When loggers compete, their bids are often twice the minimums, suggesting that the many one-bid sales are underpriced.
There are 122 national forests, and the Forest Service admits that 65 lost money on timber in 1990. Economists for Congress, the Wilderness Society and Cascade Holistic Economic Consultants calculate instead that between 98 and 108 lost money. All but one of the money-makers are in the Northwest; the exception is the Allegheny in Pennsylvania, which is full of valuable black cherry used in furniture.
Robert E. Wolf, a forester and retired Congressional Research Service economist, contends that the Treasury has lost $5.6 billion on national forest trees over the last decade.
Critics like Mr. Wolf say Forest Service accounting conceals costs several ways:
While dirt and gravel logging roads normally last about 25 years, the Service amortizes them with "cut rotation per forest" formulas that spread the cost over at least 100 years. In the Chugach Forest in Alaska, they were spread out over 1,800 years. "It's as if the current Italian Government was still paying for the Appian Way," said Steve Richardson, a staff member for Representative Mike Synar, an Oklahoma Democrat whose committee commissioned Mr. Wolf's study.
In profit-per-forest breakdowns, $110 million for the 4,000 people in the Service's Washington and regional offices is simply left out. Land surveys and road work paid for by Congress are left out, even if they are for timber. The 25 percent of sales paid in lieu of taxes to counties where the trees are logged is not counted, though any business subtracts taxes from profits.
In separate analyses of other benefits of logging, the Forest Service says 91 of its 122 forests produce "positive returns," when the value of creating wildlife habitat, pastureland, increasing water runoff and adding roads for recreation are calculated. But the critics say these analyses inflate benefits. Increased runoff, for example, is disastrous in spring floods. Clearcut patches of mountain are not easily reached by grazing cattle. Benefits to wildlife are negated if some species disappear or if new roads into deep woods invite poachers in.
"They make the savings and loan business look like an angel," said Mr Wolf. "If a private business did this, they wouldn't just end up bankrupt -- they'd end up in court."
Another quirk in Forest Service budgeting is a provision that lets regional administrators sell timber for cash to manage forests with. This has led to contradictions like timber cuts in grizzly bear habitat and Indian archaeological sites to pay for saving similar sites.
The Forest Service has argued that thousands of jobs will be lost if below-cost sales are stopped. There is no doubt that whole communities have come to depend on those sales. The number of jobs is disputed; but environmentalists reply that the demand for wood is steady, so new jobs are appearing on private lands.
In any case, timber jobs are falling on their own. New mills use fewer workers, logs exported are jobs lost. Over 200 sawmills in the Northwest closed in the 1980's. In Oregon, the number of loggers and sawmill workers dropped from 42,000 in 1979 to 33,000 last year, but the state's economy added 100,000 jobs.
Economists differ on solutions. Some would ban money-losing sales. Some would use them only to save jobs. Others say forests could make up the loss with fees for hiking, hunting and fishing. The Forest Service has said it does not want new laws banning sales, but says it will modify parts of its accounting.

HEADLINE: IRAQ IS BLOCKING AID DISTRIBUTION

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 2

 BODY:
The Iraqi Government is blocking attempts by international relief organizations to distribute food and medicine directly to hundreds of thousands of Iraqis suffering from poor health and malnutrition in the aftermath of a war and a trade embargo, relief officials and Iraqi authorities say.
Iraq's Minister of Health, Abdul Salam M. Saaid, said in an interview he would not allow food distribution by relief agencies except through the Government's distribution and rationing system. He accused the relief agencies of food distribution "gimmicks" that he said were "designed to keep quiet the good people in the United States who don't like to see others suffer." 
 The minister indicated that if the people of Europe and the United States saw a vast and direct food distribution effort under way in Iraq, it would quiet their consciences and "shut up" their opposition to continuing United Nations sanctions. These, he said, are the ultimate cause of suffering in Iraq.
Mr. Saaid's remarks, made in an interview this week, reflect how much the struggle to provide emergency care to Iraq's 18 million people has become politicized in the wake of the Persian Gulf war. The United States and its allies are seeking to maintain tight economic sanctions until the Government of President Saddam Hussein fully complies with all of the terms of the cease-fire resolution that ended formal hostilities last winter.
 
Food Stays in Warehouses
 As a consequence of the Iraqi Government's policy against third-party food distribution, food worth about $4 million, including infant formula and high-protein food packages specially prepared for children under 5, has been sitting in warehouses in Baghdad and Jordan for weeks, relief officials said.
Most of the food belongs to the United Nations Children's Fund, which in August proposed the idea of setting up special nutrition centers across the country to help about 340,000 Iraqi children who are believed to be most vulnerable to dying of malnutrition or infectious disease. The Government rationing system provides only one-quarter of what is generally acknowledged to be an infant's requirement of powdered infant formula.
Douglas Broderick, the representative here of Catholic Relief Services, a private American group, said the Iraqi authorities in recent weeks had shut down a food distribution program that was using churches and mosques in Mosul and Baghdad to serve 60,000 people.
Then, Mr. Broderick said, Health Ministry officials in southern Iraq blocked the direct distribution of 250 tons of food that he had brought into the country to help feed 23,000 families in the Amarra area north of Basra. Mr. Broderick said the food has been sitting in a warehouse for several weeks.
 
'Very Well Focused Effort'
 In Amarra, he said, "there are 3,000 pregnant women and this was a very well focused program in a population that is at risk." Iraqi authorities have suggested that the food be turned over to Iraqi Government groups, but so far Mr. Broderick has declined.
Only in Kurdistan, where the Baghdad Government has lost its authority over territory and local government, are United Nations agencies giving food aid directly to the people, officials said.
Mr. Saaid has told relief agency officials that Iraq fears rioting and demeaning scenes of people grasping for food at distribution centers if agencies are allowed to set up their own distribution centers.
"Are we a nation of beggars?" the minister asked.
"The system is there," he said. "Just open the tap for us."
He asked that the United States release some of the $1.4 billion in Iraqi funds still frozen in American banks for the purchase of food and medicine.
 
'Political Game' Cited
 A critical battleground in the war of oratory that continues between Baghdad and Washington is the effect of economic sanctions on public health in Iraq. A number of studies have tried to document increased mortality among children under 5 years of age from disease, malnutrition and the destructive effects of inflation, which has left most Iraqi families unable to afford adequate supplies of food.
Mr. Saaid said his ministry was reluctant to release figures on child mortality "because health has become part of a political game designed to undermine a political stand."
But Mr. Saaid's Under Secretary, Dr. Shawki Murqus, disclosed during the interview that projections last May by a Harvard University study team about the war's devastating impact on public health had not been borne out by official Government figures.
The Harvard team's report said increases in infectious disease compounded by poor nutrition could cause 170,000 deaths among children beyond the normal mortality rate. But Dr. Murqus said that the total deaths of children under 5 in Iraq since August 1990 was 19,863. This figure, he said, includes normal mortality as well as excess deaths caused by disease and malnutrition.
The figure is far lower than any projection developed by outside experts. It does not reflect thousands of deaths that occurred "outside" the public health system during the flight of two million Kurds last winter to the Turkish and Iranian borders and during a rebellion in southern Iraq among Shiite Muslims.

HEADLINE: CHINA CHIEFS SEEM EDGY AND DIVIDED

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 2

 BODY:
Two months after the collapse of Soviet Communism, China's leaders seem increasingly edgy and divided, and there are signs that they have responded to the events in the Soviet Union by deciding to tighten their grip on the nation further.
Chinese newspapers have carried more statements about "class struggle," there are calls for intensifying Marxist education, leaders of many work units have recently warned employees not to meet foreigners without permission, and officials at one Beijing university even called on staff members to report on colleagues who have contacts with foreigners. The officials insisted that even private correspondence with Westerners should be reported to the authorities, a Chinese who was present said. 
 That person, and many others, characterize the situation as "nei jin, wai song" -- tranquillity on the surface, repression within.
The tighter controls are imperceptible at first glance, for the streets of Beijing abound these days with mountains of cabbages rather than crowds of police, and the free markets spill out as much as ever with bright jackets and lacy underwear and other emblems of free enterprise. But members of the urban middle class, especially those in sensitive work places or with foreign friends, are feeling the political cold front.
"I can't help worrying if my leader is going to call me aside this afternoon for seeing you," a scholar in his 30's said, laughing nervously as he bid a foreigner goodbye. He said the staff members of his work unit had been banned from seeing foreigners and had been warned that the Central Intelligence Agency was trying to step up spying in China.
 
Gates Statement Cited
 The talk of the C.I.A. stems from a statement by Robert M. Gates, President Bush's nominee to be Director of Central Intelligence, in his Senate confirmation hearings. In answer to a question about China on Sept. 17, Mr. Gates said, "I think more can be done through expanded human intelligence collection."
The statement was scarcely noticed in the United States, but it has been published in secret news summaries for Chinese officials. Already nervous after the Soviet events, some hard-liners are taking it as proof of their fears of a secret American conspiracy of "peaceful evolution" that would lead to replacing the Communist Government. The leadership takes this supposed plot so seriously that it is said to have formed an "Anti-Peaceful Evolution Working Group."
Another indication that the leaders are jittery, according to one knowledgeable Chinese, is a shuffle in the command of the Chengdu Military Region. Zhang Taiheng, the commander of the region, is said to have been summoned to Beijing for "study" and retirement, and will be replaced by an officer from the General Logistics Department in Beijing.
The reason for the shuffle apparently is a helicopter crash last spring in Tibet in which a number of senior military officials died. The central authorities reportedly complained that General Zhang had led three helicopters to inspect the border area with India, even though he had been told not to take so many top generals to the area.
"Normally it would be a minor matter, but the center is very fearful now of generals who don't obey orders, and so it wants to take a very stern action," said the Chinese who recounted the episode. Government spokesmen in Chengdu could not confirm whether there had been a change in the command.
It is difficult to gauge the tension in cities outside Beijing -- partly because the authorities are so tense that they are denying permission for American correspondents to travel virtually anywhere outside the capital. The Government has refused permission lately to visit even innocuous places such as Jilin and Hebei Provinces, where there are no known political problems.
 
Official Press Is Split
 One sign of a split in the leadership lately is the divided nature of the official press. One line of articles recently has focused on the financial problems of state-owned enterprises and has emphasized that the main task in China is to boost economic reform and raise the standard of living. This line of reasoning appears to have the backing of the nation's patriarch, Deng Xiaoping.
The other line of articles in the official press argues that the most serious threat comes not from economic problems but from political enemies at home and abroad.
In a recent People's Daily article, a patron of the hard-liners, Deng Liqun, called for more "class struggle" -- a term that for many intellectuals has frightening associations with the brutality of the Cultural Revolution from 1966 to 1976. Meanwhile, the People's Liberation Army Daily revived another old expression with similar connotations: "You must beat a dog even when it is drowning."
The phrase was often used to justify further attacks on "counterrevolutionaries" who had already been persecuted. The newspaper warned that showing mercy to such a drowning "dog" is a mistake because it may swim ashore and bite people again. "Therefore," it said, "it should be bitterly beaten."

HEADLINE: THE MIDDLE EAST TALKS;
Syria's Tough Choice

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MADRID, Nov. 2

 BODY:
Despite Syria's serious hesitation in the last two days over joining the next stage of the Middle East peace conference here, Arab delegates say neither Syria, nor any other participant, can afford to stay out of the process indefinitely.
Most of those attending the talks, including the Israelis, say they view the Syrian position as part of what they predict will be years of exhaustive negotiations. The general sentiment here is that the Syrians will eventually take up a role in the talks, if not Sunday, then in a few days or a few weeks. 
 Otherwise, according to this line of thought, they will face an intolerable isolation in a fast-changing world, especially since the Palestinians, Jordanians and Israelis have agreed to talk whether the Syrians come or not.
Lotfy al-Khouli, a well-known Arab columnist and expert on Arab and Palestinian affairs who is a member of the Egyptian delegation, summed up the general opinion when he said today that the Syrians would come back because the country that issued the invitation for the talks was the United States -- now the world's solitary superpower and, he added, a nation none of the participants could afford to alienate.
 
Fear of Being Left Out
 "Everyone is inside the peace cage and the door has been closed," Mr. Khouli said. "It's an American cage from which Syrians, just like Israelis and Palestinians, cannot really get out. Anyone who thinks otherwise is engaged in wishful thinking."
There are other factors in the assessments here of Syria's future role. Several Arab delegates here said the Syrians were also concerned that talks between Palestinians and Israelis might move much faster than talks between the Syrians and the Israelis, leaving Syria stranded as other Arabs settle with Israel.
Experts here say Syria is maneuvering with its traditional politics in a different Arab world from the one it used to inhabit. The Persian Gulf states have been freed from Syrian and Iraqi intimidation by the gulf crisis. Palestinians, who never had much affection for Syria, have appeared to win publicity points here, and they see these talks as their last chance to win a measure of autonomy. Iraq, because of the gulf war, has been wiped out as an Arab force for years to come. All these changes affect the mix.
Among the sea changes of the last few years is a fundamental and revolutionary transformation in the Arab mindset, a diminution of Israel's role as the foremost regional ally of the United States and the emergence of the United States as the world power.
 
Changing Old Patterns
 Together, these factors have deeply affected the nature of the discourse among Arabs and with the rest of the world. They have also swept up both Israel and the Arabs in a process that many here regard as one made in the United States.
The process is annihilating stereotypes of the past and forcing changes in old patterns of action. Among Palestinians, this evolution has been starkly expressed by the chief Palestinian spokeswoman at the Madrid talks, Hanan Ashrawi, when she proclaimed the other day that "40 years of violence have got us nowhwere."
For Syria, far beyond any concern over the surface issue of the venue of the talks, there is a deep concern about forging ahead with the talks and thus giving the appearance that it is too quickly abandoning the hard-line public statements it has endorsed for a quarter of century on the topic of the Israeli-occupied territories.
Between the Arabs themselves, the new attitudes are illustrated by what the Egyptian Foreign Minister, Amr Moussa, calls the "civilized modalities of dealing with each other."

 
Themes From Sadat
 These themes began to evolve more than a decade ago, when President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt visited Israel and called for peace between Arabs and Jews from the podium of the Parliament. Faced at first with utter Arab rejection, the themes Mr. Sadat advocated have now found their way to the Arab mainstream.
The Madrid negotiations are in fact picking up after the Camp David accords, which brought peace between Egypt and Israel. They have emerged as an acceptable Arab choice as a consequence of the gulf crisis and the gulf war.
The war also emboldened Arab moderates in other respects too. Many are openly stating now what they have always whispered in private: that their vital interests are firmly attached to an enduring alliance with the West.
 
Support From Saudis
 King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, whose country hardly uttered the word "Israel" a few years ago, is declaring almost weekly now his support of the American peace initiative, vowing to support it, and pouring lavish praise on President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d.
For its part, the United States has framed the parameters of the "red line" of which it is the author by adopting an increasingly firm tone with Israel.
The word "evenhanded" has been pronounced repeatedly by American officials to describe their shifting approach to the Middle East peace process.
To get Israel to attend the peace conference, Mr. Bush used the carrot of $10 billion in loan guarantees for helping settle Soviet Jewish immigrants. Moreover, the United States leaned on Israel to swallow the presence of Palestinian delegates who are demonstrably affiliated with the Palestine Liberation Organization -- although the Israelis have vowed never to do business with the P.L.O.
Arab gulf countries have advanced a proposition to end their economic boycott of Israel if it were to stop Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank and the Gaza strip.
 
Egypt's Leadership
 President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, heir to Mr. Sadat's legacy, treated as a pariah for having supported the peace treaty with Israel, has recaptured much of Egypt's traditional leadership in the region. Almost every week Arab diginitaries travel to Cairo, and the League of Arab States moved back there this year, to a home not far from where the Israeli flag flutters over the country's embassy in downtown Cairo.
After the Persian Gulf war, a sort of stampede has been under way among Arab leaders, including President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, to fashion a political and strategic relationship with the United States after its emergence as the world's only superpower. In this, many of them hope to emulate the special relationship that the Israelis cultivated over the last three decades in their ties to the United States.
This new mindset is buttressed by the continuing collapse of the Communist empire, leaving intransigent Mideast regimes, like Iraq, Libya, Syria and Iran, with poor alternatives and even poorer arguments to justify their stands.
 
Pressures on Syria
 Over the last few weeks, a conference held in Teheran to inveigh against the peace process went largely unremarked in many Arab capitals. And in yet another sign of the new era that is affecting the Syrians' situation, Palestinian youths poured out into the streets of the Israeli-occupied West Bank on Wednesday to place olive branches on Israeli armored cars patrolling their cities.
These and other events have added to the pressures on the Syrians to come to the table, delegates here agree. As Mr. Moussa of Egypt said in a conversation today: "There is a red line no one can cross. Time and the evolution of things in the region make it imperative to change the way we think. There is a new order being fashioned with the good offices of the United States and no one can be excepted from it."

HEADLINE: With Pride Now and Economic Pain Ahead, Zambia Swears In New Leader

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LUSAKA, Zambia, Nov. 2

 BODY:
In a rare democratic transition, Frederick Chiluba, a trade union leader, was sworn in here today as President of Zambia. Tens of thousands of people walked miles in the hot sun to a grassy square in the front of the nation's High Court to witness the inauguration.
They listened to the new President pledge that "freedom to work and freedom of speech" would replace the "corruption, repression and dictatorship" of the past. 
 Earlier in the day, the only other President Zambia has known, Kenneth D. Kaunda, conceded defeat by a landslide at the polls on Thursday.
In a televised speech, the 67-year-old Mr. Kaunda, an often-emotional man who clutched his signature white linen handkerchief in his left hand, offered an apology to the people of his south-central African nation, saying, "I tried to do my very best."
 
Comeback Seen as Unlikely
 He said he would work to pick up the pieces of his shattered political organization, the United National Independence Party, which had virtually run the country. But few took the idea seriously. Zambians seemed to agree with former President Jimmy Carter, leader of an election observer team, that Mr. Kaunda now deserved a role as a "respected senior statesman."
The ousted President, well known in Africa and internationally, achieved far less success with the Zambian economy. He has bequeathed to the 48-year-old Chiluba a bankrupt country.
This is a comedown from Zambia's position as one of the richest nations on the continent after its first decade of independence from Britain, beginning in 1964. In colonial days, what is now Zambia was known as Northern Rhodesia.
In Thursday's voting, widespread disgust with the decrepit state of the economy and the low esteem in which many had come to hold Mr. Kaunda helped provide Mr. Chiluba's stunning majority.
Although the returns were still incomplete 48 hours after the polls closed, Larry Garber, a senior consultant with the National Democratic Institute in Washington who came here with Mr. Carter, said he believed that final counting would give Mr. Chiluba about 80 percent of the vote.
Officials of Mr. Chiluba's party, the Movement for Multiparty Democracy, said partial results showed they had won more than 100 of the 150 seats in Parliament.
 
Dissent Had a Price
 For many members and supporters of Mr. Chiluba's party, today's swearing-in represented a hard-earned victory. Sitting on the stage behind him were several civilians who had gone to jail for plotting a coup against Mr. Kaunda in the early 1980's.
Zambians seemed proud that, in contrast with much of Africa, their country was able to carry out multiparty elections without violence. "It was good Kaunda had to stay and face it," said Masiye Nyirenda, 26, a bank clerk. "We helped him pack his things and leave by voting. No shots have been fired. The people have rejected him."
Many voters credited the relatively smooth running of the elections to the presence of international monitoring teams including Mr. Carter's, as well as two Zambian teams, which fielded more than 3,000 observers.
Mr. Chiluba, as leader since 1974 of the nation's robust labor union movement, the Zambia Congress of Trade Unions, was a clear choice to lead the country's newly invigorated political opposition in the election.
But some now question whether he has the political acumen to carry through the promise of democracy and the economic skills to straighten out the troubled economy. Senior supporters say Mr. Chiluba was chosen for his vote-getting ability rather than experience in government.
 
Austerity Will Be Needed
 Those views notwithstanding, Mr. Chiluba, who describes himself as a believer in free enterprise, faces the need to make some unpopular moves. He tried to prepare the way during the campaign by telling voters that Government-subsidized food -- one of Mr. Kaunda's methods of keeping city dwellers happy -- was not a viable economic policy.
He has pledged to remove the subsidies in stages. When Mr. Kaunda reduced subsidies last year, there were riots, and out of fear of violence just before the election, he broke a commitment with the World Bank to reduce the subsidies again in September.
Mr. Chiluba has argued that the subsidies have helped break the nation -- huge amounts of state revenue has been spent on keeping grain prices artificially low for the consumer -- leaving little to pay the farmers who grow it. Thus, many farmers did not grow corn this year, leaving the country with a substantial shortage and predictions of famine in some regions.
 
Avid Reader
 Frederick Jacob Titus Chiluba was born the son of a miner in Kitwe, a major city in the northern copper belt, on April 30, 1943. He dropped out of school because of lack of money and completed his secondary education in 1971 through a correspondence course from London. Since then, he has continued to read political science and history, often quoting from the biographies of world figures.
As a young man, he went to Tanzania to work as a clerk on a sisal plantation, where, he has said, he developed his interest in the labor movement.
In 1966, he joined Atlas Copco, a Swedish mining-equipment company in the city of Ndola as an accounts assistant, and stayed at the company, rising to credit manager, until last year, when he took a leave of absence.
He started in the labor movement as a shop steward for the National Union of Building, Engineering and General Workers and became its president in 1971. In 1987, he left the union, the loser in an intramural political struggle, but soon established a new organization so he could retain his leadership of the national trade union congress.
Eight months after a coalition of politicians, students and businessmen pressed hard for multiparty elections, the Government legalized the opposition, and he was elected chairman of a new political party.
 
Jailed and Born Again
 Unlike many other union leaders in Africa, Mr. Chiluba refused to be co-opted, declining Government job offers from President Kaunda. Instead, he used his position to criticize economic policies.
Angered by such criticism, Mr. Kaunda arrested Mr. Chiluba in 1981 on charges of trying to overthrow the Government.
In three months in prison, Mr. Chiluba has said, he became a born-again Christian.
The new Zambian President is very short by the standard of most Africans -- just under five feet tall.
He is said to be an effective negotiator, yet has caused concern among some supporters for what a newspaper, The Weekly Post, called his authoritarian style as a labor leader.
"He surrounded himself with loyal followers and did not take criticism easily," the paper wrote in a profile of him last week. The same pattern, it said, was occurring in his party.
"Chiluba has already found himself surrounded by many people who are little more than professional praise singers and are looking for jobs," the paper said. "They already call him Your Excellency; some even get down on their knees to talk to him."

HEADLINE: Jackson Says He Won't Run But Seeks to Keep Coalition

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
Declaring to his supporters that "we are free agents in a political market," Jesse Jackson announced as expected today that he would not mount a third try for the Democratic Presidential nomination, and he asked his backers to withhold their support for other candidates.
In calling for the mobilization of a "new democratic majority" in a speech to about 100 people at a housing project near the Capitol, Mr. Jackson, 50 years old, sought to signal that he was not ready to have others write his political obituary. 
 But several of Mr. Jackson's advisers have already begun to worry that voters who came to the polls in 1984 and 1988 in response to Mr. Jackson's personal appeal will scatter this year or, more likely, not vote at all.
 
A Fragile Coalition
 Holding together the already fragile Rainbow Coalition that Mr. Jackson used as a framework for his previous campaigns should prove to be a daunting task. The coalition, which operates out of Washington office, has only carried political clout in the years when Mr. Jackson has run for President.
And Mr. Jackson's plan to use his supporters as leverage with the candidates seeking the nomination is an untested theory that would require a loyal, committed band of voters who could be relied upon to vote as a bloc.
"The prospect is that his political constituency could split very badly unless he moves very quickly" to throw his support to another candidate, said Ronald Walters, a former Jackson adviser who is chairman of the political science department at Howard University.
Mr. Walters said that some black political professionals who are looking for a campaign to join might be attracted to Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia, who is black. Other Jackson liberals, he speculated, might be attracted to Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, who appeals to organized labor and was warmly received at a Congressional Black Caucus reception in September.
Dennis Rivera, the president of Local 1199, the New York City health care workers' union, and a prominent Jackson supporter who attended today's announcement, said he would probably support Mr. Harkin, if Gov. Mario M. Cuomo did not enter the race.
 
Voters May Stay Home
 It is equally likely, Mr. Walters and other Jackson supporters worry, that many of the newly registered voters who joined the Democratic party in 1984 and 1988 will simply stay home on Election Day in 1992.
"I'm afraid there will be confusion no matter what happens," Mr. Walters said.
Mr. Jackson stopped short of calling for the formation of a third political party today, but he criticized Republicans as well as Democrats for failing to address the needs of the "real middle classes, those caught up in the middle."
"Too often the parties become alter egos and not alternatives," Mr. Jackson said in his speech. "They appear too close to one another and too far from the new majority. There has been too much of an unholy alliance between the two parties --leaving the electorate with two names but one party, one set of assumptions and no options."
In responding to questions, Mr. Jackson refused to criticize any of the six major Democratic candidates now in the race and took special pains to avoid offering any opinion of Governor Wilder.
Mr. Wilder, who was campaigning in New Hampshire this week, said he had already received some backing from Jackson supporters and expected to get more.
"It's not a down side for me at all," he told reporters. "If it does anything, it will free people who may have been holding back to see what Reverend Jackson would do. It has to be considered good."
Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska praised Mr. Jackson as an important voice for economic and social justice. "You don't have to run for office to make a contribution," he said. "Reverend Jackson understands that."
And Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said that Mr. Jackson would remain "a leader of our party" and that his intention to remain involved in the campaign would help Democrats "to change priorities nationwide and defeat George Bush."
Four years ago, Mr. Jackson announced he would run for President a second time before 5,000 supporters in Raleigh, N.C., in a ceremony that was replete with balloons and red-white-and-blue political signs. This time, he chose a public housing project that has been plagued with drugs and violence. Local teen-agers continued to play basketball on a court behind him as he spoke, and the crowd of was swelled by photographers and reporters. His wife, Jackie, joined him, but his five children were absent.
"Look around you," said Representative Kweisi Mfume, Democrat of Maryland. "This is not Kennebunkport. Look around you; these people are Americans."
 
Taking a Risk
 By shifting his focus from what Mr. Jackson called the "political center" to the "moral center," he is taking a risk of being counted out of the political formula entirely in 1992. He is still expected to host a weekly talk show for Cable News Network, a deal that would have fallen through if he had decided to run.
But Mr. Jackson said he would force Democrats to address a Rainbow Coalition agenda that includes support of statehood for the District of Columbia, the repeal of right-to-work laws, same-day voter registration, national health care, affordable housing and equal financing for education.
"As a Democrat, I hope that the party leadership will expand and reach out with hope and vision," Mr. Jackson said. "George Bush should be and must be beaten, and he will be beaten by Democrats if they speak with authenticity."

HEADLINE: 5 Democratic Hopefuls Mount Attack on Bush

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Nov. 2

 BODY:
Five of the major Democratic candidates for President mounted a fierce assault on President Bush here today, assailing his economic stewardship and asserting that the human cost of the recession was a direct result of Republican neglect.
One after another, the Democrats took the stage and spoke of the suffering of the jobless, the economically insecure, the parents who are working now but fear for their children's future. "These are the forgotten middle class," said Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas. "George Bush took their votes and walked away from them." 
 The New Hampshire Democratic midterm convention gave more than 2,500 of the party faithful a chance to look at a Presidential field that is still little known, even now, less than four months before the New Hampshire Primary. Today's event was the first candidates' cattle show in a state whose Feb. 18 primary, the first in the nation, is always important but is especially crucial in the closely packed race of 1992.
For the candidates, it was an opportunity to seize on the issue now considered to be President Bush's greatest political anxiety. This message was easy to tailor to New Hampshire, where the economy dominates the front pages and the political debate.
 
Message Plays Well
 Paul E. Tsongas, a former senator from Massachusetts, drew waves of cheers today when he declared: "George Bush, come to New Hampshire. There are 43,000 people in New Hampshire who are out of work because of your Presidency."
Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa set the tone when he assailed Mr. Bush as the "Herbert Hoover of the 1990's," whose economic recovery program "can be summed up in three words: cut capital gains."
And Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska asserted that Mr. Bush had built his political coalition on fear and division. "They see us as people to be used," Mr. Kerrey said, "and they use us time and again."
While Republicans worry about requiring children to say the Pledge of Allegiance each day, Mr. Kerrey asserted, the nation should be making a pledge of its own to its children, one of housing and health care and a healthy economy.
 
'Frequent-Flier Presidency'
 Mr. Harkin, whose political oratory is rarely cool, was particularly hot today, resurrecting an old attack on Mr. Bush as a man "who was born on third base and thinks he hit a triple." Again and again, he drew a biting portrait of a President traveling the world, conducting a "frequent-flier Presidency" consumed with diplomacy and out of touch with the suffering at home.
Mr. Harkin said that rather than visiting the Presidential vacation home in Kennebunkport, Me., to inspect storm damage, it was time for Mr. Bush to travel the nation "and see the damage your policies are causing America."
Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia accused Mr. Bush of dividing the nation with issues like racial quotas and asserted that this kind of politics "has produced a climate conducive to Republicans like David Duke." Mr. Duke, the Louisiana State Representative and former Klansman who has been repeatedly disavowed by the White House, is in a tight race for governor in Louisiana.
Mr. Kerrey also tied Mr. Bush directly to Mr. Duke, asserting that "for 24 years the Republican Party has watered the tree of racism" and Mr. Duke was the result. Mr. Kerrey, whose campaign seems aimed at the voters of the baby boom, devoted much of his speech today to an angry attack on Mr. Bush's use of social issues, like abortion rights.
 
Brown Doesn't Attend
 Most of the campaigns tried to put on a show of support at today's convention, with Mr. Tsongas, who has a neighboring-state advantage and began his campaign back in April, greeted with a particularly vocal demonstration on the floor. But veteran organizers said here that most of the campaigns were in their earliest stages.
Former Governor Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California was the only one of the six major candidates for the Democratic nomination who did not appear today, citing previous commitments.
Three candidates mixed it up Friday night in a televised debate that featured some edgy exchanges between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Wilder, while Mr. Tsongas sought to position himself as a truth-teller holding his Democratic colleagues to account.
Both Friday night and today, Mr. Tsongas said it was time for the Democratic Party to "liberate" itself from political action committee money and argued that the 1992 Presidential election was the place to start. He called on Mr. Harkin to renounce PAC money and return the contributions he had accepted. "Tom, give the money back," Mr. Tsongas said, in a debate sponsored by the New Hampshire Democratic Party and televised by WMUR in Manchester. "Give the money back."
 
Others Join In
 Mr. Clinton and Mr. Wilder cheerfully agreed with the demand, saying they were not accepting such contributions themselves. The exchange was one more reflection of how politicians are trying to respond to the public anger toward politics as usual.
But Mr. Harkin brushed aside the demand today. "That's a Republican argument and I'm not going to swim in those waters," he said. Lorraine Voles, his press secretary, said that less than 10 percent of Mr. Harkin's presidential campaign money has come from political action committees.
"Bush raised $2 million in Houston this week," Ms. Voles said. "And we're going to be competitive. We're not going to play touch when they're playing tackle."
The economy also dominated Friday night's debate. "Look at New Hampshire," Mr. Clinton said. "First in bankruptcies, first in welfare growth, 800 people a week exhausting their unemployment benefits. And we have a President who last month met with the leaders of 21 nations, including Micronesia and Lichtenstein, and wouldn't even meet with Republicans to discuss the economy."
 
Criticism of Tax Movement
 But Mr. Tsongas, who seemed delighted to finally have televised debates as a forum for his underdog campaign, was critical of the widespread Democratic movement for middle class tax relief as a means of jump-starting the economy.
Referring to the continued problem of the deficit, Mr. Tsongas asked: "How can we talk about middle-class tax cuts that are going to be paid for by their children? People are not foolish."
One of the sharpest exchanges came between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Wilder. Mr. Wilder said he would "not engage in negative campaigning, period," but only intervene to "set the record straight."
Mr. Clinton asked why, then, Mr. Wilder was recently quoted as saying that Mr. Clinton put a new emphasis to welfare reform after seeing Mr. Duke's success in Louisiana.
Mr. Duke, a former grand wizard of the Ku Klux Klan, is in the runoff election in Louisiana for governor and has campaigned hard against affirmative action and the welfare system.
Mr. Wilder flatly and repeatedly denied making those statements. An Associated Press reporter said the statements were made in a telephone interview with Mr. Wilder and said she stood by the story. Later, Mr. Wilder's press secretary said the Governor recalled the conversation with the reporter but did not recall making such comments.

HEADLINE: Fathoming the Gaps

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
New York City and New York State both announced last week that big gaps had opened in the budgets they had balanced just a few months ago. But while the gaps may be equally difficult to fill, they have very different causes.
State officials put much of the blame on a poor economy. But a close look at the numbers indicates that the recession's role in the budget gap lies not so much in how poorly the economy has performed but in how much better budget-makers had expected it to be. 
 The city, meanwhile, appears to have been more conservative in its expectations. But its budget fell victim to unanticipated needs as well as decisions to restore money that had been cut.
The city's budget director, Philip R. Michael, has also attributed the $200 million to $250 million shortfall, in part, to reduced revenues. But tax revenues for the city are actually more or less on target; the city expects to come up short this year by about only $50 million out of a total tax revenue base of $17 billion.
The state budget director, Patrick J. Bulgaro, attributed much of the $689 million gap in his budget to growing demands for welfare, Medicaid and other forms of public assistance -- a natural product of a recession. But the city has found that its cost of providing the same services is actually slightly below what the budget had projected.
"On the state front, it's pretty clear that everybody had too rose-colored a view of the economy," says Raymond Horton, head of the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group. "The city guessed it better than the state."
That is not to say that the city is not having problems. But its budget gap has been caused primarily by the decisions to restore services -- some because it wanted to and others because it was forced to do so by the courts. The city has to pay $32 million, for instance, to settle a lawsuit over its education spending. When certain state financing was not forthcoming, the city invested $19 million more of its own money in two City University colleges. It also restored its recycling program, certain Parks Department positions and, when sued, some health programs.
There have also been some unwelcome surprises, like a large, $22 million increase in overtime expenditures, largely because of a series of emergencies, including the racial unrest in Crown Heights in Brooklyn, the subway crash on the East Side of Manhattan and the fire at the Staten Island Ferry terminal. Those expenditures may not be offset by later cuts in overtime.
But the city's tax collections from individuals and companies -- often seen as a measure of how the economy is performing in relation to expectations -- are holding up well. Personal income-tax revenues through mid-October were on target and up 12 percent compared with the same period last year. That increase came about largely because the city had raised its tax rates for this fiscal year. But even if that effect is excluded, personal income-tax receipts would be about the same as last year, the city's Department of Finance said.
At the state level, personal income-tax receipts through September fell $128 million short of expectations out of a tax base of $15 billion. That gap is expected to widen to $311 million for the year.
On another front, business income taxes for the city through September have "met or exceeded expectations," a state report says. The report, by Elinor Bachrach, the State Deputy Comptroller for the City of New York, said the only disappointing tax was the city's sales tax. It was off target by about $4 million in the first quarter of this fiscal year, which began July 1.
Mr. Michael, the city's budget director, has decided to assume that sale-tax revenues will fall about $50 million short of the previous estimate. The reason is that the budget office had been anticipating that retail sales would be showing some improvement by now. Instead they have declined.
The $50 million gap is "very modest in terms of the overall budget," Mr. Michael said. Ms. Bachrach agrees. "The city's revenues are holding up pretty well because their estimates were conservative," she said.
The state's budget gap, on the other hand, reflects the overly optimistic assumptions that were made about how fast the economy would improve. The lingering recession has resulted in lower tax revenues and forced the state to spend more than expected on social services. Not only is the estimate for personal income tax proving to be too high, but a number of business taxes are coming in below expectations.
Mr. Bulgaro, the budget chief, defended the forecast on which the state based its budget. The consensus among economists was that a national recovery had begun in the second quarter, and the state had assumed that while employment in New York would continue to shrink, by 2.1 percent, wages would grow by 1.1 percent. "I think our projections were very prudent and sound, based on the data we had available at the time," Mr. Bulgaro said.
But now, with employment prospects much dimmer than had been expected, Mr. Bulgaro said his office would use a more pessimistic forecast for the rest of the year -- that employment will decline by 3.1 percent and that wages will grow by only 0.5 percent.
 
More School, Higher Costs
 The ripple effects of the mistaken estimates can be found on both the revenue and spending sides of the budget. Because jobs are so hard to find, many people have decided to go back to school, raising attendance at the state and city's community colleges and university systems above expectations. Since so few students are able to find work, the state is having to pay more tuition assistance.
The number of individuals seeking home relief assistance has also risen sharply. Home relief is given to people whose six-month unemployment insurance has expired but whose income is too high to make them eligible for welfare or Medicaid. Last year, the number of people applying for home relief in New York State rose by 49.4 percent over the previous year.
 
Behind Medicaid Costs
 Although the state repeatedly cites an increase in Medicaid costs in describing its budget problems, and links that to the unexpected severity of the recession, much of that increase, in fact, is attributable to other factors. Mr. Bulgaro said that about 25 percent of increased state expenses can be explained by changes in the billing practices of its health-care providers, who want their money sooner.
Further, $40 million to $50 million of an anticipated $335 million shortfall for the year is due to higher rates that the state has been forced to pay as a result of lawsuits against it. The state is still expecting to offset its higher expenses with about $103 million in cost-saving measures.
In the end, the effect of the weak economy on the Medicaid expenses can be detected only by the state's caseload estimate. Instead of a 7 percent increase, the state now expects it to be 8 percent.
What remains to be seen is how the city and state try to plug their gaps. City officials are already girding against any solution that might come at their expense. "If the state did underestimate its expenses, it's hardly fair to lay that problem on any of its municipalities," Mr. Michael argued on his way to Albany on Friday. "We can't be expected to pick that up."

HEADLINE: Voters in Maine to Decide Fate of Highway Policy

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BANGOR, Me., Nov. 2

 BODY:
When the Federal Government brought its progressive highway program to this rural state 44 years ago, the superhighway that would eventually link Maine and Florida was considered a path to prosperity, enabling cities and towns to flourish along its route.
Now, what was once heralded as progress is causing residents to question whether the priorities of yesterday are valid for tomorrow. 
 Voters are to decide Tuesday whether to abandon the traditional Federal policy of encouraging highway construction, and instead to force the state to look toward mass transit and other means to reduce traffic congestion.
The debate, focusing on a proposal to widen from four lanes to six a 30-mile stretch of the Maine Turnpike, has pitted environmentalists against construction and trucking interests.
 
Ballot Box Opposition
 Opposition to the turnpike expansion has led to a ballot measure that would block the project and put in place a new state policy giving preference to alternatives to highway construction.
Prominent opponents of the measure include Gov. John R. McKernan, a Republican, and the state's largest employer, the Bath Iron Works. Among those in favor of it is the suspense novelist Stephen King.
"Horror is my bread and butter," Mr. King says in a radio commercial broadcast across the state, "but I can't imagine a worse horror than to waste $100 million of Maine's hard-earned public money just to widen a stretch of road in southern Maine. Stop the concrete monster from gobbling up more of Maine's countryside."
Governor McKernan, caught up in a fiscal crisis that has accompanied the New England recession, balks at the opposition's charges that he is "kowtowing to construction interests," and says the project is necessary to give the state's economy a needed lift.
"I wouldn't suggest spending $100 million for a project we didn't need," he said.
 
Some Big Contributors
 The Bath Iron Works, a ship-building company in southern Maine that employs 10,400 people, has given $25,000 to a lobbying group urging defeat of the ballot measure. Construction interests from Maine and other states have also been big contributors, with the Associated General Contractors of America topping the list at $25,000.
Referendum opponents outspent backers by 7 to 1, according to campaign finance reports filed Sept. 30, the most recent reports available. Much of that money has paid for consultants' fees and television advertisements.
In the final days before the election, each campaign has been accusing the other of distortions. Opponents say a new transportation policy would create a bureacratic morass. Proponents accuse state officials of wanting to "gold-plate" the turnpike, which extends 106 miles northeast from York, near the New Hampshire border, to Augusta, the state capital.
Defeat of the measure would allow the widening of a 30-mile segment of the turnpike, extending from York to just south of Portland, and approve the financing of the project with a bond, to be repaid from toll money. Rejection would also maintain the power of the Maine Turnpike Authority to make decisions without review, said Barbara Trafton, a spokeswoman for the campaign opposing the measure.
Approval of the proposal would not only stop the widening of the turnpike, a plan that was approved by the Legislature in 1987, but would also establish a new transportation policy under which state officials would have to consider "reasonable alternatives to highway construction" before pouring more concrete, said Beth Nagusky, a staff lawyer for the Natural Resources Council of Maine, who is an author of the ballot measure.
She said the proposed policy was similiar to parts of a bill now in a Congressional conference committee that would grant states more flexibility to spend Federal money previously earmarked for highways.
In a telephone interview Mr. King, the novelist, said, "In the referendum people are questioning the unbridled buildup of highways, which has gone unchallenged until now."
Then, referring to an earlier time when the results of state elections here were taken as a gauge of national trends, he added, "These guys are afraid that as Maine goes, so goes the nation."
