HEADLINE: Haiti's Divisions Deepen Over Aristide's Removal

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Nov. 2

 BODY:
For a brief moment after the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide won the first democratic elections in this country's 186 years of independence in December, Haiti appeared more unified than at any time in a history filled with violent strife.
But in the nearly eight months that he governed as President, and in the four weeks since Father Aristide was exiled in a bloody military coup, Haiti's ancient class divisions have so deepened that many familiar with the political scene here say that the stringent international trade embargo imposed on the country this week could do little to return Father Aristide to office. 
 Presented with the stark choice of accepting an elected President's return or hunkering down as an international pariah for endorsing his overthrow, many in the small but powerful Haitian elite, from white-collar professionals to members of landed, old-money families, seem prepared to choose an isolation they believe will be temporary over a leader whose provocative class oratory they came to deeply fear.
To counter their determination, meanwhile, some of the deposed President's supporters, growing impatient over diplomatic attempts to restore constitutional order, have recently made increasingly strident calls for armed "popular resistance," or international military intervention. Those calls come even as Father Aristide rules out a violent solution.
Hardening each side's position is the fact that behind Father Aristide's active supporters stand a people who voted heavily for him and continue to profess their allegiance. Backing the elite is an army whose fear of elimination helped set off the coup in the first place, and whose fear of punishment for the deaths of hundreds makes it much harder to back down now.
"If anything the army has become more solidified over the sentiment that Aristide would never abide by any agreement," said one of several diplomats here who supported the mediation process, but questioned whether diplomacy alone could return the President to power.
Despite those odds, next week the Organization of American States, the regional group that has taken the international lead in seeking a solution to the Haitian crisis, will step onto this polarized field to attempt to obtain Father Aristide's reinstatement.
In addition to having concerns for Haitian democracy, diplomats say, many of the organization's member countries are showing unusual determination to resolve Haiti's crisis because of their own fears of succesful military coups at home.
Some civilian politicians and business executives are already vowing to negotiate in good faith toward Father Aristide's return in light of the harsh economic sanctions, which now bar Haitian exports or imports with most of the hemisphere. But some diplomats say that with the the United States and other countries forswearing military intervention, Father Aristide's return could simply remain a distant goal.
"The fact of saying you are willing to go all the way has a lot more effect," said France's Ambassador to Haiti, Jean Raphael Dufour, who argued that eliminating the threat of international force as an option could seriously weaken attempts to restore Father Aristide.
Mr. Dufour, whose country has provided strong diplomatic support for Father Aristide during a current tour of European capitals, echoed statements of the exiled President, saying that any solution must provide for elements of the Haitian Army to be strongly "punished" for their role in the coup and the 7,000-man force reorganized or eliminated to prevent future disruptions.
But diplomats from several O.A.S.-member countries, mindful of the lack of international will for an armed intervention here, said they thought the emphasis should be put instead on building democracy.
The O.A.S. will attempt to accomplish this democracy-building by sending a series of reassuring signals, diplomats say, backed by a long-term commitment to remain in the country as observers and mediatorsin order to help boost confidence on all sides.

HEADLINE: Looking for New Fashion Markets, Designers From America Go Global

BYLINE: By ANNE-MARIE SCHIRO

 BODY:
The latest buzzword in fashion isn't mini or maxi or stretch. It's globalization.
In seeking areas for expansion, American designers, manufacturers and retailers have gone about as far as they can go in this country and have turned their eyes to the rest of the world. And the world is taking notice: the spring shows opening on Seventh Avenue on Monday will be attended not only by store buyers from all over the United States but also by buyers from Canada, Europe and Asia. 
 The American industry sees unlimited room for expansion in the barely tapped $50 billion market for women's ready-to-wear in Europe, where American clothes currently represent less than 1 percent of sales.
Although some American companies have been selling their clothes in London, Paris and points east for more than a decade, it is only in the last two years that there has been a serious assault on the international market.
 
One Company's Focus
 "Since 1989, globalization has really become the focus of our company," said Stephen L. Ruzow, the president and chief operating officer of Donna Karan New York. "With the way the world economy was and the U.S. retail scene, it became critical."
He could have been speaking for the entire fashion community. You can now see labels like Calvin Klein, Oscar de la Renta, Donna Karan, Adrienne Vittadini and St. John Knits in European stores. And you can shop at the Gap, the Limited and Esprit in England and at Barneys and Charivari in Japan. American companies are following the lead of counterparts in Europe and Japan that have long looked beyond the borders of their own countries.
Oscar de la Renta made fashion history when he took his fall collection to the Paris runways last March, going head to head with the big names of Europe on their own turf. It was an $800,000 gamble that paid off with orders from 15 European stores, enough to take the designer back to Paris for the spring shows last month. Spring orders are triple what they were for fall, said Gerald Shaw, the president of Oscar de la Renta.
 
Addition, Not Subtraction
 "European stores write bigger orders than American stores," he said, "and we picked up 15 more stores. This will not supplant our U.S. business but will add to it. I think we will continue to develop more and more stores throughout Europe. And it would be wonderful to have Oscar de la Renta boutiques."
Calvin Klein had a short-lived boutique in London that was opened in 1979 by Joan and Sidney Burstein, the owners of the fashionable Browns shops. It failed because the clothes were too expensive, Mrs. Burstein said. Two years later, the Bursteins opened a Ralph Lauren boutique, which Lauren later bought from them, starting a Polo/Ralph Lauren international empire that now numbers more than 140 stores throughout Europe, Asia and South America.
Polo/Ralph Lauren is a privately held company, and its executives would not agree to interviews about their business. Industry experts estimate its total yearly sales at $1.35 billion, but it is not known how much of that is from foreign sales and how much from products other than clothes.
A well-known name makes entry into the world market easier but isn't always essential if a company can offer the right product at the right price. Both New York State and the Federal Government have initiated programs to encourage small manufacturers to enter the global market. The Commerce Department plans to sponsor United States participation at a number of European and Asian trade shows next year.
 
An American Pavilion in Paris
 With the encouragement of the American Embassy, an assault will be made on Paris next February at the Pret-a-Porter Feminin, where there will be an American Designer Pavilion featuring two dozen ready-to-wear and accessories designers who are not big enough to break into the foreign market on their own. The entry fee for each participant is $13,000, and the designers will still have to pay for transportation, hotels and the shipping of samples.
A decade ago, a strong dollar made American clothing prohibitively expensive abroad. Today's weaker dollar has helped to keep prices competitive, although American clothing often costs 30 to 50 percent more overseas than in the United States. Because of trade restrictions in Japan, most American companies have licensing agreements that allow the Japanese to manufacture and distribute the clothes in the Far East. Many designers, including Mr. de la Renta and Calvin Klein, have had licensing agreements with Japan since the 1970's.
 
First, Perfume
 "I'm an American, and I always felt that I didn't really need Europe," Mr. Klein said in a recent interview in his office. "There was so much money to be made in this country. But today, Europe wants American clothes, and America needs Europe. There are fewer stores here, especially for designer clothes."
In London, Harvey Nichols has had an in-store boutique for Calvin Klein since 1989. Stores in several German cities are now selling his clothes, and there are plans to open licensed Calvin Klein boutiques next year in Munich, Madrid and Barcelona. His strategy has been to enter a European market with perfume, which creates a demand for his high-priced clothing collection, and to follow these with his lower-priced jeans and sport collections for men and women.
"The goal is to have shops in all the major cities to showcase what I do," the designer said, "and then to more widely distribute the less expensive lines."
European retailers make regular trips to New York to order from designer collections, but less expensive lines with wider distribution possibilities need to be taken to the buyers, Mr. Klein said. Unlike the United States with its department store chains, Europe is by and large a world of individually owned shops.
"If you're selling expensive clothing, there are only so many stores and so many cities," Mr. Klein said. "But a product that can be widely distributed requires a whole other setup. You need someone to go into the hills of Austria, not just to Vienna."
 
Complicated Logistics
 Mr. Ruzow of Donna Karan said that he had been setting up a computer network to handle orders and distribution and that he expects to have a distribution center in Europe by the end of next year, when the European Community's remaining internal obstacles to free trade are expected to be removed. His company does its manufacturing in the United States and in the Far East, which complicates the logistics of selling in Europe.
"You have to deal with export quotas from Hong Kong and import quotas for each European country," he said. "It's a real pain to get import quotas for France. We're waiting to see what happens once the Common Market is operating. If there's just one quota, that's fine. If each country continues to have a separate quota, we'll open a distribution center in the country with the highest quota from the Far East."
This year, exports will account for 33 percent of the Donna Karan collection's $52 million in sales, and 12 percent of the $148 million in sales of her less expensive line, DKNY. More than half of those sales will be in the Far East, about a third in nine European countries and the rest in Canada.
 
'Europe Is Wide Open'
 Adrienne Vittadini, which has been selling ready-to-wear and accessories in Japan for nine years and in Europe for about five years, expects to do half its business on the international front within five years, said Richard Catalano, the company's president. "How much will be through stores and how much through our own boutiques we won't have to decide for about a year," he said. "Europe is wide open. The hard part is going up against the best. There's no shortage of talent in Italy."
To ease its expansion into Europe, St. John Knits, a New York manufacturer, sold 80 percent of its business to Escada, the giant German manufacturer. A Japanese connection had been made three years ago with a company called Best International, which imports and distributes the line, produced in southern California.
"If you can get started in the global market, you have a lot of room to expand," said Robert Gray, St. John's chairman. "But we wouldn't have attempted to go into Europe without Escada. Instead of a few large retailers, you have hundreds of stores in Europe. How can you reach them all? Escada has the contacts and can do the distribution."
 
From 16 Stores to 80
 Thanks to Escada, St. John has a sales representative in Munich and a showroom in Paris so the stores don't need to come to New York to see the line. St. John's first entry into Europe was last spring, with 16 stores. By this fall, that number had grown to 80.
Liz Claiborne Inc. made its first inroads into the international market last January in Selfridge's and Harrods in London. "The timing was the worst," said Jerome A. Chazen, the company's chairman. "We got there just before Desert Storm, and there was no one in London. But we're performing well now and are in about 25 more stores in the U.K. We just went into Spain to prepare for the Olympics, and next fall we're expanding into Belgium, Denmark and the Netherlands."
"It's very important to set up the appropriate infrastructure," he added. "At first, we rented a warehouse in the wrong place in the U.K. We got out of that and discovered we could set up in the Netherlands and ship faster than from Manchester."
 
$2 Million a Year
 Mackintosh of New England, a manufacturer of moderate-priced women's coats, decided to take on the British market three years ago and now sells to 100 stores in Britain, to the tune of $2 million a year. The next goal is the European continent.
"I went over to England with six samples," said Bernie Moller, the president of Mackintosh, "and was referred to Jim Knight, a retired retail executive, who said, 'We don't make coats like this anymore' and took us on."
Mr. Knight set up a distribution center for the coats, which retail for about $200 in Britain, or 20 percent higher than in the United States.
Last May, Mackintosh was bought by Biscayne Holdings, which owns several ready-to-wear companies and plans to draw upon the Mackintosh experience to enter the European market.
 
Helping Small Companies
 Six years ago, the United States Department of Education awarded a grant to the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York to inform American students about global opportunities. This led to the formation at the school of the Export Advisory Service Extension, or EASE, which counsels small companies.
"For two years we've brought in people from Europe and Japan to speak in workshops about what a particular country wants and needs," said Elaine Stone, the director of EASE. "Hue, the hosiery company, came to us to find out about export. They had targeted England, and we put them in touch with an English distributor. Irwin Pearl came to us and now has distributors in England and Singapore."
"A market in a foreign country takes time to develop," she added. "It doesn't mean an enormous initial investment, but you have to be in it for the long term."

HEADLINE: Mississippi Race Heats Up as Governor's Margin in Polls Narrows

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GRENADA, Miss., Nov. 1

 BODY:
Gov. Ray Mabus, the Democrat who is seeking a second term in Tuesday's voting, came to this small central Mississippi town today to participate in what seemed a routine announcement of an expansion by a hosiery manufacturer.
But it was anything but routine as the 43-year-old Harvard-educated politician sought to associate himself with any kind of concrete economic development efforts in the state and tout his trips to the company's headquarters to encourage the expansion. 
 It was one of the many indications that the race between Mr. Mabus and his Republican opponent, Kirk Fordice, a Vicksburg businessman, is being perceived by the Mabus campaign as closer than recent polls would suggest.
Although few observers here suggest that the Governor is headed for defeat, they point out that in a state that has two Republican United States Senators and that has delivered up to 60 percent of its vote to the Republican Presidential candidate, complacency can be politically fatal. In recent days the attacks by the candidates on each other have sharpened.
 
Gains for Republican
 According to independent poll results released today, Governor Mabus has 53 percent, as against Mr. Fordice's 37 percent. The figures are evidence of small, steady gains by Mr. Fordice since he was the upset winner in last month's Republican primary. Mabus supporters said privately that their own polls suggested that the race was a bit closer than the public poll indicated.
Among the more telling figures in the poll, done by Mason-Dixon Opinion Research, were those showing the Governor with 90 percent of the black vote, as against 4 percent for Mr. Fordice, but trailing the challenger 37 percent to 52 percent among white voters. Blacks are about 33 percent of the state's population. The poll involved 849 likely voters and had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
The poll showed the third candidate, Shawn O'Hara, an independent, with about 2 percent of the vote over all.
Mr. Fordice, who has never held elected office above the county commissioner level, criticizes the Mabus administration's "deficit spending" and what he calls an inordinate emphasis on education. He proposes more a fiscally conservative administration and changes in the state's education system built around the recomendations of President Bush's Education 2000 program, which calls for local voluntary efforts rather that increased Federal and state spending.
 
Liberalism Attacked
 Mr. Fordice said in an interview that he would stress the Governor's "Harvard, eastern liberal, elitist" background. "The problem is that he is a Harvard-educated personality who is not prepared to listen to anybody," Mr. Fordice said. "He just doesn't do windows."
But Mr. Mabus's appearance on Friday at the announcement of the expansion of the Pennaco Hosiery Company, based in New York, was an attempt to show just the opposite.
Mr. Mabus has been criticized for his globetrotting efforts to attract foreign investment at the expense of existing business.
Mr. Mabus noted in an interview that everywhere he goes to try to attract business, the first thing that prospects want to know is what he and others are doing to improve education in Mississippi, a state that generally ranks among the lowest for scores on college entrance exams. But aides concede that education as an economic development tool, while valid, is a bit too abstract and long term in an election year, and at a time when the nation is in a recession.
 
More Jobs Now
 Mississippi has 75,000 more jobs this year than it did four years ago when Mr. Mabus won his first term, and the state's unemployment rate today is a little over 8 percent as against the 12 percent level it hit in the mid-1980's. But still the sense of economic gloom nationally is prevalent here as well.
Ally Mack, a professor of political science at Jackson State University, said that black voters who find Mr. Mabus distant and a bit arrogant were nevertheless likely to support him.
"Black folks equate Fordice with David Duke," she said, noting that Mr. Fordice has mentioned some of the same issues, like welfare abuse and affirmative action, as the former Ku Klux Klan leader who is running for Governor in Louisiana.
John Quincy Adams, a political scientist at Millsaps College in Jackson, said that Mr. Mabus may have some trouble because of the sentiment in the country against incumbents. But that may be counterbalanced here by Mr. Mabus's image as a man of principle who would rather lose a fight than cut deals with the Legislature.

HEADLINE: Topics of The Times;
The Bomb, in Latin America

 BODY:
It took courage for the Presidents of Brazil and Argentina to agree to ban the bomb. But it takes persistence to follow through with detailed arrangements for international nuclear inspection. Regrettably, these efforts seem to be flagging. Last fall, Brazil's Fernando Collor and Argentina's Carlos Menem defied their military bureaucracies, renounced their nuclear arms programs and promised to open facilities to international inspection within a year.
Officials from the two countries have exchanged visits to some nuclear facilities. But they have yet to sign agreements with the International Atomic Energy Agency opening the doors of all their facilities to inspectors. Such safeguards are the best guarantee that future governments won't reverse course and resume a nuclear weapons program. 
 The two leaders are preoccupied with economic and other domestic concerns. Yet without renewed pressure from the top, negotiations with the I.A.E.A. will continue to drag -- further encouraging bureaucratic opponents of inspections to resist an accord. Mr. Collor and Mr. Menem won high praise for standing up against nuclear proliferation; they'll get more praise if they finish the deal. Should they need further inspiration, the U.S. Government can gently remind them of its own interest in a successful resolution -- and the economic benefits, including high-tech exports, that might follow.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Yet Another Summit

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
When Washington spends billions on something that seems to make little sense, the explanation is almost always the same -- politics, bureaucratic politics, pig-headed shortsightedness and more politics.
Such is the case with the vast, growing and largely ineffectual $2.7 billion program to reduce the flow of illegal drugs into the United States. 
 Most distressing, this effort is yet another example of President Bush's willful determination to seek solutions to difficult domestic problems by international showmanship. Instead of concentrating ever tighter resources on treatment/prevention and street police, programs that virtually all drug experts say promise real results, Mr. Bush continues to devote too much time and money to combating the drug trade outside U.S. borders. And for their own reasons, Congress and the Pentagon happily go along.
Mathea Falco, an international drug expert, argues the point more strongly in her forthcoming book, "Just Say Yes: Drug Programs That Work." She writes: "Everyone who has looked at this problem agrees that the progress we've made has come from education, treatment and changes in social attitudes, and not because we've succeeded in cutting supplies."
The General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, is equally blunt. In a recent report the G.A.O. says that U.S. intelligence agencies "agree that the estimated volume of drugs entering the country during 1989 and 1990 did not decline."
Experts in and out of government are loath to enter into the drug numbers game. But few would contest this conclusion about Federal efforts to stem the drug inflow: Despite spending about $13 billion over the last 10 years, there has been no significant decrease in cocaine supply, no sustained price increase and no consequential decline in cocaine purity. In New York City today, you can still buy a vial of crack cocaine for less than half the price of a ticket to the movies.
Peter Reuter of the Rand Corporation has demonstrated over and again that almost no matter what the U.S. spends, the economics of the drug trade will prevail. Coca leaf production and refinement amount to less than 5 percent of the street cost. Smuggling accounts for less than 10 percent of street prices. Given the enormous profits, it is very difficult to imagine killing the incentive to grow, refine and smuggle cocaine. Even an inconceivable doubling of supply costs would have little effect on street prices or profits.
Also, the chances of smugglers getting caught are tiny. The G.A.O. report says that in 1990 the U.S. military detected 6,729 suspicious flights, that law enforcement agencies tried to interdict 661 of these aircraft and caught only 49. It's even more difficult to monitor the traffic coming by container ships and by land from Mexico.
Pentagon interdiction efforts alone will cost taxpayers $1.2 billion this year. And officials there have no incentive to look hard at effectiveness; drug programs are simply paying the Air Force and Navy for the flying and steaming they would be doing anyway out of their own budgets.
Stephen Duncan, the Pentagon drug czar, is honest and modest in his claims about interdiction. He feels it is a deterrent, believes it will improve and is convinced that the drug traders cannot be given a free ride into the U.S. His points are well taken and focus the issue: It's not whether to try to hold down supply, but how much to spend on this inherently Herculean task.
Congress, though well aware of the limitations of stemming the drug inflow, does nothing to reorder priorities. Legislators talk about spending more on demand reduction and less on cutting supply, but don't follow through. They want to prove they're being tough on drugs, and hunting down the bad guys on the high seas sounds sexier than the dreary business of helping addicts kick their habits.
Mr. Bush reflects that attitude in spades. Last week he invited his counterparts in six Latin American nations to another "anti-drug summit" early next year. Its goal, like the 1990 meeting he engineered, is to pump new life into efforts to disrupt the international cocaine trade. Such extravaganzas show George Bush bestriding the world, but they cannot substitute for the domestic anti-drug summits he has never held.

HEADLINE: Here's an Economic Policy

BYLINE: By Robert B. Reich; Robert B. Reich, who teaches political economy at the Harvard Kennedy School of Government, is author, most recently, of "The Work of Nations."

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
President Bush knows he's in trouble on the economy, and still doesn't know what to do about it. The small uptick during the summer seems to have reversed direction. Unemployment compensation claims rose in early October while durable orders fell. Almost two-thirds of the respondents to a recent New York Times/ CBS News poll called the economy "very bad" or "fairly bad" -- eight percentage points more than in June, when the recession was thought to have hit bottom.
Unemployment, now at 6.8 percent, is edging upward and does not include millions of Americans too discouraged even to look for work or in temporary jobs when they'd rather be working full time. With the election a year away and voter confidence in his ability to handle the economy slipping badly, Mr. Bush can't afford a "double dip" into recession again. He has to do something dramatic before a Democratic challenger can ask whether Americans are better off now than they were four years ago. 
 The following advice to the White House, offered free of charge, is not entirely unsolicited. A week ago a young member of the White House economic staff came to my office in Cambridge, asking what to do about the recession -- an act that confirms the Administration's desperation.
For starters, get the problem straight. The so-called credit crunch isn't the culprit. Easy credit won't help without sufficient demand. So stop pushing the banks to make easier loans. The Comptroller of the Currency is desperately trying to reform the Wild West banking norms of the 1980's, which contributed to the savings and loan fiasco; it's dangerous and irresponsible for the White House to send the opposite message. Nor will it do any good to browbeat Alan Greenspan and the Federal Reserve into pushing interest rates lower than they are now. Any lower, and savings will start flowing out of the U.S., the dollar will drop, and we'll be saddled with inflation.
Don't count on a capital gains tax cut either. There's no evidence that it would stimulate new investment. Moreover, in the global economy, "trickle down" has been replaced by "trickle out," as American savings race to wherever around the globe they can get the highest returns. Talk about a capital gains tax cut only incites the Democrats to grandstand over the "fairness thing" and proffer their own irresponsible tax cuts.
If the White House is intent on a capital-gains tax cut, at least propose one that creates the right incentives: a three-tiered rate in which patient capitalists who hold their assets for more than six years pay no tax, speculators who hold assets for less than six months' pay through the teeth and all others are kept at the present rate.
Focus instead on raising consumer confidence. Consumers account for most of the demand-pull in the economy, but they're holding back from big purchases. Nothing dampens shoppers' enthusiasm like economic insecurity. Their confidence would get a big boost if the White House recanted on its rejection of extended unemployment insurance (financed, perhaps, by the cancellation of several Stealth bombers) and came up with a credible national health plan.
This also makes good political sense: if the recession drags on, the Democrats almost certainly will make an issue of the President's unemployment insurance veto and will point to his failure to come up with a health plan as evidence of his indifference to domestic policy.
Focus also on what Government can do to prime the pump. Announce an emergency multibillion-dollar program to rebuild and repair the nation's bridges, highways and airports. The immediate advantage is that construction jobs would quickly sop up workers who don't need much training and give them fairly good wages and benefits. No need to worry about the impact on the budget. It's perfectly justifiable to add to the public debt to improve the nation's capacity for further growth. Business executives don't flinch from borrowing money to invest in big boosts of productivity. Yes, this approach would break last year's budget deal, but the deal is on the skids anyway.
Meanwhile, to get the most stimulus out of what the Government already spends, instruct all military contractors to switch to American-based production of the weapons, goods and services they supply. (Since most big American companies make or buy their wares all over the world, corporate nationality is less important than whether the goods are actually made here.) Speed the timetable of American troop withdrawals from Europe. The Pentagon buys an estimated $15 billion a year from European vendors supplying our troops; this money, too, could be better spent stimulating our economy.
And don't forget the symbolic touches. Create a Presidential Medal of Economic Citizenship, to be awarded annually to the 10 companies that invest the most in new plant and equipment and that hire the largest number of new employees in proportion to their earnings. A little hoopla over growth wouldn't hurt at a time like this.
Replace Vice President Dan Quayle's environment-bashing Competitiveness Council with a high-profile National Growth Council, composed of leading Democrats as well as Republicans, and business and labor leaders, to advise Americans about how they can insure a better future for their kids. Not the least, stop all the Presidential and Vice Presidential golfing, tennis and boating excursions, which make the average hard-pressed American feel worse by comparison. Until after the election, switch to bowling, bingo and amusement arcades.

HEADLINE: Unpopular New Taxes Ignite a Rebirth of Populist Politics

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GLASTONBURY, Conn., Oct. 31

 BODY:
Richard Zajicek, a silver-haired local building contractor who never considered running for public office until this year, found his voice at age 59 in denouncing Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and Connecticut's new state income tax. Now he's running for the Town Council in Tuesday's elections on a quixotic third-party campaign to demolish local government and restore the old town-meeting form of participatory democracy that withered and died here in the 1950's.
Across Connecticut and New Jersey, echoes of Mr. Zajicek's message and method -- outrage about taxes, combined with a sort of misty-eyed paean to better or simpler times -- are being repeated in dozens of local and legislative races as politicians and those who hate politicians try equally to tap the mood of a dispirited electorate. 
 Voters in New York will also be going to the polls in local elections on Tuesday and many of those races are also being buffeted as well by uneasiness about the economy, taxes and the quality of government. But candidates and poll-takers say Connecticut and New Jersey will bring those concerns to a singular focus.
In both states, governors whose names are linked to huge and unpopular tax increases have haunted the election process even though neither man is running this year. And in both states, middle- and lower-income residents -- the groups generally least affected by the tax increases pushed into law by Mr. Weicker and Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey -- have formed the backbone of resentment.
 
Reacting to Strong Medicine
 Both are also at the forefront of states that have swallowed strong medicine in an effort to maintain generous public programs once paid for by the Federal Government. Some experts, therefore, see the elections as a sort of referendum on the backyard, hometown consequences of the gradual Federal retrenchment under President Ronald Reagan and President Bush. Mr. Florio, a Democrat, even called on voters earlier this week to send a message to Mr. Bush about his economic and domestic policies by voting the Democratic line.
Politicians who have spent the last few weeks knocking on doors say that things are not that simple, and that the anti-incumbent, anti-tax, anti-governor fervor that lies on the surface and catches the headlines may not really carry the day. Many of those same angry voters, for example, may also be dispirited citizens who will simply stay home on Election Day. And some politicians are playing to a public that seems to want reassurance as much as revenge.
"They're willing to support people who will say, 'I won't hurt you,' " said Henry J. Raimondo, a professor of urban and regional planning at the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University. "That's what we've been reduced to right now."
And the voters also seem willing to entertain approaches far from the beaten path. Glastonbury, a town of 28,000 people just south of Hartford, has four nonparty candidates this year who got on the ballot by petition, more than any election in at least the last 30 years. Statewide, the number of independent candidates is double the number than in the last municipal elections in 1989, according to the Secretary of the State's office. The number of independent candidates has also risen in New Jersey, where 46 third-party or nonparty candidates are running in 120 legislative races.
 
Tapping the Discontent
 Most of the independents, locked out from major-party financing, are expected to lose because they cannot afford to advertise, and some hold highly unorthodox views. Mr. Zajicek, for example, said in an interview that he thinks "British agents" secretly control of much of the United States Government and banking system.
Even traditional politicians have been forced to reckon with the mood that has given rise to such voices. In order to get on the ballot in Connecticut, nonparty candidates must get signatures from at least one percent of the number of people who voted in the last election. That was the route that Mr. Weicker took last year when he quit the Republican Party and ran under his own Connecticut Party banner.
"People are tired of the old-line approach to political processes," said Peter A. Inverso, a Republican candidate for the New Jersey State Senate in the 14th district, which takes in parts of Mercer and Middlesex Counties.
Mr. Inverso, who has pledged to try and roll back some of the Florio administration's tax increases, is locked in a tight race with the incumbent, Senator Francis J. McManimon, a Democrat from Trenton, and is also fighting off a third-party opponent, Peter P. Garibaldi.
 
Dramatic Proposals
 Mr. Garibaldi, a former Republican State Senator, has promised to try to eliminate all property taxes and pay for local government programs through the state income tax. He has also organized a loose federation of like-minded independent candidates running for state, municipal and county offices in the district.
Here in Connecticut, the drive to repeal the income tax, which was passed in August, has spawned a host of extreme fiscal proposals and has forced local politicians everywhere into making what are in effect negative promises: If elected, they pledge not to do anything that would increase spending.
"We see no growth in budgets, no growth in projects or programs and no growth in capital spending unless absolutely essential," said Sonya Googins, a Republican and the chairwoman of the Glastonbury Town Council, who is running for re-election in the same race with Mr. Zajicek. "There's no appetite for it out there in the public and you've got to be responsive to it."
Mr. Weicker has also put his own spin on the municipal elections, with repeated comments that local officials who support repealing the income tax are in effect asking that their state aid be cut because the $1.2 billion in new revenue generated mostly by the income tax goes disproportionately into town budgets. In New Jersey, by contrast, Republicans have used Mr. Florio's name to invoke curses on the heads of all Democrats for the $2.8 billion in tax increases that took effect last year.
 
Little Support for Governors
 Recent polls give both governors some of the lowest approval ratings anywhere. About 73 percent of the New Jersey residents questioned rated Mr. Florio's performance as "fair" or "poor," according to a poll by the Eagleton Institute at Rutgers, for example. The poll of 800 residents was conducted in mid-September and had a margin of error of plus or minus 3.5 percentage points.
Those figures were almost exactly mirrored in Connecticut, where 74 percent of the 500 residents polled by the University of Connecticut in October said Mr. Weicker was doing a "fair" or "poor" job. That poll had a margin of error of plus or minus 5 percent.
National political experts say that those strong public opinions, and the degree to which the two governors have involved themselves or become an issue outright in local election, have made Tuesday's results both more interesting and also less illuminating as indicators of how voters might react in next year's national elections.
"New Jersey is something that Florio messed up, and Connecticut is too Weickeresque," said Kevin Phillips, a conservative political analyst in Washington.
 
Distrust of Incumbents
 New York is not on most lists because the state has not taken the sort of dramatic action that sparks strong feelings among voters, although a new $639 million budget gap could force state lawmakers to grapple with the issue between now and next November.
"The New York story is not an interesting one because it's not doing anything innovative to solve its problems," Professor Raimondo of the Eagleton Institute said.
In Connecticut and New Jersey, however, the innovations and voter reaction seemed to have touched nearly every contest in some way.
"We came through a maelstrom and really we're better off," said Assembly Representative Ann A. Mullen, a Democrat from Erial, N.J., repeating the arguments she makes to her constituents about why she voted for the Florio tax plan. "The sad part is that people don't understand or don't believe," she said.
One Fairfield, Conn., resident, Patrick McInerney, said his mind is certainly made up. His absentee ballot has already been cast because he'll be out of town on election day.
"I voted against every incumbent in the town of Fairfield whether I liked them or not," Mr. McInerney said.

HEADLINE: Seeking a Racial Mix, Dubuque Finds Tension

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DUBUQUE, Iowa, Oct. 30

 BODY:
For years now, along the rolling bluffs in this Mississippi River city of Victorian houses and church steeples, nobody ever thought much about race and prejudice. Nobody ever had to.
There were only a handful of black people in town. A resident could go for years without seeing a black. And besides, people thought, racism was something that happened in the big cities or the Deep South, not in a nice, quiet place like Dubuque. 
 But in recent weeks and months, Dubuque residents have been talking and thinking of race often. Because of a cross-burning incident two years ago that surprised many people, the city council last May adopted an extraordinary plan to attract 100 black families in hopes of adding diversity to this virtually all-white city of 58,000 people.
 
A Backlash of Fear
 Since then, a backlash of fear and intolerance has erupted. Five crosses have been burned around town in the last four months. This week, uniformed police officers stood guard at Dubuque Senior High School after racial fights broke out. In recent days, racial epithets have been scrawled on buildings across town, some proclaiming "the New KKK."
And when a man who admitted burning three of the crosses returned from jail to his job at a meatpacking plant, his co-workers are said to have greeted him with backslaps and a standing ovation.
Scenes like these are searing to many white residents, who say they are struggling with their own racial attitudes. "This is the ignorant, oppressive underbelly of Dubuque," said Peter Kjeseth, a professor of Greek and Hebrew at a Lutheran seminary in Dubuque and a member of the local National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. "Young men who are undereducated and worried about jobs are scared to death."
All of this is happening in a tradition-bound, heartland city of mostly Irish and German Catholics, where racial minorities make up 2 percent of the population and where there are only 331 black residents scattered across the city.
The racial tension has forced residents to confront deeply imbedded prejudices. "People are wondering, 'How can we have a race problem when we don't even have minorities?' ," said Kim Clayton, a counselor at the high school and a member of the committee that drafted the plan.
 
Symbol of Intolerance
 Dubuque, with its newly tapped well of intolerance, symbolizes race relations in this country, specialists on the topic say. As the economy has stalled and as some politicians mine racial fears to win votes, unresolved prejudices have produced a kind of racism whose code words are "quotas" and "unqualified minorities," one that can explode at any time given the impetus, these experts say.
"This is not the South," said Dr. Joe Feagin, a professor of sociology at the University of Florida, who has written extensively about race relations and is white. "If in a heartland city with no history of slavery and segregation, you find such virulent racism, it suggests that it is a cancer affecting us all."
For years, blacks in Dubuque say, they have felt alienated and isolated, enduring namecalling and stares. But what seems to have spurred the latest incidents is a plan to encourage local employers to hire minority workers, particularly blacks. The plan's goal is to recruit 20 minority families a year for five years with financial incentives and recognition awards to businesses that hire minority members. The program is to be financed by Federal grants and private donations.
 
A Minority in the N.A.A.C.P.
 The plan came in the wake of a cross burning two years ago that ignited a black family's garage. A task force set up to examine the situation found what most Dubuque residents already knew: The city is an isolated, homogeneous island where everything from the police force to the fire department to every teacher in every public school is white and where blacks are even a minority in the local chapter of the N.A.A.C.P.
The task force of business leaders and school and city officials said that what Dubuque needed was more minority citizens; the hope was that exposure to other groups might make people more tolerant. The City Council approved the plan, 6 to 1, last spring.
Although the city government devised and adopted the plan, its execution is up to private employers, and it is unclear whether they have had any success in luring black workers.
But merely the idea of an influx of new black residents has enraged some residents. Some young whites express fears of black newcomers taking their jobs. Others speak of crime and mayhem coming to Dubuque. People are afraid, as one resident put it, that "we won't be able to open our windows, sit on our porches, stroll in our neighborhoods." One rumor has it that "busloads of gang members from Chicago with guns" will be deposited right on Main Street.
 
David Dukes in Dubuque
 "Dubuque missed the 50's and the 60's," said Mayor Jim Brady. "We didn't go through what Selma and Montgomery went through. We watched and applauded from afar. But we didn't face it ourselves because we didn't have the numbers of black people. Now we're finding we have our David Dukes right here in Dubuque."
It is white, working-class young men frightened by an uncertain economy who have been the most openly hostile, orchestrating fights and cross burnings out of protest against integration.
"We're speaking up for white people," said Michael Lightfoot, 19, a sometime meatpacker, who with a friend admitted to several recent cross burnings. Mr. Lightfoot and his friend pleaded guilty to arson and were given two-year suspended sentences and ordered to perform community service. "Everything in the town was just fine until this. We need to take care of the people here instead of bringing these other people in. It's us against the blacks."
Mr. Lightfoot and his friends are starting a local chapter of the National Association of White People, a group founded by Mr. Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan grand wizard who is running for governor in Louisiana.
Mr. Lightfoot's view is echoed at the high school, where racial clashes, student walkouts and wild rumors have pitted some of the 1,450 white students against the 12 black students.
Tensions reached a fever pitch last week when a group of 30 white students stood outside the cafeteria, complaining about the black students. Suddenly, a black senior, James Lewis, walked around the corner.
"There goes one now!" a white student shouted, as the other white students stared. Mr. Lewis, his defenses up, asked if they were looking for a fight. A white student, Scott Perry, made an obscene gesture toward Mr. Lewis, who then punched Mr. Perry. Both were briefly suspended.
"I used to have some white friends, but they left," said Mr. Lewis when he and Mr. Perry recounted the details of the fight. "And everybody else is scared of what their friends will say."
 
White Images of Blacks
 The hostilities are surfacing in an atmosphere of ignorance and innuendo, where in the absence of personal knowledge of blacks, white images of them take on a kind of mythology.
In a letter to the local newspaper, The Telegraph Herald, a white resident asked why town leaders thought black people would come to Dubuque when "everyone knows blacks don't like cold weather." Last week, a rumor that black students were bringing guns to the high school prompted officials to search lockers. A jackknife was found.
Some are convinced that, based on what they've seen on television, blacks might do anything. "They're always the mean guy in the movies," said Brian Ainley, a senior at the high school.
Nothing riles people like Steve Dunne, whose goal is to be an auto body mechanic, more than the idea that more black residents might come to town and take jobs he could have had. "It's bad enough to lose your job to a white guy," Mr. Dunne said. "But a black guy? It would mean you lost a job to someone that everybody knows is lower than you."
Supporters of the integration plan say such fears about jobs are unfounded. Dubuque's 6 percent unemployment rate, frequently cited by detractors as the reason the town does not need any more workers, is lower than it was a decade ago. And the positions that supporters of the plan would like blacks to fill are primarily professional jobs that many in Dubuque would not qualify for anyway. One new black resident is a neurologist, for instance, although his recent move here is not related to the city's plan.
But that has not blunted the anger. In recent weeks, anonymous advertisements have run in The Telegraph Herald, urging residents to join a petition drive against the integration plan.
 
'We're Not all Racists'
 Donald Deich, the only city council member who voted against the plan, says he does not think the city should be in the personnel business at taxpayer expense. "We're not all racists," Mr. Deich said. "They can bring in 200 of them as long if we don't have to pay for it. It doesn't bother me any. As long as they behave themselves and don't bring a bunch of ragtag relatives that cause trouble."
Specialists in race relations say that what has happened in Dubuque could happen anywhere.
"This shows we're not very far from old-fashioned racism, and we are able to revert very quickly if social or economic anxieties arise," said Dr. Marilynn Brewer, a psychologist who is director of the Institute for Social Science Research at the University of California, Los Angeles.
What is not at all clear is how city leaders will persuade black people to come to Dubuque. For now, they are hoping that a few pioneers will want to try life in a clean, quiet city that is at least trying to face up to its prejudice.
"Dubuque needs black people more than black people need Dubuque," said Ernestine Moss, a black resident who is president of the local N.A.A.C.P. "Dubuque needs black people to bring it into the 20th century."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 14; Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 451 words

HEADLINE: Military Spending Binge Got Us Into This Mess;
Put People to Work

 BODY:
To the Editor:
There appears to be a consensus that the United States will emerge from recession by consumer spending. Some members of Congress have proposed tax reductions, which they believe will put more disposable income into our pockets. 
 Are they naive, cynical or did they just plain forget Economics 101? A reduction in taxes will do nothing to increase consumption because it will not accrue as cash. This money will not be spendable because it has already been spent to meet daily living expenses in most instances. Therefore it is more likely that any tax reduction will reduce the amount to be borrowed to cover individual tax underpayments. In any case, no tax break will appear before spring because Congress must first pass, and the President must sign, it into law.
The Federal Reserve Bank lowered interest rates to stimulate industrial and entrepreneurial borrowing and subsequent investment, which would generate new jobs. This version of the trickle-down theory puts the cart before the horse. The need for capital is created by a need for increased productive capacity. Companies do not generally borrow when the outlook for an upswing is as gloomy as it is now. The market for new homes has not expanded as expected because of high prices and uncertainty. Staff reductions in virtually every industry, coupled with the reluctance of banks to lend money for operating costs, expose this policy's flaws.
By extending the number of weeks for collecting unemployment insurance, Congress attempted to put money into the hands of those who need it most for survival. This small step toward putting cash in people's hands was stopped by a Presidential veto.
The average person needs to work for money. We know that almost all income is spent on personal consumption. A percentage of each expenditure is an income for another person, who will in turn spend it and so on. In this way, $100 of income may generate a multiple of itself. Obviously, we need to put people to work to generate consumption, which will ultimately revive the economy. When private sector employment shrinks, new jobs need to be developed in the public sector to take up the slack.
Notwithstanding the gradual disintegration of the country's infrastructure, Federal policy appears to be opposed to large public projects or to expanding the public sector even temporarily. The states cannot absorb the costs. The passage of a five-to-six-year $150 billion transportation bill by Congress is the only glimmer of light in an otherwise distressing picture.
 
MEYER SHOPKOW
New City, N.Y., Oct. 24, 1991
 
The writer is professor emeritus of business, Bronx Community College.

HEADLINE: SPECIAL REPORT;
Businesses Go Back to School

BYLINE: By John Holusha

 BODY:
OWNERS and managers of small- and medium-size manufacturing businesses are going back to school today as they try to improve the efficiency of their operations by harnessing the power of the computer.
That is what Dominick Martorana did when he decided to add computerized controls to the automatic machine tools that cut and shape parts for electronic devices at his Highland Manufacturing Company, in Highland, N.Y. But Mr. Martorana did not head for an ivy-swathed university. Instead, he went to Hudson Valley Community College in nearby Troy, for instruction in computer-aided manufacturing and the details of the software packages that control the machines. 
 Community colleges, the two-year institutions that have long provided economical access to higher education, are increasingly staking out a role as the agents of technology transfer for manufacturing industries. Instead of simply preparing students for transfer to four-year institutions or providing low-tech vocational training, many community colleges are teaming with industry and government to retrain the existing work force in computer operations and modern manufacturing methods, such as just-in-time inventory management.
 
'Much Stronger Role'
 "Community colleges have been in the process of a major transition during the 1980's," concludes a recent report by several Federal research laboratories. "They have moved toward a much stronger role in vocational education and in supporting U.S. industry."
"Community colleges are probably the most liberated and aggressive force in American education today," said Hirsh Cohen, education specialist at the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation in New York, which promotes science, technology and management. "They do not have the rigidity of the K-through-12 system and are more aggressive than four-year, research universities."
Mr. Martorana said that Hudson Valley College had provided the help he needed for his 20-worker factory. "I did research on what kind of software to buy," he said. "Then Hudson Valley sent people down here and analyzed my shop to see what I needed." Now computer controls are boosting productivity for him, since machines can be quickly programmed to shift from producing one type of part to another.
These work-force training arrangements are also benefiting the community colleges, which in recent years have become big business. According to the American Association of Community and Junior Colleges, there are about 1,200 such institutions around the nation, with about six million students taking courses for credit and five million more in noncredit training programs.
Federal agencies, such as the Tennessee Valley Authority and the National Institute of Standards and Technology, and national research laboratories such as Lawrence Livermore in California are choosing the colleges as the vehicle for bringing high technology to the shop floor. Increasingly, these ventures are three-way alliances, with a Federal laboratory or major university providing technical expertise, private industry supplying money and equipment and community colleges doing the instruction.
Hudson Valley, for example, has formed an Advanced Manufacturing Resource Center in association with the federally financed Northeast Manufacturing Technology Center at nearby Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. Although the R.P.I. center directs the program, which is intended to upgrade competitiveness of small- and medium-size businesses, teaching has been delegated to Hudson Valley and 11 other community colleges in the state.
"We are oriented toward transferring technology to small businesses," said Douglas Baldrey, associate dean of the college's school of engineering. Four-year colleges, Mr. Baldrey said, are more academically oriented and interested in basic research rather than factory-floor operations. "We offer a course in selecting computer-aided manufacturing systems," he said. "That is not something a Rensselaer or a Cornell wants to do."
 
Industrial Courses
 The advanced manufacturing program includes industrial short courses for workers seeking to upgrade skills -- courses like Introduction to Computer Aided Design and Manufacturing, Data Acquisition Using Personal Computers and Advanced Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.
But the manufacturing center also includes an academic track for students, who can take courses in computerized design and manufacturing equipment, automation and robotics. They can graduate with an associate degree in, say, industrial technology or mechanical engineering technology and machine processes, and head for a ready job market.
"The people who run companies around here say they cannot get skilled workers," Mr. Baldrey said. "That is why some of them are asking us to set up apprentice programs." He said there were about 200 students pursuing manufacturing technology degrees at Hudson Valley, with an equal number of industrial workers taking noncredit courses.
At the college, both sets of students receive instruction on how to use the myriad of computer-aided design programs. And they learn how to translate those designs into instructions for automated machinery in industrial settings.
With grants from the Northeast Center, Hudson Valley is also taking its courses to the companies themselves, conducting training sessions at 22 factories and shops this year.
Nationally, about 50 community colleges have built technology centers to enhance local manufacturers. "We know we need to do something with regard to manufacturing competitiveness," said Karl J. Jacobs, president of Rock Valley College in Rockford, Ill., which has built such a center.
Not all programs involve classic, metal-cutting manufacturing. Lawrence Livermore and other Federal centers in the West have set up programs with community colleges in California, Nevada, Utah, Arizona and Hawaii to train environmental cleanup and hazardous-waste specialists.
"It is pretty obvious that rising numbers of people will be needed to work in environmental restoration, pollution prevention and waste management," said Paul Dickinson, an education specialist at Lawrence Livermore. Mr. Dickinson said the program, called the Partnership for Environmental Technology Education, would be a joint government-industry-academic undertaking.
Livermore has also signed an agreement with the 107-campus, 1.5-million-student California Community College system to establish 16 Centers for Applied Competitive Technologies. The agreement is part of an effort to find commercial applications for technologies such as advanced high-temperature materials developed by the labs during the cold war.
The Tennessee Valley Authority is trying to help the 40 community colleges in its region stay close to technology's cutting edge. "The pace of change in some technologies is so fast the instructors cannot keep up," said W. Carroll Marsalis, a sector manager with the authority. "So we are focusing on training and retraining for instructors. We have helped establish a National Institute for Technical Training at Mississippi State University."

HEADLINE: SPECIAL REPORT;
School Sports' Last Rah-Rah?

BYLINE: By Michel Marriott

 BODY:
FOR THE first time in the collective memory of Lorain, Ohio, autumn blew into the small, blue-collar town this year and no season of public high school football was there to greet it. No cheerleaders. No pep rallies. No football players hitting the field and each other in the name of school pride and personal glory.
"It feels kind of messed up," said Frank (Scooter) Shrieves, the 17-year-old quarterback for the Lorain High School Steelmen, who still wears his football jacket to school. 
 In Lorain, as in an increasing number of American school districts, student athletic programs are under siege. In recent months, a lingering national recession and a creeping unwillingness among taxpayers to pay yet more for public education have strained school budgets throughout much of the United States. More and more, school administrators complain that they are being pressured to choose between textbooks and touchdowns.
"It's made me sick to the stomach," said Thomas Bollin, superintendent of Lorain's 12,000-student system, about the deep cuts he made in school sports programs in March. When residents voted down a special levy that would have generated the necessary revenues, Mr. Bollin said he had no choice but to cancel sports.
Dozens of other school administrators nationally, many of whom acknowledge the teamwork and leadership skills that sports teach, have made or are facing similar decisions.
 
$750 Per School
 In Chicago, a yawning education budget deficit prompted school officials to slash athletic budgets for its 64 high schools from an already tight $6,700 a year to $750. In Los Angeles, where transporting one team to play another costs on average more than $200, school officials trimmed athletic budgets by 20 percent as funding streams for education run dry. Communities in other states, including Arizona, Florida and Maryland, have endured similar cuts in school athletics.
In some schools, cuts have been accepted with resignation. Elsewhere, school officials have devised sometimes desperate ways to raise money.
In San Francisco, city officials passed a measure in January that placed a one-year-only surcharge on ticket sales for some professional sports to raise money to support local student athletics -- a first in the nation. High school sports were saved from extinction for at least a year, said Anne Herinline, commissioner of athletics for the city's junior and senior high schools.
Ms. Herinline added that the sports programs were being helped by a local group, Save High School Sports, which has raised more than $100,000 a year for supplies and equipment since it was founded in 1985 by Don Barksdale, a former player for the Boston Celtics. Still, she said, the school district will be "looking at the same black hole next year" as education revenues are outpaced by educational needs.
"How can you have sports programs if you don't have schools?" asked Linda Matsumoto, a spokeswoman for the Chicago Board of Education, which was forced by law to close a $315.8 million budget gap before schools could reopen this fall. "Unfortunately, we had to make some difficult cuts," Ms. Matsumoto said. "But learning takes place in the classroom between teacher and student. That relationship is sacrosanct."
Gary Marx, senior associate executive director of the American Association of School Administrators, said American public schools were increasingly confronting that fact of educational life. "Every administrator I talk to is concerned about what is happening in the academic program and coming up with adequate funding to hold their own," Mr. Marx said.
But Carey E. McDonald, executive consultant to the National High School Athletic Coaches Association, suggests that school officials are using cuts and threats of cuts to sports and other extracurricular programs as a ploy.
"Communities don't seem willing to fund the schools," said Mr. McDonald, who said he had been involved in student athletics for 45 years, "and administrators are smart enough to know that if they threaten to cut sports or band, they'll get support."
In Chicago, however, no rescuers have come running, said Lonnie Williams, the football coach at Martin Luther King Jr. High School on the city's South Side. The result, Mr. Williams said, is that the level of participation in athletics will fall, especially among low-income black students attending "ghetto schools" like Martin Luther King. Professional sports, long a showcase and marketplace for black athletes, will be beyond those students' reach. Cuts in high school sports today, Mr. Williams said, mean limited access to lucrative sports careers tomorrow.
Administrators fear that cutting sports programs may discourage some students from attending school at all because their dreams of becoming another Michael Jordan, the multimillionaire Chicago Bulls basketball star, will be dashed.
The alternatives, Mr. Williams said, are the gang and the street and a premature death.
Four students from Martin Luther King, for example, were murdered over the summer within a four-block radius of the school building, he said.
In Tucson, Ariz., education officials faced with deep cuts to sports and other extracurricular programs rallied round their high school teams by eliminating ninth-grade sports altogether and instituting a pay-to-play plan for the rest.
The plan has met with mixed success. Last year, students paid $60 if they wanted to participate in fine arts programs, such as band, debate and drama, and $105 to play sports. Parents complained, said Sheila Baize, director of extracurricular programs for the Tucson Unified School District, Arizona's second largest. Students spoke with their feet; some 2,000 of them walked away from the extracurricular programs, Dr. Baize said.
This year the fees were reduced to $30 for fine arts and $50 for one season of one sport; ninth-grade programs were restored. The extra revenue came from a $300,000 state budget reallocation; more was raised by a private, nonprofit group in Tucson, the Educational Enrichment Foundation.
 
'Scholarships' Offered
 For students who wanted to participate but were unable to pay, the foundation offered "scholarships" to cover the fees, Dr. Baize said. Nonetheless, she added, there were students who would not ask for financial help although they needed it. "Any time you have to ask for a dollar amount to participate in any educational activity, you automatically restrict some students from participating," she said.
In Lorain, Ohio, school officials decided to borrow $650,000 from the state after the elimination of sports brought protests from parents and moved scores of students to leave the district. But the restoration of sports and other extracurricular activities came too late for this football season, said Mr. Bollin, the superintendent.
The special school levy will again go before the voters on Tuesday. Hopes are that this time it will pass.

HEADLINE: SPECIAL REPORT;
Principals of Success

BYLINE: By Anthony DePalma

 BODY:
SCRATCH the surface of a good school, one where learning is abundant and real joy accompanies the search for knowledge, and it is almost certain that a good principal will be there leading the way. While there is no consensus on what makes one principal more successful than another, there is consensus on the need to find out.
"The traditional role of the principal has to change if schools are going to change," said Phillip C. Schechty, president of the Center for Leadership in School Reform, a nonprofit organization in Louisville, Ky., that works with school leaders nationwide. "If principals keep on doing what principals have always done, schools will keep on doing what they've always done. Even if they were real good at it before, that may not be good enough today." 
 Studies conducted over the last decade to determine what makes a successful principal show that at the very least, those who are most effective generally know how to identify important tasks and then spend most of their time on those tasks. Successful principals also demonstrate an ability to delegate authority, communicate effectively and set an example by their hard work.
But the job of principal, most principals themselves argue, entails more than the basics of a graduate business degree. And Mr. Schechty and other experts say the standard regimen for principals in most states -- a master's degree in any field, 30 graduate-level credits in subjects like school administration, school law and school finance -- no longer is adequate for the leader of as complex an enterprise as a school.
 
'I Learned by Doing'
 "To be honest, I can't say that anything I learned in those school administration classes has come to play in my job over the last seven years," said Dennis W. Boswell, principal of the Conway Middle School in Jefferson County, Kentucky. "I learned by doing rather than by having someone lecturing at me."
Efforts are under way to upgrade the training that principals receive, and some innovative changes, such as New Jersey's alternate route for principals, have already been effected.
At the heart of the issue, though, is an unresolved debate over the very function and focus of a principal. Some believe that today's schools are like small corporations. Thus principals should be trained like corporate managers, able to keep their schools running smoothly, with food in the cafeteria and chalk in the classrooms, allowing teachers and students to pursue their missions without interference.
But many others, while acknowledging the importance of strong managerial skills, maintain that the principal remains the heart of a school and sets the academic tone there. As such, he or she needs to be able to motivate teachers, deal effectively with human-relations issues and shape the educational enterprise.
In most cases, a principal needs to be both manager and educational leader. But it is a matter of philosophy, and often of a school's disciplinary and economic environment, that determines the degree to which one attitude dominates the other.
Successful principals acknowledge that the skills they draw on most are those they picked up on the job, most often working as an assistant principal to someone willing to share administrative responsibilities.
Jane A. Kendrick, a principal in Hammond, Ind., now on leave to work as a special assistant to the superintendent, said that when she received her doctorate in school administration, "that pretty much covered the management piece, what we called budgets, butts and buses." But for Miss Kendrick, it was working with principals that gave her the leadership skills she needed when, in 1978, she went to Henry W. Eggers Elementary/Middle School in Hammond, a 1,000-student, multicultural, multi-ethnic school known as the "zoo." It took time, but she was able to draw in parents, community leaders and teachers in a site-based management reform, in which teachers have more responsibility for curriculum development and classroom management.
The reform of principals' instruction programs formalizes and gives prominence to such on-the-job training. Programs such as Stanford University's "New Pathways" work with hypothetical situations and the team approach to problem-solving.
By contrast, several programs rely on what is basically a corporate management training model. The Bell South Corporation in Atlanta, for example, takes its own employees and local principals into the woods for several days of exercises intended to help develop leadership skills.
For the last six years in New Jersey, a corporate group called The Partnership for New Jersey has been bringing inner-city principals to corporate training programs by businesses such as Johnson & Johnson and Nabisco Brands Inc. to learn leadership skills such as managing organizational change.
 
'Schools Are Businesses'
 "Schools are businesses to the extent that they have to balance budgets, evaluate employees, deal with issues such as stress management," said Jan Carlsson-Bull, associate director of the Partnership.
New Jersey has gone farther than other states in recognizing the managerial skills needed by principals. Along with its widely praised alternate route program that allows people to become teachers without having to take education courses, the State Department of Education offers an alternate route to becoming a principal for someone who has never taught but has a master's degree in some leadership field such as business administration.
The New Jersey program essentially follows the notion that principals learn what they need to know by working on the job. For two years, a business executive-turned-principal must report to an experienced principal who can provide education leadership skills the alternate-route trainee may not have.
The unusual nature of this approach has not been fully tested, since all two dozen people who have come through the program in the last two years had taught. Still, the program remains controversial. "If a principal is expected to hire teachers, evaluate teachers, support teachers, a principal ought to have spent time in a classroom," said Patrick J. Ragosta, a former teacher who now is principal of Burlington Township High School in southern New Jersey.
Mr. Ragosta added, and other principals agree, that working as a vice-principal under an effective principal is the best route to becoming a school leader. They also said principals must be able to juggle several tasks at once, and deal effectively with adults and children.
And then, there is that intangible quality separating the adequate from the extraordinary. "Part of it is instinct," said Eileen Petruzillo, the principal of Greenwich High School in Greenwich, Conn., and a former New York City school principal once called exemplary by a United States Secretary of Education. "It's the ability to say 'My own agenda is that I want this place to be better when I leave than when I came.' "
