HEADLINE: Drop in Births Reported, And Recession Is Blamed

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
Five years of steady increases in the number of births in America ended abruptly this year, and many demographers and economists are blaming the recession.
 The Federal Department of Health and Human Services reported last week that 2,361,000 babies had been born in the first seven months of 1991, a decrease from the same period in 1990. Since 1987, births had been increasing by more than 100,000 a year. 
The decrease thus far in 1991 puts births 50,000 below the same period in 1990, but that does not include the July figures for Connecticut, Illinois, Maryland and Oregon, which were not reported. But all of these, with the exception of Illinois, had already shown declines in the first few months of 1991. No 1991 statistics for Illinois are available yet.
 Marriages also fell 2 percent in the same seven-month period of 1991, the department said.
 
Economy's Consequences
 Although the final figures could change slightly once all states have reported and corrections have been made, economists and demographers generally agreed that the decline in births and marriages was significant and was caused by the 16-month recession.
 The last three national recessions were followed by reductions in the total number of births in the years immediately after.
 "It's almost certain that the increases of the past years have stopped, primarily because there is a perception that the economy has entered a questionable phase," said Carl Haub, the director of demographic analysis for the Population Research Bureau, a private company in Washington. "The faith of young couples in the job outlook and the economy has been shaken."
 Richard Easterlin, a professor of economics at the University of Southern California who has for two decades been a leading proponent of theories that fertility follows economic cycles -- up in good times, down in bad -- said, "This recession is serious and long and hurting many of the types of people who do the most family planning, who tend to time births and space them."
 This year, the clearest regional decline, 5 percent in the first six months of the year, was in the Pacific states where jobs have rapidly evaporated, particularly in the military-contracting industry. In the Middle Atlantic region, including New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, the decrease was less than 1 percent in the first seven months, and the rate of decline was even lower in the mountain states.
 But, while the depressing effect of a recession on births is a constant, demographers and economists say they still have no clear picture of how it works -- which income groups or age groups delay childbearing and which children are delayed, first or second babies, or later children.
 
'We Don't Feel We Should'
 "We still hope to have a third child," said Deborah Lillian, 33 years old, of Montclair, N.J., "but we don't feel we should right now." Her husband, Jonathan, a banker, lost his job in August and has just started his own business.
 The couple has two children, 3 1/2 years old and 10 months old. "We were going to space the next one a little closer, but it wouldn't be responsible to go ahead," Mrs. Lillian said.
 But other young couples, like George Houk and Pat Bailey of Washington, will not let the economy get in the way of their plans. "I lost my job last January, but it had very little impact on our decision to have another child," said Mr. Houk, 34, an architect who had worked for a design and construction firm in Maryland. Like Mr. Lillian, he has gone into business for himself.
 His wife is due to have their second child at the end of January. "We're more concerned with how old the respective siblings are and how old we want to be as new parents," he said.
 Just as the two couples differ in their responses to the recession, economists and demographers are split in predicting whether the current demographic reversal portends a long-term decline in births and in the average number of children born to each woman.
 "It wouldn't surprise me if 1990 was the peak for the remainder of the century," said Martin O'Connell, chief of the Fertility Statistics Branch at the Census Bureau. He said that he did not expect any increase in average family size and that now that the oldest baby-boomers were edging past their childbearing years there would be a slow decline in births, at least until 2000.
 
Some See It as Temporary
 But other economists see the decline as a temporary setback, arguing that women will soon be having more children apiece. Experts follow that trend, measuring it in a statistic called the total fertility rate, or the average number of children a woman will have in her lifetime.
 At its peak, in 1957, in the midst of the baby boom that began after the end of World War II, the fertility rate in the United States was 3.77. At its trough, in 1976, it was 1.77. In 1990, the national rate stood at 2.1, called by experts the "replacement rate," or the birth level at which the population, in the absence of immigration, remains stable.
 These figures reflect the complex demographic minuet between the baby-boom generation in the two decades after the war and the baby-bust generation that followed. Baby boomers in the 1970's and 1980's ushered in the phenomenon of delayed childbearing, pushing down the fertility rate while they were in their 20's, and pushing it back up as they reached their 30's and finished forming families. But as they did so, the baby busters were re-inventing the practice of having babies while in their 20's. The combination pushed the fertility rate and the total number of births up rapidly in the late 1980's, Mr. Haub, Mr. McConnell and other demographers said.
 The baby boomers are now beginning to move out of their childbearing years, leaving a smaller number of women to have children. But Diane J. Macunovich, an assistant economics professor at Williams College in Massachusetts, said she believed that this smaller group of women could expect more success at work because they had fewer competitors. This success, she said, will make them more willing to have three or four children each.
The current downturn "is a blip on an upward trend," she said.

HEADLINE: Giving Downtowns a New, Alluring Look

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD

 BODY:
AFTER years of being passed over in favor of regional malls and shopping centers, downtown districts throughout the metropolitan area are reworking their images to try to bring back shoppers and revive their commercial centers.
They are doing this through mixed-use developments involving residential as well as commercial projects to put more middle-class and affluent residents right in the center of town. 
 This month, after 25 years of debate about how best to proceed, the Village of Scarsdale in Westchester County will begin demolition to make way for redeveloping part of its downtown.
The village and the Penn Central Corporation have signed a memorandum of understanding giving the railroad exclusive development rights for a year and setting forth such preliminary steps as site-clearing. Details of the plan remain flexible and subject to village review proceedings and financing has yet to be worked out.
As it stands now, the plan calls for 22,478 square feet of retail and other commercial space and parking for 539 cars. Above the retail space will be about 150 condominium units.
Similar mixed-use projects are planned for downtowns in such places as Danbury, Conn.; Patchogue, L.I., and Englewood, N.J.
These downtown projects seem to be almost the only ones -- except for super expensive apartments in Manhattan -- where condominium development is going forward in the New York region.
Developers apparently believe that despite the oversupply of condominium units throughout the area, there is still demand for those close to transporation and shopping. In fact, all the downtown housing developments now under way are being targeted specifically to young professionals and the elderly, for whom convenience is of paramount concern.
Much of the impetus behind this push to redevelop downtowns comes from the railroad companies that own land near the tracks. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Penn Central Corporation and the New Jersey Transit Corporation are currently involved in developing sites near railroad stations. Not only is this a profitable use of land owned by the transportation companies, but it also increases the number of people who use the trains.
PENN CENTRAL owns half of the three-acre redevelopment site in Scarsdale; the village owns the rest. In exchange for using village-owned land, Penn Central has agreed to make public improvements. The most important, said John Crary, the village's deputy manager, is repairing and widening the Popham Road Railroad Bridge, built in the 1920's and in a "steady state of deterioration in recent years."
The demolition, which is expected to be completed this month, involves three abandoned buildings considered an eyesore in the affluent village. The structures, an old office building, a railroad sub-station behind it and a gas station, "have been deemed to have no historic value," Mr. Crary said.
"A preservation group examined them," he said, "and just asked to have some brick and a sign salvaged and that will be done."
There has been some public opposition about the scope of the development. Some believe it will urbanize the village and the buildings will obscure tree views for some residents. There has also been concern about the affordability of the housing units.
"Because this is a very expensive site to build on, the units are expected to be 1,500-square-foot luxury condominiums," said Mr. Crary. "It's still too early to get more specific than that."
Mr. Crary pointed out that the zoning governing the site requires setting aside 10 percent of the units for the elderly. But some village residents worry that few elderly people will be able to afford them, since they will sell at market rates.
The new buildings will have to mesh with the village's prevailing Tudor style.
"Any design we consider can't just be good," Mr. Crary said. "If it doesn't look outstanding, we're not going to do it."
Taking a slightly different tack is an ambitious downtown project currently under way in Danbury, which is expected to include 20,000 square feet of retail space, 10,000 square feet of offices, 165 restaurant seats, a 1,000-seat triplex movie theater and 86 housing units. The housing, to be marketed to young professionals, will be one- and two-bedroom condominiums, priced between $90,000 and $115,000.
"The whole package is designed to bring the middle class back to the city," said Dennis Elpern, the city's planning director. "To do that, we have to offer the kind of amenities that will make the downtown stand out in this highly competitive market."
As in Scarsdale, this project has been in the planning stage for several decades. What finally got it off the ground was an $8 million state grant that is being used to build a 550-car garage that is expected to be completed next month. That same grant is also being used to build a landscaped median along the shopping district on Main Street.
The plans include building a brick walkway along the shopping corridor and creating a village green, a 19,580-square-foot plot off Main Street that will be landscaped with $250,000 in state funds.
Like many other cities in the Northeast, Danbury's downtown has been devastated by the plethora of shopping centers and malls that sprang up on the city's outskirts. The city now has a 25 percent retail vacancy rate and 20 percent of its office space is unoccupied. To turn things around, city officials hired Hyett Palma, a commercial development consulting firm based in Washington.
"Malls have been very good at locating their retail spaces in positions where they can benefit each other," said Dolores P. Palma, the firm's president. She recommends that downtowns do the same through the "clustering of businesses," where a shoe store, for example, would be positioned next to a shop that sells scarves and handbags, and another that has women's clothing.
The company also advocates "a healthy mix of retail, offices and housing," she said.
"The best cities, like Seattle and Boston, have that," she said. "It creates a synergy that makes for more active streets and more business."
In some communities, housing did not start out as part of the original downtown redevelopment plans, but was added later.
In heavily "malled" Long Island, the village of Patchogue has been struggling, with some success, to keep its downtown shopping district competitive.
The latest attempt is the proposed building of a 27,000-square-foot retail center on Main Street that would have national chain stores. Among the proposed features are storefronts with uniform awnings and a sidewalk arcade where shoppers could view showroom-size windows.
This new look for downtown led a local developer, Connor Construction, to begin building a 30-unit condominium complex, called Seacrest Village, two blocks from Main Street. Designed to appeal to young families, the one- and two-bedroom units are expected to sell for $99,900 to $118,900.
A nearby site at the west end of Main Street is also being for housing.
A similar snowball effect is expected in Englewood, N.J. There, a project called Palisades Court will comprise 60,183 square feet of retail space, a 51,429-square-foot supermarket, 28,100 square feet of office space and a three-level, 100-car garage and additional parking for 553 cars.
It already has all its approvals and is "moving ahead," according to Peter M. Beronio, director of the Englewood Development Corporation.
At some later point, Mr. Beronio envisions a residential complex to be built on a site adjacent to the redevelopment site.
"There's an area southwest of the retail development that the City Council has already deemed in need of redevelopment," he said. "If all goes well with downtown, it should happen."

HEADLINE: Selling Software, Soviet-Style

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN

 BODY:
Selling software in the Soviet Union has its own special set of challenges. The Nantucket Corporation, a $35 million, privately held software maker in Los Angeles, is learning that in a country with no clear notion of ownership, much less intellectual property rights, building a market can be daunting. "Copying is so pervasive that the people over there think that Maxell and Verbatim, the floppy disk makers, are actually the software publishers," said Larry Heimendinger, Nantucket's president.
Nantucket, however, is showing other major software companies how to succeed there by painstakingly convincing Soviet software developers that buying is preferable to pirating. Nantucket's popular Clipper package, used to develop software, is unusual in that 2,000 legal copies have been sold in the Soviet Union. 
 Esther Dyson, a consultant and publisher of the Release 1.0 newsletter who has studied the Soviet computer industry, said Clipper's joint venture there appears to be the most successful of any software maker's. Companies like the Microsoft Corporation and the Lotus Development Corporation are using it as a model.
"Nantucket has paved a path," said Jane Kitson, business development manager for Lotus in the Soviet Union. "They were the first to sell software for rubles and to successfully convince customers of the value of the service and support they'd get if they bought the product." Lotus expects to open a wholly owned subsidiary there by the end of the year.
Microsoft, whose earlier attempt to start a Soviet joint venture reportedly failed, has encountered delays in setting up a wholly owned subsidiary, said Charlotte Guyman, director of international marketing. Ms. Dyson pointed out that Microsoft is already "omnipresent," with virtually every personal computer running a pirated copy of its DOS operating system.
Nantucket is already seeing the results of its evangelistic efforts. At a recent computer trade show in Kiev, an irate Clipper user stood up to complain that only registered buyers were eligible for official user groups.
After a tense moment, a registered buyer said, "I paid for that service and support and so should you." Others cheered.
The first step for companies like Nantucket is to spread that attitude. Nantucket has already devoted more than two years and $650,000 to its Soviet effort, with little hope of recouping its start-up costs for years.
To Mr. Heimendinger, it is worth the risk. Though popular in other countries, Clipper -- which has sold 250,000 copies worldwide and lists for $795 in the United States -- has achieved near-legendary status in the Soviet Union from the thousands of illegal copies.
Like other software, Clipper can be traded on the black market. Nantucket's success in selling Clipper, priced at 15,000 rubles, has come in part because it is a software development package, often bought by people who hope to market their own software.
Nantucket built its Soviet business, which now has 30 employees, a two-story headquarters 20 minutes from the Kremlin, a telephone hot-line and a walk-in service center, by selling its product for rubles.
Instead of earnings that can be brought back to the West, Nantucket's immediate goal is market share. "When we started this in early 1989, our only thought was that eventually the Soviet Union would have to become a free-market economy to survive," said Larry Heimendinger, Nantucket's president. "We figured, let's get in now, seed the marketplace with our product and worry about profits down the pike."
In less than a year of selling its software there, Nantucket has made more than 5 million rubles profit, which it is using to manufacture Clipper in the Soviet Union. This month, Nantucket began selling a Cyrillic version written and produced there, except for the disks.
The Soviet Union, with its estimated 600,000 or more personal computers, has been an open frontier of software piracy. But with 280 million people, a good portion highly educated and eager to get their hands on personal computers, Nantucket saw an opportunity too good to pass up.
Rather than sell through a Europe-based distributor, as most major software makers do, Nantucket sought a joint venture. Mr. Heimendinger was overwhelmed by the response to his request for partners. "It was amazing how naive they were," he said.
One man arranged a secret meeting with Mr. Heimendinger in Cologne, Germany. "He came in, locked the door, pulled down the shades and said, 'I need to sell Clipper. I make a list and send everyone a letter telling them to buy it from me,' " recounted Mr. Heimendinger. "I said, 'Oh, you mean mail order?' And he got upset and said 'Who told you my plan?' He thought he had a unique idea."
Unable to discern the good offers from the bad, Mr. Heimendinger turned to Nantucket's Los Angeles office and Vanessa Wade, a native of Poland who speaks fluent Russian. She moved to Moscow and spent the next year simply figuring out how business was done there.
Ms. Wade eventually discovered a Moscow clinic that helps disabled children use computers. Nantucket persuaded it that a joint venture would benefit both parties. Nantucket contributed computers and hypodermic needles and other medical supplies; the clinic offered a perfect base.
Once the venture, JV Magnet, was set up, Ms. Wade brought in an American couple, Robert and Virginia Clough, to manage it. They had worked on Microsoft's joint venture, and were eager to try again.
They understood the difficulties of motivating a Russian staff. "We constantly had to pound it into their heads that they could make decisions and have an opinion and get results," said Ms. Wade. "It took a year to instill that."
Now, the single telephone help-line is constantly busy. The service and support center is usually filled, with a line out the door. The August coup caused only a slight dip in sales, said Ms. Wade, who now oversees the Moscow operation from Brussels, where she is managing director of Nantucket's Belgian subsidiary.
Ms. Dyson believes all the key software makers will seek a formal presence in the Soviet Union. "It's a huge untapped market," she said. "It's extremely difficult to do anything there but if you do, people really want what you sell."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bob Clough and Alla Zubova, of Nantucket's joint venture. (Bill Swersey for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BOOKS & BUSINESS;
Chain Store Massacre

BYLINE: By Jesse Kornbluth; Jesse Kornbluth, a contributing editor of Vanity Fair, is the author of a forthcoming book about the financier Michael Milken.

 BODY:

GOING FOR BROKE
How Robert Campeau Bankrupted the Retail Industry, Jolted the Junk Bond Market, and Brought the Booming Eighties to a Crashing Halt.
By John Rothchild.
Illustrated. 286 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster. $21.  
 It is the time of year when children begin dreaming of a white-haired man from the North bearing gifts. That is the right spirit to approach this engaging and deft book about Robert Campeau, the frosty-haired Canadian who descended on Wall Street in 1986, playing Santa Claus for the fee-hungry lawyers and bankers who helped him take over the Allied and Federated department store chains. Predictably, the Grinch -- in this case, an $11 billion debt load that Mr. Campeau could never have managed -- stole Christmas.
The story of Robert Campeau may well represent the definitive account of the greatest gouging of a client in the history of American finance, but in "Going for Broke," John Rothchild, the author of "A Fool and His Money," has not produced a finger-wagging Wall Street morality tale. "This is the story of a marvelous financial calamity," he promises, and until events become too grim for laughter, it is actually possible to forget how much damage Mr. Campeau and his enablers did to our economy. In this respect, "Going for Broke" does for corporate finance types in yellow ties and jaunty suspenders what Michael Lewis did for bond traders in "Liar's Poker."
This absurd story began improbably, as these things do. Robert Campeau was a survivor of two mental breakdowns, a physical fitness devotee whose regimen included sheep-brain injections and daily swims in a "specially purified" pool, and an energetic Lothario who had spent the 1960's running back and forth between two women and two sets of children. When dealing with bankers, an aide recalled, "Our idea was to let Bob speak last at these meetings, and then hold our breaths."
In 1985, when Edward Finkelstein, the chairman of R. H. Macy & Company, was working on a leveraged buyout of the department store chain, Mr. Campeau got the wacky idea that he should be involved. Mr. Finkelstein declined to meet him. Undaunted, Mr. Campeau decided to buy a chain of department stores and, in the process, become Mr. Finkelstein's equal.
Mr. Campeau was cash-poor, with a spotty career as a developer of shopping centers and apartment and office buildings. But this was the golden age of hostile takeovers, and investment bankers were willing to entertain the notion that Mr. Campeau might actually be a suitable owner of Allied Stores, the third-largest retail conglomerate in the United States (their 750 stores included Brooks Brothers and Ann Taylor). Indeed, Mr. Campeau was the perfect client. No one knew anything about him; he knew zilch about investment banking. In short order, Allen Finkelson of the distinguished New York City law firm Cravath, Swaine & Moore was "charmed by Campeau's quirky bravado."
Such assessments worked only until Bob -- no one called him Robert or Mr. Campeau -- actually talked finance. "Mad Bomber," Citicorp bankers dubbed him. "A Steinbrenner in the making," a retailer concluded. "Nothing the man was saying made any sense," noted Eric Gleacher, then of Morgan Stanley.
Mr. Campeau's luck improved when Bruce Wasserstein, at that time the ranking mergers-and-acquisitions wizard of First Boston, gave him "his famous 'dare to be great' speech, the gist of which was that to be great, you had to be willing to take on huge debts and pay huge fees." Mr. Campeau swallowed this line whole; Mr. Wasserstein called him "a brilliant although misunderstood businessman." Still, once First Boston learned that Mr. Campeau consulted a fortuneteller, Mr. Wasserstein made sure he did not give his client a dime until he had paid his commitment fee by wire transfer.
Mr. Rothchild says Mr. Campeau played the part of the empty suit beautifully, showing up at First Boston on an October morning in 1986 to sit with Mr. Wasserstein, Mr. Finkelson and a gaggle of investment bankers. A few minutes later, Boyd Jefferies -- the founder of a brokerage firm that, among other services, was then accumulating stock for favored clients -- just happened to call and to wonder if anyone was interested in buying 32 million shares of Allied Stores. This coincidence was, for these men, considerably less astounding than the fact that, after acquiring Allied, Mr. Campeau could not make the down payment.
Six hundred million dollars in fees later, however, First Boston and Citicorp were only too happy to help Mr. Campeau buy Federated Stores, a mammoth chain with 650 stores (including the glittering, highly successful Bloomingdale's) and 134,000 employees. That transaction generated $200 million in fees for First Boston alone -- more than Federated earned in a year. Unsurprisingly, it only took six months for Mr. Campeau's empire to topple. Allied and Federated went bankrupt, 8,000 employees were fired, Citicorp stock and the junk bond market crashed, First Boston lost a bundle. The age of what Mr. Rothchild terms "the Debtor Barons" was over.
Robert Campeau, who has also been forced to declare bankruptcy, now lives in an Austrian mansion and avoids all depositions "on the advice of his physician." He probably missed a recent advertisement for fur coats. Among the women pictured was Susan Finkelson, wife of the lawyer who was once so helpful to Mr. Campeau that he made him a director of his company. Mrs. Finkelson modeled chinchilla -- from Bloomingdale's. In another time, that would be an insignificant detail. After Mr. Rothchild's book, it offers some crackpot solace: at least the lawyers escaped unscathed.
 
 
THE CAMPEAU TOUCH
 Once, at a retirement party for a longtime employee, [Robert Campeau] tried to make a deal to buy back the man's Campeau Corp. stock at a favorable price. Once, the sale of his house in Ottawa to his own daughter was stalled over his insistence that the washer/ dryer unit didn't come with the property and still belonged to him. Once, the sale of a $600,000 apartment building in Ottawa was held up while Campeau and the buyer argued over who got to keep the lawn mower. . . .
If the Ottawa zoning codes set a height limit of 325 feet for new buildings, as they did in certain sectors of the city in the 1960s, Campeau demanded 450 feet. When government officials acceded to 342 feet, Campeau offered to compromise at 375. When they held him to the 342-foot requirement, he put up a 342-foot building, but with an extra 28-foot "pimple" for rooftop equipment. Campeau argued that the extra 28 feet didn't count as part of the building's formal height. His opponents saw it as another example of his relentless one upmanship. From "Going for Broke."

HEADLINE: Backers Say 'Core' Bank Plan Lives

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
Although it was ultimately defeated on the floor of the House of Representatives last week, the proposal by Representative Charles E. Schumer to set up a "core" banking system in the United States is not likely to disappear.
Core banking would split each of the nation's banks into two: a core bank that would take in Government-insured deposits and make only traditional loans to small business and homeowners and a "wholesale" bank that could use its uninsured deposits to lend pretty much as it pleased. The notion is to reduce the amount of risky activities that are protected by Federal deposit insurance. 
 That this approach, a fundamental change in the structure of the banking system, was able to attract the support of 106 House members was a sign of how far many frustrated legislators are willing to go to deal with the deteriorating banking system.
 
Overwhelmed by the Opposition
 Presented as an amendment to the banking overhaul legislation now before the House, the proposal was opposed by nearly every bank lobbying group and, after heated debate, by 312 legislators.
Despite losing by 200 votes, Mr. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, predicted as he left the House floor: "Core banking will pass, and it will be law within three years. It's an idea whose time will soon come."
Others agree. "Core banking is on the shelf," said Robert Litan, a banking analyst at the Brookings Institution. "It will be one of the first things to be resurrected if the banking system deteriorates."
And Samuel J. Baptista, a lobbyist with the Financial Services Council, a trade group representing both banks and securities firms, commented, "Win, lose or draw, core banking is a concept that will not go away."
That's too bad, almost all banks say. They contend that core banking has so many pitfalls it would weaken an already fragile system.
The core banking idea was first floated by Lowell L. Bryan, a banking consultant with McKinsey & Company, who sent a book he wrote on the subject to all members of Congress. He followed up with personal visits and in Mr. Schumer found a responsive ear.
 
Two Main Features
 Under the Schumer proposal, core banking would have two main features. First, an interest-rate ceiling would be reimposed for depositors in the core bank, on the theory that competition by banks to attract depositors with higher rates push them into risky lending. Second, the Schumer proposal would limit the loans a core bank could make to a single borrower, on the belief that such concentrated loans put a bank more at risk. These two proposals, with the changes in the banking system being considered in Congress to allow banks to enter the securities business, would bring about a core banking system of insured banks doing traditional lending and uninsured banks undertaking riskier ventures.
 
Search for Higher Returns
 Few bankers care for this approach, and in a rare united front, big and small banks criticized the proposal. One big bank that favors it is the NCNB Corporation, based in Charlotte, N.C. "Core bank is a four-letter word for comprehensive reforms, and we at NCNB like many facets of it," said Timothy P. Hartman, chairman of NCNB Texas. NCNB, many banking experts say, is already structured along core bank lines and could make the switch more easily than many banks.
But Mr. Bryan of McKinsey calculated that the interest rate ceiling would drive $800 billion to $1 trillion in funds from core banks as depositors fled in search of higher returns. This money should flow to the uninsured part of the bank, he said, which would pay higher rates but offer no Government guarantees against loss.
Bankers do not see it that way. Without money on deposit, banks would have no money to lend, making the already existing credit shortage even worse. "This proposal suffers from all the basic problems of price controls," said Edward L. Yingling, a lobbyist for the American Bankers Association. "It would drive a lot of money out of the system. It would cause credit crunches if too tight. If not tight enough, it has no teeth."
William M. Isaac, chairman of the Secura Group, a Washington bank consulting firm, and former chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, was even more blunt. "The last thing we need right now is a plan to drive a trillion dollars of depositors out of the banks," he said.
 
Premiums of Deposit Insurance
 In addition, Mr. Isaac said, the money that would flow to the uninsured bank is money that could be used to pay premiums into the Government's bank deposit insurance fund. Since the uninsured banks would be able to turn to the Federal Reserve System in times of trouble, they would be getting the benefits of Government bank guarantees without paying the premiums, a situation that Mr. Isaac terms unconscionable.
The second part of Mr. Schumer's proposal, to limit the amount a bank could lend to a single lender, is criticized by banks as unnecessary. They say the problem with banks is not that they lend too much to any single lender, but that they overly concentrate loans to single risky groups -- for instance, too much commercial real estate loans or loans for leveraged buyouts.
"You can't find a bank that has failed because it made too big a loan to one person or group," Mr. Yingling of the bankers association said, "but you can find lots of banks that failed because of overconcentration in one area, and this lending limitation accomplishes nothing about that."

HEADLINE: Compaq Moves Are Reported

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Nov. 3

 BODY:
James M. Harris, a co-founder of the Compaq Computer Corporation, and two other senior executives have left the company, The Houston Chronicle has reported.
The departures follow the ouster of another founder, Joseph R. Canion, who had been chief executive and president. 
 The Chronicle reported on Saturday that several employees had said Mr. Harris, 47 years old, had decided to retire. He had been senior vice president of engineering.
The newspaper said the others who left included Robert Vieau, Compaq's senior vice president of manufacturing, and C. Murray Francois, the senior vice president of corporate quality and materials.
Compaq officials could not be reached for comment over the weekend. Mr. Canion, reached at home today, said he did not have enough information about his former colleagues' departures to comment.
Compaq, hurt by the recession and increased competition, announced on Oct. 23 its first-ever quarterly loss and said it would lay off 1,400 employees, or about 12 percent of its work force. The first layoff notices were issued on Friday.
Eckhard Pfeiffer, the chief operating officer, was named to replace Mr. Canion.

HEADLINE: Rare Miscalculation by Honda

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Among automotive cognoscenti, the Honda Motor Company sits on a tall pedestal for its almost uncanny ability to aim at a market niche and fill it with a wildly popular car. But after Honda's introduction of its Accord station wagon, that pedestal is not quite so high.
Nearly a year after Honda showed off its first Accord wagons at its Marysville, Ohio, assembly plant, American sales are running at about 2,000 cars a month, well short of the 3,000 cars Honda had hoped for. 
 True, a recession in the United States has severely hurt car sales and promises to give Detroit its worst financial beating ever. And true, the station wagon market has been shrinking, badly hurt by the growing popularity of mini-vans.
But Honda's wagon is also off to a slow start because of its lofty price, its comparatively modest amount of space and a missing feature or two.
 
Problems of Price and Space
 Honda, for its part, says it is not disappointed with station wagon sales. They will improve, company executives insist, as the model becomes better known and the economy improves. In any event, they say, the plant where the car is built is operating at close to full capacity, partly because Honda is exporting the station wagon to Europe and Japan.
Honda's first mistake, several Honda dealers said, was in pricing the compact wagon considerably higher than the Honda Accord sedan -- initially more than $2,000 higher. Shoppers quickly noted that the wagon was not all that much bigger than the sedan and concluded that it was not worth the added cost.
Given what Honda initially wanted for its wagon, ranging from $17,300 to $19,800, many buyers chose roomier competitors like the Subaru Legacy or the Volvo 240 wagon, which costs only slightly more than a fully-equipped Honda wagon. Others just chose the Accord sedan.
"In the climate we're in, purchase price is a major factor," said Larry Brueshaber, a Honda dealer in Cincinnati.
Because Honda's wagon is generally less roomy than many other wagons, as well as comparably priced mini-vans and utility vehicles, it is also less useful. With 64.6 cubic feet of cargo room with the second seat folded down, the Accord compares poorly with the midsized Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable wagons (81.1 cubic feet), and import wagons like the Subaru Legacy (71 cubic feet) or the Volvo 240 (76 cubic feet).
"Honda may have overestimated the potential for a sporty-type wagon without that much space in the back," said Craig Scott, who owns Scott Honda in West Chester, Pa. "And I think Honda has to address the fact that a station wagon is perceived to hold more than four people."
Although a third adult could squeeze into the back seat, enabling the car to carry five adults, Honda engineers lacked room for a foldaway third seat in the rear similar to the third-seat option offered by Ford on its Taurus and Sable wagons and on the Chevrolet Caprice, Volvo and others. Honda executives have said they are considering adding a third seat, but not until the car is redesigned in 1995 or 1996.
 
Swayed by a Radio Ad
 Debbie Luciano of Lincroft, N.J., had been planning to buy a 1992 Honda station wagon, and she even put $2,000 on one. Then she heard a radio advertisement that compared its size with that of a Volvo. "I started thinking about these high school kids I drive around," she said. "They are big."
After comparing the $20,020 price for the well-equipped Honda with the $21,500 cost of the Volvo, she and her husband decided that the extra space was worth the extra money.
With the 1991 introductory price of $17,300, the basic Accord wagon cost $2,205 more than a comparably equipped Accord sedan. The most expensive wagon had a $19,800 price tag, $2,255 more than the most luxurious Accord sedan. By contrast, prices for a Ford Taurus station wagon start at less than $15,000.
Honda has since made some pricing changes. For the 1992 model year, it narrowed the price difference between the wagon and the sedan, not by cutting prices but by raising the price of the sedan more than the wagon. Now, the least expensive Honda wagon costs $17,450, compared with $15,825 for the least-expensive sedan, a $1,625 difference. The most expensive wagon costs $20,650, only $655 more than the costliest sedan.
A Honda spokesman said the value of the station wagon was enhanced this year by the addition of a driver's side air bag as standard equipment. The sedan has featured an air bag since last year.
Executives of Detroit's Big Three, who have watched glumfaced as Honda's Civic, Accord and Acura models have inexorably devoured their sales since 1973, can barely conceal their glee now that Honda may finally have hit something short of a home run.
"It surely hasn't measured up to vaunted expectations," said Joel Pitcoff, a research analyst for the Ford Motor Company. "If their strategy was to woo away Taurus and Sable owners, that's going to be a tough struggle."
The Honda wagon is also struggling in a shrinking market. Throughout the 1980's, mini-vans steadily gained ground as the multipurpose vehicle of choice, while station wagon sales steadily declined. Since 1985, station wagon registrations have plummeted 57 percent, to 390,770 cars in 1990, while mini-van registrations have more than doubled in the same period, to 829,126 units.
 
Resisting the Mini-Van Trend
 Ford, for example, discontinued its full-sized wagons this year after annual sales had dwindled to less than 15,000 cars. It continues to make the Taurus and Sable wagons.
But Honda has resisted the mini-van trend, preferring to invest in other projects like its Acura luxury models. The Acura Legend was the first Japanese luxury car to be sold in the United States and quickly captured a niche because it was priced slightly below European luxury brands like Mercedes-Benz and BMW and won more praise from reviewers than American luxury models like Lincoln and Cadillac.
Since most shoppers consider domestic or foreign brands exclusively, Honda probably did not hope to attract much crossover business from Ford. Still, Honda has to wonder whether the Accord wagon possesses the attributes for its target audience: import buyers who like a sporty vehicle but need a roomier car than a sedan.
Honda dealers say more changes in the pricing stategy could go a long way toward increasing sales. Generally, Honda cars have been so popular that the company has not offered rebates. But Honda will sometimes subsidize leases or pay incentives to dealers, which can indirectly lower a customer's price.
 
A Comparison With Subaru
 Mr. Scott, the Pennsylvania Honda dealer, said the Honda wagon "drives and handles like the sedan and has more space, but it still could cost almost $2,000 more," taking into consideration options and incentives.
"At that price," he said, "people start comparing with the Subaru wagon, which is $3,000 less, or they discover they can get something much bigger for about the same money."
Last fall, a few months before the Accord wagon was available, John Lewis and Judith Bell-Lewis, his wife, of Lynchburg, Va., were hunting for a station wagon. They bought a four-wheel-drive Subaru Legacy wagon for $15,500. The Honda dealer had told him a comparably equipped wagon might cost $18,000.
"The Subaru was a great value," Mr. Lewis said. "My wife owned a Honda Accord sedan and loved it, but we have no regrets."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Fed Delay Of Rate Cut Expected

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
On the eve of the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions, many credit market traders and investors expect the Federal Reserve Board to move today or tomorrow to push short-term interest rates down to levels that have not been seen since Richard M. Nixon was President.
But many analysts who agree that another cut is coming say the Fed may wait a bit before pushing rates down to the levels of the early 1970's. 
 Current conditions and recent history support the argument that the Fed will quickly push the discount rate, the rate the Fed charges banks to borrow at its discount window, down by half a point, to 4.5 percent, as well as cut the overnight Federal funds rate for loans among banks by another quarter-point, to 4.75 percent.
 
Continuing Weakness
 Recent economic reports have quashed talk of an accelerating recovery and strengthened the possibility that the positive growth registered in the third quarter was merely a blip in a lengthening recession. And recent inflation statistics give little reason to suspect that price pressures are anything but tame.
"We have enough information to say that the fourth quarter and the first quarter of 1992 will be very soft," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Corporation. "And there is no inflation threat anywhere."
But one of the Fed governors asserted yesterday that the economy would not slide back into recession, pointing to figures showing economic growth over the summer. "I don't think there will be a double dip," John P. LaWare, told a conference of bank-loan and credit officers in Washington.
Mr. LaWare said pessimism among consumers and businesses was dragging down the economy. "What is most worrisome is not so much the basic statistics, but confidence," he said.
 
Cut at Last Refunding
 Expectations of an imminent rate cut have also been raised by the Fed's recent history of easing policy. While the bond market's collective memory is not long, it does extend back three months, and the Fed did ease at the start of the August refunding. Four times each year, the Government sells three- and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds.
But when the Fed's policy-making Open Market Committee meets in Washington tomorrow, other considerations are likely to provide more compelling ammunition for delaying action, analysts said.
A delay in easing rates would most likely sit well with the bond market, where stubbornly high yields suggest that the Fed's efforts to stimulate the economy have been largely unappreciated. At this juncture, coaxing long-term interest rates down is more important than cutting short-term rates again, analysts said.
"They need to convince a lot of money managers that the economy is soft and getting softer and that inflation is not a threat," said Jerry L. Jordan, senior vice president at First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles.
The efforts to refocus the bond market's attention on the economy and on inflation were helped by the dismal October employment statistics released on Friday.
The report contained few positive elements, but traders and analysts said the one-tenth of 1 percent rise in the unemployment rate, to 6.8 percent, had probably cooled political pressures in Washington to consider fiscal policy changes, at least until after next year.
Talk of tax cuts haunted the bond market through much of October, effectively blocking the Fed from reducing the funds rate by another 25 basis points until last week. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
 
Impact on Dollar
 In addition to assessing the bond market's probable reaction, analysts said the Fed must be concerned about what another quick cut in short-term rates would do to the dollar, which came under savage attack last week.
A decision by the Fed to pause before cutting rates again would almost certainly push short-term market rates higher over the next few days. But analysts and money managers said such an increase might be necessary to insure success for this week's refunding auctions.
"It is time for the Fed to act," said Robert A. Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities International. "But easing before the refunding is like having dessert before the entree, because it makes it very difficult to distribute these new issues."
As the auctions approached, traders and money managers said the crucial issues surrounding the debt sales centered on whether bond yields would have to exceed 8 percent to stimulate demand, and how the lingering effects of the Salomon Brothers scandal involving improper Treasury auction bids might influence the auction process.
The bulk of the new securities will almost certainly be bought by domestic investors, analysts said.
Net purchases by foreigners of Treasury securities totaled an enormous $13.6 billion in the second quarter, Treasury data show. But since then, the differences in interest rates overseas and here have narrowed further and the dollar has weakened. And compared with last spring, there seems less chance of a further big recession-related decline in American rates.
 
Taking Long-Term Risks
 In the recent past, investors have found it a mistake to buy bonds yielding less than 8 percent. But at the end of last week the spread, or difference, between yields on two-year notes and 30-year bonds was a 2.30 percentage points. Given that sort of premium, the risk of buying long-term securities is worth taking, some money managers say.
"People haven't been very successful buying bonds at under 8 percent," said one money manager, who insisted on not being identified. "But this time I think I will, because the economy stinks and inflation isn't a problem at all."
William H. Gross, a managing director at the Pacific Investment Management Company in Newport Beach, Calif., said: "With inflation at around 3 percent, bond yields are very attractive at close to 8 percent. I believe that, but I don't know if the rest of the market believes it."
Although the Treasury has held a number of debt sales since the Salomon scandal erupted in August, this week's refunding will be the first sale since then of the Government's most speculative securities.
Since the scandal broke, Salomon has been barred from bidding for clients at auctions, and other houses have become much more circumspect about their conduct. Those changes could have an effect this week, traders said.
"All of the primary dealers are much more sensitive about what they can and can't say," since the scandal, one trader said.
"As a result," the trader added, "I think distribution of these securities may not be as efficient as at previous refundings."

HEADLINE: BAKER WILL VISIT CHINA THIS MONTH

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MADRID, Nov. 4

 BODY:
After several months of secret negotiations, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d announced tonight that he would visit China this month, a trip that is bound to revive the debate over the Bush Administration's stance toward the hard-line Beijing Government.
Mr. Baker will be the highest-level Bush Administration official to visit Beijing since the violent crackdown on democracy demonstrators at Tiananmen Square in June 1989. His announcement of the trip, in a news conference at the close of Middle East peace talks in Madrid, came only a few days after reports that China may be helping Iran develop a nuclear bomb. 
 Clearly aware that his trip will re-ignite the debate between the Admministration and Democrats in Congress over how tough the United States should be in dealing with Beijing, Mr. Baker immediately took the offensive.
"China has almost one fourth of all the people in the world," he said, echoing Mr. Bush's argument that China, no matter how repressive its domestic policies, is simply too big to ignore. "It has nuclear weapons, it has great influence in the region and it has immense economic potential."
 
Invokes Human Rights
 Seeking to justify the timing of the trip, Mr. Baker said his mission was the only way of persuading Beijing to make changes in its arms control and human rights policies.
"We cannot make headway unless we discuss them," he said. "Ignoring them will not make the problems go away."
Mr. Baker's trip will also take him to Korea and Japan.
The Administration's policy toward China is widely believed to be governed by President Bush himself, who was the top-ranking American diplomat in Beijing in the mid-1970's.
It was Mr. Bush who dispatched thenational security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, on two secret trips to China in 1989, a decision that stirred wrath in Congress when the visits were disclosed late that year. Mr. Scowcroft made the first trip only a month after the killings of the -democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square.
 In addition to China's poor human rights record, American critics have assailed its reported sales of ballistic missiles to the Middle East and growing trade surplus with the United States. Tensions in the trade relationship have increased with reports that China uses prison labor to make cheap exports.
Negotiations about the possibility of a Baker visit are believed to have been under way for months, with the United States seeking specific assurances from Beijing that some kind of formal agreement could be reached during the visit. Most expectations focus on arms control accords.
 
Signing Arms Pacts
 During a visit in August by the Japanese Prime Minister, Toshiki Kaifu, China said it would sign the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. During Mr. Baker's visit, it is possible that China will also declare its willingness to sign the Missile Technology Control Regime, an accord that curtails the transfer of medium-range missiles, or other agreements limiting the sale of conventional weapons.
Chinese leaders have pressed hard for a visit by Mr. Baker, who even journeyed to the tiny neighboring country of Mongolia in July without stopping in Beijing. China feels that Mr. Baker's visit would be an important propaganda victory, demonstrating China's continued importance in the new world order and Washington's willingness to work with its hard-line leadership to resolve the strains in their relationship.
While other foreign leaders are now regularly visiting Beijing -- albeit complaining each time about human rights violations -- Chinese officials have expressed frustration that ties with Washington are not improving. They argue that their relationship with Japan has been normalized and relations with Europe have "basically recovered" since the Tiananmen Square crackdown, and that only the United States has held back on repairing ties.
Aside from arms control, issues on Mr. Baker's agenda will presumably include trade and human rights. The Chinese now profess a willingness to discuss human rights in general, though they reject specific criticism as interference in their internal affairs. Mr. Baker may ask for assurances that certain dissidents or their family members will be allowed to travel to the United States.

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Shopping as Soviets Offer To Sell Once-Secret Technology

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
The Soviet Union is marketing an array of secretive items from its space program -- things that no spies or reconnaissance satellites could have pried loose during the cold war -- and the United States is so interested that it is sending teams of bargain hunters to look at the merchandise.
Items on the block include nuclear reactors, satellites, rocket engines, space stations, plutonium for compact power sources and a host of scientific reports on space testing and experiments. The goods are seen as the cream of the Soviet industrial complex and in some cases are considered better than similar items in the West. 
 "Nobody ever contemplated that the Soviet military-industrial complex would end up in Chapter 11," said Russell Seitz, an associate at the Olin Center for Strategic Studies at Harvard University who monitors the Soviet activity. "It's the yard sale at the end of history."
 
Some Are Resisting
 Few sales have been completed so far, and some Government and military officials are resisting the idea.
But in an important change, Federal experts are now making secretive trips to Moscow and beyond to sample the merchandise, and interest in the Defense Department and Congress is running high. The White House has begun a high-level review of the policy issues surrounding any possible purchases.
"There is clearly a rising level of interest and activity," Dr. Richard L. Verga, a Pentagon official in charge of developing advanced technologies for the Administration's "Star Wars" anti-missile research program, said in an interview. "As the result of decades of investment, the Soviets have all kinds of equipment and technologies that might be of interest to us."
Dr. Verga said the Soviet goods were apparently being quietly marketed to many countries, not just the United States. "When you're in the hotel bar over there," he said, "the language at the next table is German, and at the next one over is Japanese."
Mr. Seitz of Harvard said a major problem was simply sorting through all the offerings, which in recent months have increased sharply. For the Soviets, any sales would result in an influx of hard currency and the satisfaction of having their technical work admired and acquired.
For the United States, the purchases would be a technical bonanza and would possibly help stabilize a rival superpower now on the brink of chaos. The Soviet predicament is seen as so dire that Congress is moving to transfer up to $1 billion from the Pentagon budget to give the Soviets food, medicine and technical aid on converting their industries to peaceful purposes.
The Soviet space enterprise is the world's largest and most active, forged in the cauldron of the cold war and surrounded by layers of secrecy. For decades its successes dazzled the world. Starting around 1987, amid pressure to become more self-reliant financially, Soviet officials in charge of the vast complex began trying to market a diverse line of goods and services.
But that effort largely failed, mainly because of the West's resistance. The United States, for instance, banned the launching of most American payloads atop Russian rockets, partly for reasons of national security and partly because it preferred to spend its space dollars at home to stimulate domestic industry.
The West's resolve, however, has recently begun to weaken. Early this year, the Pentagon announced that it intended to spend $12 million to buy an advanced Soviet nuclear reactor for generating power in space, similar to ones that have powered Soviet spy satellites. The aim is to learn about technology, since the United States has long studied that type of advanced reactor but has never built one.
Pentagon teams have made repeated trips to the Soviet Union in preparing for the deal. Dr. Verga said he last went there in July and saw sprawling reactor test installations, parts of which are up for sale, that could not be duplicated in the West for $1 billion.
 
Soviet Edge on Alloys
 The Soviet Union has lagged in many aspects of the world's technology revolution, especially those relating to computers and electronic miniaturization. But it is ahead in others. For instance, its scientists have mastered the manufacture of high-strength, high-temperature alloys that are virtually unknown in the West. These metals can be important in the design of advanced rocket engines and nuclear reactors, which generate tremendous heat.
The Air Force, tempted by such wares, has quietly made repeated inquiries about buying an advanced Soviet rocket engine known as the RD-170, said to be the most powerful liquid-fueled rocket engine in the world. The Soviets are eager to sell. An industry expert privy to the East-West negotiations said a major problem was a conflict in the American military over whether it was wise to aid a former adversary by making such a purchase.
"It's schizophrenic," said the expert, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "Middle management will talk to the Soviets, who get all excited. But when it goes to the next step, upper management is not interested, leaving the Soviets up in the air. That's also a problem on the Soviet side. Middle management tries to cut a deal. But upper management says, 'Hey, we don't know anything about this.' Part of the problem on both side is lack of clear direction from the top."
Nonetheless, American interest is growing. A six-member team, led by Leonard Caveny, deputy director of innovative science and technology at the "Star Wars" program, the Strategic Defense Initiative Organization, recently returned from a Soviet visit. It included two civilian scientists from NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif.
The team went to the Institute of Thermal Processes, a military research and development center just outside Moscow, where they tested a very small but advanced space engine that uses magnetic fields instead of burning chemical fuels to move a spacecraft. Such a small engine could have many uses in the American space program for propelling satellites and payloads that have already been boosted into orbit.
 
'Very Moderately Priced'
 The Soviets are offering the device for $500,000 to $1 million. "It's very moderately priced," Mr. Caveny told Space News, an industry publication, in September before the visit.
In an interview last week, Dr. Verga, the Pentagon official, said that the results of tests by the American team "were quite favorable" and that interest in a purchase was growing.
Dr. Verga added that the engine was small enough to fit into the palm of a hand, and that the purchase price would include all associated flight hardware, such as equipment to condition the electricity that powers the device. "This kind of engine has been kicking around on paper in this country for 30 years, but never in space," he said. "The Soviets are actually flying these things."
So too, the Air Force is said to be interested in acquiring some secret Soviet data on the atmospheric effects of nuclear blasts, which has recently been put on the block. "They're selling everything," said an expert familiar with the negotiations.
The shopping spree, begun by the military, is beginning to attract others. Plans are under way for a large interagency team, including the Defense Department, the Energy Department and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, to visit the Soviet Union to evaluate a host of high technologies.
So too, the Energy Department has reportedly obtained from the Soviets 27 grams, or less than an ounce, of plutonium 238, a radioactive chemical that emits heat and can be used to make electricity. A different isotope, plutonium 239, is used to build nuclear weapons. Compact power sources made with plutonium 238 are used on NASA's deep-space probes, although supplies of these sources in the United States are likely to run short in the near future because of problems in the nation's reactors that make plutonium.
The Albuquerque Journal reported yesterday that the Soviet plutonium had been obtained and analyzed by the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico and been found to be of high quality. The Energy Department, it reported, is now weighing a purchase. The plutonium 238 would be used to power NASA space probes.
 
Congress Is Interested
 Congress, too, is interested in Soviet space goods. Representative Bob Traxler, the Michigan Democrat who heads the House subcommittee that oversees NASA's appropriations, and Representative Bill Green, a Manhattan Republican who is the subcommittee's ranking minority member, recently wrote NASA's Administrator to inquire about the technical feasibility of using the Soviet space station Mir or some part of it as a complement to the American program. The Soviet station is reportedly up for sale.
In an interview, Mr. Green said he had also made inquiries to Soviet diplomats about a possible purchase.
In its current issue, Space News reports that during the summit meeting in Moscow last summer, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev gave President Bush a document calling for an easing of trade restrictions to help the Soviet space industry. The White House is reportedly preparing a response.
With political pressures mounting to help the faltering Soviet economy, some Western experts see a growing chance for the success of East-West sales. But there is also much skepticism. Some officials fear that the swift pace of political change in the Soviet Union and the sense of impending chaos make it impossible to know who will be in charge in a few months to see any deals through.
 
U.S. Manufacturers Resist
 Moreover, there is resistance to sales by American space manufacturers, who have been battered by a global recession in space sales and a sputtering economy at home.
Adm. Richard H. Truly, NASA's Administrator, gave voice to such apprehensions in writing to Representative Green on Oct. 23 to discuss possible purchases of Soviet goods.
"The Administration is intensely concerned about the health and capabilities of the U.S. aerospace industry," Admiral Truly wrote. "Depending on the specific case, procuring a Soviet system or technology in place of a procurement from U.S. industry may or may not be in the overall national interest."
While the Administration will consider purchases, Admiral Truly said, it is unlikely that movement in that direction will occur quickly. "We do not anticipate any precipitate or speedy actions in this regard," he wrote.

HEADLINE: Louisiana Governor's Race Becomes Debate on the Past

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 3

 BODY:
While State Representative David Duke styled himself as the candidate of change and former Gov. Edwin W. Edwards talked of being able to unify disparate interests, the main thing the two men running for Governor in Louisiana did Saturday night in their first televised debate was to exchange accusations about their pasts.
At the end of the hourlong confrontation, Mr. Duke had a slight edge on the number of attacks. He repeatedly accused Mr. Edwards, who served three terms as Governor, of selling state jobs "three and four times over" to win support. 
 In his closing, Mr. Duke, who is running as a Republican, held up a sheaf of papers that he said were copies of pardons signed by Mr. Edwards and said, "Some said that he sold these pardons, but I don't know whether he sold them or gave them away."
 
Answering Duke
 Mr. Edwards, 64 years old, gave as good as he got. At one point Mr. Duke, 41, dismissed the worries of the business community and state tourism officials that his background as a former Ku Klux Klan official and neo-Nazi could scare away business, tourist and conventions; he said similar fears were expressed before the elections of men like George Wallace in Alabama and Lester Maddox in Georgia.
Mr. Edwards replied: "I think it is very interesting that my opponent identifies himself with the politics of the past in naming Lester Maddox of Georgia and George Wallace. The wrong signal at this time could cost this state 45,000 jobs and $1.8 billion in economic recovery if we don't get in step with the rest of the nation."
The slashing in the debate is likely to be seen increasingly in the two weeks remaining before the election, as interest groups express concerns about Mr. Duke's extremist ties and about the past of Mr. Edwards, who has been accused, though never convicted, of political corruption.
One such group, the Louisiana Coalition Against Racism and Nazism, which was formed to counter Mr. Duke's bid for the United States Senate in 1990, began an advertising campaign today with a full page in The Times-Picayune in New Orleans that quotes racist and anti-Semitic statements it says were made by Mr. Duke in the last six years.
Lance Hill, director of the group, said in an interview that it was important to show that Mr. Duke's views reminiscent of Nazism were not mistakes of his youth, as he often argues, but are indicative of his current attitudes.
"Many argue that we are confronted with two bad choices," the advertisement said. "But there is a considerable difference between good ole boy politics and genocide."
 
From Fringe to Spotlight
 Mr. Duke and Mr. Edwards were the top vote getters in a 12-candidate primary last month and will face each other in a runoff on Nov. 16.
Edward Renwick, director of the Loyola University Institute of Politics here who conducts polls for local news organizations, said neither candidate had scored a knockout in the debate. Mr. Duke seemed "more strident," he said, while the usually flamboyant Mr. Edwards was "more conciliatory."
Democratic strategists here say that demeanor was intended for Mr. Edwards to attract the reform-minded supporters of Gov. Buddy Roemer, who switched from Democrat to Republican earlier this year but who did not win enough votes in the primary to advance to the run-off.
James Carvin, a political consultant here, said he had worked with business groups to produce advertising for Mr. Edwards that expressed fears about what a Duke victory would do to tourism, investment, the convention trade and big-ticket sporting events. "I think there will be a half a dozen groups doing such ads," said Mr. Hill, of the Coalition Against Racism and Nazism.

HEADLINE: '90 Pact Failing To Curb Deficit, Lawmakers Say

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3

 BODY:
Members of Congress say that last year's budget agreement, despite its heralded promise to reduce the Federal deficit, has given them virtual license to disregard a deficit that has swollen to its highest level ever.
The budget agreement, reached a year ago by Congressional leaders and the Bush Administration, imposed new fiscal discipline on Congress, requiring it to pay for new spending with tax increases or spending cuts elsewhere. And it included yearly targets for the size of the deficit. 
 But there is no immediate penalty for missing the target, and lawmakers and economists say it has become almost meaningless.
The agreement did not require the Government to find savings to offset the extra costs of unemployment insurance, food stamps and other benefits arising from the recession, or the huge cost of protecting depositors at Government-insured financial institutions.
 
No Alarms Sounded
 As a result, there was virtually no reaction here when the Treasury reported last week that the deficit for the last fiscal year had surpassed all records, at $268.7 billion, a figure that reflects the extra costs of public assistance and the savings and loan bailout. Neither at the White House nor in Congress did anyone publicly express alarm.
"The age of no-fault budgeting has arrived," said Allen Schick, a professor of public policy at the University of Maryland, who has studied the budget-making process for many years. "Nobody is to blame for the deficit, and nobody has to do anything about it. Last year's agreement has paralyzed the Federal budget process and frozen budget priorities."
And Representative Bill Gradison of Ohio, the ranking Republican on the House Budget Committee, said: "The budget agreement has nothing to do with the deficit. It abandons meaningful annual deficit goals which we had under the Gramm-Rudman law." As originally passed in 1985, the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law was supposed to balance the budget in the fiscal year 1991, which just ended.
As the nation heads into a Presidential election year haunted by an anemic economy, conservative Republicans and liberal Democrats alike are agitating for changes in the budget agreement, including tax cuts to stimulate economic growth. But major changes in the agreement appear highly unlikely this year because there is no consensus in either party, much less between the two parties. Thus, lawmakers say, if the budget deal is reopened, the negotiations are just as likely to produce a political stalemate as an economic elixir.
Many Democrats and Republicans praise the agreement and say the deficit would be even bigger without it -- more than $300 billion in the year just ended, rather than the $268.7 billion actually recorded.
Representative Leon E. Panetta, Democrat of California, chairman of the House Budget Committee, described the agreement as "one of the most important fiscal disciplines that we've put in place in more than a decade."
And Representative Gradison said: "I voted against the budget agreement because it didn't promise sufficient deficit reduction. But I've become one of its strongest supporters because every alternative I see as worse."
 
More Than a Statistic
 The Federal budget deficit is more than just a statistic. Many economists, including Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, say that increases in the deficit adversely affect the American standard of living because they reduce funds available for private savings and productive investment by businesses and households.
When President Bush signed the budget bill on Nov. 5, 1990, he said it was "the centerpiece of the largest deficit reduction package in history." The deal was supposed to reduce the deficit by $482 billion over five years, one-third through tax increases and most of the remainder through spending restraint.
But since the package was adopted, official projections of the total deficit for 1991 through 1995 have increased 70 percent, to $1.3 trillion. The figure for the current fiscal year, which began Oct. 1, shot up $100 billion. The Congressional Budget Office now estimates the 1992 deficit at $362 billion, up from its estimate of $262 billion in December 1990.
"Those deficit-reduction measures, while very significant, did no more than keep the problem from getting a lot worse," said Mr. Reischauer, of the Congressional Budget Office.
In the fiscal year just ended, Federal spending for unemployment insurance benefits increased 40 percent, reaching $28.4 billion. The cost of the food stamp program rose 23 percent, to $19.6 billion. Medicaid spending, to finance health care for low-income people, rose 28 percent, to $52.5 billion. Cash assistance to the elderly, blind and disabled, under the Supplemental Security Income program, increased 23 percent, to $15.5 billion.
While increases like these are not limited by the 1990 budget agreement, Congress has found several ways to get around the fiscal constraints that do apply. In passing appropriations bills, it often stipulates that Federal officials may not make commitments to spend money until September 1992, so the outlays will not count against the limits for the current fiscal year. Congress has also tried to get around the limits by labeling appropriations as "emergency requirements," though Mr. Bush often refuses to go along with that designation.
Still, Congress has generally adhered to the spending constraints, to the surprise of many here. On three occasions this year, the Senate has decisively rejected proposals to suspend the budget agreement because of the recession, and no such proposal has reached the floor of the House.
 
Concerns About Flexibility
 Mr. Panetta and the chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, Jim Sasser of Tennessee, have defended the agreement even when they sympathized with Democratic efforts to undo it by shifting money from the Pentagon to programs aiding poor children. "We have adhered to the caps on spending that were established by the law, and we have adhered to its pay-as-you-go requirements," said Mr. Panetta.
There is growing concern that the spending limits in the agreement are too inflexible because they do not allow the Government to respond to changing priorities or new developments. The agreement, intended to last five years, is likely to be renegotiated in 1993, or perhaps earlier if the economy remains weak.
Senator Bob Kasten, Republican of Wisconsin, called last week for "abandoning the 1990 budget agreement to take into account the recent economic downturn." Another Republican, Representative Vin Weber of Minnesota, said the agreement was "a failure because it hasn't helped the economy and hasn't reduced the deficit."
Democrats on Capitol Hill have repeatedly tried to breach spending limits in the budget agreement to provide extended unemployment benefits to jobless workers without cutting other programs.
And others have spoken of reducing Pentagon spending. "If we could have foreseen this year's events in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union," said Representative Anthony C. Beilenson, Democrat of California, "we would likely have set a lower spending cap for defense programs."
