HEADLINE: As Maine Voters Cut Back Spending, Police Force May Go From 1 to None

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STOCKTON SPRINGS, Me., Nov. 1

 BODY:
Ted Reed, the police chief in this rundown town of weatherbeaten houses by Penobscot Bay, now exists on a salary made up of donations. His old cruiser runs on gasoline provided by a garage owner.
Chief Reed's plight has been brought about by growing anger among the town's 1,383 residents over the recession and rising property taxes. In September they voted to do away with their one-man police force, and the drive stalled temporarily only after some townspeople took up a door-to-door collection to keep Chief Reed on the job. 
 On Tuesday the question will be settled by a referendum. If the vote goes against keeping the Chief, the town will have to fall back on the county sheriff's office and the state police. Tempers are running high.
 
Familial Insults
 At a selectmen's meeting on Thursday night, with beige quilts covering the windows to keep the cold out of the unheated room, members of the audience insulted each other's families and one burly man poked his finger in another's face. Afterwards, Parker Gray, the head selectman, summed up the sentiments: "If you took these same parties and put them in a bar, with a couple of .38's, I think you can imagine what kind of problem you'd have."
Although the amount of money at stake here is small -- it would cost $4,000 to keep Chief Reed and his patrol car operating till the end of the year -- the issue touches a raw nerve in Maine, where the economy has been declining and frustration over taxes has been building for two or three years, especially in poor rural areas.
Similar concerns led two other towns in Maine to eliminate their police forces last summer. In one, Lebanon, a town of 4,300 people in the southwest near the New Hampshire border, an 18-year-old security guard at a campground was stabbed to death while trying to stop a break-in shortly after residents voted to abolish the town's seven-member police force in July.
Some local and state authorities worry that more communities will follow suit next spring at their annual town meetings, New England's traditional form of town government in which financial and other major decisions are made by a vote of those attending. "Our small towns see their police departments as discretionary spending; it's not like it is in big cities where crime is a big threat," said Jim Damicis of the Maine Municipal Association.
These towns are counting on their county sheriffs and the state police to take over the duties of their police forces, Mr. Damicis said. But the sheriffs and the state police have been hit by budget cuts of their own and are concerned that they may not be able to provide adequate assistance.
Col. Andrew E. Demers, head of the Maine State Police, said, "If there are any more cuts, I am afraid there will be a point where we'll have to decide what we can do and what we can't."
 
Town Business and Feuds
 In Stockton Springs, the battle over whether to keep the Chief's job is typical of the fights elsewhere in Maine, and, as is true of small-town tussles, it is spiced with local feuds.
The conflict began at the town meeting last March when Mr. Gray, newly elected as head selectman, proposed a Police Department budget of $22,000, including Mr. Reed's salary, gasoline and maintenance for his cruiser. That was $9,000 less than was spent the previous year.
Mr. Gray said he believed that the department was simply too expensive. "People were in a cutting mood," he recalled. They had just watched as their property taxes were re-evaluated, with the valuation on some waterfront land jumping to more than $100,000 an acre from $3,000.
Mr. Gray offered the Chief an option: Take a cut in his $440-a-week pay, or face elimination of his job when money ran out in September.
Chief Reed, a blunt-spoken 56-year-old man who some people here say "would arrest his own mother," took his chances, reckoning that come September the citizens would vote to draw enough money from the town's general fund to cover his expenses.
But at a special town meeting on Sept. 26, after two disputed ballots, the decision was no, by four votes.
Ed Marshall, a retired 69-year-old traveling salesman who voted to extend Chief Reed's pay, said: "We all felt sick when we left the meeting. I tossed and turned all night."
Mr. Marshall said he remembered what it was like when Stockton Springs, a working-class town of clam diggers and mill hands, did not have a policeman. He lives across the street from the local school, and he recalled young people gathering there, drinking and swearing and breaking into the buses.
 
The Drive for Donations
 So Mr. Marshall and some friends came up with a plan. The next week, at the selectmen's meeting, after Chief Reed's job was terminated, Mr. Marshall's group asked if the Chief could be kept on with contributions. The answer was a grudging yes, and so the Chief was rehired a few minutes later.
In the next two days Mr. Marshall's group raised $2,000 for their police officer. Mr. Marshall's team also circulated a petition, getting 242 signatures, seeking a referendum on Election Day that would have the town pay the rest of Chief Reed's expenses until the end of the year. That way, under Maine's form of government, the Chief would automatically be kept on three more months, until the next annual meeting. Perhaps then, Mr. Marshall thought, the town would come to its senses.
But Manly Shute, a barrel-chested carpenter and lobsterman, was angered by the donations scheme and the referendum. He saw the donations as a trick, because it forced the town to continue paying the Chief's insurance.
 
'They Don't Give a Darn'
 "I'm not against the officer personally," Mr. Shute said in an interview. "It's just that it's the poor people who keep paying and they don't give a darn about the poor people."
So Mr. Shute began gathering signatures for another petition, which he presented at the selectmen's meeting on Thursday, calling on the town to stop the donations plan.
At the meeting, one supporter of Chief Reed shouted at Mr. Shute, "Your problem is, your name is Shute" in a derogatory reference to Mr. Shute's large clan of relatives in town.
Mr. Marshall tried to quiet the dispute. "Let's not get into this," he said. "This is a good town."
Mr. Shute replied, "Well, it was."
It was Halloween, and as the angry participants, including Mr. Reed, left Town Hall, they noticed his cruiser. It had been splattered with eggs.

HEADLINE: Motorists Are Still Shunning Car Pools: They Want to Be Alone

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Every weekday, Janet Perkins commutes between her home in Fairfield, Conn., and her job 15 miles away in Greenwich, blissfully alone in her car and clearly not doing her part to reduce traffic congestion on Interstate 95. The very picture of someone who ought to be car pooling.
Tell her about it. 
 "I quit car pooling because the people I commuted with were total geeks and I began to loathe every moment I spent with them," said Ms. Perkins, a 32-year-old software engineer. "One guy in the car pool picked his nose constantly, and another woman used to sit in the corner and read comic books and shriek with laughter. I couldn't take it any more."
Ms. Perkins is not alone in her drive-time solitude. Car pooling, long promoted as a remedy for worsening traffic, has simply failed to catch on in the New York metropolitan region despite a decade-long campaign to persuade people to double, triple and even quadruple up in the interest of reducing traffic congestion and pollution.
 
Why They Won't
 The reasons are many, and maybe predictable. Some commuters drive alone because they want to be able to leave work early or stay late and not be bothered by someone else's schedule.
Some want their own cars on hand so that they can run errands at lunch, or depart immediately in case of family emergencies.
Some want to listen to their favorite radio stations.
Some want to be able to smoke.
Some want to drive as fast, or as slow, as they please.
And some, if not most, find the notion of car pooling to be, at bottom, positively alien to their unfettered, get-in-the-car-and-go American individualism.
According to surveys conducted by transportation agencies in the metropolitan area, 85 to 90 percent of commuters who take cars to work in the region are driving by themselves. The figures were borne out in interviews recently with commuters in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, almost all of whom said they had never joined a car pool. Nationwide, the number of people who car pool has been declining over the past decade. In 1980, 33 percent of commuters who drove to work participated in car pools, compared with 22 percent in 1990, according to Commuter Transportation Services, a nonprofit transportation management company.
Commuters like Isabella Tandy, an executive secretary for TransAmerica Leasing in White Plains, say driving alone is an escape. "Commuting is the only time in my life when I am really alone," Ms. Tandy said. "In the morning I listen to traffic reports while I am driving, but not at night. That's decompression time."
For another woman, who would not identify herself, driving alone has psychological benefits. "I feel nervous about driving with other people in the car," she said. "I'm phobic, and I do not feel guilty about it."
The woman, who works for a direct mail company at the Schulman Office Park in White Plains, said she recently learned that a worker in the next office building lives near her in New Rochelle, so she felt compelled to suggest a car pool.
"She said no," the woman recalled. "I was so relieved."
 
Where They Are
 Most highway commuters in the region work in clusters of businesses and office parks that have sprung up along major roads in Westchester County, on Long Island, in Fairfield County in Connecticut and in Bergen, Passaic, Morris and other northern New Jersey counties.
As populations in these suburbs soared in the late 1970's and 1980's, creating traffic tie-ups on highways and back roads that were not designed to handle the sharp increase in cars, transportation officials looked to car pooling, van pooling and mass transit to help relieve congestion.
But that has not happened, mainly because there are no significant incentives for people to give up the convenience and flexibility of driving their own cars to work, transportation officials say.
"The jury is still out on car pooling," said Jeffrey M. Zupan, a senior fellow at the Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit research organization. "It can work and help reduce traffic but not until we come up with new ways to make it more appealing to the average commuter."
A recent study by the planning association found that many car pools are disrupted when riders change jobs or residences. Half of all Americans change jobs or move every five years, the planning association said.
 
Why They Like It
 Despite the odds and the widespread preference for riding solo, not all commuters are averse to car pooling. Some say it saves them money on parking, gas and tolls. Others, worried about air pollution, say ride-sharing is simply the right thing to do. And still others say they enjoy the company and conversation.
Ray Anderson, Edward Battistelli and Robert Hamm have been commuting from their homes in Fairfield to their research jobs at American Cyanamid in Stamford for 20 years.
"The reason we have stayed together so long is that we have very lax car-pooling rules," Mr. Anderson said. "Some car pools have very complicated formulas that they use to determine how many times a week a person drives, and what can and cannot be done in the car, but we just relax and do whatever we like."
Some commuters who car pool are not all that happy about it. Vincent Carr and Cosburth Quailey, tax accountants for TransAmerica Leasing, drive a blue van along with three other employees from their homes in Queens to the White Plains office. They park the van in a preferred parking space, and are reimbursed by the company for gas and toll costs.
 
They Have No Choice
 Despite the free ride, both Mr. Carr and Mr. Quailey said that they would prefer to drive alone. "It's very tiring, and it's very stressful," Mr. Quailey said of ride sharing. The five car poolers must be ready to leave at 6:30 A.M. and most do not return home before 8:00 P.M. "We have to do it because it's a condition of the job," Mr. Quailey added, referring to an agreement the car poolers made with TransAmerica when the company moved its offices to White Plains.
Eric B. Langeloh, Commissioner of Transportation for Westchester County, said that a recent study of traffic congestion on the Cross-Westchester Expressway found that there are few local incentives to car pool.
"Car pools work but they must be made to work better," Mr. Langeloh said, calling for economic incentives like cheaper tolls for group rides.
Dee Angell, president of Metropool Inc., a nonprofit company that helps commuters and companies form employee car pools in Southwestern Connecticut and the Lower Hudson Valley region of New York, said, "We will not see a significant increase in car pooling until we make driving alone so costly and unfavorable that people only do it in extreme circumstances."
 
Cost Savings
 Car pooling already has many advantages that are often discounted or go unnoticed, she said. For example, Metropool estimates that a person driving alone pays about $300 a month in driving costs to travel 55 miles round trip. The same commute would cost the members of a two-person car pool about $150 each, the company said.
Car pooling also reduces the stress of daily commuting and saves on personal car maintenance and insurance. Metropool operates a referral service for commuters who wish to form car pools and distributes a registry of commuters looking for car poolers.
Despite the advantages, many still resist car pooling. One woman, a data processor who works at the Schulman Office Park in White Plains, said that she has considered car pooling but that she continues to drive alone.
"I'm free to get away from the office," said the woman, who refused to give her name. "I'm free to go home early. I'm basically free."

HEADLINE: Ogata Journal;
Japan's Unlikely Rebels: The Fabled Rice Farmers

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OGATA, Japan

 BODY:
When this village on the edge of the Japan Sea was created as a giant national experiment 25 years ago, it was called frontier land in a nation with no frontiers.
Farmers were lured from all over the country with promises of vast, cheap land and a stake in a new Japan. It was here, they were told, that the Japanese would teach themselves how to rival America's biggest farms and ease the country's perpetual worries about its over-reliance on foreign-grown food. 
 It did not turn out that way. In the new Japan, fiber optics and computers proved a lot more important than rice and soybeans. A generation of Japanese fed on McDonald's hamburgers eat far less rice than their parents did, and now Japan produces much more rice than it can consume. And that has started a series of events that have transformed Ogata from a rural utopia into a bitterly divided community.
At its core, the argument centers on those who think the Japanese Government is saving the fabled Japanese rice farmer -- descendants of the men extolled in song and swathed in nationalistic myths -- and those who think it is dooming him to extinction.
 
Farmers Flout the Law
 Ogata is the site of a rice rebellion, one Tokyo is eager to put down before it spreads throughout the country.
Nearly half the farmers here have openly flouted the law that requires them to keep their rice production within strict quotas and to sell their entire crop to the Government, at Government-set prices. It is then sold to long-suffering consumers at upward of four or five times the world market price.
Until now, the price-fixing system has worked because Japan has imposed a ban on all foreign rice, a perennial irritant in its relations with the United States.
But on the edge of town here, Kyoji Suzuki and his fellow farmers have decided to produce as much rice as they want and sell it for whatever they can. "We've lived under the thumb of the Government for years now," Mr. Suzuki said the other day, while his colleagues bagged their rice for direct delivery to their customers, evading the Government system. "We've had enough."
Last year, Mr. Suzuki said, his band of rebel farmers sold $4 million worth of rice, despite what he called a campaign of harassment by Government agents."
Grass-roots rebellions of any kind are rare in Japan, and not surprisingly Mr. Suzuki has not quite got the hang of being a free marketeer. His rice is scarcely any cheaper than the Government's, and he is not eager for foreign competition either. But price is not the issue, he says. He argues that the real problem is that Japan's overregulated agricultural markets are an example of economic planning gone wild.
 
Diplomats Are Interested
 He and his friends are getting a lot of visitors lately who agree, mostly from foreign embassies in Tokyo. The diplomats are drawn here because they see the Ogata rebellion as evidence for their case that Japan must give in to the inevitable, and crack open its market for rice.
It is a move being desperately opposed by farmers, the Agriculture Ministry and the many politicians who depend heavily on Japan's extraordinarily influential farm vote.
If Japan sticks to its position, many here fear, it will be blamed for scuttling the global trade talks known as GATT -- something that Japanese officials fear as much as farmers' protests. The new Prime Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, has hinted recently that he will continue Japan's hard line against opening the rice market.
Among the many disputes that trouble relations between America and Japan, rice can seem pretty trivial. Measured in dollars, it pales next to automobiles or supercomputers, and one could argue that it is hardly worth the passion expended by either side. But it is futile to argue that point here: The Government has promoted much of the mythology about how Japan has long fed its own and how its "food security" would be threatened by imports.
 
'Spitting Into the Heavens'
 Here in Ogata, the farmers who have abided by Japan's rules say foreigners and next-door-neighbors alike are risking the ruin of rural Japan.
"They are spitting into the heavens, and it will fall back on them," said Seiki Miyata, the Mayor of Ogata, which was created by filling in Japan's second largest lake. "Japan is not prepared to liberalize these markets. If we do, it will destroy rice growing, and with it all of our villages and our towns."
In truth, Japan's farming villages and towns are fading out already. At the agricultural high school in Akita, there were 286 graduates in March. "Forty-seven of them went to university," the principal, Yoshimitsu Ikeda, said the other day. "The rest went to work. But the number who started to work as farmers is zero."
Eventually some of those will drift back to agriculture if they take over the family farms. But they hesitate. "We try not to say we will be farmers, because the image is not so good," said Takashi Tamura, a student at the school. "We're told it is not so easy to find a wife."
Meanwhile, in the country that celebrates "wa," or harmony, Ogata remains a decidely unharmonious place. At the new year's party, opposing groups will not eat at the same table.
"We have two villages really, existing side by side," says Shinichiro Sakamoto, one of those who has vociferously argued against opening the market. "These days, we don't talk to each other very much."

In Ogata, at a "rebel" rice processing operation, farmers are evading the system and selling directly to Japanese families. (David E. Sanger/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Revising Budget Plan, Mayor Scrambles to Balance Taxes and Services

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Two days before Mayor David N. Dinkins must submit a four-year budget plan, a stiff warning from Gov. Mario M. Cuomo not to count on too much help from a state takeover of Medicaid costs has left the Mayor struggling to decide how and whether he can freeze property taxes, protect services and salvage his political standing.
Mr. Dinkins is to present the plan Wednesday and much is riding on its reception, including a potential $1 billion aid package from the Municipal Assistance Corporation that could ease the pain of service cuts or reduce the need for new taxes. 
Last week, senior mayoral aides said they hoped to freeze property taxes for at least two years to stabilize the economy and quell a growing chorus of demands from business groups and the City Council. But this plan would also assume nearly $1 billion in help from a state takeover of Medicaid by 1995, roughly twice what Mr. Cuomo had proposed.
 
Boon for the City
 The Governor's original proposal is already under attack by the Republican-led State Senate, which sees it as too big a boon for the city, and on Friday, Mr. Cuomo told the city that it should not ask for more.
"I don't see any reasonable possibility of additional money," Mr. Cuomo said. "It's not a question of the desirability of giving the city that money. But it seems to me as a simple practical proposition that they cannot reliably include that money in their plan. If they do, it will threaten the reliability of the entire plan."
As chairman of the State Financial Control Board, to which Mr. Dinkins must submit the plan, Mr. Cuomo will be one of the chief judges of its credibility. Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, has repeatedly said he wants assurances from the Control Board that the plan balances the city's recurring revenues and expenditures before agreeing to provide the $1 billion in aid through refinancing corporation bonds.
 
Series of Meetings
 All that led city officials, in a series of meetings over the weekend, to reassess their plans on the speed of the state's takeover of Medicaid costs and to review a complex array of options, including financing bridge maintenance or garbage collection through a mix of fees or new tolls. They hope to reach final decisions by today.
"We've got to figure out all these variables," the city's Budget Director, Philip R. Michael, said last night. "It's hard to hold one steady while the other three are moving."
Mr. Cuomo has his own worries. His aides say he will probably not reveal his intentions on seeking the Presidency until he sees the city's plan and his own budget division's blueprint for closing a $689 million gap in the current state budget. In making his comments on Medicaid, they say, he was warning that any attempt by the city to speed up a takeover could doom the effort to failure with the Legislature.
 
Seeking Support
 But mayoral aides say they are most worried about the first two years of the plan, which cover the rest of Mr. Dinkins's term, and they believe there is room to argue over the last two years. And the Governor is not the only player from whom they want support.
They have also courted the support of the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, for creating new bridge or garbage authorities, as a way of extending the tax freeze Mr. Vallone wants.
Mr. Vallone's aides say he will not support any move that leads to tolls on the East River bridges that are now free, or that means fees for garbage pickups. But he has not ruled out some kind of new auto-use fees or other revenue plan, like diverting money from the state bottle-deposit, to pay for such needs.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Seeks New Environmental Fund to Aid Economy

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 3

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo will propose the establishment of a special state fund to pay for tens of millions of dollars of water, sewage and other environmental improvements on Long Island, as part of a new state effort to rebuild the region's faltering economy, administration officials said today.
The environmental fund, the officials said, will be part of a broader plan to speed up public works projects immediately, to work on long-term development of airports, roads and ferry service, and to help Long Island cope with its rising unemployment and faltering defense industries. Mr. Cuomo is scheduled to unveil the plan next week. 
 In an interview today, the Governor declined to discuss the details of his plans, but he said it was the natural extension of a $7.8 billion plan for job creation and ecnonomic development in New York City that he proposed in September in New York City. These packages would be followed by similiar efforts across the state.
"This is statewide, it is not New York City, it is not Long Island," he said. "We have to go around the state and see how we can prod the economy. This is not a reaction to anything, except the recession, and the failure of Washington to do anything for us."
Mr. Cuomo dismissed suggestions that the plan was shaped in part to show he was on top of New York's economic problems as he ponders a race for President in which the suburbs are apt to be a key battleground.
"You don't plan an economic and fiscal plan for every part of the state just so you have a quick answer in the political department," he said.
Business leaders and environmentalists on Long Island, as elsewhere, have long been at war over many issues, from nuclear power plants to highway expansion, and Mr. Cuomo's plan is clearly seeking to meet the concerns of both groups.
Among the projects to be included in the Long Island plan, officials said, was speeded-up construction of a $110 million widening of the Long Island expressway and state support for a new freight jetport at Calverton that could be linked to a high-speed ferry to transport the freight across Long Island Sound. Details of some of the projects were reported in Newsday last week.
But state officials said that the plan would be a "broader blueprint" than support for economic development projects. They said it would include programs to improve schools and parks, protect undeveloped land and help local governments cope with fiscal problems brought on by the recession.
It was not immediately clear where New York State would find the money to finance the special fund. Officials said that among the sources being considered were admission fees from state beaches and parks on Long Island -- which produced a surplus last year -- and leftover bonding authority from a 1986 environmental bond issue.
Asked about the Governor's proposal, State Senator James J. Lack, an East Northport Republican, said that Long Island legislators of both major parties had already called for legislation dedicating state park fees for parks, after the state threatened to close Robert Moses State Park earlier this year. "All these inclinations by the Governor are always welcome," he said. "But like the nine years of his governorship, they are long on perceptions short on substance."
Richard Amper, executive director of the Long Island Pine Barrens Society, an environmental group, applauded the Governor's environmental initiatives, but he noted that the proposed freight jetport would be in the middle of the enviromentally sensitive pine barrens that are critical to maintaining water quality on Long Island.

HEADLINE: Lure Talent, Urban Experts Tell New York

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
Manhattan remains the economic engine of the metropolitan region, but New York City is misdirecting its development efforts in a futile drive to retain traditional factories and back offices, a new study has found.
With the regional economy reeling from the recession, the study's authors say the city is wasting much of the hundreds of millions of dollars it offers each year in development incentives by directing such a large proportion to the real-estate industry. 
 Instead, it should concentrate on the true sources of future growth by reinforcing the city's role as a center of brainpower and talent, the authors, two New York University urban affairs experts, say.
The authors, Hugh O'Neill, a senior researcher, and Mitchell L. Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at N.Y.U., wrote the report, "Reinventing New York," for the Andrew W. Mellon and Charles H. Revson foundations. It is to be formally released today.
 
Magnet for 'Intellectual Capital'
 City officials, who have yet to see the report, concede that their development program often focuses on retaining offices and factories. Yet they say they have little choice but to do all they can to preserve jobs, especially in a depressed economy.
The report says Manhattan is crucial to the region's economic future because it is a magnet to individuals and companies at the cutting edge of their industries. The city is not just a financial center, the report says -- it is the place to be for law firms, publishing houses, advertising and media companies, architects, fashion designers, actors and painters.
That mass of what Mr. Moss and Mr. O'Neill call "intellectual capital" creates about one-quarter of all the jobs in the region, the report estimates, and in turn creates demand for local services: grocery stores, dry cleaners, copy shops, messenger services and so on. Those industries generate about half the region's jobs.
The report argues that New York City should be concentrating on vocational training and investments that will bolster its position as a center of intellectual capital. Instead, the city has funneled its economic incentives to real-estate developers and manufacturers and to financial firms that are considering moving their back offices out of the city.
 
No Need for More Offices
 Yet the last thing the city needs now is more office space, the authors say. As for companies that mass-produce goods and services, the experts conclude that since they compete on the basis of cost, they are almost inevitably going to leave New York anyway. As Mr. Moss and Mr. O'Neill point out, "routine production," which generates just 20 percent of the city's jobs, has been declining in both good times and bad.
Mr. O'Neill and Mr. Moss argue that no matter how humane the city's economic development strategies may have been intended to be, they have not helped those at the bottom. From 1979 to 1989, their report states, average family income for the poorest fifth of New York City's families fell by 30 percent, adjusted for inflation, while the incomes in the poorest fifth within the larger region fell by 18 percent.
The authors say officials in the region should spend money on job training, should invest more in the region's airports, and should encourage foreign companies to establish research and development divisions.
The report also argues that the city needs to invest more in telecommunications, because its leadership is being eroded by investments elsewhere. And instead of cutting back its support for cultural institutions, New York should increase it, and acknowledge its role not as a frill for the rich but as a vital ingredient in economic development, the report says.
 
Dealing With the Short Term
 "Our assets are quite strong," said Mr. Moss, "but we don't invest in them." Mr. O'Neill added that in the last fiscal year the city provided economic development incentives to businesses valued at $700 million, more than $500 million of which was directed to the real-estate industry.
Although city officials call those numbers overstated, Mr. O'Neill argues that whatever the number, "If there's a single major change in emphasis, it should be away from subsidizing and providing tax abatements for the real-estate industry and towards investing in human resources and certain types of infrastructure."
Easy to say, says the city's deputy mayor for economic development, Sally Hernandez-Pinero. While she said she agreed with a number of the recommendations in the report, which she had not seen, she said that government does not have the luxury of thinking about just long-term strategy. Instead, she said, government has to deal with more immediate issues, like job preservation, when the private economy is so weak.
"I'm not foolish enough to think that we can keep those jobs here forever," she said. But she emphasized the social and political implications of just letting them go. "These are folks who, if they are not working, might be very expensive for the city to support," she said.

HEADLINE: Bumpy Ride for C.I.A. in Effort to Hire Minorities

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3

 BODY:
As the Central Intelligence Agency struggles to catch up to a changing world while simultaneously changing its image, one of its major tasks is attracting the right people to do the job.
But its first post-cold war recruiting campaign -- a full-page advertisement in Ebony magazine to lure black Americans into the traditionally white intelligence world -- has met with brickbats from lawmakers and prominent blacks. 
 "Wouldn't you want to know if U.S. territory was going to be invaded?" the headline reads in an ominous, decidedly pre-new-world-order tone.
A color photo shows a gray-haired black woman sitting on the stoop of a well-kept brownstone graced with windowboxes of flowers, a black boy maneuvering on a skateboard and three black girls jumping rope. "The thought of a gang wreaking havoc to your neighborhood is disturbing," reads the text. "Not to mention frightening. Of course you'd want to know if you could stop them way ahead of time. It's the same way for the President when it comes to America's security. And that's why he depends on the country's largest information network -- the Central Intelligence Agency."
 
Harsh Response
 For years, the C.I.A. has run recruiting advertisements, usually somber blocks of type in publications as varied as The Wall Street Journal and Air Force Times. But the agency's first foray into glossy full-color has evoked a response unprecedented in its harshness.
"African-Americans have fought long and hard for full participation in American society and in that sense the ad is a welcome reflection of that acceptance," said Wade Henderson, Washington director for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. "But its message is simplistic and ambiguous, particularly given the C.I.A.'s history in Africa and in Latin America, and the fact that the world is no longer dominated by Communism."
Senator David L. Boren, the usually cautious Oklahoma Democrat who heads the Senate Intelligence Committee, put it more bluntly: "Invaded? That's not something we think is about to happen. It's a scare tactic thing that I do not approve of. If they had some black people in decision-making roles out there, they would know better."
The C.I.A. asserts that the Ebony advertisement, developed by the black-owned Mingo Group in New York for $50,000 and published in the 1.8 million circulation magazine for an additional $34,000, illustrates its enlightened approach in trying to hire minorities. "Black agency employees were very much involved in developing the ad and in the decision to go with it," said Mark Mansfield, a C.I.A. spokesman. "The feedback we're getting is that it's an innovative ad, an ad that will enhance our recruiting efforts."
 
A New Breed of Employee
 Hiring blacks and other minorities is not the only recruiting problem the C.I.A. faces. Instead of armies of political analysts to analyze the Kremlin and Soviet weapon systems, the agency now needs engineers who can develop intelligence collection systems, bankers to carry out technical financial investigations, physicists to analyze nuclear, chemical and biological proliferation and linguists to understand better what people are saying, said Eugene J. Horan, the C.I.A.'s director for employment.
In his confirmation hearings before the Senate Intelligence Committee, Robert M. Gates, President Bush's nominee for Director of Central Intelligence, also said the agency must dramatically expand its "clandestine human intelligence effort" by installing more secret operatives around the world to run informants, penetrate societies and ferret out political intentions. Unfortunately, training such people in languages and steeping them in cultures takes years.
Adm. Bobby Ray Inman, the former Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, said at the hearings that the agency could not "go out and easily hire people who've got a language capacity in Uzbek."
Recruiting priorities are complicated by dramatic budgetary cutbacks that are forcing a 60 percent reduction in hiring and a 15 percent reduction in the work force over the next six years. Agency recruiters still visit college campuses, despite isolated campaigns to eject them, although budget cuts have meant that last year they visited only 250 campuses, as against 450 the year before.
"The agency is going to take massive cuts," Mr. Horan said, "and we are looking at major battles over priorities. On the one hand, you have to do 'precision hiring' of economists, for example. At the same time, you need to change the culture of the agency to reflect American society."
 
Low Turnover, Tough Tests
 In addition, the low rate of employee turnover at an agency where people tend to stay for life makes it harder to rid the C.I.A. of unproductive workers. During the Gates hearings, for example, Admiral Inman estimated that 5 percent to 10 percent of the agency's employees "don't measure up to the high standards we would all like to see."
Hiring is also made more difficult in the C.I.A. than in other governmental agencies because applicants must pass a polygraph test and survive rigorous security and medical screening. Drug use and theft are the top reasons for failing the lie test, although some applicants have failed because of violent crime, including rape and child abuse, Mr. Horan said.
For decades, the C.I.A. was a white, male preserve, where Ivy Leaguers, Jesuit-educated Irishmen and Italians and Midwestern Protestants seemed to thrive. Over the last several years, the agency has made some strides in recruiting and promoting women. Thirty-six percent of its "professional" positions are held by women, and the C.I.A. general counsel and comptroller are women, although only about 8 percent of the 60 senior "office director" posts are held by women.
The agency has done much worse in its hiring and promoting of minorities, many of whom have been skeptical of joining an organization with a history of conducting coups, assassination attempts and covert operations in the third world. Only 6.4 percent of the agency's "professionals" and only one of the office directors are black, while an additional 3.7 percent come from the other minority groups: Hispanic, Asian-American and Native American.
"Over the years, there's been a lot of reluctance in minority communities to look at the agency as a place to work," said Gary E. Foster, Deputy Director for Planning and Coordination, who added that 20 percent to 25 percent of employees hired last year -- professional, clerical and technical -- belong to minorities.
The agency is so pleased with its Ebony advertisement that it is working on a similar one in Spanish to attract Hispanic applicants. In that advertisement, the setting will be a kitchen, and the photo will probably feature a grandmother and a young child. A suggestion by the C.I.A. to put a crucifix on the wall was vetoed by the advertising agency. Like the Ebony advertisement, the Spanish one will include the C.I.A. seal and its new recruiting motto: "The C.I.A.: Our business is knowing the world's business."


GRAPHIC: Photo: The Central Intelligence Agency has come under fire from lawmakers and prominent blacks for an advertisement intended to lure black Americans into the intelligence world.

HEADLINE: Philadelphia's New Mayor to Face Tough Job

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3

 BODY:
The 127th Mayor of Philadelphia, to be elected Tuesday, faces one of the most challenging jobs in America.
The new Mayor, most likely the Democratic front-runner, Edward G. Rendell, will take over the helm of a city that has been stumbling out of control for many years, racking up chronic deficits, and losing population, respect and political clout in Harrisburg and Washington. 
 The new Mayor will almost certainly have to deal with an immediate cash crisis, negotiate a long-term fiscal strategy with a newly formed state oversight authority, pull in the reins of an City Council accustomed to running the city, negotiate new contracts with all 25,000 municipal workers and further reduce services for residents who have seen services steadily cut in recent years. At the same time, the Mayor will have difficulty fulfilling expensive campaign promises, like Mr. Rendell's pledge to hire 1,000 more police officers.
 
'Very Painful Process'
 If the Mayor succeeds in pulling the city back from the brink of insolvency, he would then be in a strong position to plead with the state Legislature to pick up most of the cost of state-mandated county courts, prisons and social services. Without state relief, the rising cost of these services will ultimately bankrupt the city, as just about everyone says.
State lawmakers say they have been reluctant to give the city assistance until they are confident that the money will be spent efficiently. Philadelphia spends more per capita on its courts than any other major city, and it ranks second in spending per capita for human services, health care and corrections, according to the Pennsylvania Economy League, a not-for-profit research organization that monitors the city.
"Philadelphia is in the final stages of never-never land, so it's going to be a very, very, very painful process to rescue it," said Frederick L. Voight, executive secretary of the Committee of Seventy, a not-for-profit public policy organization here.
Mayor W. Wilson Goode, the city's first black Mayor, completes his second four-year term this year and the City Charter forbids a third consecutive term. He has talked about teaching and advising other cities on how to become more efficient.
 
List of Candidates
 The city's black community, which represents 40 percent of the 1.5 million population, was unable to agree on a single black candidate this year. A black, the Rev. Dennis M. Wesley, a Baptist minister, is running as an independent, but he has trailed Mr. Rendell in the polls by up to 60 points. Most black leaders have endorsed Mr. Rendell, a 47-year-old former District Attorney.
The city's fiscal crisis and crime have been the only significant issues in the campaign. Mr. Rendell, who holds a 40-point lead over the Republican contender in most polls, has taken a tough stand on reining in city expenses. In particular, he has said he would seek concessions from municipal workers, whose total compensation exceeds that in the private sector by more than 20 percent, according to some estimates.
Mr. Rendell said he would face down the unions and let the workers strike before he would give in to high contract demands, if need be, and would consider contracting out some labor-intensive services like garbage collection if the unions would not budge. "We have to downsize expenditures and cut a quarter of a billion dollars out of the cost of government," he said, suggesting a 10 percent decrease in the city's $2.3 billion budget.
 
'A Results Guy'
 The Republican candidate, Joseph M. Egan Jr., is a 57-year-old real-estate developer and former head of a quasi-public industrial development commission in the city. He became the party's nominee after Frank L. Rizzo, the winner of the Republican primary this spring, died of a heart attack on July 16.
Mr. Egan has run a lackluster campaign. He has offered no substantive program for rescuing the city, but asserts he is qualified for the job because he is "a results guy, a coalition builder." He presented his first position paper on the city's fiscal condition just five days before the election.
A third candidate, Pamela Rainey Lawler, 41, is the founder of Philabundance, a not-for-profit organization that picks up surplus perishable food and distributes it to the hungry. Running on the Consumer Party ticket, she has advanced few ideas for fixing the city. One of her ideas is for the city to sell city-owned real estate and other assets to help balance the books.
Mr. Wesley, a 41-year-old Republican who is running as an independent, primarily talks about reducing city expenses, like consultants' fees.
"The money is there if you cut off the gravy train," he said. "Every year we give away over $500 million in consulting fees to people who are only interested in building pools and Jacuzzis for themselves in the suburbs."

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
After 50 Years, a New Powell On an Expanded City Council

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
FIFTY years ago today, a 33-year-old minister named Adam Clayton Powell Jr. melded protest and electoral politics to become the first black member of the New York City Council.
Tomorrow, his legacy will be rekindled when 29-year-old Adam Clayton Powell 4th is assured of election to the Council. The Puerto Rico-born Mr. Powell decisively won a special primary last week in a Harlem district where twice as many Hispanic people live as blacks. In January, he will join 20 other black and Hispanic members of an expanded Council. 
 What a difference five decades make! What difference?
In 1941, after a cumbersome proportional representation process, Mr. Powell's election was certified on the same day that he and hundreds of other Harlemites jammed an emergency meeting convened by the Social Service Bureau of the Magistrate's Courts. Fifty years later, sentiments expressed at that meeting reverberate in painfully familiar oratory, in part because some solutions proposed then were largely unheeded.
Magistrate Anna M. Kross insisted that the fundamental problem was a "social and economic one, created by lacks of many kinds." Vivan C. Mason, a Welfare Department official, complained that to pay for an apartment, relief recipients "must use not only the money that is budgeted for rent but also part of the food budget."
And Anna E. Lawson, principal of Junior High School 81 in Harlem, lamented: "I have in my school 1,600 girls, and 1,400 of them are as fine and decent and upstanding girls as any in the city. But 200 of them are pretty low, and I could pick out 30 of them who will be behind bars in a few years. If I had skilled help, I could save some of them, but I can't get it. When the board of superintendents asks for help to deal with these problems what do we get? We get a cut in the budget instead."
In his new book, "Adam Clayton Powell Jr. -- The Political Biography of an American Dilemma" (Atheneum), Prof. Charles V. Hamilton of Columbia University recalls Mr. Powell's own agenda that day.
"Right now," Mr. Powell said, "there are 1,400 persons on the city college faculties. There is a payroll of about $4 million. But there are no Negroes on these faculties. The day after I'm sworn in at the Council, there are going to be pickets outside the offices of the Board of Higher Education. I'll raise a ruckus in the Council, but I think it will look better with 2,000 or 3,000 people crowding around Park Avenue and 68th Street."
He also disclosed that blacks would be instructed to call operators for assistance instead of dialing telephone numbers directly and, as a result, the "telephone people will find they need maybe a thousand operators to carry on the business." He added: "I think they'll hire Negroes. The bus companies didn't like it at first either. But they came around."
Mr. Powell's institutional base at the Abyssinian Baptist Church enabled him to jump the ideological traps that ensnared some political successors. "Locally, Adam was the first to effectively combine protest action and electoral politics," Dr. Hamilton said. Only the Rev. Jesse Jackson has approached Mr. Powell's skill at finessing a fundamental conflict that dogs Mayor David N. Dinkins and other black politicians, Professor Hamilton said, as they win higher office and become accountable to broader constituencies.
"Does that mean David Dinkins should not lay off people?" Dr. Hamilton said. "No, it means that his task of explaining this to his base constituents is going to be so much greater. Adam Clayton Powell never had that problem. We never expected anything but the leadership of oratory, and he delivered."
Expectations for Mr. Powell's son are somewhat lower, although he has signaled his independence by bucking the Mayor in Mr. Dinkins's home base and by endorsing rule changes proposed last week by Council members Sal F. Albanese, Susan D. Alter, Alfred C. Cerullo 3d, Stephen DiBrienza, Ronnie M. Eldridge, C. Virginia Fields, Carol Greitzer, Carolyn B. Maloney and Stanley E. Michels. They constitute a potentially influential maverick minority that is likely to enlist some of the Council's new black and Hispanic members -- only one of whom, though, was elected from a predominantly white district, in a pointed reminder of how little is different after 50 years.
The elder Powell aspired to be an irritant and succeeded. Like him, his son harbors Congressional ambitions in a district now represented by Charles B. Rangel, who defeated Representative Powell in 1970 after the House voted to exclude him for, among other allegations, padding his payroll with his wife, who was actually raising Adam 4th at the time in Puerto Rico.
For all the shortcomings that made him vulnerable to a double standard, Mr. Powell could use power even more effectively than he abused it. "Nobody," his son says, "will ever be like him."

HEADLINE: Ernest Nathan Is Dead; Entrepreneur Was 86

 BODY:
Ernest Nathan, an entrepreneur and supporter of Jewish and Israeli causes, died on Saturday at Miriam Hospital in Providence, R.I. He was 86 years old and lived in Providence.
He died as a result of a stroke, his family said. 
 Mr. Nathan, a native of Augsburg, Germany, graduated from the Institute of Textile Technology in Reutlingen, Germany, and began working with Chemische Fabrik Pfersee, a chemical company that his family started in 1868. In 1929, he moved to West Warwick, R.I., for a joint venture with the Crompton Corporation to produce Impregnole, a water repellent that his company had developed.
He sold the Impregnole business to the Sun Chemical Corporation and was a company vice president from 1948 to 1952. After working on Israeli industrial development for two years, he returned to Crompton in 1954 to run its Chemo Products Teflon division in West Warwick.
In 1962 he bought Elmwood Sensors, a new company in Cranston, R.I., with four employees that was set up to make thermostats. He expanded the company to include more than a thousand workers and a second factory in England before selling it in 1980.
Mr. Nathan, a naturalized American citizen, helped dozens of other Jews escape from Europe to America in World War II. Later, as vice president of the Palestine Economic Corporation, he helped develop industry in Israel.
He is survived by his wife, the former Pearl Gluck; two sons, Alan, of Barrington, R.I., and Richard, of Italy; a daughter, Joan Gerson of Washington, and a sister, Alice Regensteiner of Warwick.

HEADLINE: Fear and Dependency Jostle in Shelters

BYLINE: By THOMAS MORGAN

 BODY:
Close to midnight, about the time that Nelson Echevarria wanders onto the armory drill floor in a Brooklyn men's shelter to find his assigned cot, fear and uneasiness settle in among the homeless there who struggle to sleep amid the cacophony of hacking coughs, blaring radios and moans from violent dreams.
This dimly lighted, unheated cavernous shelter at Atlantic and Bedford Avenues, with its sea of cots, is the kind of city shelter that has frightened many homeless people into staying on the streets. 
 But many of the 900 men who sleep there have grown increasingly comfortable with it, even calling it home and staying on for months or years.
 
Violence and Drugs
 Some advocates and city officials worry that the city's shelter system is breeding dependency: often the only decision required of residents -- who are served meals and given bed linens -- is not to cause trouble with the staff.
Mr. Echevarria, who has lived in the shelter for two months after exhausting other alternatives, understands why so many of the homeless living on the streets in paper boxes or rickety lean-tos say they are terrified of shelters and refuse to go to them despite recent efforts of the Dinkins administration to clear some streets and parks of the homeless.
"I have been threatened and I've seen people pull out razors," said Mr. Echevarria, 30 years old, a former building superintendent who lost his job and apartment and now seeks retraining as a boiler repairman. "You never know when a guy with a mental problem or someone smoking crack is going to go off. You have people in here who use drugs in the bathrooms, and the guards and institutional aides do nothing about it."
More than 7,000 men and 1,300 women live in the shelters and, though there is no precise figure, about 1,000 people are thought to have been there for more than a year.
Roger Barry, 39, has lived in the shelter for seven months now. Mr. Barry, who has a prison record and is trying to break a heroin addiction, found part-time work as a barber but said that he did not earn enough to afford an apartment on his own.
"It's not bad here," Mr. Barry said matter-of-factly. "It's what you make it. It's in my best interest to stay here until I can get myself together and afford to leave."
 
Bullies and Thefts
 At the Atlantic Avenue Armory, as in many other shelters, fights break out with little interference from security guards. The mentally ill sleep unsupervised side by side with men displaced from single-room-occupancy hotels, former prison inmates, crack addicts and alcoholics.
Sometimes in retribution for some perceived slight, bullies and their friends wait until a man is asleep and then toss a blanket or a sheet over him and beat him with pipes and sticks, shelter residents say. Theft and extortion are so common that everything from sneakers to underwear are taken. Men put the legs of their cots into their worn shoes or use their shoes as pillows to keep them safe.
 
Adopting Prison Ethic
 As he spoke, a roach crawled across the lips of a man who had passed out on the floor of the shelter's recreation room. It took 45 minutes for the security guards standing at the entryway to notice that the man was not moving and to attempt to rouse him. When the guards eventually woke the man, he grumbled obscenities, slumped in a metal chair and pointed to something in the air that only he could see. Many of the men who have lived in the shelters for years say they survive by adapting a prison ethic to shelter life, lessons that many of them actually learned in prison. No one is trusted.
Eric Watkins, 34, has lived in the Atlantic Avenue shelter for two years and still dreams of being a floor sander. He has refused to join self-help programs, saying he knows best how to help himself get back on his feet. His caseworkers think he is mistaken.
 
'We Have to Push'
 Rife with tuberculosis, bronchitis and other infections, congregate adult shelters like this one have become dumping grounds for men without homes who have been released from prisons, hospitals and other institutions, advocates and city officials say. The number of single men in city shelters changes with the weather, rising to 9,000 on very cold nights. On average the cost of basic shelter is $39 per person per day.
City officials are increasingly focusing on services that will help the homeless get back on their feet.
"Sometimes we have to push. Sometimes we have to say, 'Why don't you call about a job? Why don't you see your family?" ' said Tony Branch, 28, the director of the Atlantic Avenue shelter, who has started a number of innovative self-help programs there.
"When they start calling a shelter home, it makes you think," he said. "Some people say it's cleaner than the environment they grew up in. They have guaranteed breakfast, lunch and dinner. They get clothing and a place to sleep. By court decision we have to offer shelter to anyone who asks for it. To be honest with you, a lot of guys come in here who need mental repair. They lose faith in themselves. They've been put down by a lot of people.
"We try to encourage them to take advantage of the self-help programs, the Narcotics Anonymous and Alcoholics Anonymous," said Mr. Branch, who is alternately dismissively gruff and sympathetic to men twice his age who stop him to plead for favors like children ask for candy. "But we can't make them."
 
'Place to Throw Away'
 Psychologists and social scientists call the adaptation to life in homeless centers "shelterization."
Dr. Kim Hopper, an anthropologist who studies homelessness among single men at the Nathan Kline Institute for Psychiatric Research in Orangeburg, N.Y., said that skid row in the 1950's was similar in many ways, "a place to throw away" mostly old white male alcoholics who were demoralized and deemed unproductive.
Today, he said, the shelters are the new "zones of discard" and the homeless men are primarily black or Hispanic of all ages and with a range of disabilities.
"It doesn't take much of a social historian to track the changes that account for that very different configuration of discarded men," Dr. Hopper said. "There are fewer jobs, hospitals that took care of the mentally ill are closed and families that used to be able to put up a dependent member, temporarily out of work, are much more sorely strapped today."
Statistics for New York City are unavailable, but about 30 percent of the homeless adults in shelters are thought to be mentally ill and another 30 percent are former prison inmates, according to Jeffrey Carples, executive deputy commissioner of the city's Human Resources Administration who is in charge of the adult shelter system.
 
5-Year Plan
 Mr. Carples said the shelters are ill-equipped to handle the range of clients and problems they receive despite their best efforts to provide services to all who need them.
But a five-year shelter development plan that Mayor David N. Dinkins proposed last month calls for smaller city homeless shelters with more special services geared to the problems of homeless men and women, would increase the range of services that the agency would offer, like job training and counseling, psychiatric therapy and substance abuse counseling. But the five-year plan is under considerable attack by elected officials and community residents who do not want such shelters in residential communities.
What Mr. Carples envisions is a shelter system that is really temporary and offers the homeless whatever skills and services they need to move toward independent living.
"A lot of these guys have never lived on their own," he said. "Beyond dealing with the substance abuse problems for example, you have to teach somebody not only a work skill but how to groom themselves a certain way, to dress a certain way. It's basic things about how to live in a society, but these clients have not been socialized to this extent."
The Atlantic Avenue Armory shelter has the kind of programs that city officials would expand on in smaller, future shelters, city officials said. For instance, there is an assessment unit there that attempts to place men in other shelters that provide counseling for specific problems like unemployment. There are what officials call clean and sober dorms inside the Atlantic Avenue shelter where homeless men who are attempting to stay sober sleep in a room segregated from others who are still using drugs. Advocates for the homeless say that despite the programs offered in the shelters, the men become despondent because there are few permanent apartments available.
"Unlike the family shelter system, these men are not transitioned into permanent facilities," said Mary Brosnahan, executive director of the Coalition for the Homeless. "For those who work and have to go back to a shelter bed, there is not much incentive to continue to work."

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

HEADLINE: Review/Theater;
'A Piece of My Heart,' Women In Vietnam

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH

 BODY:
At the end of "A Piece of My Heart," Shirley Lauro's new play about the unsung American women who served in Vietnam, the characters appear before a replica of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington and place homely mementos of the war at its base. It is a powerful tableau -- like every other glimpse of that long, dark wall -- and it allows Ms. Lauro at last to stir up the feelings of grief and anger that she has been chasing all night.
Yet, for me at least, the feelings evaporated the moment I was back on the street, at which point I resented having my buttons pushed so cheaply. Right until its coda, "A Piece of My Heart," a Manhattan Theater Club presentation by way of the Actors Theater of Louisville, is embarrassingly cliched in its efforts to bring home the stories of forgotten survivors of the Vietnam nightmare. Are we to applaud a playwright who uses the wall to prop up what is otherwise an incompetent piece of work? 
 "A Piece of My Heart" can be called incompetent because it coarsens and wastes valuable documentary material. Ms. Lauro's source is a 1986 oral history by Keith Walker in which 26 of the estimated 1,500 American women who went to Southeast Asia recounted their experiences, whether as nurses, civilian do-gooders or entertainers. These women had their own distinctive and courageous war to fight: with their consciences, with the Vietnamese, with the American military command, with primitive medical facilities and, most pointedly, with men.
Though the playwright draws on the words of her actual subjects, her play seems synthetic, like an old-fashioned news-magazine round-up story with archetypal, if not composite, characters speaking in souped-up quotes. Bizarrely enough, most of Ms. Lauro's major characters are so generic that they could have stepped out of the stereotyped male ranks of bygone service comedies like "Mister Roberts" or "No Time for Sergeants": the tough-talking but big-hearted military lifer (Novella Nelson), the rich college kid (Sharon Schlarth), the religious small-town naif (Corliss Preston) and even the immortal Andy Griffith role, that of the thick-accented yet shrewd country bumpkin (Cynthia Carle) who strums a mean guitar.
"A Piece of My Heart" never makes the audience feel close to these or its other characters because Ms. Lauro manipulates them from without rather than observing them from within. Once the women have shipped off to Vietnam, the action of the play is not driven by their specific narratives, intimate thoughts or feelings; instead the players become faceless, symbolic figures in a mural.
Whether appearing individually in didactic vignettes or banding together for lengthy rounds of group recitation, the women react mechanically to the expected checklist of red-letter experiences, from their first encounter with the brutality of combat through their initiations into drugs and booze, sexual harassment and official duplicity (during the Tet Offensive). When the women return home to face a series of new indignities in Act II (unemployment, discrimination, Agent Orange mutations), they go their separate ways but just as predictably. The alcoholic finds salvation in Alcoholics Anonymous; the idealist joins Vietnam Veterans Against the War; the true believer becomes a born-again Christian.
Everything in this play is over-generalized to the point of blandness. Even the potentially theatrical idea of assigning all the male roles to a single actor (Tom Stechschulte) -- a conceit reminiscent of Amlin Gray's harrowing Vietnam play, "How I Got That Story" -- comes to nothing because virtually all the male roles turn out to be variations on the same blue-collar white Everyman. The ideological point of this all-purpose man is clear and unexceptional enough -- "Men wanted that war, men made that war," says one of the women in Act II -- but the device has the odd and falsifying side effect of completely eliminating black men from the Vietnam story.
Such lapses are surprising coming from Ms. Lauro. In "Open Admissions," her searing play about a confrontation between a black male student and a white female teacher in an urban university, she met head-on the sorts of complex ideological and racial conflicts that are either oversimplified or sidestepped here. "A Piece of My Heart" has far more in common with another Manhattan Theater Club production this year about a neglected patch of American military history, "Black Eagles," in which the tale of black World War II fighter pilots was reduced to a lulling pageant of unassailable worthiness and infinitesimal drama.
Ms. Lauro's play must struggle under the additional handicap of being presented at the expansive Union Square Theater (until recently the home of the Roundabout Theater Company) while "Lips Together, Teeth Apart" continues its extended run at the Manhattan Theater Club's snugger auditorium at City Center. Under the direction of Allen R. Belknap, the performers often seem to be inflating their soliloquies, whether perky or sorrowful, to fill the big house, with the consequence that both their wartime experiences and sobbing postwar nervous breakdowns sometimes come across like audition monologues from "A Chorus Line." Mr. Belknap's staging also boasts an arsenal of cheesy sound-and-light effects that, like the rest of the evening's sloppy histrionics, say nothing about the tragedy of Vietnam that can remotely match the eloquence of the wall's mute, unadorned listing of the names of the dead.
 
A Piece of My Heart
 
By Shirley Lauro, suggested by the book by Keith Walker; directed by Allen R. Belknap; sets by James Fenhagen; costumes by Mimi Maxmen; lighting by Richard Winkler; sound by John Kilgore; production stage manager, Richard Hester; guitar and vocal arrangements, Cynthia Carle. Presented by the Manhattan Theater Club, Lynne Meadow, artistic director; Barry Grove, managing director; by special arrangement with Roger L. Stevens. Michael Bush, associate artistic director; Victoria Bailey, general manager. At Union Square Theater, 100 East 17th Street, Manhattan.

HEADLINE: Vote 'Yes,' Three Times

 BODY:
New York voters will find three proposals on their ballots tomorrow, one big and two little; all three make sense and deserve approval.
The truly important ballot measure is Proposal One, which would expand the borrowing power of the Job Development Authority. This is a state agency that makes low-interest loans to businesses trying to expand. Its record of loan repayment is impeccable.
Though opponents fear further indebtedness by state authorities, the authority is one of the state's most effective levers for economic growth. A "yes" vote is all the more important in light of the current economic slump.
Proposal Two would authorize a 50-acre land swap. Piseco Airport, a one-runway haven for small planes in Hamilton County, and the only airport in the southern Adirondacks, is threatened by the growth of trees. A constitutional amendment is required to authorize a swap of locally owned land for 50 acres of forest preserve that will enable local authorities to clear land around the runway. The impact on the forest would be negligible; the additional safety factor is extremely significant. Vote "yes."
Proposal Three would authorize new development along the Erie Canal, which crosses the state, connecting the Hudson River with the Great Lakes. This early 19th-century development was instrumental in opening the Midwest to settlement. It has become a lively tourist attraction; to expand that role, a constitutional change is required to permit leasing and development of adjacent areas. Tolls would also be authorized.
Objectors are right to insist that a comprehensive plan should be developed, but the time to develop it is after the voters have indicated their support. Again, vote "yes."

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
The Last Vestiges Of the 80's Boom

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill.

 BODY:
THE United States is glutted with newly built, unoccupied office space, and that makes the once-common sight of a skyscraper under construction a rare one today. So it is a pleasant surprise to drive into downtown Peoria and come upon just such a scene: three luxury office buildings in various stages of completion, with sidewalks blocked off to make room for steel beams and slabs of marble facing.
Peoria is not an anomaly. Office towers are also going up along the downtown streets of Cleveland, Columbus and Milwaukee, among other Midwestern cities. But if Peoria's builders are any guide, then the construction so visible in these heartland cities is hardly a leading indicator of a construction revival elsewhere in the land. Rather it signals that the nation's free-wheeling office-building of the 1980's is in its last throes. 
 Certainly G. Raymond Becker, Peoria's leading builder, thinks so. "I don't believe anyone will get stuck with the three buildings now going up, but in Peoria there won't be any more need for office space for the next 10 years," said Mr. Becker, who is building the tallest of the three, a 20-story tower with its steel frame not yet enclosed.
That is a gloomy assessment. But George A. Christie, chief economist at the F. W. Dodge division of McGraw-Hill, which tracks construction data, considers it an accurate one for cities in the former Rust Belt states -- particularly those in the Great Lakes region -- where manufacturing, after a disastrous period in the early and mid-1980's, made a comeback.
That comeback explains why office towers are still rising in the Midwest. While much of the country was putting up office buildings and shopping malls in the mid-1980's, Mr. Becker and other Midwestern builders stood by, as local manufacturers shed thousands of workers, closed factories and struggled to become efficient and profitable. In 1988, when Caterpillar Inc., this city's major employer, had finally recovered and was once again breathing extra money into the local economy, Peoria's office vacancy rate stood at 5 percent -- far below the national level of 19.8 percent.
The revival began modestly. Mr. Becker bought and renovated a dilapidated office building. Caterpillar, briskly selling tractors and heavy construction equipment again, also bought existing office space for its headquarters operation. With space disappearing, new construction began, and ground was broken last year for the three buildings that are now more than half-finished. The problem is that tenants are lately hard to find.
That's the case for a six-story structure with pink marble facing that Jay Jansen, head of a Peoria law firm, is building. Mr. Jansen's lawyers will occupy three floors; the rest are still unleased, although a restaurant has rented basement space. Nearby, Diane Cullinan, a developer, is raising an eight-story brick structure, and so far only 40 percent of the space is leased, to Cilcorp, the holding company for the region's electric utility.
Finally, there is Mr. Becker's skyscraper, with 65 percent of its space to be occupied by an accounting firm, a law firm, Mr. Becker's own real estate operations and the Illinois Transportation Department, which is taking 4 of the 20 floors and paying nearly enough rent to cover the mortgage.
Mr. Becker, who has been putting up an assortment of buildings for 40 years without a major reversal, says that unlike much of the nation, Peoria has not fallen into the trap of speculative over-construction. "I think we will rent all the space," he said. "The Federal Government is looking for space, and state agencies are also a possibility."
But then what? Most economists count on a revival in construction to sustain a recovery from the national recession, but as Peoria's experience indicates, commercial construction is not likely to make this possible. Nationwide, the value of newly started commercial buildings -- mostly offices, but also shopping malls, warehouses and the like -- has fallen to an annual rate of $40 billion, from $60 billion in boom years, F. W. Dodge reports.
The much larger housing sector has taken up some of the slack, having risen to an annual rate of $100 billion in new starts from $75 billion in January. But this is treading water. With family incomes barely rising and the population growing more slowly than in the 1980's, home construction in the early 1990's probably won't reach the boom levels of previous post-recession periods.
That leaves public works, an area restrained by government budget cutbacks, and commercial construction. "Normally, commercial construction kicks in about a year after a recovery is under way," Mr. Christie said. "But this time you probably won't get that secondary kick until much later in the decade."

HEADLINE: Economic Memo;
Wall St. Finds Silver Lining In Cloudy Economic Reports

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
Some curious things, it seems, are happening this fall to the Washington-Wall Street axis. With few exceptions, each time one of the Government statistics mills issues a discouraging report on the economy, the stock market takes off toward a new high. And when politicians talk about tax cuts -- which would reduce burdens on producers of wealth -- the market takes a dive.
Confusing? Sure. Illogical? Not necessarily. 
 In Wall Street's orthodox view, the stock market, reflecting collective investor opinion about the prospects for corporate profits, looks to the future, not to the past or present. And what it sees, with inflation modest and some interest rates at the lowest levels in 14 years, is an economic recovery ahead that will lift profits and thereby support today's valuations.
"I think it's an unmistakable recovery sign," said Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Company, referring to the stock market's ebullience. "There's no doubt in my mind the recession's over."
History tends to support this conclusion, with the stock market enjoying a reputation as one of the better predictors of the economy. In fact, the Commerce Department includes the Standard & Poor's 500 in its index of leading indicators, the Government's principal business forecasting gauge.
But there is at least one other possible explanation for the elevated stock market. This is that the market is artificially high, benefiting in part from over-optimism about a recovery that struggles ahead, "but in the face of a 50-mile-an-hour headwind," as Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said last week, referring to the reluctance of some banks to lend.
The Dow Jones industrials are selling at 30 times the earnings of their latest 12 months -- more than twice the ratio of a year ago -- though the market has declined modestly in the last three sessions. In addition, the trading volume in over-the-counter stocks has surpassed that on the New York Stock Exchange for two straight weeks.
 
Savers Flock to Stocks
 Also contributing to the notion that stock prices are too high is evidence that savers, confronting drastically reduced returns on certificates of deposit and Treasury bills, are pouring money into equities. Some of this is moving directly into stocks and some is channeled through mutual funds.
Charles I. Clough, chief investment strategist for Merrill Lynch & Company, is one person on Wall Street who has turned cautious about the stock market rally, which he says may have gotten ahead of itself based on economic fundamentals.
"There is some speculation going on, and that's bothersome," Mr. Clough said. He added that while much of the hyperactivity was in one industry, biotechnology, he was concerned that the market might be overly optimistic about the pace of economic recovery. He noted that the Fed has been easing monetary policy, pushing interest rates down, for a year, but still has a negligible rebound to show for it.
In the view of James Grant's Interest Rate Observer, one of Wall Street's most insightful publications, Mr. Greenspan has "driven income-seeking people" into growth stocks and bond funds, thereby increasing the amount of speculative money outside the banking system. This made Mr. Greenspan's relationship to Wall Street comparable to that of "a bush beater to a party of quail hunters."
But even if the stock market is more vulnerable than is generally recognized, a drop would not necessarily imply that the economy will tumble back into recession. This is because stocks seem to have been overrated as a predictor of business activity, and the linkage has recently gotten weaker.
A study by Michael P. Niemira of the New York office of Mitsubishi Bank found stock prices to be "a prime candidate for replacement" in the Commerce Department's economic-forecasting index, because they have emitted a high rate of false signals, particularly since 1980. He would favor using instead a gauge of interest rates like the yield curve -- the difference between rates for three months and those for 30 years.
These days, reports of a weak recovery tend to raise stock prices, since it is assumed that the news increases the likelihood of further easing by the Federal Reserve, which will meet on Tuesday for one of its every-other-month strategy sessions.
Yet there must be a limit, analysts say, to how long bad news for the economy can be good for stocks. Ultimately, of course, it means a dearth of profits.
