HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Continues to Decline On Outlook for Lower Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday amid pessimism about the United States economy and the expectation of lower interest rates. Gold prices were mixed, rising in New York after falling overseas.
Analysts said the dollar continued where it left off last week -- declining as traders anticipated the Federal Reserve would have to lower interest rates after several negative economic reports, including an increase in the unemployment rate. Lower interest rates are generally bearish for the dollar because they lessen the value of dollar-denominated securities.
 
Brief Rise Possible
 Richard Levine, a foreign exchange broker with Merrill Lynch & Company, said the dollar could briefly move higher because it had been heavily oversold. 
 It would be difficult, however, for the dollar to sustain a long-term advance because of the continuing weakness in the economy.
Some overseas brokers said the dollar could fall as low as 1.5850 German marks in the coming weeks. The dollar fell to 1.6385 marks yesterday, down from 1.6445 late on Friday.
In earlier European trading, the dollar slipped to 1.6316 marks from 1.6605.
The dollar fell to 129.185 Japanese yen in New York, from 129.73 late on Friday. Markets were closed in Tokyo yesterday for Culture Day -- a national holiday -- but in London, the dollar fell to 128.95 yen, compared with Tokyo's Friday close of 130.74.
The British pound gained against the dollar, rising to $1.7740, from $1.7675 late on Friday. In London, sterling rose to $1.7810 from late Friday's $1.7680.
Other late rates for the dollar in New York, compared with late Friday's prices, included: 1.4425 Swiss francs, down from 1.4435; 5.6000 French francs, down from 5.6215; 1,227.00 Italian lire, down from 1,233.65, and 1.12125 Canadian dollars, up from 1.12005.
Gold for current delivery rose $1.20 on the Commodity Exchange in New York, closing at $356.80 an ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $356.40, up $1.40.
But gold fell in London to a late bid price of $356.60 from $357.85 late on Friday. In Zurich, gold fell to $356.30 from $357.50. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.29 to close at $356.85.
Silver for current delivery gained 2.1 cents on the Commodity Exchange, ending at $4.067 an ounce. Silver fell in London to $4.08, from $4.11 late on Friday.

HEADLINE: Dow Off 10.73, to 3,045.62, in Light Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks closed lower yesterday in light trading as investors worried that the Fed would not cut its discount rate soon with the Government's quarterly refunding beginning today. Easier credit would buoy economic and corporate growth, many traders believe.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell by 10.73 points to finish at 3,045.62. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 155.7 million, down from 206.5 million shares traded on Friday, as declining issues outpaced gainers by 974 to 658. 
 Robert H. Stovall, president of Stovall/21st Advisers, described yesterday's market performance as not the most sterling. "There will not be much coming data from Washington this week, he said. The focus will now turn to the refunding by the Treasury and possible Fed action because of the absence of economic news and because third-quarter corporate earnings results are largely over."
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks was down 1.04, to 390.28, with the Big Board composite off 0.58, to 215.43. Trading on the American Stock Exchange lowered that composite by 2.75 points, to 384.10.
The Nasdaq composite index was down 3.43, to 537.50, while the Russell 2000, a narrow measure of small stocks, was down 0.76, to 183.86.
Initially, stocks opened lower, and losses widened as bonds slipped in a moderate selloff ahead of the Treasury's refunding. Analysts said some investors were cashing in after last Friday's sluggish report on jobs and a decline in the index of leading economic indicators showed a stumbling recovery.
Investors are expected to remain mainly on the sidelines during most of the week, because they are uncertain whether the Fed is going to act and therefore are not sure what tack to take.
In market activity, Compaq Computer, hurt by the recession and increased competition, fell 1 1/8, to 26 3/4, after The Houston Chronicle reported over the weekend that James M. Harris, a co-founder, and two other senior executives had left the company. On Friday the company sent out the first layoff notices that are going to 1,400 employees.
Shares of Agouron Pharmecuticals closed unchanged at 18, after the company said it had received approval from the United States Food and Drug Administration to begin tests on human beings of a psoriasis treatment. The stock was as high as 18 1/2 yesterday.

HEADLINE: A.T.& T. Plan To Expand Europe Cable

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
Anticipating a huge rise in business telephone traffic between the United States and Europe, A.T.& T. said yesterday that it planned to lay two 4,500-mile undersea cables in the Atlantic Ocean that will more than double the number of possible trans-Atlantic conversations.
A.T.& T. said the sharp expansion of telephone capacity was necessary because of the coming unification of Western European markets at the end of 1992 and the emerging market economies of Eastern Europe. 
 Yesterday's announcement means that 80 percent of A.T.& T.'s total trans-Atlantic capacity will have been added between now and August 1993, all of it with the latest in high-capacity fiber-optic technology.
 
Capacity for 300,000 Calls
 About 57,750 simultaneous conversations are possible today, and a further 80,000 calls will be possible with capacity due to be added in February 1992. But the planned undersea cables announced yesterday would add capacity for 160,000 more calls, as well as data and video, resulting in a total capacity of nearly 300,000 calls.
"Every time we've had to do these things, we've had to rush" to add capacity, said Charles G. Schmitz, A.T.& T.'s district manager for facility planning and agreements. "Now, we wanted to make sure we had enough capacity to serve customer needs."
Mr. Schmitz said the new capacity was not intended to cure any current problems, such as too many calls flooding over too little capacity into Europe, but rather to handle complex blocks of data, like Wall Street trading data and airline reservations.
The new capacity is intended to expand service from the United States to Germany, France and Britain.
The cables, which carry fiber-optic filaments the size of human hairs, vary in size over the varying terrains of the Atlantic Ocean. Dropped by special cable ships, the lines range from the thickness of a human thumb in the least vulnerable areas, like the deepest parts of the ocean, to the thickness of three fingers for reinforced cable near shore, where fishing boats and other boat traffic could ensnare and cut a cable.
A 4,400-mile cable will stretch from Greenhill, R.I., through the North Sea oilfields of Scotland to the coastal towns of Norden, Germany, and Alkmaar, the Netherlands. Another 4,470-mile cable will stretch from Manahawkin, N.J. to Swansea, England, and St. Hillaire, France.
 
Lower Fiber-Optics Costs
 The new cables, known as Trans-Atlantic-Telephone 10 and Trans-Atlantic-Telephone 11, or TAT-10 and TAT-11, must still be cleared by the Federal Communications Commission. Mr. Schmitz said he expected F.C.C. clearance as early as this month, but noted that another telecommunications company, Submarine Lightguide Cable, wanted to lay its own cable and had filed an objection to A.T.& T.'s plan.
TAT-10 is set to be completed in August 1992 and TAT-11 in August 1993.
Installation of the new A.T.& T. cables will cost $300 million for TAT-10 around the North Sea oilfields and $280 million for TAT-11, which crosses a somewhat shorter and less hazardous path.
Mr. Schmitz said the huge addition of capacity had been made possible by advances in fiber-optic technology, which makes undersea cable far less costly than in the past, especially compared with satellite transmission, once thought to be the best and cheapest means of international long-distance calling. A large telecommunications satellite can carry 135,000 calls or more.

HEADLINE: 2 Democrats Seek Tough Trade Policy

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
Reviving a fiercely debated issue from the 1988 Presidential campaign, two Democratic members of the House introduced legislation this afternoon that calls for trade sanctions against countries that unfairly exclude American exports and run trade surpluses with the United States.
Democrats and Republicans agree that whether trade becomes a leading issue in next year's Presidential campaign will depend on whether the recession ends, whether the nation's trade deficit continues to narrow and whether negotiations for an international round of reductions in trade barriers prove successful. 
 Representatives Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, and Sander M. Levin of Michigan introduced the bill, which broadly resembles the legislation that Mr. Gephardt advocated during his unsuccessful Presidential campaign in 1987 and 1988. That bill was widely criticized as protectionist by Republicans and some Democrats.
 
3 Democratic Proposals
 Today's bill was the latest of three Democratic bills attempting to limit the Administration's time to seek negotiated reductions in barriers before imposing sanctions. Consideration of the bills coincides with Democrats' efforts to blame President Bush for continued economic weakness.
"Trade by itself isn't the critical issue -- it's the economy," Mr. Levin said at a news conference today.
"But trade is a metaphor," he added, for the nation's economic problems.
The Administration and most Republican members of Congress oppose all three bills. "It would seem to me harder to get this out of the Ways and Means Committee than 6 or 12 months ago," said Representative Willis D. Gradison Jr., an Ohio Republican who is a leading opponent on the Ways and Means Committee of protectionist legislation. He said the bill's prospects would be dimmed by recent indications of a possible breakthrough in the Uruguay Round of trade negotiations. Those talks, which began in Uruguay in 1986, are the latest in a postwar series of negotiations to reduce tariffs.
"The weak economy makes it more attractive, but the signs of progress on the Uruguay Round make it less attractive," Mr. Gradison added in a telephone interview.
But Representative Robert T. Matsui, a California Democrat who is also a member of the Ways and Means Committee and who also opposes Mr. Gephardt's initiative, said the current economic climate and public anxiety could mean that this year's initiative has a better chance of becoming law than the majority leader's last attempt.
Mr. Matsui said he opposed Mr. Gephardt because "I don't think you can legislate toughness," and because he thought structural issues like a weak educational system and fractious labor relations lay at the base of the nation's competitiveness problems.
 
Trade Deficit Has Fallen
 The nation's economy grew 4.5 percent in 1988, so the job losses caused by imports were less a concern than now, when the economy is struggling to emerge from a recession. But the trade deficit has narrowed from $152.1 billion in 1987 and $118.5 billion in 1988 to an estimated $70 billion to $80 billion this year, prompting some Administration officials to predict privately that trade will be less of an issue in next year's Presidential campaign than it was in 1988.
Mr. Gephardt said recent shrinkage of the deficit was inadequate. "It is still way too high, way too high, and still presents a real danger to the American economy and the American citizen," he said.
Mr. Gephardt's bill would revive and extensively modify the so-called Super 301 legislation, a watered-down version of Mr. Gephardt's proposals in the mid-1980's that was passed in 1988 and expired last year.
 
Attempt to Require Sanctions
 Super 301 was a series of amendments to Section 301 and other sections of the 1974 Trade Act, and was intended to obligate the Administration to impose sanctions on countries that did not quickly lower barriers toAmerican exports.
Mr. Gephardt's proposals, both now and during his Presidential campaign, have linked the size of a country's trade surplus with the United States to whether it would be cited for unfair trade practices.
Senators Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, and John Danforth, Republican of Missouri, introduced legislation two weeks ago that would revive Super 301 but give the Administration more time to negotiate before beginning formal proceedings against another country. No hearings have been held on the bill.
Mr. Matsui and Mr. Baucus sponsored legislation early this year that would require the United States trade representative's office to review each American trade agreement annually and three months before it expired, and to take action if necessary.

HEADLINE: American Express's Rating Cut

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
The financial troubles at American Express widened yesterday, as Moody's downgraded the rating on about $7 billion in the company's long-term debt. It was the first time in the American Express Company's history that any of its debt was downgraded by Moody's.
The rating service took the action because of problems in American Express's credit business and because the company faces growing competition. 
 In the summer, the Standard & Poor's Corporation lowered its rating on the company's long-term debt because of turmoil at American Express's securities subsidiary, Shearson Lehman Brothers.
Although the downgrading will raise some financing costs, the action did not affect the company's short-term debt -- an effect that could have hurt American Express's ability to raise money to finance daily operations. But the move will have a much greater impact on confidence in American Express, analysts said, which in many ways depends on its image as a skillfully run company providing financial services for affluent customers.
 
Lack of Improvement
 The action by Moody's Investors Service Inc. is the first indication that recently disclosed problems at American Express may not be improving. Last month, American Express took a $265 million charge against third-quarter earnings, including $155 million in new reserves to pay for losses that resulted from defaults on credit.
In a statement, Moody's said it had downgraded the debt because of the continued deterioration in the quality of the company's assets and because of "competitive challenges in American Express's core Travel Related Services segment." Moody's added that the asset quality pressures could continue for some time.
American Express stock closed yesterday at $18.625, down 50 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. The loss dropped the share price to just $1 above its 52-week low of $17.625 and nearly 39 percent below its high for the period of $30.375.
Moody's still rates the debt at investment-grade. American Express's domestic debt and Eurodebt was lowered to A-1 from Aa-2, and the preferred stock was lowered to A-2 from Aa-3. Some debt for a number of other divisions, including the American Express Credit Corporation, the American Express Bank and the IDS Life Insurance Company were also reduced.
 
Aware of Concerns
 In a statement, American Express said, "While we're disappointed with the Moody's decision, we were aware of their concerns in view of the economy, the additions to our credit reserves and our recent quarterly results."
The company added that it would continue in its plans to issue new stock, and it said the downgrading should not increase the potential costs of borrowing.
Such a downgrading had long been feared. That concern was a driving factor behind a number of the company's most significant actions in the last two years, including the decision to recapitalize and then purchase all of the public shares it did not already own in the predecessor to Shearson Lehman Brothers.
The fear of a downgrading has been strong because of the dependence of the financial services company on its rating to keep finance costs low. The move will increase those costs slightly for long-term financing.
The troubles at American Express, which began in 1989 when Shearson's debt was put under review by Moody's, grew worse this year as the core business lines began to deteriorate. While the troubles at Shearson came under better control, the company's Travel Related Services division, which oversees the well-known green, gold and platinum charge cards as well as the Optima credit card, turned in its first losses in decades.

HEADLINE: Tour Industry's Busloads of Gold

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CLEVELAND

 BODY:
Every year, thousands of tour buses crisscross North America. With each busload of people spending about $4,300 a day on food, lodging and admissions, it is little wonder that thousands of tourist attractions, restaurants and hotels eagerly roll out the welcome mat.
Hoping to cash in on this rare bright spot in their industry, about 2,500 representatives of everything from the Civil War battlefield of Vicksburg, Miss., to the World's Only Corn Palace gathered in the Cleveland Convention Center recently to woo 575 operators of escorted bus tours. 
 The tour-bus business is big and getting bigger, especially in the decade since the deregulation of the bus industry. Enthusiasts say it provides safety in numbers, companionship and a relatively problem-free vacation. Like airline and travel agency packaged tours, which they often supplement, most bus tours are less expensive than the sum of their individual parts.
One suitor in Cleveland was Rozella Hahn, executive director of the convention and visitors bureau of Iowa's seven Amana Colonies. Amana's religious and communal tradition attracts more than 1.5 million visitors a year, including many tour groups. Ms. Hahn came here to reacquaint herself with existing customers and to drum up new ones.
Altogether, some 3,100 people attended the convention of the National Tour Association, whose membership includes most of the nation's escorted tour-bus operators. The members spent much of their time either making or listening to quick pitches for hundreds of the nation's "must see" tour stops.
During the convention, Ms. Hahn and her fellow tourism officials conducted some 70,000 seven-minute meetings between the companies that package, market and operate escorted bus tours and those that own the attractions, hotels and restaurants vying for their business.
 
No Rest This Year
 With 58 appointments crammed into less than seven hours over two days, Ms. Hahn, her turtleneck sweater and jacket set off by a strand of black glass beads, had little time to sing Amana's praises to prospective visitors before she had to dash down the aisle to her next meeting.
"Usually I have a break or two between appointments," Ms. Hahn said, "but this year I'm so busy I even have appointments during my breaks."
In 1986, 44.7 million escorted passengers spent $10.7 billion for transportation, food, lodging and admissions, according to S.E.A./Tourism-Travel Research in New Bedford, Mass. Last year, ridership increased to 60.7 million, and passengers spent $13.8 billion. This year's totals are expected to be even higher, despite the recession and the Persian Gulf war's dampening effect on much of 1991's travel plans.
The typical traveler on an escorted tour is more than 55 years old, the tour association estimates, but the average age is falling steadily -- just as it has fallen among those who take sea cruises.
 
After Tuitions Are Paid
 "What we often see now," said John P. Stachnik, a veteran tour operator and the new president of the association, "is that adults take their first escorted tour in their late 40's or early 50's, about one year after they have paid off their children's tuition and have become empty nesters." About 75 percent of escorted tourists are repeat customers.
It helps that today's buses, unlike the Spartan vehicles of the past, actually give some validity to the industry designation motor coach. They have plush reclining seats, large tinted windows, sun shields and larger bathrooms. Many have television monitors with individual headsets and controls. Just days ago the National Motorcoach Network, a consortium with headquarters in Fairfax, Va., announced plans for a motor coach television network that will distribute videos to coach operators beginning next year.
"Some new buses even have card tables," said Don Dunham of Yankee Line Inc. of Boston, as he showed a visitor through one of Yankee's newest models, parked on the convention floor. Other buses have microwaves, coffee makers and refrigerators.
While group bus tours have been around at least since the 1920's -- Tauck Tours Inc. of Westport, Conn., started in 1925 -- the Bus Regulatory Reform Act of 1982 helped to break up what Mr. Stachnik described as "protected fiefdoms" and helped encourage innovation and competition.
The most popular tours are still those to national parks and natural wonders, and to old standbys like Mackinac Island, Mich., and Colonial Williamsburg. But the younger people taking the tours, and the relative fitness of even the older travelers, have prompted tour companies in recent years to add an array of what Mr. Stachnik, the president of Mayflower Tours of Downers Grove, Ill., terms "soft adventure" tours -- everything from ski trips to rafting to mule trips in the Grand Canyon.
And the industry is growing so fast that it offers thousands of tours for specialized events like Mardi Gras, Kentucky Derby Week, athletic events and class reunions.
 
Returning to China
 Many tour operators also combine their bus tours with air, sea and rail transportation, sometimes to overseas destinations. Maupintour Inc. of Lawrence, Kan., one of the nation's biggest escorted tour operators, offers tours not only in the United States but to Europe, Africa, Asia, India and the Middle East. Next year it will add new tours to the Netherlands and the Canary Islands, and it will return to China for the first time since 1989, when the Beijing Government crushed the pro-democracy movement.
In contrast to Maupintour, 80 percent of whose group tours combine bus and airplane, only 5 percent of the group tours of Eyre Tour and Travel Ltd. involve air travel. Instead, the family-owned business in Glenelg, Md., offers an extensive range of domestic tours using its own 50 buses and limousines.
 
Tour Operators Courted
 The star attractions of the convention were neither the new machines nor the many educational seminars on subjects like ecotourism, professional liabilities and personal motivation. They were the tour operators, who on average change about a third of their tours in any given year. They sometimes also switch from hotels and restaurants whose standards of quality and service have slipped.
Operators also switch to hotels and restaurants that offer them better discounts. Success in the highly competitive tour industry is closely tied to the ability of tour operators to keep prices low, which means striking the right deal with suppliers.
In many of her seven-minute appointments, Ms. Hahn began by extolling the Amana Colonies' new 300-seat theater, then -- flipping to the appropriate photos -- proceeded to remind her hosts of the 12 family-style restaurants, 6 museums, factories where visitors can see furniture being made by hand, more than 500 motel rooms, 3 bakeries and a new golf course.
"It's an absolutely beautiful thing," she assured one bus operator, inviting the tour operator's gaze to linger over the photo of the golf course in all its greenery. Ms. Hahn used her last minute or so to throw in a good word about some other Iowa attractions, including a nearby Amish community, the Hoover Library in West Branch and the birthplace of John Wayne in Winterset.
The tour operators have also been busy. The 300 or so scheduled appointments for Brownell Tours of Birmingham, Ala., included visits from representatives of Carlsbad Caverns, N.M., the Chattanooga River Boat Company, the Alabama Shakespeare Festival in Montgomery and the Corn Palace, an auditorium decorated with 3,000 bushels of corn in Mitchell, S.D.
"We do between 300 and 400 motorcoach tours a year," said Bill Sellmer of Brownell Tours, "and right now we're looking ahead to where to go next year and in 1993." A colleague, Marie Byers, added, "Every year we try to find something new, and to improve on what we have."

HEADLINE: U.S. Mail-Order Merchants Try Japanese Market

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
When its warehouses are bursting with expensive ostrich boots, fancy fringe jackets and stacks of twill fishing bags, where is a mail-order merchant to turn?
To Japan. 
 At the suggestion of a big Chicago printer, the R. R. Donnelley & Sons Company, a dozen mail-order merchants are collaborating on a catalogue designed to sell slices of Americana to Japanese consumers.
Land's End, Tweeds, L. L. Bean, Orvis and eight others each have two pages in the catalogue, which is expected to arrive in 50,000 Japanese homes later this week. Using the catalogue, Japanese shoppers can order from a handful of each company's products or order a complete catalogue from any of the merchants.
A second mailing, to 500,000 homes in Japan, is planned for February.
 
Donnelly Picking Up the Tab
 Although L. L. Bean has already been sending its own catalogue to Japan, the idea for the group effort came from R. R. Donnelley, which prints and mails catalogues for many of the nation's largest mail-order retailers and is picking up the cost of the Japanese experiment.
The American mail-order business is as slow as the rest of the economy, and Japan, after the United States, is the second-largest consumer products market in the world. Luxury merchants like Tiffany & Company have opened stores in Japan, but most United States retailers have been deterred by the prohibitively high cost of Japanese real estate.
"The Japanese are hungry for a certain kind of Americana." said George Rosenbaum, president of the Chicago market research firm Leo J. Shapiro and Associates.
Mail-order retailing has been slow to catch on in Japan, but the American merchants are banking on the popularity of name-brand American products among fashionable Japanese.
With the help of a Japanese advertising firm hired by R.R. Donnelley, the first catalogue is carefully tailored to the Japanese market. Retailers were told to emphasize fashionable apparel and to avoid including electronics products or products that were labeled "Made in Korea." Japan and Korea are trade rivals.
For a nation of golf buffs, the first mailing includes a golf ball personalizer and personalized golf tees from Austad's golf catalogue. There is also lots of denim (acid- and stone-washed) and things like silver-plated bolo ties for the well-dressed Eastern Westerner. The Sheplers Western Wear section of the group catalogue offers, in addition to $850 cowboy boots, a $1,400 lamb blazer that would do any Texan proud.
The mail-order business in the United States has slowed recently after years of growth because of the weak economy, increased mailing costs and heavy competition.
But in Japan, the mail-order market is still growing, accounting for $11 billion, or 1.3 percent, of the country's retail sales in 1990, said James H. Stewart, senior vice president of Donnelley's catalogue group. In the United States last year, mail-order sales accounted for more than $30 billion in sales, or 4.8 percent of total retail sales, Mr. Stewart said.
Japanese consumers are still becoming accustomed to shopping by mail. Katsuhiko Nitta, vice president of Mitsukoshi U.S.A., an American division of the one of Japan's largest department store retailers, said early efforts at mail order merchandising in Japan had not been successful.
"Shopping by mail was not a preferred method," he said. "They like the old way, turning over and handling the merchandise." Mr. Nitta said, however, that the resistance to mail-order shopping was receding and that Mitsukoshi was increasing its activities in that area.
New customers' names are the key to growth in mail order. But until recently, Japanese mail-order companies have been unwilling to rent or sell their lists of names to foreigners. "That has been the big barrier," Mr. Stewart said. R. R. Donnelley, he said, had convinced the Japanese companies to provide names of Japanese consumers by persuading them that exchanging information on customers was the best way to build the mail-order business.
The cover of the catalogue, called American Showcase, features a photograph of a woman with blond hair and blue eyes peering over a Japanese-style hand fan emblazoned with an American flag. The catalogue is printed in Japanese.
The 2-ounce, 28-page catalogues will be mailed from the United States for about 24 cents apiece, compared with more than a dollar apiece if they were mailed in Japan, according to Mr. Stewart of R. R. Donnelley.
Donnelley research found that Japanese were more comfortable dealing with a venture based in Japan. As a result, Japanese shoppers will send their orders to an R. R. Donnelley facility in Japan, which will fax the orders each day to the various retailers in the United States.
Mr. Stewart said merchants were not charged to be included in the first catalogue, but that they would be charged for future editions. He said an additional dozen companies would be included in a second catalogue to be mailed early next year.

HEADLINE: Prescribing a Dose of Confidence

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
America's business leaders are usually more comfortable talking about their companies' bottom lines than the mood of the country's body politic. But as the economy continues to flounder, they are becoming less reticent about sounding off about what needs to be done.
The problem, as many executives see it, has more to do with sagging spirits than with dollars and cents. And their antidote to the nation's economic anxiety depends less on the mechanics of monetary or fiscal policy than on clear signs of some leadership from Washington. 
 Jerry Della Femina, a New York advertising executive, says the American economy needs a cheerleader President, another Ike or Ronald Reagan -- a Mario Cuomo, in fact, he says. James M. Zimmerman, chief of the Federated and Allied department store chains, based in Cincinnati, says Washington should acknowledge that the economy is in trouble and come up with a plan of action promptly. H. Ross Perot, the Texas entrepreneur, admonishes politicians to get back to the basics, as does R. David Thomas, the founder of Wendy's, the hamburger chain whose worldwide headquarters are in Dublin, Ohio.
In more than a dozen interviews, occupants of the executive suite, like other Americans, said they were dismayed by what they see as partisanship and just plain perverseness in Congress. "Can they govern or what?" asked Curt Bradbury, an Arkansas banker.
Old-fashioned tonics like easier money and fiscal stimulus are not out of favor. Many of the executives favor cuts in taxes, especially taxes on capital gains, and in interest rates. But for the most part they emphasized other means when asked their prescriptions for the nation's ills.
 
H. Ross Perot
Chairman, Perot Systems Corp. Herndon, Va.
 We're approaching the 1992 election. The economy's still in a slump. We'll do what we did in 1988. Think of a great old race horse with sore legs. Just before the election, we'll get the horse out of the barn, shoot up its legs with painkillers and hope that we can win one more race.
All those quick fixes, like running interest rates down or fiddling with taxes, won't work. The only real trick is hunkering down and doing what we know we have to do.
Step One: You've got to say to the White House, Congress, the Democrats and Republicans: "Stop acting like little boys in a schoolyard fight. Link arms. The nation's at risk."
Step Two: Make our Government sensitive to the voters, not to PAC's. Tell politicians they can't give themselves a raise unless they put it on the ballot. Change the laws to hold elections on Saturday and Sunday so that the average guy has more than an hour in the morning and an hour at night to vote.
Step Three: Stop spending beyond our means. We've got to draw a line in the sand. These people work for you and me, but they don't act like our servants. Close the barber shop, the gym, the parking lot. Make them pay for it. Ground every airplane for Federal officials except Air Force One. Let 'em fly commercial, get in line, wait three hours, get their baggage lost. We're going broke, and they're flying around in our airplanes.
I watch these C.E.O.'s wandering around with their blow-dried hair, their $3,000 suits, their 23-year-old trophy wives and I think, "These are the stewards of millions of jobs." I'd give anything if the old man in the White House would call them in and tell them: "I'll support you, or I'll tear your head off. I'm tired of excuses. I want the jobs to stay here; I want the TV's made here. No excuses. Let's go back to basics."
 
T. J. Rodgers
President, chief executive, Cypress Semiconductor Corp., San Jose, Calif.
 I believe that Government deficit spending is really hurting us. By sucking huge amounts of money out of the economy, our Government makes it difficult for high-tech companies to get cheap debt and cheap equity to build plants and hire people. Expensive capital is kind of like lead poisoning. It's always in your system, always weighing on you, always slowing you down relative to your competitors.
I've never wanted to mess with the Constitution, but I've come to a firm conclusion that we need a balanced-budget amendment. I've watched Gramm-Rudman fall apart. It taught me that every bona fide effort to control spending would fail if it was subject to politics. You can't leave politicians under a system that rewards them for spending and punishes them if they don't bring home the projects and expect them to respond differently.
 
R. David Thomas
Founder, senior chairman, Wendy's International, Dublin, Ohio
 The Government has got to stop hurting business and help it instead. The luxury tax that was passed last fall didn't hurt the rich, but it did put 17,000 people out of work. The boating industry was hurt, and recreational vehicles are almost dead. Congress needs to repeal that tax. Washington can't do everything, but it can stop hurting the people who create jobs.
We should take the peace dividend and use to it take care of the problems that we've got. We have a big drug problem, a big alcohol problem. We have people who don't want to work, and we have welfare programs that break up families. Every city, every neighborhood, has got to work on its problems.
I hate the Democrats and the Republicans when they don't take care of what they are supposed to be taking care of. We elected them to take care of the people, not special interests. I think there should be a limitation on politicians' terms. Let them make the laws for a couple of terms and then let them go home to live under those laws.
 
James M. Zimmerman
Chairman, chief operating officer, Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores Corp., Cincinnati
 The key is leadership in Washington: first to deal with perceptions, then to deal with reality.
It's critical that consumers have hope. Washington should send a strong message to consumers that the Administration and Congress will do whatever is necessary.
Instead of bickering, the Government needs to acknowledge there's a problem. And then it needs to do something promptly. Washington not only should continue to pressure the Federal Reserve to lower rates, but Congress and the Administration need to consider tax cuts.
The fixation on the budget deficit is wrong. Some action on taxes would send consumers a message of hope. If you want to have a big budget deficit, let the economy go into the tank next year. Compared to that alternative, a tax cut is cheap.
 
Curt Bradbury
President, Worthen Bank, Little Rock, Ark.
 What is retarding the economy is the inability of small banks to lend into their community to revive their local economy. You've got a dynamic driven by fear, and that fear translates into regulatory stingency that then translates into a sectoral credit crunch. In our part of the country home building is done on spec. Well that's virtually gone.
The jawboning from George Herbert Walker Bush, I've noticed, is having a positive effect on the regulatory cadre that comes into our bank. But the dynamic is being driven by bank bashers in Congress.
In the face of all this, when small banks cannot lend to revive their local economies, Congress cannot pass a bank reform bill. Isn't that staggering? Can they govern or what? The Dingell-Gonzalez compromise, in terms of how it affects the economy, is worse than anything the Judiciary Committee did on Hill-Thomas. On the one hand people decry the credit crunch. On the other hand, the answer from enlightened leadership is to bash the banks some more.
The simple answer is to pass the Senate bank reform bill. The more likely scenario is that we will have to abort what we have now, get a bill that recapitalizes the bank insurance fund and adds teeth to the regulatory process. But let's don't address the issues of reform in this environment.
 
F. Kenneth Iverson
Chairman, chief executive, Nucor Corp., Charlotte, N.C.
 Partly, we're just washing out the excesses of the last half of the 80's. Corporations still have too many management layers, too many administrators, too many fringe benefits for executives. When you listen to all those people who are restructuring, taking thousands of jobs out, you wonder why in the devil they put them in in the first place. You don't need a new manager every time you hire six people. That was an excess.
But we're also getting a poor selection of qualified individuals, whether for blue-collar jobs or jobs that require college degrees. That's the fault of our education system.
I'm not sure that the Government can come out with any grand program to improve education. One of the primary problems of schools is the same problem American companies have. Here in Charlotte, we have an administrator for every teacher. It used to be where we had an administrator for every 10 teachers. Like everything else, it's a bloated bureaucracy. We've gotten into some very bad habits.
 
Richard D. Besser
President, chief executive, Chicago Pneumatic Tool Co., Utica, N. Y.
 I'm a Republican and much as I hate to say it, a tax cut for the middle class will motivate spending. After Reagan cut taxes in 1981, the economy just soared. People are saying that we need a meaningful tax cut and that it has to be revenue neutral. But that's not possible. If we take away every time we give, it won't be meaningful. We've got to be aggressive about lowering taxes, and we're going to have to break the budget agreement.
 
Jerry Della Femina
President, Della Femina, McNamee Inc., New York
 The problem is confidence -- confidence in our leaders.
George Bush is not leading the cheering squad. Since Truman, the U.S. economy has only done well when we've had a cheerleader in the White House. Now everybody's whispering the D-word. And there's no one connected with the Government that can bring it back with a speech.
My clients are the smartest, the most conservative people in the world. They're not going to spend money. They don't believe the President. I believe my bookie, who says business has never been so bad, more than I believe the President.
When the stock market dropped a zillion points in '87, reporters asked Reagan "What's wrong with the stock market?" The helicopter was going so he yelled back: "I can't hear you. Everything seems fine to me." Instead of screaming "String up the President, it's his fault," everybody said, "He said that it's O.K., so we guess it's O.K." And we came back. And we came back.
Whatever people thought of Ronald Reagan, he had a certain credibility. Let's face it, we were in a recession in '80. Carter was saying: "Wear sweaters. You have to suffer; the world is bad; everything is terrible. This is the time to tighten your belts." Boom. There's an inauguration. Reagan gets up and makes a speech. The hostages are set free. The economy starts sailing up and doesn't stop until he leaves. For better or worse, people believed this man.
The only person in politics now who can inspire confidence is Mario Cuomo. He may be a Hamlet-like character, but there's a sense that he's telling the truth. And this is a Republican speaking.
 
Benjamin F. Edwards 3d
Chairman, chief executive A. G. Edwards Inc., St. Louis
 The crucial thing is: Are we or are we not competitive in world markets? We do have our problems, like the S.& L.'s, but I think that American industry is healthier now than I have ever seen it.
We're in a fundamentally strong position unless Washington puts layers of costs -- whether it's tariffs or taxes -- on industry. If our costs get inflated, we either operate at a loss or pass those costs on as price increases. And if we give price increases to a market that doesn't have to pay 'em, people will say "Look, we don't want your expensive stuff."
So ultimately we've got to keep our costs down. Greenspan has it just right. Inflation is his No. 1 fear. He gets a lot of grief from politicians, but inflation is the No. 1 worry.
 
G. Lee Thompson
Chairman, chief executive, Smith Corona Corp. New Canaan, Conn.
 We have to tighten up our trade laws. We tend to bend over backwards to be fair. No other country in the world is as liberal. The biggest protectionist in the world is Japan. It's time to get tough.
 
Karen Horn
Chief executive, Bank One, Cleveland
 I think we ought to put monetary and fiscal policies in place that we think are good for the long term. Money growth is a bit too slow. I think you'd want to get money growing at a reasonable 3 percent to 4 percent rate.
There's a lot of talk about changing taxes to somehow give the economy a short-term lift. But I guess my view of tax cuts or tax redesigns is that they take a long time to propose, they take a long time to get implemented and, thirdly, they take an even longer time to take effect. With these big deficits, I don't think we have at our hands the fiscal-policy tools to do what we used to be able to do. I also believe if we started doing things with cutting taxes, and the financial markets thought it would worsen the deficit problem, we wouldn't entirely get a positive effect.
Long-run fiscal policy should be that the Government would not absorb a significant proportion of the private saving and allow those savings to be used by business for investment. There's a wonderful quote by Washington Irving, "When traveling by stagecoach, it is often a comfort to shift one's position and be bruised in a new place." The idea is that if we take actions that we hope help us in the short run, we might find that they are bruising and damaging in the long run.
 
Charls E. Walker
Chairman Charls E. Walker Associates, Washington
 The sluggishness of this recovery partly reflects the markedly lower rate of investment in this country in the 1980's. The chickens have got to come home to roost sooner or later, and they may be coming home now.
Tax-policy actions alone raised our capital costs in the 1980's by 23 percent. Congress and the Adminstration should start reversing that bad tax policy on investment. We should show the world that we're going to have a sensible, competitive tax policy. High real interest rates also raised our capital costs. Quite obviously we should move that deficit back to balance.
The most powerful bang for the buck is the investment tax credit for new equipment.
One thing that's so disturbing about this town is that we're got an "inside the Beltway" warp and our own debates over taxing capital are completely out of sync with academics like the Shovens, Krugmans, Summers and Boskins. The old distinction between liberals and conservatives on such things as equipment investment is obsolete. Those men stand on a dime.
If nothing happens in 1992, I would hope that the Democratic and Republican leaderships would sit down and draw up a new bipartisan budget agreement in January 1993 that would include a value-added tax, a capital gains tax cut and an investment tax credit.
 
E. W. Deavenport
President, chief executive, Eastman Chemical Co., Kingsport, Tenn.
 I think we should use the peace dividend for reducing the deficit, lowering taxes and new programs for people -- all three. In the short term, one of the better things we could do would be to take some of this money and put it into infrastructure spending, provide jobs and stimulate the economy. A lot of the infrastructure is starting to wear out. Tax cuts are also very, very important. I'd certainly like to see continuing talk on capital gains reductions. That would be a stimulus to the economy and to investment.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
The House overwhelmingly rejected legislation that made it more difficult for banks to expand into the securities and insurance businesses than the Bush Administration wants. The 324-to-89 vote was the product of intense lobbying by senior Administration officials, including Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, who combined forces with representatives of the nation's largest financial institutions, like American Express, Citicorp and J. P. Morgan. [Page A1.]
People reaching the age of 65 will now be able to buy private health insurance to fill the gaps in Medicare without having to worry about being rejected because of illness, injury or prior medical problems. [A1.] 
 Some curious things, it seems, are happening this fall to the Washington-Wall Street axis. With few exceptions, each time the Government issues a discouraging report on the economy, the stock market takes off toward a new high. Economic Memo. [D1.]
The Justice Department will study evidence that lenders discriminate against black and Hispanic home buyers. [D2.]
Two Democratic members of the House introduced legislation calling for trade sanctions against countries that unfairly exclude American exports and run trade surpluses with the U.S. [D10.]
 
COMPANIES
Moody's downgraded the rating on about $7 billion worth of the long-term debt of American Express. It was the first time in the company's history that it was downgraded by Moody's. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Zambia's Democratic Shock to Africa

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LUSAKA, Zambia, Nov. 4

 BODY:
The peaceful and speedy transition in Zambia from Kenneth D. Kaunda's authoritarian leadership to the democratically elected Government of Frederick Chiluba is likely to send shock waves into Africa's long-entrenched regimes and embolden opposition groups, international election observers here say.
They say the victory of Mr. Chiluba, leader of this country's labor union congress, and his new-born opposition party against Mr. Kaunda, one of Africa's "big men," should hasten Africa's "second independence" -- the end of the end of the post-colonial autocrats who rule their countries as personal kingdoms. 
 Now that an African country has achieved the political pluralism that Western aid donors have been seeking, the United States plans to provide inducements to others to follow Zambia's example, Assistant Secretary of State Herman J. Cohen said over the weekend.
 
Pressure on Old-Timers
 Few predict the lightning transformations that swept Eastern Europe in 1989. But the optimists believe that the example set here will put pressure on all the old-time leaders, one of whom, Felix Houphouet-Boigny, the 86-year-old President of the Ivory Coast, took office in 1960.
Former President Jimmy Carter, who headed an election-monitoring group here, said, "It will be much more difficult for the oppressors to keep their people oppressed."
Others were not so sanguine. An African ambassador who watched the elections here as part of a delegation from the Organization of African Unity was more cautious. "Some of the strongmen could react with fear and dig their heels in," he said. Several African ambassadors representing their countries in Zambia were "outraged," he said, that the O.A.U. had given credence to the elections by sending a delegation.
 
Vary From Country to Country
 Thus, the impact of the Zambian elections will vary from country to country on this continent, depending on the status of opposition groups, the character of the governments and the personality of individual leaders.
In the Sudan, for example, where a military dictatorship dominated by Islamic fundamentalists is in charge, it will be difficult for the Zambian result to even register. One of the Sudanese military leaders recently called multiparty democracy as alien to Africa as a "three-piece suit in the desert."
In West Africa, movements toward democratization already taking place through national conferences that bring together governments and opposition groups, may get bolder, the international observers said here.
But the Zambian experience, they said, will reverberate most acutely in East and Central Africa. There, former British colonies like Zambia, formerly Northern Rhodesia, inherited institutions -- a judiciary, a press and professional organizations -- that had not been entirely eroded and could be used by an opposition, said Richard Joseph, a professor of political science at the Carter Center of Emory University in Atlanta.
 
Looking to History
 Mr. Joseph cited Kenya, headed by President Daniel arap Moi, and Zimbabwe, now a one-party state that has been led since full independence in 1980 by President Robert Mugabe. "Moi and Mugabe are going to have to take a look and decide: 'Do I want to be a Kaunda or a Mobutu in the historical record?' "
Mr. Kaunda will be remembered, Mr. Joseph said, as having led his country to independence and then having agreed to multiparty democracy. By contrast, he predicted, President Mobutu Seke Seso of Zaire, who resists power sharing as his country seems to disintegrate, will go down as a dictator who ruined his land.
Mr. Carter expressed hope that in Kenya the Zambian experience would infuse the opposition with more courage to stand up to coercion.
While few doubt that there will now be increased calls in Kenya for elections, Kenyans and other Africans say it may take time for the pressure to mount on either President Moi or President Mugabe as it did on Mr. Kaunda. The former Zambian President, apparently feeling little choice, legalized political party activity last December after food riots and an attempted coup. Mr. Moi has categorically refused to allow the formation of opposition parties and threatened to crush demonstrators "like rats."
 
Economic Advantage
 Mr. Moi has the relative advantage in Kenya of a stronger economy. Mr. Chiluba conceded in an interview that his campaign was helped by conditions in Zambia -- a lively labor movement and almost universal economic despair -- that did not exist in Kenya.
On the diplomatic front, the Zambian elections may have a vital effect: It will be harder for the British Government, the main foreign backer of Mr. Moi, to maintain its public silence about his conduct.
A British Conservative legislator, Anna Nicholson, here as an election observer, said she planned to raise the contrast between Zambia and Kenya in Parliament this week. "I think it's time we came out in the open for multiparty democracy," she said. "I think it is a disgrace that Moi has been able to get away with it for so long."

HEADLINE: Senate Expected to Approve Gates by a Sizeable Margin

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
The Senate opened debate today on the nomination of Robert M. Gates to be Director of Central Intelligence, as the endorsement of two leading Democrats helped assure him of a comfortable margin of approval when the Senate votes on Tuesday.
Supporters of the 48-year-old nominee, who is the deputy national security adviser, made opening statements that praised him as a man of competence, remorse and experience who had learned from his mistakes and would ably reorganize the Central Intelligence Agency and its sister intelligence agencies. 
 Detractors dismissed Mr. Gates as an ambitious, unimaginative bureaucrat who would be beholden to the White House and the wrong person to lead the intelligence community in the post-cold war era.
Mr. Gates was nominated for the intelligence post in 1987 but withdrew his name after questions were raised in the Senate about his role in the Iran-contra affair while he served as a senior intelligence official. Although similar questions came up again this year, the passage of time and Mr. Gates's service as deputy national security adviser since 1989 muted concerns in the Senate.
 
Gates's Integrity Is Praised
 In announcing his support for Mr. Gates, Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who was a member of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence from 1981 to 1989, praised his integrity, experience and his cooperation with Congress. Senator Bentsen said these were necessary ingredients "to do the job that has to be done."
Senator Claiborne Pell also announced that he would vote for Mr. Gates. "I realize he has made errors in the past," said the Rhode Island Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. But he added that the endorsement of the nominee by the Senate's intelligence panel, by an 11-to-4 vote, as well as his own conversations and correspondence with Mr. Gates had satisifed him.
Senator David L. Boren, the Oklahoma Democrat who is chairman of the Intelligence Committee and who earlier had lavished praise on Mr. Gates, thanked both Mr. Pell and Mr. Bentsen. Mr. Boren has telephoned or met with several Democratic colleagues urging them to vote for Mr. Gates.
But two Senate Democrats, Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York and Bill Bradley of New Jersey, faulted Mr. Gates for what they called his pessimistic, misguided cold war views that they said made him blind to irreversible changes in the Soviet Union. And Senator Jim Exon, the Nebraska Democrat, announced that he would vote against the nominee.
Today's discussions also became a debate over the extent to which the C.I.A. failed to predict the problems in the Soviet economy and the weakness of the entire Soviet system.
Mr. Moynihan said, "For a generation the C.I.A. told successive Presidents everything they needed to know about the Soviet Union except the fact that it was about to fall apart."
It was only in 1989, he added, when the Soviet Union was about to collapse, that the agency began to revise its view. "By confirming Mr. Gates, the Senate will confirm this revisionist view," he added.
 
Criticism of Administration
 Mr. Bradley concurred, faulting the nominee for what he called his lack of intellectual curiosity, political judgment and managment skills.
"How can we be assured he won't make the same mistake with China?" he asked.
Mr. Bradley also sought to use the nomination to indict the Bush Administration for failing to predict the changes in Moscow. "The fundamental question posed by this nomiantion is not about Bob Gates, but about this Administration and its failure to understand the emerging post-cold war world," he said.
In rebuttal, Mr. Boren interjected into the record excerpts from a number of previously classified C.I.A. reports from 1979 on that he said proved that the agency had documented the decline of the Soviet economy, saying it was an overstatement to say that in the last decade the intelligence community's record was "totally wrong."
 
Excerpts Unclear
 Because the excerpts were so brief and some of their conclusions equivocal, it was difficult to assess the extent to which they showed "conclusively," Mr. Boren said, that the C.I.A. "got it right."
One 1982 C.I.A. assessment released by Mr. Boren, for example, noted "general social malaise, ethnic tensions, consumer frustrations and political discontent." But it added, "How these internal problems will ultimately challenge and affect the regime, however, is open to debate and considerable uncertainty."
A September 1985 C.I.A. assessment stated that the Soviet system could not simultaneously maintain growth in defense spending, satisfy consumer demand, invest in economic modernization and support client-state economies, but its conclusion did not predict the failure of the Soviet economy. It only stated, "It is an open question how much economic improvement will occur and how long it can be sustained."

HEADLINE: Defying Stereotype, Woman Runs for Salt Lake Mayor

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 2

 BODY:
If Deedee Corradini wins Tuesday's mayoral election and becomes the first woman to lead Salt Lake, another old stereotype about this city will crash with a thud.
Ms. Corradini is not a Mormon. She has been divorced. And she vows to bring more members of ethnic and racial minorities into City Hall. 
 "Don't vote for me because I'm a woman, but because I'm qualified," Ms. Corradini often tells voters. "But if you think my being a woman is a bonus -- great."
Public opinion polls show Ms. Corradini, 47 years old, who owns a management consultant business, leading David Buhler, 34, the State Director of Commerce.
The election is non-partisan, but Ms. Corradini is a Democrat, and Mr. Buhler is a Republican in a city that tends to elect Democrats as Mayor.
And Mr. Buhler, a Mormon who says he "neither advertises that fact nor denies it," acknowledged that being a Republican "is not an advantage here."
But he said voters want a candidate with expertise in government. "When it comes to managing government," he said, "I'm the candidate with real world experience."
 
Big Group Is Undecided
 A poll prepared for publication last Sunday in The Salt Lake City Tribune showed Ms. Corradini with an eight-point lead. In the poll, conducted by Insight Research, Ms. Corradini was favored by 45 percent of those questioned while Mr. Buhler was favored by 37 percent; 18 percent were undecided. The poll, which questioned 600 prospective voters, had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 4 percentage points. Support for Ms. Corradini was nearly identical among men and women.
Seeking to capitalize on the prospect of being the city's first woman Mayor, billboards for Ms. Corradini declare: "It's time."
In Salt Lake City, many voters said they would support Ms. Corradini, in part, because she is a woman.
"I choose politicians the same way I pick a doctor," said Jamie Kamm, a 30-year-old genetic counselor, as she pulled two children from car seats. "When all other things are equal, I go with the woman."
There does not appear to be a significant philosophical difference between the two candidates. Indeed, some Democrats said they would vote for Ms. Corradini, but disapproved of her close ties to Republicans. She attended a $300-a-plate fund-raising dinner for President Bush, for example.
 
'They're Both Acting Civil'
 "It hasn't been a dirty campaign," said Horace Reschke, a genealogist. "They're both acting civil, handling themselves in an intelligent, responsible manner. So I think we're safe either way."
Ms. Corradini would not be the city's first non-Morman Mayor. The current Mayor, Palmer DePaulis, who is not seeking re-election, is Roman Catholic.
If the election of Ms. Corradini would come as a another jolt to the stereotype of Salt Lake as a city run by men in which women are expected to tend to the home, a victory by Nancy Boyasko for a City Council seat would be a real shocker. Ms. Boyasko is a member of the Socialist Workers Party. She finishing second in the primary, trailing the front-runner, Alan Hardman, by 400 votes. She said her Socialist affiliation has not frightened or offended voters.
"We're not insulated in Salt Lake," said Ms. Boyasko, a 34-year-old laborer for the Kendicott Copper Mine. "People here know what it's like to go from paycheck to paycheck."
In the mayoral race, Ms. Corradini expects to spend about $150,000, about twice the amount spent by Mr. Buhler.
In recent years, the economy in this area has shown robust growth. Corporate employers are fond of its relatively low wage scale, plentiful numbers of young workers and ethos of hard work.
 
3,000 New Jobs in a Year
 In the past year, the region has gained 19 new employers, adding about 3,000 workers. Another 21 companies have expanded, adding 1,500 new jobs.

HEADLINE: Darman Sees Deadlock On Plan to Spur Growth

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
Republicans have decided to delay any push aimed at spurring economic growth, because such an effort now would lead to "political skirmishing" and nervous bond markets, Richard G. Darman, the budget director, said today.
No legislation could be passed now, he told reporters. Mr. Darman said that the Republican Congressional leaders who emerged from the White House on Oct. 17 promising legislation by the next week had later concluded that the only certain and immediate consequence of such a proposal would be "an unproductive fight of the class-warfare type." 
 Any measure intended to spur growth would include a renewed appeal for lower taxes on capital gains, a proposal that most Democrats say would be helpful mainly to the wealthy.
Besides the "class warfare" argument, Mr. Darman said, there was a strong risk of a "bidding war" that would threaten last year's budget agreement.
 
'Sound' and 'Sustainable'
 He said that in later meetings with the same Rebublican Congressional leaders, "a fairly strong majority of us concluded" that it would be better to wait until next year. That would provide time, he said, to "get our own act together on a basis that is not only sound programatically, but sustainable politically."
In the waning days of a Congressional session, he said, Democrats could control what issues the public paid attention to. Next year, with a Presidential campaign on, it would be easier for the Bush Administration to make its case, he said.
While Mr. Darman charged that Congressional inaction on several Administration proposals had hurt the economy, he identified one area of potential quick agreement: extended unemployment benefits.
"If there's good will we could have a bill this week," he said.
Mr. Darman said he believed that money could be found to pay for a program costing $4 billion or a little more. The most recent Democratic proposal, which stalled Friday in the House Ways and Means Committee, would cost $5.5 billion.
 
Key Leaders Out of Town
 Otherwise, there was no significant action on the issue today, with Congressional leaders like Thomas S. Foley of Washington, the Speaker of the House, and Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate Republican leader, out of town until Tuesday.
Mr. Darman also accused Congress of disregarding some measures the Administration had offered. President Bush was not sitting back and waiting before proposing measures to help the economy, he insisted. Instead, the budget director said, "Congress has failed to give him a number of things he has requested to deal with the economy."
These included proposals to lower the tax on capital gains, banking changes, highway authorization, an extension of the research and development tax break and a plan to allow Individual Retirement Acount money to be spent on home ownership.
Mr. Darman complained that every bill in Congress "threatens to make the banking industry less competitive," while the Administration sought to make the industry more competitive
On the highway authorization measure, he said he had expected the bipartisan interest in developing the nation's infrastructure to produce action long before today. Now, he said, he had just heard that a four-month House-Senate conference was likely. "There's no need to do that," he said. "That bill could be settled in 24 hours if people had a responsible interest in trying to sort out the differences."
 
Education Changes Needed
 Mr. Darman said that in the long run the economy could not be made competitive without education changes. "We simply will not adequately improve our productivity if we don't get a fairly radical reform of our educational system," he said.
He said Congress was ready to accept some elements of a necessary program, such as setting national goals and moving toward a national testing program.
"But then what you really need badly is the pressure in the system to change, to reform, when people don't meet the goals," Mr. Darman added. For that, he said: "I think you need choice in the system. That is very much harder to get legislatively."
He said pending House legislation was "permissive" toward allowing parents to choose what school their children could attend, "which is a step forward," but the Senate was flatly opposed to Administration proposals that would let Federal aid follow students who wanted to attend private schools.

HEADLINE: Patterns

BYLINE: By Woody Hochswender

 BODY:

 
Whereas, and So Forth
 The model in black lace waltzed down the runway at the Hotel Pierre, made a turn and posed, like Camille in your high school play.
"That is a very pretty dress," said a woman. 
 "Do you think I dare?" wondered another.
"I really don't think you could," remarked the first.
Time to consider fashion again, even though a lot of people are saying no one is in the mood.
It is spring fashion week in New York, and if anyone had any doubts, Mayor David N. Dinkins proclaimed it so, with lots of whereases and therefores. The city assigned additional police coverage to Seventh Avenue between 37th and 40th Streets, where many of the designer showrooms are; the Sanitation Department scheduled an extra sweep-up in the garment district to make a good show for the out-of-town retailers and journalists.
None of this was any consolation to Eleanor Brenner, the Seventh Avenue designer, who had a trunk of 40 expensive samples stolen last week from outside her showroom. They found the trunk, empty, in the Times Square subway station.
"They probably sold the clothes for $5 each," said Ms. Brenner, adding that one of the beaded jackets had cost $2,000 to make.
"It's an ugly situation," she said, "but the show will go on."
 
Toast of the Titans
 The spring showings begin at a time when many people have been talking about a new era in fashion, a new consumer spirit and so forth. In one sense it is a new era, as two of the titans of the industry, Ira Neimark, the chairman of Bergdorf Goodman, and Marvin S. Traub, the chairman of Blooingdale's, have announced their retirements this winter.
There are so many tribute-party invitations, no one can see straight. Mr. Neimark, who was honored at the "21" Club this summer and at the Museum of Wine in Paris last month, will be toasted at a black-tie dinner-dance tonight at the Plaza and with cocktails at the Pierre tomorrow. Mr. Traub, who was honored by the French at the Hotel de Crillon a week ago, will get the black-tie treatment at the Waldorf-Astoria next Monday.
Kind of a long goodbye.
 
The Enduring Video
 Several designers have either canceled their shows or come up with new ways to present their collections. Norma Kamali has decided to produce and direct videos for her three spring lines.
"The shows are boring, abstracted," Ms. Kamali said. "Walking on the runway has little to do with the street. Video has a much longer life than the show itself."
She added that the cost of the videos -- $100,000 to $150,000 -- is about the same as for a fashion show.
For the first time, Ms. Kamali will sell her sportswear to stores other than Bloomingdale's, which has sold it exclusively for three years. The less expensive clothes ($15 to $200) are based on the white shirt: body shirts, shirt jackets and shirt dresses.
"These are basics that have nothing to do with fashion," Ms. Kamali said. "The timing is right, with the economy being so terrible."
 
New Backing for Shamask
 Ronaldus Shamask, who has been out of circulation after the withdrawal of his Japanese financial backer, Mitsukoshi, is back.
Mr. Shamask has signed a licensing agreement with Barneys New York to make two men's wear collections exclusively for that store. Both lines -- with suits at $900 to $1,100 and at $700 to $800 -- are for "the streetwise businessman," he said, and will be available in the spring.
"Having the men's wear license will free me to do a proper women's collection," he said. "Before I start, I will rethink the needs of the consumer. There are a lot of clothes out there."

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY VOTES, AND FLORIO IS ISSUE

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, Nov. 4

 BODY:
With control of both houses of the New Jersey Legislature at stake on Tuesday, about 1.7 million voters who have been lobbied for months in one of the state's most expensive midterm elections will choose their legislators and, perhaps, determine the fortunes of Gov. Jim Florio.
Though Mr. Florio's name will not be on the ballot for the election, which will fill all 120 seats in the State Senate and the Assembly, his $2.8 billion tax increase has been the pivotal issue in the campaign, and the vote's outcome is sure to change the way New Jersey is governed.
 
'The Real Question'
 
 Mr. Florio was not making predictions today; indeed, he seemed to be looking beyond Tuesday's results. "The Governor will work with whoever wins the election to move ahead on confronting some of the people's real concerns," said Jon Shure, Mr. Florio's spokesman. "We're at the point where the real question is, regardless of who wins, how do you govern a month down the road?"
If the Republicans take control of the two houses, in which Democrats have long held majorities, one of the first items of state business is likely to be a Republican pledge to reduce the sales tax to 6 percent from 7 percent. Mr. Shure said that the Republicans had yet to say how they would replace the $500 million such a reduction would cost and that Mr. Florio would resist their effort until they come up with an acceptable revenue source.
On the other hand, if the Democrats retain control of the Legislature, they and Mr. Florio will have to make a priority of restoring the coalition of labor, teachers and urban voters that had traditionally supported them. The unions representing state workers have been dismayed by budget cuts and layoffs. The teachers were angered by the diversion of $360 million from education aid to property tax relief, and low-income voters opposed the sales tax increase.
Mr. Shure, the Governor's spokesman, insisted that his remarks about working with the election's winners were not a concession of victory to the Republicans, adding that neither the Governor nor anyone else knows what will happen on Tuesday.
 
What the People Want
 "But whether he is dealing with a Democratic or Republican Legislature or one that is split, the people don't want to hear politics as usual," Mr. Shure said. "They want a health-care program that holds down costs and leadership that will get us out of the national recession, and they don't care about party labels."
Such talk suggests that the Republicans might be dealing with a conciliatory Democratic Governor if they take control of one or both houses of the Legislature on Tuesday, and that idea came as a surprise to Jeff Michaels, the executive director of the Republican State Committee.
"That's not his style," Mr. Michaels said. "He usually comes out swinging. But if he is willing to work with a Republican majority, it will be a pleasure, and all we can say is, it's about time."
 
'Get Off Your Knees'
 After keeping a low profile for several months, Mr. Florio showed some of his combative personality in the closing weeks of the campaign. Apparently dismayed by the Democrats' strategy -- running without mentioning party affiliation or defending their votes for the new taxes and the property-tax relief and increased school aid it helped support -- Mr. Florio told Democratic candidates: "get off your knees" and carry the fight to the Republicans.
Stephen A. Salmore, a professor of political science at Rutgers University, who is a consultant to the state's Republican Party, said the Governor's late campaign cut into a growing Republican lead in party surveys.
"The Democrats," he said, "in districts where they have a base of voters were not only losing the independents but also some of their own base by not telling voters what they have done for the last two years. When the Governor began to campaign, we noticed some movement toward the Democrats; at least it began to bring back their base voters."
Mr. Michaels of the Republican State Committee predicted that Republicans would take control of both the State Senate and the Assembly, something they last accomplished in 1971. Steve DeMicco, the executive director of the Democratic State Committee, was not so sure. "It's difficult to say how the final winds are blowing," he said. "But I think we're in a position to hold our own." The Democrats now hold slim majorities of 23 to 17 in the Senate and 43 to 37 in the Assembly.
The one advantage the Democrats enjoyed throughout the campaign was a bigger war chest, created by the fund-raising leverage that goes with control of both the Governor's office and the Legislature. State election officials have estimated that $14 million will be spent when all the bills are paid, and Democrats are expected to outspend Republicans by almost three to one.
Republicans were further encouraged over the weekend by a Star-Ledger/Eagleton Poll in which respondents favored Republicans over Democrats by 9 percentage points. The statewide telephone survey of 539 likely voters, conducted from Oct. 22 to 30, has a possible sampling error of plus or minus 4.3 percentage points.
 
Making Up Ground
 But Mr. DeMicco of the Democratic State Committee also found something encouraging in the poll. "About six weeks ago," he said, "we included a similar party-preference question in our surveys, and we found people favoring Republicans by 17 points over Democrats. That means that Democrats have made up ground between our survey and the Eagleton poll."
The last flurry of what has been a blizzard of campaign literature went to the post office on Friday, and Mr. DeMicco and Mr. Michaels have been getting their telephone banks humming and their volunteers assigned to the "get out the vote" effort. Democrats, with the deeper campaign pockets, will again be passing out "street money" to local political figures to inspire the door-to-door canvassing that may turn out a few more votes.
Mr. Michaels said he has to be ready to compensate for "volunteer slippage" in one district or another, and today he had to switch a planned 50,000 telephone calls from one district to another because polling suggested some slippage in the second one.
Mr. DeMicco of the Democrats said he was still receiving last-minute requests for money, and both party leaders said they would have teams of lawyers ready to march into court to stop perceived interference in the election.
Mr. DeMicco said he expected the Republicans to mount a "ballot security task force" operation in Mercer, Middlesex and Bergen Counties to try to reduce the number of minority voters.
He was recalling an effort he said was carried out by the Republicans during the 1981 gubernatorial election, especially in minority areas in urban counties. The Republicans later signed a consent order, agreeing to refrain from such abuses as congregating outside polling places and posting signs warning that illegal voting could be prosecuted.
Mr. Michaels said the Republicans' Election Day effort would stay within the law and the consent order. He accused the Democrats of "waving the bloody shirt." But he said lawyers would be on hand to guard against abuses.
"We're concerned about the integrity of the election process," Mr. Michaels said. "And we're going to make sure this is one election that doesn't get ripped off."
