HEADLINE: A Neighborhood Struggle With Despair

SERIES: Life at the Bottom: Mott Haven, the Bronx -- First of four articles.

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ with CELIA W. DUGGER

 BODY:
Six days a week, from midmorning until nightfall, Shirley Flowers sits alone in the lobby of her South Bronx apartment building, greeting neighbors with cheerful banter while doing her best to banish the nervous strangers who wander in after buying crack in a nearby basement.
The 48-year-old grandmother is all that remains of the tenant patrol she started two years ago to rout the crackheads who lolled in the building's hallways and stairways. Coaxed into being out of apathy and fear, the 340 Beekman Avenue patrol could never overcome its dubious birth. 
 "Sometimes I get disgusted with the tenants," Mrs. Flowers said one day as a steady stream of neighbors slid by. "They like to complain, but nobody likes to participate."
Shirley Flowers keeping her solitary vigil at a small school desk in her lobby: This image is a minimalist metaphor for one of the city's most forlorn neighborhoods, Mott Haven, at the southern tip of the Bronx.
To visit Mott Haven -- and there are Mott Havens in most large American cities these days -- is to discover a world apart. Here, poverty cuts deeper than the lack of money, the lack of health care, the abundance of drugs. This gray place is largely bereft of many of the threads that knit other very poor neighborhoods together: strong tenant organizations, powerful community groups, charismatic leadership, even a safe playground.
"We're like the forgotten city here," said Janet Jones, a native of Mott Haven who left college to raise her three children alone and on welfare in a building around the corner from Mrs. Flowers. "When we need something done, we're always the last ones."
Now, this already strained neighborhood of 50,000 people around East 138th Street and the surrounding avenues is being strained even further as the city moves 200 formerly homeless families into two transitional shelters and hundreds more into renovated apartments. Inadvertently, this immigration has often pitted neighbor against neighbor, as longtime tenants in city-owned buildings watch the homeless move into renovated apartments with new appliances while they remain in the same decaying quarters.
In Mott Haven, the strongest community is the one defined by hardship. No wonder Shirley Flowers can't get any help.
Once, Mott Haven was a bustling enclave of Irish and Italian immigrants who toiled in the factories and rail yards that ringed their tenement neighborhoods. The postwar boom spurred their exodus to the suburbs, attracting in their stead rural Southern blacks and Puerto Ricans.
But the factories, and their seemingly insatiable appetite for unskilled labor, moved away as the city's economy changed, taking with them that immigrant staple, hope, and leaving Mott Haven as the flashpoint for the blight that engulfed the South Bronx. When it emerged from the arson-fired crucible of the 1970's, Mott Haven had lost nearly half its population; the rest stayed behind to witness the devastation wrought by thousands of smaller fires -- flames that heat crack pipes and cook heroin.
 
Beer and Beepers
 Now, the landscape is almost unceasingly drab. Towering red brick projects that house half its souls loom high along its southern border. The new arrivals are filling the valley to the north, where apartment buildings are crammed along side streets, their lobbies secured by dented metal doors shut tight with magnets, the mailboxes sealed in wire mesh to keep out thieves.
There is a park here in Mott Haven, St. Mary's, a rectangle of green stretching six blocks north from 143d Street between St. Ann's and Jackson Avenues, but many residents say they avoid it for fear of robbery. The only other patches of green often are scraggly lots choked by weeds.
Along streets littered with garbage, men sit on boxes sipping beers and playing dominoes near young women pushing strollers and young men with beepers standing on street corners. Under the shade of the Bruckner Expressway, where scavengers have ripped up the cobblestones for sale to suburban homeowners, prostitutes take their midday break.
 
Signs of Progress
 Almost 40 percent of Mott Haven's residents survive on welfare. More than two-thirds of the families are headed by single women. Pregnant women in Mott Haven are the most likely in the city to receive late or no prenatal care and among the most likely to give birth to drug-exposed babies, according to statistics from the City Health Department. The children of Mott Haven are more likely to die before their first birthdays than children in other neighborhoods.
Which is not to say that there are no signs of a future worth working for. Churches and their schools are trying to nurture Mott Haven's young people while hoping to unite their parents into effective neighborhood groups. Commerce and construction bustle along East 138th Street. And nestled along a block once dominated by crumbling tenements, a strip of two-family houses is attracting working-class homeowners.
Still, for every Mott Haven resident who works, there is another who does not. Just one block north of 138th Street is another thriving bazaar, where the wares are illicit, addictive and sold in small vials and glassine envelopes. In Mott Haven, progress often seems like a limited partnership, and even the hardest-working people fear that the problems run too deep to solve.
"There is a combination of things that keep depressing the area," said one detective at the 40th Precinct. "It builds up a momentum that this community by itself cannot stop."
 
Random Violence
Crackling Gunfire And Early Deaths

Mrs. Flowers arrived in Mott Haven 20 years ago, when denim-clad gangs like the Savage Skulls and the Black Spades waged fierce turf battles. When word of a rumble spread through the neighborhood, the streets would clear as in an Old West town anticipating a showdown.
"I'd rather have those days than what we have now," she said. "They fought among themselves but looked out for most of the people they knew around here. These kids around here today, they don't care."
At night, the rhythm of life is jolted by the crackle of gunfire and the crash of bottles flung off roofs. So fearful is Mrs. Flowers of the random violence that plagues her neighborhood that she refuses to let her grandchildren go to the store alone.
"Sometimes you look out your window and are surprised to see how many kids grew up to kill each other," she said quietly.
 
Remembering the Dead
 Around the corner, by a scruffy asphalt schoolyard flecked with glinting shards of glass, 20-year-old Joey Maysonet, surveyed a horizon of ghosts. He pointed to one corner, recalling how in this year alone, three of his friends had died there. Swiveling, he cast his gaze beyond a fenced-in grassy lot, to the block where his brother Ismael fell to the streets in 1983. He was 23.
"He used to rob people and take their drugs," Mr. Maysonet said. Ismael was shot while sitting in a car with several friends, presumably by a victim seeking revenge.
Capt. Carl Larsen, commander of the 40th Precinct, said there have been 66 murders through mid-October, up from 52 for the same period last year. Much of the violence erupts along East 139th Street, where heroin dealers shout out their wares with abandon while lookouts scan the streets calling out "ta to," Spanish slang for "all clear."
Tracy Pringle, a 19-year-old whose basketball skills have made him into a respected local hero, said that despite his celebrity he sometimes feared becoming a victim of the neighborhood's violence. Survival and success hinge on a commitment to his family and college while giving a wide berth to the drug dealers who strut past him.
"If they don't get you, they get your family,' he said. "You've got to learn to live with it."
 
Community Organizing
Using the Church To Fill a Gap

Before becoming acting pastor of St. Ann's Episcopal Church, the Rev. Earl Kooperkamp thought he had seen the worst of social entropy in Harlem and East New York in Brooklyn. Now he knows better.
"It's a whole other magnitude of poverty here," he said.
In a city where cutbacks are the order of the day, his church and others have stepped into the breach, providing after-school programs, cultural activities, and help for immigrants. A food pantry helps stretch welfare budgets and put food on the table, while the soup kitchen feeds scores of people who line up early outside, spilling down the steps and onto the sidewalk.
The flood of newcomers has strained his church's resources; the food pantry regularly runs out of the monthly donated food a week early. Hardly a day passes without a disoriented, newly arrived family stopping by in search of a handout or help with cashing an emergency food check.
"It's easy to move people into the neighborhood," Mr. Kooperkamp said. "The hard part is getting people to be part of a community."
 
'They Want Solutions'
 Parishioners like Edwin Lorenzo, a friendly 20-year-old with a spot of gray above his forehead, are trying to forge a sense of community through church-sponsored outreach and tenant organizing. "People are tired of hearing other people tell them their problems," he said. "They want solutions."
In his case, that means earning his neighbors' trust by getting quick results on apartment repairs, teaching them how to file complaints and going downtown to complain at the Housing Authority headquarters.
More than half the families in his 16-story building in the Millbrook Houses have enlisted in the association. Together with residents of other buildings, they have started a tenants' committee that lobbied successfully for new street lamps along the project's newly paved walkways.
Part of their success is the relative success of the housing projects, generally the most stable housing in the area. Despite the ominous shadow they cast on the horizon, the buildings' tenants are mostly either employed or elderly and the crime rate is lower than in the blocks of tenements that ring them.
Welfare families, who account for about a quarter of the complex's tenants, have been the hardest to get involved. "They don't know they can challenge the government," Mr. Lorenzo said. "They fear if they challenge the government their aid will be taken away from them."
Without more effective organizing, he worries, things will only get worse. "The people who are working are the ones who are leaving," he said.
 
Dearth of Support
Social Service Cuts Despite Poverty

Some urban planners say the city has only added to Mott Haven's problems by reacting too quickly to the double burden of having a community rife with abandoned housing and a growing citywide problem with homelessness. Shelters that better-organized neighborhoods blocked found their way into politically powerless Mott Haven, even as many homeless families moved into city-owned buildings.
Camilo Jose Vergara, a sociologist and photographer who has documented Mott Haven and other impoverished urban neighborhoods, calls them "new ghettos" -- neighborhoods where crime and poverty coexist on a scale unknown, and untolerated, in other communities.
"It is a proof of the distance from the public eye or wherever the moral and political center of the city is," he said.
 
Creating a Housing Mix
 In the last couple of years, though, the city has begun to modify its policies.
Felice L. Michetti, the city's Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development, said the city was developing a healthy economic mix of housing where fewer than half the new or renovated apartments would be for the homeless; the rest would go to low- , moderate- and middle-income people. Mott Haven, city officials say, is unlikely to get any more homeless shelters.
"We want to create an economic ladder in housing," Ms. Michetti said.
She disputed the idea that placing the poor in places like Mott Haven is inherently wrong. The real issue, she said, is whether services are available to help integrate the new families into the neighborhood.
But in Mott Haven, by and large, they are not.
"It was just bricks and mortar. It was not community development," said Bernd Zimmermann, director of planning and development in the Office of the Bronx Borough President. "We need programs that serve the community, not a community to serve the programs."
This year, social services to help the formerly homeless were slashed because of the Dinkins administration's budget cuts. The Human Resources Administration closed the 34 branches of the Office of Family Services, which used to aid relocated homeless families. Ken Murphy, deputy commissioner for crisis-intervention services, said the city planned to distribute $5 million to community groups to pick up the slack. But that money has not been found.
 
Battling to Save Lives
 The city now has a staff of 21 to do follow-up. They can help only about one-fourth of the 4,000 families resettled annually, Mr. Murphy said, and they carry heavy caseloads of 35 families at any given time.
Health care is one of the most crying needs.
Like a garrison digging in before a major assault, boxes of medical supplies are stacked in the basement of the Segundo Ruiz Belvis Neighborhood Family Care Center, Mott Haven's only city health clinic besides Lincoln Hospital, which is almost always oversubscribed. J. Gilberto Sierra, the clinic's quick-thinking administrator, stockpiled the supplies soon after the city announced budget cuts earlier this year.
Most of the cuts have been staved off, but the air of urgency lingers in an area where poor housing and inadequate nutrition complicate health problems, and a reputation for danger makes it hard to recruit doctors.
AIDS, drug and alcohol abuse, as well as chronic diseases like asthma, have made Mott Haven among the city's leaders in serious illness, Mr. Sierra said. And with a young population, there has been a continuing increase in teen-age pregnancies.
"Compared to other areas, our patients have a multitude of problems," Mr. Sierra said. "We cannot handle the demand. If we had three more centers like this we could fill them up easily. We're maxed out."
 
Revitalization
Seeking Stability In Homeownership

Homeownership, a traditional benchmark of stability, is virtually nonexistent in Mott Haven; only 3 percent of the area's housing units are owned by residents. An adventurous attempt to do something about that can be found along East 145th and 146th Streets, where rows of boxy two-family town houses with wrought-iron gates and tidy backyards stand along blocks once lined with burned-out tenements and peopled by dazed addicts.
Costing about $145,000, the houses require a down payment that is roughly double the median family income for Mott Haven, which is $7,600. Nonetheless, nearly all of the first 44 houses are occupied by people from nearby neighborhoods. A total of 112 homes will be built through a partnership of a private developer and the Southeast Bronx Community Organization with state and city subsidies and marketing assistance from the New York City Housing Partnership.
Nana Asare had looked in neighborhoods in the north Bronx but decided to buy his house at 452 East 146th Street because it was the best deal he could get on a new house. And while he knew the neighborhood had its own dangers, he hoped more families like his would bolster the area.
"I look at it this way," he said. "If the place is improving by putting in working people who are more responsible, you would think the area would improve as time goes on."
 
Forming Role Models
 Genevieve S. Brooks, a former housing advocate who now is deputy Bronx borough president, said the new homeowners were vital to the area's turnaround. As a founder of the MBD Community Housing Corporation, a nonprofit housing sponsor, she helped transform Charlotte Street in Morrisania from a national symbol of urban blight into a community of ranch-style homes and white picket fences.
"They are better able to stay on top of public servants and see that they deliver the services people are entitled to and to be a beacon and a role model for people in need," she said.
That may not be evident at first. The aluminum siding on Orlando Andrade's new house on East 146th Street is pitted from rocks hurled by children playing on a nearby rooftop.
"Maybe they are jealous of the people who have houses and cars," he said.
The Bronx, he said, will change: "It won't always be bad." But he still wonders if moving to Mott Haven was the right decision.
"I'm beginning to doubt it," he said. "I'm not sure."

History
 Mott Haven was named for Jordan L. Mott, an inventor who purchased 100 acres in the mid-19th century to build a foundry and a community to house his workers.
 
Ethnicity
 Originally Irish immigrants, then Italians at the turn of the century, then hispanic and black families after World War II.
 
Housing
 Nearly two-thirds of all the homes and apartments in Community District 1 are publicly owned; more than half are in city Housing Authority projects.
 
The Homeless
 Two hundred homeless families live in two shelters; 1,254 others live in apartments provided by the city.
 
Murder Rate
 Murders are up this year in the 40th Precinct, 66 through mid-October compared to 52 at the same time last year.
 
Drugs
 With 1,400 drug-related arrests through mid-October, the area is notorious. Tainted heroin sold in Mott Haven killed several addicts early this year.
 
Poverty
 Only about half of area residents who could work have jobs. The median family income is about $7,600.
 
Economy
 Not as weak as might be expected. Retailers are expanding, thanks to welfare checks and food stamps. A nearby industrial park provides thousands of jobs.

HEADLINE: Lag Is Seen in Transplants

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Nov. 4

 BODY:
Advances in organ transplant technology are racing far ahead of the ability of the nation's health care system to provide the organs and the funds needed to perform costly life-saving operations, says a study made public today.
As a result, more than 23,000 Americans are waiting for new hearts, kidneys, lungs, livers and pancreases, 10,000 more than were on waiting lists just five years ago, according to the 11-volume report, which was issued at a medical conference here.
Roger Evans, a researcher with Battelle Human Affairs Research Center in Seattle, said the three-year study found transplants were cost-effective despite their relative expense. 
 But he said a shortage of donor organs had hidden the true cost of the new technology because the shortfall ruled out surgery for many people who needed a transplant.
"It's rationing on the basis of available organs instead of on the basis of the ability to pay," Mr. Evans said.
"Improving organ supply will perhaps cause more economic problems than we have now."
 
Cost of $39,000 to $1.5 Million
 Few patients can afford the operations, which usually cost from $39,000 to $145,000 but can soar as high as $1.5 million. And many insurers are reluctant to pay for them.
In addition, many transplant recipients remain chronically ill long after their operations, requiring medical care that costs on average $10,000 a year, five times the per capita rate for medical care in the United States.
Mr. Evans said as medical techniques improved, the Government might be forced to limit the availability of the new technology to keep medical costs from rising.
The three-year study was a cooperative research project carried out by Battelle, the United Network for Organ Sharing, and the United States Health Care Financing Administration and the United States Health Resources and Services Administration.

HEADLINE: Stark Data On Women: 100 Million Are Missing

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
LITTLE girls in China no longer have their feet crushed by foot-binding, and widows in India are no longer supposed to be roasted alive on the funeral pyres of their husbands. But a stark statistic testifies to women's continuing unequal status: at least 60 million females in Asia are missing and feared dead, victims of nothing more than their sex. Worldwide, research suggests, the number of missing females may top 100 million.
If sex discrimination in the West means office harassment or fewer good jobs for women, in the third world it often means death. A traditional preference for boys translates quickly -- in China, India and many other developing countries -- into neglect and death for girls. While the discrimination is widely seen as a relic of outdated attitudes, in fact the problem appears to be getting worse in Asia. Recently released census data in China and India show that in both countries the sex ratio of the population became more skewed over the course of the last decade. 
 The tens of millions of missing include females of all ages who are aborted or killed at birth or who die because they are given less food than males, or because family members view a daughter with diarrhea as a nuisance but a son with diarrhea as a medical crisis requiring a doctor.
"If a boy gets sick, the parents may send him to the hospital at once," acknowledged Li Honggui, an official in China's State Family Planning Commission. "But if a girl gets sick, the parents may say to themselves, 'Well, we'll see how she is tomorrow.' "
 
 
A Shadow on Census Data
 Remarkably little research has been conducted on the plight of the missing women, and even their disappearance is discernible merely as a shadow on the census data and mortality statistics.
"It's shocking that so little is known," said Amartya Sen, a Harvard economist who has tried to call attention to the issue. Professor Sen estimates that considerably more than 100 million females are missing around the world, and he asserts that the reason the shortfall is getting worse in some areas is that girls are not allowed to benefit as much as boys from the improvements in health care and nutrition that are lowering death rates in developing countries.
Any investigation into the case of the missing women begins with one fact: 5 or 6 percent more boys are born than girls, but in normal circumstances males die at higher rates at every age thereafter. Typically in the West, where female infanticide is not considered an issue, children are disproportionately male, the number of men and women evens out by the time people are in their 20's or 30's and the elderly are disproportionately female. In relatively advanced countries like the United States, Britain and Poland, there are about 105 females for every 100 males.
 In India, however, a census this year found only 92.9 females for every 100 males, down from 93.4 in the 1981 census and 93.0 in the 1971 census. And in China, the 1990 census found just 93.8 females for every 100 males, compared with 94.1 at the time of the 1982 census. By a conservative calculation there are 30 million females missing in China, about 5 percent of the national total and more than are missing in any other country.
 A United Nations report this summer, "The World's Women," found that other countries with very low ratios of females include Afghanistan, with 94.5 for every 100 males; Bangladesh, 94.1; Bhutan, 93.3; Nepal, 94.8; Pakistan, 92.1; Papua New Guinea, 92.8, and Turkey, 94.8.
"Millions of women have died because they're women," said Sharon Capeling-Alakija, director of the United Nations Development Fund for Women, adding that mothers as well as fathers are responsible. "In most societies, women are the bearers of tradition, and if decisions are made between boy children and girl children, women were involved in making those decisions."
 While the countries with shortages of women are all quite poor, it is not inevitable that poor countries will mistreat and kill their females. In sub-Saharan Africa, for example, poverty and disease make life perhaps more grim than on any other continent, yet there are 102 females for every 100 males. In Latin America and the Caribbean, for all the influence of machismo, there are equal numbers of males and females.
 Even within India, there are huge differences. The southern state of Kerala, which is among the most educated, has a ratio of 104 females for every 100 males, almost the same as the United States and Europe. Despite the immense number of missing females, it is virtually impossible to find human faces to match the statistics. Strolling around Chinese villages, it is easy to find out about girls who died of pneumonia or some other disease but difficult to prove that they were victims of their sex.
 
Statistical Challenge
 It is only in the overall statistics that the shortfall becomes clear. A study published early this year by a Swedish expert, Sten Johansson, suggested that in countries without strong patterns of discrimination about 130 infant boys die for every 100 infant girls. In China, however, only about 112 boys die for every 100 girls -- presumably because boys are favored.
The Swedish study calculated that these data point to 44,000 female deaths each year that are the result of unequal treatment, just among infants less than 1 year old.
Likewise, two studies in India reportedly found that for most of the first year of life, girls had lower mortality rates than boys, but that later in infancy boys did better than girls. This may be because early in life the infants were fed from the breast, which was gender blind, but that parents later favored their sons over their daughters in allocating food and medical treatment.
Perhaps the most challenging problem statistically is to determine the number of missing females around the world. The difficulty is to derive the sex ratio that would exist in a population if males and females were treated equally.
The ratios in Western countries are perhaps inapplicable to developing countries because of the difference in age structures. A population with a lower average age should have a higher proportion of males, because children are disproportionately male. Thus a country with a short life expectancy or with a rapidly growing population -- both reasons for a low average age -- would have relatively fewer females than Western nations.
 
A Reporting Problem
 Even so, the 2 percent surplus of females in sub-Saharan Africa and the 4 percent surplus of females in Kerala may suggest that those ratios are benchmarks for the third world if it were gender-blind. If one picks a ratio, such as 103 females to 100 males, as the one that would prevail in an equitable developing country, that would indicate that more than 100 million females are missing around the world.
Ansley J. Coale, a Princeton University demographer, outlines a much more sophisticated method in a forthcoming article in Population and Development Review, the journal of the Population Council in New York. Professor Coale calculates a hypothetical sex ratio that might be expected to exist in each of a half-dozen countries, based on their fertility and mortality rates. For example, he calculates that China should have 101 males to 100 females, and that India should have 102 males for each 100 females.
Those ratios suggest that 30 million Chinese females are missing, along with 22.8 million Indian females, 3.1 million Pakistanis, 1.6 million Bangladeshis, 600,000 Egyptians and 200,000 Nepalese. In these countries alone, nearly 60 million females are unaccounted for by this method -- a figure Mr. Coale notes is lower than other estimates but one he calls "still distressing."
Using Professor Coase's method, 5.2 percent of females are unaccounted for in China, along with 5.6 percent of females in India, 7.8 percent in Pakistan, 3.8 percent in Bangladesh and smaller proportions in other countries.
Huang Baoshan, a spokesman for China's State Family Planning Commission, suggests that at least in China a significant number of the missing females are very much alive but have eluded census takers because peasants officially limited to one or two children are reluctant to report the birth of a daughter.
Still, before the "one child policy" was introduced a dozen years ago, there was no obvious reason to under-report girls. Yet even then, millions of girls were missing. The 1953 census found 107.6 males per 100 females -- a ratio even more skewed than today's, presumably largely because of female infanticide and discrimination against young girls in the first half of the century.
 
The Ultrasound Option
 The killing of newborn girls was banned in India in 1870, and was denounced and outlawed by the Communists after they imposed order on the Chinese countryside after the 1949 revolution.
Nevertheless, female infanticide has deep roots in rural China -- partly because infants were not always regarded as full persons until they had lived for a year or grown their teeth. An old fable recounts approvingly how a couple buried their daughter alive so they would have more food to give to the man's mother. In burying their child, the couple found a treasure and were thus rewarded for their filial piety.
Each year in China, about 600,000 fewer girl births are reported to the authorities than there should be, based on the number of boy births and the ratio that should exist between them. A large number appear to be surreptitiously given up for adoption, and many others are simply raised quietly by their parents or relatives without registering the birth. Some are also drowned at birth by a midwife who keeps a bucket by the mother's side, in case the infant proves to be an unwanted girl, but it is impossible to know how often this happens.
These days, technology has presented parents with a tidier option than infanticide: ultrasound tests that determine whether the sex of a fetus.
"Everyone wants a son, so they get an ultrasound test and if it's a girl they have an abortion," said a businessman from a rural area in Fujian Province. Though the practice is illegal in China, the man said: "There's no law for the doctors. It's all money and connections."
In India, amniocentesis is sometimes used in the cities to determine the sex of a fetus so that it can be aborted if it is female.
The United Nations report cited 8,000 abortions in Bombay after the parents learned of the sex of the fetus, only one of which involved a male. Professor Sen believes that the practice is not widespread enough throughout India to account for a significant proportion of the millions of missing females. In China, however, anecdotal evidence suggests that selective abortion may be having an impact on the statistics.
Chinese law prohibits doctors from telling prospective parents the sex of the fetus, but the prohibition simply raises the cost of the bribe to extricate the information from the ultrasound operator. Even official reports acknowledge the practice.
"Ultrasound has brought great joy to peasants who still carry old ideas," Science and Technology Daily reported earlier this year. It quoted a peasant as saying: "Ultrasound is really worthwhile, even though my wife had to go through four abortions to get a son."

HEADLINE: Danes Link Sunspot Intensity to Global Temperature Rise

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
ARE changes in the intensity of the Sun's radiation partly responsible for the rise in global temperature that has been observed over the last century and especially over the last few years? If so, it would mean that heat-trapping atmospheric gases like carbon dioxide played a smaller role in the warming than some scientists have believed likely.
The possibility has been raised anew by Danish geophysicists. They report in the current issue of the journal Science that they have established a close statistical correlation between variations in the length of the sunspot cycle -- which they say are an indicator of changes in the intensity of solar radiation -- and fluctuations in the world's surface temperature over the last 130 years. 
 The analysis was made by Dr. Eigil Friis-Christensen and Dr. Knud Lassen of the Danish Meteorological Institute in Copenhagen.
 
Bush's Cautious Approach
 Their finding is one of a number of new pieces of information being considered by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, an international group of scientists convened by the United Nations to make a continuing assessment of the global warming problem as new evidence develops.
In international talks on a treaty to deal with the threat of global warming, the Bush Administration has taken a cautious approach on the question of whether to reduce carbon dioxide emissions. It argues that significant reductions would be economically damaging and that not enough is known about the magnitude of the threat. Earlier suggestions that changes in solar radiation might affect the climate as much or more than the heat-trapping gases have played to the Administration's hand.
Some scientists say that if the findings of the Danish scientists are borne out by further investigation, carbon dioxide's suspected role in the warming of the last century would have to be downgraded. But they emphasize that even then, no conclusions could be drawn as to how the climate would be affected by changes in solar radiation over the next century, since the length and intensity of solar cycles are unpredictable. Meanwhile, atmospheric carbon dioxide is expected to increase steadily as a result of the burning of fossil fuels.
To cancel out the warming that many scientists expect to come from carbon dioxide would require a decrease of 2 percent in the intensity of solar radiation, "and I don't know of anyone who believes there is that large a variability" in solar activity over a century's time scale, said Dr. James E. Hansen of the Goddard Institute for Space Studies in New York. Dr. Hansen is a foremost proponent of the view that global warming caused by humans is taking place.
He and others, including the authors of the new study, point out that the new finding is based on a statistical correlation and that no physical mechanism for the supposed variations in solar radiation has been demonstrated.
 
A Remarkably Close Fit
 Dr. Friis-Christensen and Dr. Lassen analyzed the lengths of sunspot cycles, which vary from 9 to 13 years with an average of 11 years. Shorter cycles, they said, are associated statistically with more intense solar activity. The variations in cycle length, the scientists found, almost precisely match the fluctuations in Northern Hemisphere temperatures from the mid-1850's to the mid-1980's.
The years immediately before 1985, when temperatures were rising, coincided neatly with a period of shorter solar cycles lasting about nine and a half years. By contrast, the years from 1945 to 1970, when the climate cooled, coincided with a period of longer cycles.
While the correlation established by Dr. Friis-Christensen and Dr. Lassen falls short of definite proof, a number of scientists nevertheless called it remarkable in its close fit between the solar and temperature trends. The findings were termed "a major advance" by Dr. Robert Jastrow, a professor of earth sciences at Dartmouth College who is also the president of the George C. Marshall Institute in Washington.
 
A 'Gut Feeling'
 In 1989, the institute issued a report, cited favorably by Bush Administration officials, which said that the last century's warming could have been caused partly by solar variability. It also said that natural cooling factors could partly or largely offset any temperature increase caused by carbon dioxide in the next century.
Dr. Hansen said that while the Danish researchers' statistical correlation may or may not hold up, "my gut feeling, nevertheless, is that they're at least partly right." If the findings turn out to be true, he said, the variations described by the Danes "could substantially moderate or enhance" climate changes brought about by heat-trapping gases.
If the findings are ultimately borne out by physical evidence, they would advance the effort to separate from a welter of natural variations whatever amount of warming humans have contributed to a rise of about 1 degree Fahrenheit in the average surface temperature of the globe over the last century. The Danish scientists said that human-induced warming could have taken place but might have been counteracted by air-polluting sulfates produced by industrial activity. These are believed to exert a cooling effect on climate.
It is also possible, Dr. Friis-Christensen said, that some of the observed warming might be attributable to human factors and some of it to increased solar radiation.

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS;
After Mega-Losses, Mega-Alterations?

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir

 BODY:
Flo Ziegfeld's Follies. Seward's Folly. Now, CBS's $604 Million Follies.
CBS wrote off $282 million on its major league baseball deal last year, anticipating future losses. CBS underanticipated. Badly. Last Friday, the network wrote off $322 million more on its baseball and National Football League properties. Quite a reality check after all that World Series euphoria. 
 Unfortunately, CBS won't provide the baseball-football breakdown in the new write-off. But figuring conservatively that just a half of the write-off was from baseball means CBS now expects the baseball contract to lose $443 million over its four-year term, or almost 42 percent of the value of the $1.06 billion deal.
Will there be more write-offs next year? Will CBS miscalculate the 1992 advertising environment as badly as it did the 1991 market? Said John Reidy, a media analyst with Smith Barney: "If they can't figure it out by now, they'll never figure it out."
Like Arthur Watson, his predecessor as the president of NBC Sports, Dick Ebersol isn't shy about leading the CBS-Has-Ruined-Network-Sports Police. Said Ebersol of CBS's newest losses: "It's cataclysmic. This mini-series of mega-losses will change the basic economics of American sport. What's happened in the American economy is finally coming to sports."
And it's coming soon to NBC, which has a write-off of its very own speeding down the red-ink highway. Already that network has lost $50 million in the first two years of its $752 million N.F.L. deal. But within the next two months, an estimated $90 million will be written off the value of its four-year N.F.L. contract in anticipation of future losses.
"It's the worst deal at the network -- the deal was made in March of 1990 and by August, Bob Wright was saying he wished he hadn't made the deal," Ebersol said, referring to the president of NBC. "If we're not able to get a risk-free deal the next time out, we won't be there."
Yes, football fans, NBC may be out of the football business if it can't get a saner N.F.L. deal next time around. That means more sponsored, made-for-TV beach volleyball and bicep beauty contests on Sunday.
"The N.F.L. has been a good partner," Ebersol said. "They may see fit in the months ahead to initiate some sort of restructuring. But we won't ask them for any relief," on the current contract.
Val Pinchbeck, the league's director of broadcasting, said: "We meet with the networks routinely, where the subject of their losses has come up. They paint a dark picture of what's going on."
Is Ebersol's salvo merely public posturing or an illustration of deep concern? Probably some of the former, but more of the latter. His ultimate boss is Jack Welch, the chairman of General Electric, NBC's parent. Welch is considered one of the toughest bosses in America. You figure out how much he likes financial write-offs.
 
Musburger on Golf
 Roger Twibell and Dave Marr are out as the voices of ABC's golf coverage come January. In are Brent Musburger as the host (promoted from World League of American Football games), Mark Rolfing (from NBC) as an on-course reporter and Steve Melnyk (from CBS) as an analyst at the 18th hole. Twibell will shift downward to the W.L.A.F.; Marr will be gone by 1992.
 
Albert's No. 25
 Marv Albert, who will be behind the microphone for tonight's Knicks-Bucks game on the MSG Network, on entering his 25th year as the radio-then-TV voice of the team: "My kids make fun of the 25 years, which is why they no longer receive tickets." . . . Quinn Buckner, the new studio host of NBC's "NBA Showtime" pre-game program, on the player's perspective he will try to bring: "The salary cap is an issue, but the players haven't made it one. No one is under the illusion that it hasn't been a positive, that it saved the league, but is it necessary to keep saving the league by keeping the salary cap?" . . . The weekend's broadcast highlight may have been Tom Durkin's calls of the Breeders' Cup on Saturday for NBC, especially of Arazi's stunning victory in the Juvenile. Throughout the seven races, Durkin was excited, knowledgeable and cliche-free.

HEADLINE: Housing Law Challenges Power of Zoning Boards

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRUMBULL, Conn., Nov. 4

 BODY:
A Connecticut law intended to spur the construction of affordable housing is putting on trial one of suburbia's most powerful institutions, the planning and zoning commission.
The law allows a special housing judge to overturn the decisions of town zoning officials if they cannot prove that health and safety concerns "clearly outweigh the need for affordable housing." In doing so, it strikes at more than half a century of freedom that suburban zoning boards have had in shaping and protecting their communities, often by excluding cheaper housing and the people who live in it. 
 That power to exclude has long been blamed for making possible the racial segregation that divides cities from suburbs across the Northeast. Only recently, however, in court decisions in Yonkers, on Long Island and in Connecticut, have judges made the connection between housing policies and segregation and begun to attack zoning's power to discriminate economically.
A shortage of affordable housing has also brought zoning under attack in legislatures. Connecticut, Rhode Island and New Hampshire all recently adopted zoning appeal laws, modeled on one in Massachusetts that established a state Housing Appeals Committee more than 20 years ago.
 
Misuse of Power?
 "The reason towns were given the power to zone was not so they could do whatever they wanted to do," said Terry J. Tondro, a University of Connecticut law professor involved in proposing the Connecticut law in 1989, "but so they could improve the welfare of the residents of their community."
"To allow a community to use a state power to keep some of us out," he said, "means they're not using the power given to them for the proper purpose."
More than half a dozen developers have begun appeals against zoning commissions under the law, but the first case scheduled for a hearing, in Hartford on Friday, is by far the largest.
In it, the nation's largest builder of apartments, Trammell Crow Residential, is challenging the zoning commission of one of the state's most suburban communities, Trumbull, home to the 1989 Little League World Champions.
At issue is the fate of 38 acres near the Bridgeport border, which the zoning commission has marked for a future office park. In a town of 32,000, where more than 93 percent of the homes are traditional single-family houses, where there is not a single apartment building, where no land is zoned to allow apartments, Trammell Crow has proposed a 600-unit apartment complex for the site.
The key, for Trammell Crow, is that it proposed to rent 20 percent of the apartments at prices that meet the state's definition of "affordable." Providing that housing, under the law, turns the tables on Trumbull's zoning officials, requiring them to prove that their concerns over traffic, sanitation or other local factors outweigh the need for a kind of housing that the town does not have.
"Affordable," is relative, however, and it has not escaped Trumbull officials that state income guidelines would allow Trammell Crow to rent its 120 affordable apartments for as much as the other 480. Market rates for a three-bedroom unit range from $800 to $1,200 a month. Under the income guidelines, someone renting an "affordable" apartment could be charged as much as $960 a month, but no more than the market rate. All units would be part of an upscale complex with its own clubhouse, gym, pool and tennis courts.
So the real effect of the law here would be to open a suburban community to apartments for the first time. That possibility alternately encourages and alarms those involved.
"Very few towns are going to change until someone gets whacked," said Timothy S. Hollister, a Hartford lawyer who represents Trammell Crow. Mr. Hollister earlier won a landmark decision from the Connecticut Supreme Court, in a zoning suit against East Hampton, that laid a foundation for the appeals law.
Trumbull's lawyer, Burton S. Yaffie, says the law threatens to give a judge absolute power over towns.
"So much for Home Rule!" he exclaimed in his brief opposing Trammell Crow's appeal. "So much for local control of zoning! So much for the longstanding controls and checks and balances that have been built into all of our land-use powers during the last century!"
In the rarefied world of Fairfield County real estate, Trumbull is both a wealthy suburb of Bridgeport and a haven for commuters to Greenwich and Stamford who cannot afford the more expensive houses there.
It is 95.3 percent white, according to the 1990 Census. Its Town Council has refused to join a regional compact to develop affordable housing, making it the only holdout among the suburbs of Bridgeport, which is 51.7 percent black and Hispanic. But First Selectman David A. Wilson suggests that the town's character is more family-centered than exclusive.
"Trumbull has more volunteer boards and commissions than any town in the state," Mr. Wilson said. "We play every sport, no matter the size or shape of the ball. There is absolutely no activity that we don't have for youth. It's a very family-oriented community."
Mr. Wilson is troubled by the state's definition of "affordable housing": housing affordable to people with incomes no more than 80 percent of a region's median. That "moderate" income in Trumbull can range up to $38,400 a year.
To people like Mr. Wilson, who served on Trumbull's police force for 25 years, that means a developer is seeking to break the town's zoning to provide "affordable housing" for people earning more than he did for most of his life.
"My own daughter just got married," he said, "and she can't afford Trumbull. But if she works as hard as my wife and I did, and her husband does, they'll find a way. Not everybody can afford to live in the suburbs."
Trammell Crow, however, says Trumbull doesn't realize how much soaring prices changed the suburban housing market in the 1980's.
"It doesn't take a rocket scientist to figure out there are lots of middle-class and lower-middle-class people in Trumbull who bought their houses 20 or 25 years ago," Mr. Hollister said. "Now they're worth astronomical amounts, and they couldn't afford to buy them if they were just coming to Trumbull for the first time."
 
Strict Quotas Unwanted
 Trammell Crow, an Atlanta-based partnership with its Northeast division's offices in New Canaan, says the high density it proposes -- 16 apartments per acre -- is necessary to make a profit. It will not disclose the purchase price for the property, on which it has an option.
The judge in the case, Marshall Berger of Hartford Superior Court, could find in favor of Trammell Crow, but simply instruct Trumbull zoning officials to reconsider its plan. A major goal of the law is to persuade towns to accept housing voluntarily. No one wants the strict quotas that New Jersey imposed after its Supreme Court, in two cases involving the town of Mount Laurel, ruled that all communities had an obligation to provide housing for people of all incomes.
Professor Tondro said the law is intended not to strip towns of the ability to plan for themselves but to insure that they use their zoning powers to promote the general welfare, not to discriminate.
"What we were seeing," he said, "was that these kinds of decisions were being kept in the hands of local people who were intent on keeping outsiders out, apparently for racial, or most frequently, economic reasons, and sometimes just because they liked their quiet corner of the world.
"What we're doing," he said, "is asking the courts to examine their purpose."

HEADLINE: Many Dreams, Fewer Dollars In Lotteries

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD

 BODY:
In some ways, New York would like to be more like Connecticut; in other ways, more like New Jersey. New Jersey wouldn't mind being a little more like Connecticut. In certain respects, New Jersey and Connecticut would like to be more like New York. And everybody would love to be a lot more like Massachusetts.
This envy has nothing to do with violent-crime rates, yearly rainfall or the percentage of houses without aluminum siding. Rather, it concerns that fascinating obsession of the not-yet-rich: state lotteries. 
 While the lotteries in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey have all been around so long that their growth has stalled -- they are grappling now with how to change that -- and while all foist a similar mix of games on a similar mix of people, they achieve different results. It is treacherous to judge their relative performances: You're better off trying to calculate the winning chances of playing your grandmother's baptism date seven times a week in alternate months.
But certain conclusions can be reached by studying several barometers. A fundamental measure that lottery directors look at is the net per capita revenues their states reap each year. In the 1991 fiscal year, Connecticut achieved $71.21 a person, the fifth-best rate in the country. New Jersey was close behind at $68.30. New York lagged at $52.86. The much-envied Massachusetts led the nation with a whopping $83.24.
 
In Pursuit of Preposterous Odds
 "We trail all the neighboring states in per capita sales," lamented Peter Lynch, the director of the New York Lottery. "That indicates there is opportunity for us to do better."
Even though there should be certain efficiencies of scale, New York spends the highest percentage of revenues on operating its lottery. It also pays the smallest slice in prizes, and therefore a higher split of revenues flutters into state coffers. New York spends 56 cents of each lottery dollar on prize money and operating expenses, while New Jersey spends 58.7 cents and Connecticut, 57 cents.
In fiscal 1991, Connecticut collected $228.6 million from its lottery. New Jersey produced $529.3 million, its best performance after $532.2 million in 1989. New York generated a record $940 million. But each of the three states' incomes grew less than 2 percent.
"You've got three remarkably similar lotteries," said Terri LaFleur, a senior editor at Gaming and Wagering Business Magazine. "Without new product introductions, they're going to stall at their slight growth rate."
All three states are frantically rooting in a cornucopia of possibilities to get people to part with more dollars in the pursuit of preposterous odds -- everything from rejiggering the dimensions of their jackpots to hooking into a televised lottery game show to sponsoring instant games that anoint winners every few minutes.
Mr. Lynch is of the mind that New Yorkers need to bump into lottery machines much more often. He sees no reason why a lottery machine shouldn't present itself whenever a routine errand is run, and is beginning a pronounced effort to put them into gasoline stations, supermarkets and convenience stores like 7-Elevens.
"We're trying to get the impulse player," Mr. Lynch said. "The person who leaves the house not necessarily to buy a lottery ticket but to get gas or some bread and milk."
At the same time, a new advertising campaign is about to be unveiled. The state is dumping its catchy and highly successful "A dollar and a dream" slogan for "Hey, you never know," a phrase meant to suggest that you just never know if you might win many millions of dollars.
 
In Airports and a Casino
 New Jersey is looking to lasso more out-of-state visitors. Frank Pelly, the executive director of the lottery, said he sees no reason why tourists and business visitors shouldn't take a fistful of New Jersey lottery tickets home with them. Beginning early next year, the state is putting lottery machines in turnpike rest stops. It recently installed machines at two terminals at Newark International Airport and is looking to add them to train stations. Just weeks ago, in another experiment, it put its first lottery machine in an Atlantic City casino, Harrah's.
All three states are weighing new games and ways to reconfigure existing ones. They have emulated the enormously successful Massachusetts strategy of putting multiple instant scratch-off games on the streets simultaneously. New Jersey has increased its selection to three at a time. In early 1990, Connecticut switched from one game to as many as five. New York now has seven.
As early as January, New York might introduce a variation of the Fantasy Five game offered in Florida, where players pick 5 out of 39 numbers. Because the odds of winning are appreciably better than in the main lotto game, the product might appeal to players who have spent small fortunes buying lottery tickets and never won a dime. For those impatient gamblers, New York is also looking at the keno game in Oregon that produces a drawing every five minutes.
Meanwhile, Connecticut is exploring lump-sum lotto games that pay out immediately rather than over 20 years. Both Florida and Massachusetts have tried these.
 
Like Jeopardy Without Answers
 One of the hottest ideas in lottery circles is a lottery game show on cable television. A consortium of states is exploring this prospect. The way it might work, players purchasing tickets that match winning numbers or color combinations drawn on the show would become eligible to appear as contestants. "This could produce prize money at a level never seen before in the game show industry," said Mr. Lynch. "You could have $1 million a day given away on the show."
Other magical hopes that the three states are examining are video lottery games, which could produce staggering sums of money. For the last two years, South Dakota has had video poker and keno, and Eugene Christiansen, president of Christiansen-Cummings Associates, a consulting firm that tracks the gambling business, said that "these games have stimulated the greatest increase we have ever seen in any form of gambling that we have observed since we started in 1982."
A fundamental principle of lottery strategizing is to weigh the drawbacks of worsening the odds for players against the lure of building larger jackpots. Research has shown that players covet monstrous jackpots; at the same time, they get peeved if they don't occasionally win decent money for a second or third prize.
New York has been stingier than any state in how much of its lottery sales are paid out as prizes, something sophisticated lottery players doubtlessly take into account in deciding whether they might be better off stepping into a bordering state to try their luck.
 
How New Jersey Sales Grew
 Still, because of New York's far larger population and poorer odds of winning, the biggest jackpots in the region appear in New York. The record jackpot was the $90 million awarded in January. New Jersey's biggest jackpot was $29.2 million, while Connecticut has not gotten beyond $22.7 million.
New Jersey, jealous of those bigger jackpots, restructured the prize distribution in October so that 70 percent, rather than 35 percent, of the prize pool was devoted to the top prize. (New York devotes 50 percent and Connecticut allocates 51.1 percent.) This enabled the state to vastly increase the size of its jackpot without lowering the odds of winning.
Since the change, New Jersey lotto sales gained by 15 percent and in September, the state realized its biggest jackpot. New York has been closely studying the New Jersey experience.
Because of player dissatisfaction with lower prizes, Connecticut significantly added to the prize pool for second place in 1989, as well as putting more money into first place. It tripled the average payout for getting five numbers right to about $3,000.
 
Pizzas as Booby Prizes
 Though the Connecticut lottery has fared well in per capita sales, the mood is chilly about its future. The General Assembly in Connecticut has financed a state study of legalized gambling in the state, which is due early next month. The lottery is hopeful it will supply provocative ideas to counter the constrictions of a mature lottery in a bad economy. In particular, the lottery is fretful about the debut of casino gambling when an Indian casino opens in Ledyard in February.
Lottery officials in all three states are looking at cross promotions with private companies. "We could get together with a soda company or a pizza company," Mr. Ziemak said. "The company might accept losing lottery tickets in return for 10 percent off on a pizza. And then the company would promote the lottery in its ads."
As the states broaden their lottery options, deep suspicion is likely to spread about how healthy all this is. Mr. Christiansen, the consultant, who said he doesn't gamble himself because he finds it boring, said he sees absolutely nothing wrong with lotteries and their variations, but he wonders about the motivations driving their expansion.
"It's often argued that gambling is painless taxation," Mr. Christiansen said. "I think taxation should be painful. I'm not against lotteries, but I'm not sure that trying to balance your budget by encouraging people to gamble is good government."

HEADLINE: Incumbents Hunker Down As Discontent Flies Over

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
In tiny Neptune Township, N.J., local Monmouth County Republican candidates bought time on cable television to denigrate their opponents as "Florio-type Democrats." In Harlem, a Democrat was nominated for the City Council last week after declaring that Mayor David N. Dinkins had "neglected his base." And in Bridgeport, the mayoral election has been turned into a referendum on Mayor Mary C. Moran's budgetary strategy that led Connecticut's largest city to file for bankruptcy.
"It's good to be the king," Mel Brooks said smugly, playing Louis XVI in his film "History of the World, Part 1." But in tough times, as Louis later learned, incumbency can become a fatal liability. 
 Incumbents throughout the New York region -- including some office-holders who are not even up for election -- find themselves on the defensive, although most, particularly in Democratic strongholds like New York City are considered safe. Today's off-year elections could have profound consequences in 1992 if challengers can capitalize on unassuaged voter dissatisfaction.
This year, Democratic candidates in New York have largely avoided any association with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the state's leading incumbent. But nationally, victories by political outsiders could send a powerful signal to Mr. Cuomo as he contemplates a challenge to the consummate Washington insider, President Bush.
 
47 Independents
 The strategy of attacking the ins threads through disparate local elections in New York and Connecticut and crucial races that could cost Democrats their slim majorities in both houses of the New Jersey Legislature -- 23 to 17 in the Senate and 43 to 37 in the Assembly -- for the first time in two decades. Fully 47 candidates appear on the ballot as independents -- more than four times the number who ran in 1987 without being identified as Democrats or Republicans.
In nearly every campaign, challengers are mining discontent over tax increases and service cuts that have outraged voters ravaged by a stubborn national recession that has proved to be particularly intractable in the Northeast.
In New York, mayors from Newburgh to Niagara Falls decided not to even seek re-election.
In New Jersey, Gov. Jim Florio's own name won't be on the line until 1993, but it became a Republican epithet as he emerged as the clearest target of a tax-increase backlash. He has struggled to convert the legislative races from a referendum on his $2.8 billion tax package into a vote on President Bush's domestic policies.
 
'Very, Very Bad Year'
 Patrick G. Halpin, the Democrat elected as Suffolk County Executive in an upset four years ago, is also pointing fingers upward -- at Albany and Washington -- to divert blame for Long Island's economic slump.
Paradoxically, said John A. Marino, the New York Democratic state chairman, some Republican challengers are "in better shape politically because their president has given us a national recession.
"It's a very, very bad year for incumbents," Mr. Marino added, predicting, hopefully, that voter antipathy will not abate in 1992 when a Republican United States Senator from New York and a Republican President run for re-election.
The smallest Republican gain numerically -- though larger symbolically -- may come in New York City, where reapportionment and expansion of the City Council have transformed the November election from the usual formality. Republicans are poised to expand their Council minority of one, possibly by unseating one or two incumbents on Manhattan's East Side and by capturing up to three other seats.
One of those seats is on Staten Island, where the Democratic organization formally disavowed the Mayor last week, in part to absolve its Council nominees of guilt by association. No Democratic Council member has lost a general election since 1985, and that was on Staten Island where the proportion of enrolled Republicans is higher than in any other borough.
Only one incumbent was unseated in the September primary.
Regardless of whether Republicans gain, tomorrow's special election will produce 16 more incumbents. It will transform the Council's complexion, if not its ideology, by ratifying the results of primaries that guaranteed a dramatic rise in black and Hispanic representation, from 25 percent of the current 35-member Council to about 40 percent of the 51-member body that will be inaugurated in January.
Barring upsets, the Council also will have its first Dominican member and two openly gay Councilmen.
In the region, the immediate threat is to the gains Democrats in county executive races four years ago in Suffolk and in Monroe County upstate. And the Democrats' half-century hegemony in Albany County may be jeopardized.
Thomas Frey, the first Democratic County Executive of Monroe, surrounding Rochester, even produced a television commercial that expressed his frustration over being held accountable for economic conditions beyond his control: "Did you ever know anybody who got so mad they went home and kicked their dog?" the commercial asks, as the camera pans from a labrador retriever to the county executive. "Well sometimes I know how the dog feels," Mr. Frey says.
In Westchester, the outcome of tomorrow's ballotting for the Board of Legislators could also determine who succeeds County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, a Republican who has been nominated for a Federal judgeship. His successor will be chosen by the board, which Republicans now control 10 to 7.

HEADLINE: Observer;
Polls and Quacks

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER

 BODY:
Among the many terrifying and shabby facts of modern life is the fact that our rulers never make a move without taking a public-opinion poll. In Ronald Reagan's favor let it be noted that sometimes at least he preferred the astrologer's counsel to the guidance of the poll-taker.
In this he was attuned to the wisdom of the ancients who pondered chicken entrails as well as the flight patterns of birds and asked advice of the Cumaean Sibyl, the Delphic Oracle and other such frauds before undertaking new adventures in statecraft and war. 
 For predicting the course of human behavior, quacks may be no more dependable than scientists, but a statesman relying on the latest chicken-entrail readings is apt to be less sure of himself than one under the influence of scientifically calibrated instrumentation, hence more likely to think for himself, which, after all, is what we're paying him for.
These reflections are prompted by the latest poll stating that a large majority of the population disapproves of the United States Congress.
And who elects this Congress of which a large majority of the population disapproves? Of course: a large majority of the population. Since the Congress then reflects the people who elect it, is the poll telling us that a large majority of Americans are fed up with themselves? Incapable of making choices that don't disgust them?
Of course not. The poll isn't telling us anything unless you think it news that public opinion about Congress hasn't changed from public opinion reflected 110 years ago in Eugene Field's observation: "Some statesmen go to Congress and some go to jail. It is the same thing, after all."
Being sick and tired of Congress is a traditional and honorable American state of mind, and not doing anything about it is as American as not getting carried away by gun-control fanatics every time a mass murderer lets off a heavy load of psychic steam by mowing down a dozen people or so.
Congress may hate these mass murders, but it is never stampeded by them into assaulting the constitutional right to bear the weapons that make them such an easy option for the aggrieved and maladjusted. In the same way, every two years Americans, though fed up with Congress, refuse to be stampeded into electing a new one and vote to re-elect 95 percent of the membership.
There are several explanations for this, none flattering to the kind of Americans who get surveyed by the poll-taker. One is that these disgusted masses who are fed up with Congress are fed up with everybody's Congressmen but their own, so they keep electing him.
Another is that once somebody gets elected to Congress the corrupt system of financing so vital to American political campaigns makes it impossible for an outsider to beat him; in other words, Americans can't bear to vote against anybody coarse, tasteless and brutal enough to subject them to an overwhelming assault of television commercials.
President Bush's approval by polled America is down too. Presidential popularity polls yo-yo up and down with the flow of events. With war, they rise in the usual opening surge of patriotic zeal; with unemployment, they fall, and fall, and fall.
We are now in the unemployment phase. Until it ends, count on it, the Bush yo-yo will keep dropping unless a war comes along. If Saddam Hussein is aware of the way American politics works, he might sensibly stop asking for a punch in the nose unless the American economy improves before next November.
That it might not improve before next November must be more than the Bush people can bear to contemplate. Another year in these doldrums would leave the invincible Bush looking so vincible that it might even breathe life into the Democratic Party.
Before this could happen, of course, somebody articulate and with a few ideas would have to tell the Democratic Party who it was, what it stood for and what it wanted the country to become. At present, at the Washington level, it is only an association of office-seekers, which stands for getting its members elected, and which wants the country to become a place that will quit electing Republican Presidents and now and then choose the occasional Democrat.

HEADLINE: Cars Are America's Main Form of Mass Transit

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Right Road for Transportation" (editorial, Oct. 26), you understate when you observe that the Federal transportation bill shows less appreciation for the country's changing needs than for traditional practices like building more highways and passing out more pork to individual members. The House and Senate bills fail to address the real problems except to provide funds for maintenance of highways and bridges.
The attempts by Congress to improve "mass transit" address less than .5 percent of the problem, while virtually ignoring 98 percent. According to Department of Transportation statistics for passenger-miles traveled by Americans, cars account for 86 percent; airlines 12 percent, and the remaining 2 percent takes in all forms of "mass transit," of which rail (including commuter) represents .44 percent. 
Congress fails to realize that we enjoy the most advanced mass-transit system in the world -- the private automobile, which gets you from where you are to where you want to go. And when distances are longer, you drive to the airport. Long-distance passenger rail travel is a thing of the past, no matter how fast the trains run. Magnetic levitation will not save Amtrak.
Money would be better spent improving car and air travel, which account for 98 percent of passenger miles. For example, air travel's growth has produced gridlock congestion around major airports with skyrocketing parking costs. Airport parking should primarily be for those living within the airport vicinity, with satellite parking lots within 20 to 30 miles of major airports, linked with the airports by a relatively low-cost overhead transit system. The same transit system could link the three major airports in the New York area.
For freight transportation, neither the Senate nor House bill has considered pneumatic capsule pipeline technology, which would allow common carrier freight to be moved through underground pipelines in an automated system. This would displace most of the long-haul trucks from the interstate highway system. The technology has been extensively developed, and because of projected economies this looks like the freight transportation system for the 21st century. Aside from relieving surface congestion, such systems are environmentally benign, operate with a high degree of safety and reliability, and are highly energy efficient.
The House bill states that Congress finds that "Despite annual expenditures in excess of $10 billion on surface transportation and its infrastructure, the Federal Government has not developed a clear vision of how the surface transportation system of the 21st century will differ from the present." Congress has overlooked moving freight underground through pipelines. The Soviet Union has about a dozen such underground freight transport systems operating today, and the number is growing.
 
JOHN A. BRADLEY
New York, Oct. 29, 1991
 
The writer is a management consultant in distribution of goods.

HEADLINE: Our Diplomats Need Lessons in Diplomacy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your account of the behavior in Japan of David C. Mulford, Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, who harshly criticized the Japanese on financial regulation (Business Day, Oct. 18), raises questions about the training that American diplomats and officials receive. Presumably, Mr. Mulford was in Japan at the invitation of the Japanese Government. His performance was a remarkable example of cultural insensitivity.
I have no doubt that Mr. Mulford, and others of his kind, have been well schooled in the traditional disciplines of economics, political science and history. The students of their generation functioned in a much more homogenous world, dominated by Anglo-European concepts of diplomacy and international relations. The world has changed and, like it or not, the balance has tilted. The players now adhere to a variety of cultural concepts and norms.
If the United States is to remain a respected and central player, it will have to come to terms with the new internationalized workplace. Likewise, the training its players receive will need to reflect these changes. International studies programs in many colleges recognize this trend. Their curriculum goes beyond the traditional political and economic base to provide training in crosscultural communication and an appreciation of the diverse value systems at play in the world.
It is time our political decision makers caught up with the younger generation.
 
MARINA W. FERNANDO
Pelham Manor, N.Y., Oct. 20, 1991
 
The writer directs the international studies program at City College.
