HEADLINE: Economic Trend for 90's: Fear;
Grappling With Tough Times on Long Island

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 4

 BODY:
It is hard to pinpoint, but sometime in the last year economic fear took deep root in New York's suburbs. William Butler, head of the state unemployment office in Hempstead, saw it by March. "We had so many white collar professionals coming in," he says, "we didn't know what to do with them." He started job-search seminars, but couldn't keep up. The waiting list is now a month. Last week's seminar included a lawyer, an accountant, three teachers, four engineers and a company vice president.
In the suburban malls -- where there is no weather -- everyone talks about the economy. "It's the main thing I discuss with friends," Seth Rosenthal, a Macy's manager, was saying at the Roosevelt Field mall in Carle Place, L.I. "We were talking about this before Judge Thomas, and we're talking about it now." 
 It is there in the numbers: Unemployment in New York's suburbs has nearly doubled in the last year, from roughly 3 to 6 percent, going as high as 7.8 percent in Suffolk County; Long Island is losing jobs for only the second time since the state began keeping statistics in 1958; the Federal bankruptcy court in Westbury, L.I., had 15,000 filings by the end of October this year, compared with 11,600 for all 1990 and 6,000 in 1986.
Economic fear drives people to do things they wouldn't do in better times. Last month Peter Daraio, principal of Clara Carlson Elementary School in Elmont, L.I., reported to the Federal authorities two illegal immigrants: children who had come to register at his school. Though he was criticized by refugee advocates and Hispanic groups and told not to do it again by his superintendent, he had no apologies. "We can't go on taking care of the world," he says. "We're not in good shape. When I came to this school seven years ago, we had one teacher for every 15 or 16 kids in primary grades. Now with budget constraints, it's one for 28."
The Elmont district, which borders Queens and is far more integrated than most Long Island districts (about half minority), has hired investigators to make sure that students from New York City are not sneaking into the schools. "Each year 10 to 15 students who want a better education are tossed out of my school and sent back to Queens," Mr. Daraio said. "And here we have illegal aliens, and we must give them space. That doesn't make sense to me."
 
'Very, Very Bad Here'
 Rita Mezzapelle, who runs the Elmont Herald (circulation 5,200) from the den of her five-room Cape Cod, wrote an article about the burdens illegal immigrants put on taxpayers, right after receiving a $400 increase in her school tax bill. She was angry when the Federal authorities said they did not have staff to go after the immigrant family, which had since disappeared. If Federal law requires illegal immigrants to be educated, Ms. Mezzapelle said, the "education President" ought to supply more money. "Things are very, very bad here," she said. "I've been putting out the paper since 1978, and I've never had more than one legal notice of a foreclosure. In the edition I'm doing now, I have four foreclosures. No, I missed one -- five. Five!"
The Renards, at 6 Diamond Street, are one of those foreclosures. They bought their three-bedroom house six years ago for $165,000. When the economy boomed, Duverna Renard took the profits from his two taxis and invested in a limousine service. He lost the limo service, and when he tried to make up the money through the taxis, the recession had hit. "The gulf war killed me," he says. "People stopped flying. You'd wait hours at the airport for a fare."
Elmont is primarily a middle-class and blue-collar suburb, but there is plenty of fear and loathing, too, in Huntington, L.I., an upper-middle-class town that is venting its spleen at a cable company. Since deregulation, cable companies have operated in each town as virtually unchecked monopolies. There have been periodic uprisings on Long Island against Cablevision, the major supplier here, but nothing with the broad support of the current Huntington outburst.
It started when Cablevision announced that it would modernize the town's system at no charge. On the surface that sounded great, but in practice it meant that subscribers who on their own had hooked up a second television to cable would now have to pay an extra $7 monthly for that additional set.
Before long, the town hall was crammed with angry citizens; Democrats and Republicans had found a common enemy. Two propositions are on Tuesday's ballot asking voters if they'd like to kick out Cablevision. Never mind that Cablevision backed down, making the modernization optional for each subscriber. Never mind that the state cable commission calls the referendum illegal.
"It has lots to do with the economy," said Thomas Sinnickson, counsel for Huntington's recently formed cable committee. "In boom times you could justify paying $40, $50 a month on cable. Now -- you know what it is? Everybody's on edge. And the edge is, you don't know if it'll ever come back."
Mr. Sinnickson sounds like a 60's radical when he speaks of cable: "Cable operators as a whole have become pigs! With no competition they gorge themselves in greed!" He's a Republican.
The particulars for each suburban region differ, but the end point is the same. On Long Island, says Gary Huth, a state economist, it started with layoffs by military contractors, then the real estate and construction industries, retail sales, banking, insurance and most recently, government. "Health services are strong," he said. The good news is that people continue to get sick.
 
Lulls and Layoffs
 Frank Cohen, 66 years old, of Long Beach, L.I., has been in the tire business most of his life. He knows idle trucks don't wear out tires. "Everyone's hurting," he says. "You understand Yiddish? Right now there are no big machers." And furthermore: "I reiterate, no big machers!" He is angrier. "Yeah, you hate the people you hate more." In Mr. Cohen's case, that's former President Reagan and President Bush. ("What's he doing traveling around the world?") Other people suburbanites hate more are their Governor, the Democratic Congress, "those damn politicians," inhumane bosses and themselves.
A year ago Kathy Jackson moved to Great Neck, L.I., and within three days found a job as a legal secretary for $28,000. She types 65 words a minute, knows six word-processing programs, has 15 years' experience. Last spring things got slow at the firm. She's been out five months now and has no savings. The unemployment checks stop this week.
Last year Terry McQuade, who made $40,000 with overtime in building operations for Merrill Lynch, and his wife, a computer operator, bought a house in Elmont. A few months later he was dismissed, and he hasn't been able to land steady work since. He puts on one of his three blue suits and walks up and down Manhattan, dropping off resumes, hoping a personal visit will make an impression. "A lot of companies I couldn't get by security. I tried." It's hard making his monthly mortgage payment of $1,637. "Hard? I've gone into all my cash advances on my credit cards. It's destroying my marriage."
 
Support Groups for Jobless
 There are so many support groups for unemployed professionals in Connecticut -- at least 50 -- that they now hold a statewide gathering on the first Saturday each month in Ridgefield. Robert Lobman, a computer systems expert who has made as much as $110,000 yearly, lives in Wantagh, L.I., but drove to Saturday's meeting with two other men from Long Island. He goes to unemployment support groups nearly every day. On Monday nights he runs his own group in Wantagh. Tuesdays he attends meetings for unemployed computer specialists at Le Bistro in Elmwood Park, N.J. (The restaurant donates a dining room; to save money, the group doesn't eat.) Wednesdays he attends a group in Rye, N.Y., one of Westchester County's wealthiest suburbs.
"I'm busy, so I keep an 'up' attitude," said Mr. Lobman, who has been out of work for 16 months. "The less busy you are, the worse you get. It feeds on itself. I refuse to be embarrassed. I have two people on my block unemployed, they won't come to our group. They don't want anyone to know."
One of the most telling images of the Great Depression is a Walker Evans photo of a line of unemployed men and women standing in front of a billboard advertising new cars. For the 90's recession, the proper visual would be men and women alone in their suburban kitchens, using their touch-tone telephones to tell a computer they're still out of work.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Capital Crunch: Capitol Quandary

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
IS the credit crunch real? Are banks denying creditworthy businesses the loans they need to invest the economy out of the recession?
The idea certainly appeals to the White House, which is in hot pursuit of a villain or three to explain why the stalled recovery is not the President's fault. But many economists remain skeptical. The fall in the volume of bank loans, they point out, could be explained equally well by a recession-induced decline in the demand for credit. 
 Or at least it could until now. Minds are bound to be changed by the release of the first serious analysis of the crunch hypothesis, by Ben Bernanke of Princeton University and Cara Lown of the New York Federal Reserve Bank. The study, to be published in the January issue of the Brookings Papers on Economic Activity, confirms that a scarcity of bank capital has indeed affected the supply of loans. But the two economists believe that the full weight has been felt only in the Northeast. And they say the impact on jobs and incomes may be smaller than anecdotes of businesses' drying up for want of liquidity would suggest.
Everyone agrees that the banks have been bloodied by losses on business loans in general, and commercial real estate in particular. Everyone agrees that the timing of losses could not have been more awkward, since banks are under orders to beef up their stockholders' capital to comply with an international agreement signed by regulators in 1988.
But while the experts also agree that the fall in lending during this recession has been exceptionally severe, most acknowledge that the decline does not amount to proof that financially sound loan applicants have been given the bums' rush. It is possible that businesses have been inclined to borrow less than usual during this recession because they are carrying smaller inventories -- and because many overdosed on debt during the long boom of the 1980's.
But the Bernanke-Lown research blows away the case for a pure "demand-side" credit bust. They use simple statistical techniques to show that roughly half the state-to-state variations in the rate of change of business loans during this recession can be explained by parallel changes in bank stockholders' capital. New England has been hit hardest, with an 18 percent drop in commercial and industrial loans. Only the Pacific states have been spared a net decline in business lending.
Mr. Bernanke and Ms. Lown are quick to add that the reality of the bank credit crunch does not necessarily mean that the crunch is a principal cause of the economy's current woes. Most businesses look to alternative sources of finance when banks reject their loan applications. And if the crunch were severe, the two economists argue, one would have expected a surge in loans from insurance companies and non-bank finance companies, as well as increased sales of short-term corporate debt called commercial paper. In fact, the growth in alternative financing has been tepid, leading the two economists to conclude that demand for loans has cooled in tandem with the supply.
This latter point does not impress Ben Friedman, an economist at Harvard who was asked by Brookings to analyze the Bernanke-Lown results. The lack of an upturn in non-bank financing, he notes, may simply be because non-bank lenders are suffering a capital shortage of their own. Certainly, life insurers and the big industrial lenders like Westinghouse are in no position to profit from the banks' woes. Nor, in light of the perilous state of the junk bond market, is it plausible to assume that less-than-blue-chip companies can sell commercial paper.
Mr. Friedman also takes issue with the Bernanke-Lown view that the crunch has not reduced the Federal Reserve's room for monetary maneuver because, one way or another, the Fed's purchases of Government securities from the private market will still depress interest rates. The Harvard economist believes that blockage of the primary route to money creation, increased bank lending, could certainly slow down this process and limit its impact on business activity.
The least disputed implication of the research is perhaps the least expected. If Mr. Bernanke and Ms. Lown are to be believed, banks in New England are not making business loans as they otherwise would if they had a plumper cushion of capital. But the Federal prohibition on interstate banking stops better-endowed lenders from other parts of the country from coming to the rescue. New Englanders, it seems, are paying a hefty price for Washington's inclination to protect the turf of all those friendly neighborhood banks.

HEADLINE: Pushing Video in the Film Capital

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 5

 BODY:
The technological revolution they once hoped to bring to Hollywood has not yet arrived, but the Japanese companies with stakes in the entertainment industry are starting to attract attention with advanced video systems that might soon change the way movies and television shows are made.
The new high-definition video systems, which can record and display images in much sharper detail than current video technology, are perhaps best known to consumers as the basis for the next generation of television sets. But the Japanese companies with the greatest involvement in Hollywood, including Sony and Matsushita, are also promoting high-definition video as a breakthrough for film editing and special effects and ultimately as a new movie-making medium. 
 The Japanese are already seeing some results. The director Francis Ford Coppola recently used Japanese high-definition cameras and videotape to shoot screen tests for his next movie, "Dracula." The Walt Disney Company is using the process to help create special effects for the sequel to "Honey I Shrunk the Kids."
The technology was also used in making a commercial for Michael Jackson's forthcoming album, "Dangerous," and in production of "Prospero's Books," a recently released film based on Shakespeare's "The Tempest."
"These tools are going to make the movies of the future," Mr. Coppola told a conference on high-definition video technology earlier this year.
But many other directors and cinematographers remain more skeptical about high-definition video's value to them, and almost no one foresees it taking the place of 35-millimeter film any time soon.
Film makers say that for all the crystal clarity of the images it produces, high-definition video cannot come close to film's ability to capture the moods, the richness of color, the contrasts and shadings that collectively give a story visual life.
And 35-millimeter color film technology, the industry standard for six decades, has advanced significantly in recent years, giving movie makers considerably more flexibility in creating visual images. Competitive pressure from the Japanese high-definition video systems has also led the Eastman Kodak Company, the leading supplier of film to Hollywood, and other companies to develop sophisticated new editing and special- effects technology of their own.
High-definition video "is desperately trying to solve a need in the motion picture industry that simply doesn't exist," said Harry Mathias, a cinematographer who has studied and written about the new process.
 
Special Uses, Initially
 Recognizing that movie makers are not rushing to dump 35-millimeter film, the proponents of the new technology are concentrating for now on its advantages as a tool for special effects and editing. Editing videotape is far less costly and time consuming than editing film, and some studio executives are advocating the transfer of movies from film to high-definition tape for editing, and then back to film again for theatrical distribution.
In special effects, high-definition systems make it much easier to meld images from different sources into a seamless picture -- combining a background shot on film, for example, with an effect generated by a computer.
 
Patient Optimism by the Japanese
 The Japanese companies say that they are taking a long-term view, and that ultimately the technology will play a major role in Hollywood. The Sony Corporation has gone so far as to open a high-definition video laboratory in the middle of the lot of Columbia Pictures, the studio that Sony acquired two years ago. The lab is just steps from where technology-minded film makers like Steven Spielberg have been making movies.
Sony has been the most visible proponent in Hollywood of high-definition video. The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, which last year acquired MCA Inc. and MCA's Universal Pictures studio, is also promoting the technology. So are several other Japanese companies with Hollywood ties, including NHK, Japan's state-run broadcaster. On Nov. 25, NHK plans to increase its broadcasting of high-definition television from the current one hour a day to eight.
Thomas Pollock, the head of MCA's motion picture group, said of the promotional efforts, "We're trying to educate people in the community and ourselves as to what you can do and can't do, and trying to educate the manufacturers, Matsushita and others, as to what film makers need to use this technology."
That Japan's initial influence on Hollywood is turning out to be more technological than creative is in keeping with the rationale offered by Sony and Matsushita when they bought the American studios.
Each company said it wanted a library of existing movies and television shows and a steady output of new entertainment "software" that could be shown on the high-definition television sets and other "hardware" they were developing. And they clearly saw Hollywood as an ideal proving ground for the potential of high-definition video.
Their vision was that television shows and movies could both be shot on high-definition videotape, broadcast to high-definition television sets or played on high-definition videocassette recorders in homes, and one day shown through high-definition projection systems in theaters.
Even the technology's boosters acknowledge, however, that the future is arriving more slowly than they had hoped.
The technology has been hindered by disagreements among Japan, the United States and Europe about what technical standard to adopt for high-definition broadcasting.
Some experts have argued that it is not worth investing billions of dollars in high-definition systems when an entirely new generation of video, based on digital technology, is likely to develop in the near future. In a digital video system, the image would be translated into a binary code of 0's and 1's that would let the picture be stored, manipulated and transmitted in the same manner as computer data.
And even though high-definition video has its advantages in editing and special effects, it is encountering stiffer-than-expected competition. Eastman Kodak last month introduced a system that uses powerful computers to transfer filmed images to a digital form. That allows those images to be manipulated or melded with other material to create the desired effects. The sequences can then be transferred back to film or to videotape.
To date, only one full-length feature movie has been shot in high-definition video -- "Julia and Julia," starring Kathleen Turner, which was released in 1988. The movie was shot by the Italian television network RAI and then transferred to film for theatrical distribution. The movie generally received poor reviews and sank with barely a ripple at the box office.
Executives at the Japanese-owned studios still insist that their technology will improve enough that shooting, editing and even projecting movies in high definition will one day make both artistic and economic sense.
"Creating feature films shot in HD is problematic, but possible still," said Sidney Ganis, an executive vice president of Sony Pictures Entertainment, the parent company for Columbia.
"In the meantime," he added, "the technology is proving extremely useful to the creative community. It has people intrigued, and it has people using it."

HEADLINE: Bush Seems to Oppose Tax Cut This Year

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Apparently ending any chance that the Administration would offer a plan this year to spur economic recovery through tax cuts, President Bush warned today that such action could prove counterproductive by driving interest rates "through the roof."
While insisting that he had not yet made up his mind, the President was seen as now firmly in the camp of advisers, including Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and the White House budget director, Richard G. Darman, who oppose tax cuts on the ground that a Congress controlled by Democrats could turn any fiscal initiative to their political advantage by simply increasing any benefits that Mr. Bush proposes. Mr. Darman said Monday that the Administration had decided to postpone any action until next year. 
 Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher, Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp and Vice President Dan Quayle have been urging Mr. Bush to propose cutting capital gains and other taxes to demonstrate engagement on the home front as the economic recovery loses momentum.
"What I don't want to do is come up with a growth package that just further burdens the American taxpayer, and I'm not going to do that," Mr. Bush said at a picture-taking session at the White House. "So some of these suggestions that shoot the long-term interest rates right out through the roof are simply unacceptable."
One Democratic measure, proposed by Lloyd Bentsen, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, would give families a $300 tax credit for each child. Another, offered by Senator Albert Gore and Representative Thomas Downey, would cut tax rates for middle-income Americans and impose a surtax on the rich.
The White House seems to have been impressed with negative reaction in the bond market when tax-cutting was broached by Democratic leaders in late October. Interest rates jumped, reflecting fears of higher budget deficits and revived inflation.
Mr. Bush expressed his own concern about this today, referring to what he called "the idea of getting broad tax cuts without regard as to what it does to long-term interest rates and the budget agreement." The budget deal struck with Congressional Democrats last autumn provided, among other things, that any new tax breaks must be offset by revenue increases elsewhere or by a decrease in Government spending.
The Administration has had on the table all year various measures, including a capital gains cut and expanded deductions for individual retirement accounts, that it contends would stimulate the economy without breaking the agreement.
Today's comments, however, were not seen as ruling out more aggressive efforts next year, when electoral pressures will intensify.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Rate Uncertainty Leaves The Dollar Little Changed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was little changed yesterday as the expectation of lower interest rates in the United States cast a pall over the foreign exchange markets.
Gold prices were lower, slipping $2.70 on the Commodity Exchange in New York, to $354.10 an ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $354.10, down $2.30. 
 Few traders want to stake out big positions in the currency markets because they expect the Federal Reserve to push interest rates lower soon. A decline in interest rates would make United States Government securities and other dollar-denominated investments less attractive, thus lowering demand for the American currency.
Some analysts had expected the Fed to move before yesterday, when the Treasury began a three-day auction of new securities. But the central bank did not act, and no move is expected until Friday at the earliest -- after the current round of refinancing.
Most of the dollar buying yesterday was technical, pushing the currency up marginally against some major currencies.
The dollar rose to 130.025 yen in New York, from 129.185 late on Monday. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 129.38 yen, down from 130.74 on Friday. The Tokyo markets were closed on Monday for Culture Day, a national holiday. In London late yesterday, the American currency was quoted at a higher rate of 129.80 yen.
The British pound fell against the dollar. In New York, sterling edged down to $1.7725, from $1.7740 on Monday, and in earlier London trading, it fell to $1.7695 from $1.7810.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.6385 German marks, unchanged; 1.4455 Swiss francs, up from 1.4425; 5.6020 French francs, up from 5.5600; 1,228.00 Italian lire, up from 1,227.00, and 1.12065 Canadian dollars, down from 1.12135.
Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $356.40 an ounce, down from $356.60 late on Monday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $356.50 from $356.30. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold closed at $356.64, down from $356.85 late on Monday.
Silver dropped 1.9 cents on the Commodity Exchange, closing at $4.048 an ounce. Silver rose in London to a late bid of $4.09, compared with $4.08 late on Monday.

HEADLINE: Blue-Chip Issues Fall, With Dow Off 14.31

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks fell in choppy trading yesterday, but the broad market was stronger. The Dow Jones industrial average was off by 14.31 points, to 3,031.31, with a decline for Walt Disney accounting for more than half the loss.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was a moderate 172.1 million shares, up from 155.7 million on Monday. Declining issues had a small lead on gainers by 869 to 763. Trading on the Big Board pulled the composite down 0.75, to 214.68. 
 The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 1.57, to 388.71, while the American Stock Exchange Composite gained 0.84 to close at 384.94.
In Nasdaq trading, the composite index rose 1.32, to 538.82, while the Russell 2000, a measure of smaller stocks, inched up 0.10, to 183.96.
Ricky Harrington, director of equity investment for Marion Bass Securities, saw the market testing its support level of 3,000. And one obvious test at that level will be the Treasury's quarterly refunding, he noted.
"When the word got around about the disappointing three-year note auction yesterday, the stock market, which was dead even up until then, followed the bond market down," he said. "This may translate into problems possibly with the 10-year note and 30-year bond auctions to follow today and tomorrow. As a result, there is a risk that interest rates may turn higher and in turn put pressure on the economy and the stock market."
"If the market does not break below the 3,000 level in the next few days, we may be due for a further rally going into Thanksgiving," Mr. Harrington said.
 
Tracking Program Trades
 Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trades, said there were two buy programs in the morning and five program sells in the afternoon. The total impact on the Dow pulled it down 19.31 points.
Disney was down as Richard F. Simon an analyst at Goldman, Sachs, lowered his earnings estimate and removed the company from the recommend list. Trading on the stock was delayed earlier in the day, as the stock closed down 4 5/8 to finish at 113 3/4.

HEADLINE: The Mixed Blessing of Empty Bins

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONTEREY, Ind.

 BODY:
A quiet yet radical change in American agricultural policy has largely eliminated the mountainous food stockpiles of the mid-1980's. But the new policies, of reducing price supports and subsidizing exports, have devastated the grain storage industry and angered other grain-exporting countries.
By encouraging farmers to grow less food and send more of what they do produce overseas, the Federal Government has mostly quit the expensive business of storing huge supplies of grain. Poor harvests in the last two years also contributed to clearing out stockpiles. Reserves are now so low that the Agriculture Department may soon start giving cash subsidies to exporters instead of free grain and dairy products. 
 The trend toward smaller stockpiles has been masked because the Government keeps separate statistics for each type of food. But when added, these figures show that Government-owned stores of grain and soybeans have plummeted by more than four-fifths in the last four years, to 561 million bushels this year.
 
A Giant Bin Is Empty
 The effects of those dwindling stockpiles are starkly visible at the grain elevator here in Monterey, a town of 230 people 36 miles southwest of South Bend.
Four years ago a tarpaulin here extended from the top of a 40-foot pole down to a circular wood fence and covered a million bushels of Government-owned corn. Today the pole and fence remain, but the tarpaulin is gone, and this temporary storage bin, like hundreds of others scattered across the Midwest, stands unused.
Nationwide, the stockpiles of cheese, honey and cotton have also shrunk, while only the stores of butter and dry milk have risen, a result of low market prices for these dairy products.
And grain-exporting countries like Australia, Brazil and Canada complain bitterly that they are losing markets to subsidized exports from the United States and Europe.
The policy shift has helped taxpayers by reducing the direct cost of supporting the nation's farmers to about $10 billion in the fiscal year that began last month from $14 billion in the 1987 fiscal year.
The Government paid $1.1 billion during the 1987 fiscal year to grain elevators for storage. For the fiscal year that ended on Sept. 30 about $251 million was paid, and the estimate on payments for the current fiscal year is $142 million.
The new policy has, however, hurt grain elevators and it may have made food prices more volatile.
Government stockpiles can be sold only when grain prices reach fairly high levels. Large supplies, as during the 1988 drought, tend to moderate any big rise in grain prices, said Darrel L. Good, a professor of agricultural economics at the University of Illinois at Urbana.
"If we'd had the current stocks in 1988, then I'm convinced prices would have gone higher than they did," he added.
The poor crops in the last two years, combined with low stockpiles, could lead to a leap in prices, said Carol G. Brookins, the president of World Perspectives Inc., a Washington agriculture consulting firm.
Agriculture Secretary Edward R. Madigan said in an interview that he was not concerned about a possible shortfall because he had ordered that less land be held out of grain production next year than this year. "It has been a goal of the Administration to reduce those stockpiles," he said, "because large stockpiles have a very depressive effect on market prices for farmers' commodities."
Stockpiles ballooned in the mid-1980's because the Government allowed farmers to repay many loans with grain that was valued at far above the market price. In 1985, for example, farmers could sell corn on the open market at about $2.23 a bushel, and use the cash to pay off their Government loans. Or, they could give their corn directly to the Government, which counted each bushel as a payment of $2.55.
Now, the loan price supports are well below the market price for most commodities. Corn, for example, earns a credit of just $1.57 a bushel, as against the $2.41 cash price available in Monterey.
 
A Troubled Industry
 With all the changes, the grain elevator industry is going through a wrenching contraction.
Grain elevators deal directly with farmers and make money by shelling, drying, and either storing or trading grain. Most are privately owned, so figures on revenues and profits are hard to obtain. But the National Grain and Feed Association, a Washington-based trade group, says the nation's elevators have gone from being three-fifths full in 1987 to less than a third full this year.
Temporary bins across the United States are being abandoned, and the industry is struggling to keep its silos and permanent bins in operation. Some elevators are now operated only during the harvest season. A few permanent bins, which resemble long sheds with metal roofs or giant metal tanks, are even being used to raise hogs or have been partitioned to create personal storage areas for rent, said Kendell W. Keith, the association's executive vice president.
"Sometimes they're just abandoned because the revenues don't justify the costs of operating," he added.
 
One Elevator's Story
 At the Buckeye Ag-Center elevator in Monterey, much of the revenue and most of the profits during the mid-1980's came from the storage of Government grain. During that time, the grain elevator continued to buy some farmers' grain and either load it into railroad cars for shipment or store it for delivery at a higher future price. But much of the local farmers' grain was taken by the Government at steep market-support prices and stored in two permanent storage bins, built in 1983, and a temporary bin, built in 1986.
For the elevator operators, storing the Government's corn meant removing any remaining corn cobs with a shelling machine, drying the kernels with hot air in large metal cylinders to prevent decay, pumping the kernels into the storage bins and then collecting quarterly checks for years.
For them, the arrangement was almost as easy as holding Government bonds, and so lucrative that the temporary bin paid for itself in a year and a half, said Don Smolek, the grain manager here, who added that the elevator is breaking even now.
The grain "came in, and we clipped coupons," he said of the Government storage program.
 
The Effects of Change
 Now, the shrinkage of stockpiles has left a lot of extra storage room, so the Government and private owners are paying less per bushel to store less grain. In addition, many farmers now own big trucks that allow them to carry their crops economically over greater distances to the elevator offering the highest price.
International negotiations aimed at ending the competitive use of export subsidies could, if successful, increase exports and cause grain production to increase. But even this would only slow, and not reverse, the elevator industry's broad decline, experts agree.
"We're still going to have a reduction, but if we have full production then we'll have a more orderly reduction," said Donald G. Brouillette, the majority owner, chairman and chief executive of privately held Demeter Inc., which owns 23 grain elevators in three states and is based in Fowler, Ind., 55 miles southwest of Monterey.
There are 13 mostly aging grain elevators around Fowler, but the region could be served by just two large modern elevators, Mr. Brouillette said, adding that he is considering operating some of his elevators only during harvest season because of weak demand. "It hasn't been nearly as lucrative because there are too many people scrambling for too few bushels," he added.

HEADLINE: Bank Funds and C.D.'s Fall

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on deposit accounts fell sharply again this week in anticipation of further easing of interest rates by the Federal Reserve, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, a trade publication that covers interest rates.
"Deposit yields on savings accounts will be directly affected by whether the banks lower their prime rate by one-half point or by one-quarter point of 1 percent if the Federal Reserve cuts its discount rate a half-point," said Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Bank Rate Monitor. "If the banks do not match the Federal Reserve reduction, in essence they would be pocketing the difference at the consumer-borrower's expense." 
 Outside of the New York area, the commercial bank cutting its money market fund by the largest amounts was Seafirst of Seattle, which cut the yield offered as of today to 4.08 percent from 5.13 percent.
In the New York area, the largest cut among commercial banks was made by First Fidelity Bank of New Jersey., which cut its money market account by 35 points, to 4.50 percent. A point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
First Nationwide, a unit of the First Nationwide Financial Corporation, which is a subsidiary of the Ford Motor Corporation, was the savings bank that cut its three-month and six-month rates the most. The three-month certificate of deposit was lowered by 35 basis points, to 4.50 percent, and the six-month certificate of deposit was lowered 35 points, to 4.75 percent.
At New York commercial banks, the average yield on money market accounts was cut by 9 points, to 4.55 for money market accounts, while the average yields on three-month and six-month certificates were 4.68, and 4.77 percent, respectively.
At savings institutions in the New York area, yields on money market accounts were cut to 5.16 percent, down 2 basis points; 5.22 percent for three-month certificates, down 5 basis points, and 5.44 percent for six-month certificates, down 5 basis points.
The Bank Rate Monitor said the average yields on money market accounts at 20 big banks outside the New York area were cut by 12 basis points, to 4.71 percent, and by 7 basispoints, to 5.03 percent, on six-month certificates.
By comparison, at the Treasury's weekly bill auction on Monday the three-month bill was auctioned at an average discount rate of 4.74, compared with 4.99 a week earlier. The six-month bill averaged 4.80 percent, compared with 5.04 a week earlier.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
3-Year Note Auction Goes Badly

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The first Treasury debt sale under new auction guidelines imposed in the wake of the Salomon Brothers bidding scandal went extremely poorly yesterday, as the Government struggled to sell $14 billion worth of new three-year notes.
Traders and analysts cited a number of reasons for the poor auction. But all agreed that it would cost the Treasury -- and the taxpayer -- well over $120 million in higher interest over the life of the securities sold yesterday. 
 Aside from an adverse reaction by primary dealers in Government securities to the new rules, traders said that the low level of short-term market rates and disappointment that the Federal Reserve Board did not move to cut key interest rates yesterday contributed to the poor results.
 
Watching Fed Policy
 Continued signs of economic weakness had led some traders and analysts to believe that the central bank, whose policy-making Open Market Committee met in Washington yesterday, might decide to lower the overnight Federal funds rate to 4 3/4 percent from its current target of 5 percent before the refunding auctions began.
The auction had a negative impact in the secondary market for Treasury notes and bonds, where prices fell sharply, and interest rates rose after the results were announced.
The new securities were sold at an average yield of 6.00 percent, down from an average yield of 6.92 percent at the last three-year note sale on Aug. 8.
The poor reception given the notes was visible in an unusually wide discrepancy between high and low bids placed for the securities and the total amount of bids placed at the auction.
 
Less Efficiency Perceived
 The spread, or difference, between high and low bids -- an indicator of how efficient the price discovery mechanism has been at the auction -- was an unusually wide 6 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. At previous three-year note auctions a spread of 1 or 2 basis points has been the norm.
Moreover, the Treasury received only $21.7 billion worth of bids for the $14 billion worth of securities sold, the lowest total of bids placed at a three-year auction since 1978. In recent three-year note auctions, total bids have amounted to $40 billion or more.
Traders and analysts said the low total was at least partly a protest by primary dealers against the new auction rules.
"This was probably the worst auction in the last 10 years," one government securities trader said. "Low short-term rates probably had a good deal to do with the results. But there may have been a sort of coordinated protest on the part of the dealers, too. And it has cost the taxpayer money."
The new auction guidelines, announced Oct. 26, were intended to open up the bidding process to brokers who have not been designated as primary dealers in Government securities by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
The rule changes were made in response to the bidding violations disclosed by Salomon Brothers in August. Previously, firms wishing to place bids at Treasury auctions did so through the primary dealers, a group of 39 securities firms and banks.
"The trend in Washington is to chip away at differences between primary dealers and non-primary dealers," said Louis v.B. Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates, an economic consulting firm. "But if you chip away all the differences then the dealers won't be there. These auction results serve as a reminder to the Treasury that something quite specific is gained from the commitment dealers make to backstop Treasury auctions."
 
Only a Rational Response
 Raymond W. Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that provides research and commentary on developments in the foreign exchange and credit markets, said the reaction by primary dealers was not a protest, but merely a rational reflection of how the rule changes have increased the risk and lowered the reward for primary dealers bidding at the auctions.
"Rather than a protest, I think this is a natural response on the part of primary dealers to the change in incentives," Mr. Stone said.
Jay Powell, the Treasury's Assistant Secretary for domestic finance, said in a telephone interview: "We had an auction that was not as successful as we had hoped, But we find it a little far-fetched that the kind of rule changes we made would have a material effect on an auction."
The debt sale was the first leg of the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions, which continue today and tomorrow with the sale of a total of $24 billion worth of new 10-year notes and 30-year bonds.
Analysts said the results of the much less speculative three-year note auction cast doubt on how large demand would be for the securities.
Late yesterday the new 10-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.53 percent, up sharply from 7.47 percent late Monday.
Traders in the secondary market for Treasury securities responded to yesterday's results by pushing prices of outstanding notes and bonds down sharply.
By late in the day, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 101 1/8, down more than a point, or more than $10 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, to yield 8.02 percent, compared with 7.95 percent late Monday.
Among note issues, the 6 7/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 3/8, down 9/32, to yield 6.78 percent. And the 6 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 18/32, down 1/8 point, to yield 5.69 percent.
 
Bill Rates Are Up
 Late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 4.74 percent, up 2 basis points. And six-month bill rates rose by a basis point, to a late offered rate of 4.79 percent.
Fears that interest rates may have bottomed prompted a number of investment-grade corporations to price new debt issues.
Among the issuers was Sears, Roebuck & Company, which sold a total of $900 million worth 3- 7- and 20-year securities through and underwriting group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
Yields on the securities ranged from 7.08 percent on the three-year notes to 9 3/8 percent on the 20-year securities.
The issue is rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by Standard & Poor's.
Salomon Brothers acted as lead manager for an offering of $542 million worth of securities backed by auto loan receipts from a financing entity of the Chrysler Corporation.
The 6.25 percent securities, which have an average life of 1.8 years, were priced at $99.637 to yield 6.55 percent, 85 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 percent two-year notes at the time of pricing.
The issue is rated triple-Aby both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
 
Popular High-Yield Issue
 In the high-yield junk bond market, the Maxxam Group priced a $130 million offering of four-year notes through an underwriting group led by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
The 12 3/4 percent notes were priced at $99, to yield 13.08 percent.
Due to strong demand, the size of the issue was increased from $100 million. The securities are rated B-2 by Moody's and B-minus by Standard & Poor's.
The slide in Treasury prices had a negative impact on prices of secondary issues in the investment-grade and tax-exempt municipal bond markets.
Corporate traders said prices of most issues had fallen by anywhere from 1/4 point to 3/8 point.
Meanwhile, prices of widely quoted issues in the secondary municipal bond market slipped by 1/8 point to 1/4 point, market participants said.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Grains and Soybeans Drop On Doubts Over Soviet Aid

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Grain and soybean futures prices fell yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid flagging hopes for an announcement soon on new United States food aid to the Soviet Union.
Wheat for delivery in December dropped 1/2 cent to settle at $3.62 1/2 a bushel; December corn fell 2 1/2 cents, to $2.49 1/4 a bushel; December oats fell 1 1/2 cents, to $1.30 1/4 a bushel, and November soybeans slipped 3/4 cent, to $5.63 a bushel. 
 Last week's expectations for an imminent award of Soviet food aid approaching $3.5 billion have given way to perceptions that President Bush is reluctant to propose such a large package to a Congress preoccupied with domestic economic woes.
President Bush said yesterday that he planned to discuss a possible Soviet aid package with his economic advisers but did not indicate when an announcement would be made.
"The United States has always tried to be of assistance to people who are really truly hurting, but there's certainly some constraints on what the United States can do right now because of our own budget problems," he said.
Prospects for a multibillion-dollar Soviet aid package heavily weighted toward livestock feed helped corn and soybean prices last week. But some analysts now doubt the White House will offer more than $1 billion in export loan guarantees.
"We aren't seeing anything in the market to push it toward the positive side except these credits, and any kind of delay is just pushing us toward a weaker tone," said Jason Roose, a broker with U.S. Commodities Inc. in Des Moines.
A further drop of 5 cents in the corn market would likely start heavy selling by traders who bought into the market during the last two weeks on speculation that a Soviet aid announcement was just around the corner, said Katharina Zimmer, a grain analysts with Merrill Lynch Capital Markets Inc.
Orange juice futures rose sharply for the third straight day on the New York Cotton Exchange on news of price increases by Brazilian processors and exporters of frozen concentrated orange juice. Brazil supplies about 25 percent of the American orange juice market.
November deliveries of frozen concentrated orange juice surged 3.95 cents in New York to $1.722 a pound.
Crude oil was little changed on the New York Mercantile Exchange but refined petroleum products rallied amid scattered refinery troubles and speculation that the nation's gasoline supply was still falling.
December deliveries of light crude oil fell 2 cents to $23.78 a barrel.
After trading ended, the American Petroleum Institute reported that the gasoline supply fell by 1.4 million barrels last week to 204.3 million.

HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales End October Even Lower

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Sales of cars and light trucks built in North America declined 8 percent in late October from a year earlier, the 11 domestic auto makers reported today. Analysts said the figures suggested that underlying demand remained weak, largely because of consumers' concerns about the economy and anemic growth in real wages.
"It appears we're beating a dead horse," said Tom Webb, chief economist of the National Automobile Dealers Association, who added that many special financing deals were having little effect. "No matter how low the interest rate, it's difficult to get a financially strapped and psychologically skittish consumer to sign a five-year contract to buy a new car." 
 For the 10 days that ended on Oct. 31, the seasonally adjusted annual selling rate for cars was 6.2 million, compared with 7 million a year earlier. Domestic car sales totaled 228,637 in the period, down 10.4 percent from 1990. There were 10 selling days in the period this year, and 9 in the 1990 period.
Light-truck sales fell 3.7 percent in the 10-day period, to 132,252.
 
Lowest Sales Rate Since May
 The annual selling rate for the month was 6 million, the poorest showing since May. Sales of cars, both domestic and foreign, dropped 10.9 percent in October, while sales of light trucks were off 8 percent.
Analysts noted that the weak figures were due partly to lower fleet sales to car-rental companies, a result of the car makers' new policy that forces the rental companies to keep cars longer before trading them in. Even after those sales are discounted from the overall numbers, however, the figures point to sluggish consumer demand.
"There is still no turnaround," said Jean-Claude Gruet, an analyst with UBS Securities in New York. The auto makers recently announced production cuts for the remainder of the fourth quarter, providing more evidence that they are bracing for further sales declines.
Dealers across the country reported mixed results in recent weeks. Several echoed the plaint of James M. Rife, who said showroom traffic was down 30 percent at his family's Chevrolet dealership in Sebeka, Minn. Shoppers are uneasy about the economy, he said, and some are trying to make unrealistic deals, thinking that dealers are more willing to slash prices in light of the financial difficulties of the American auto makers.
Mr. Rife still has eight new cars and trucks from the 1990 model year on his lot. "I've never had this problem before," he said.
But one dealer said incentives and new-model introductions had helped to generate sales. At Kurland Cadillac-Oldsmobile-GMC Truck in Nanuet, N.Y., sales were up 24 percent in October from a year earlier. Joe DiRocco, general sales manager, attributed the increase in part to the introduction of restyled Cadillac Seville and Eldorado models. General Motors' three-year, $499 lease special on deVille models and 2.9 percent financing on the Oldsmobile Eighty-Eight Royale are also raising sales, he said.
American auto makers continued to lose market share to the Japanese in October. The Big Three held 67.9 percent of the overall vehicle market, including imports, compared with 70.2 percent a year earlier. Japanese car makers increased their share to 26.6 percent, from 23.9 percent. The market share of non-Japanese importers fell to 5.5 percent, from 5.9 percent a year earlier.
Sales of all cars and trucks, imported and domestic, fell 10 percent for the entire month, to 1.03 million, from 1.14 million in October 1990. G.M. sold 230,170 North American-built cars in October, a drop of 13.5 percent from a year earlier; Ford sold 137,067, a drop of 15.6 percent, and Chrysler sold 63,579, down 21.7 percent.
G.M.'s total market share for all cars in October was 34.2 percent, compared with 35.3 percent in October 1990. Ford had a 20.8 percent share, compared with 21.4 percent a year earlier. Chrysler's total market share was 10 percent, down from 11.3 percent. Toyota's market share was 9.7 percent, up from 8.3 percent, and Honda's share was 10.6 percent, compared with 9.4 percent.

HEADLINE: Productivity Rose at 2.4% Rate Last Quarter

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Caution and cost-cutting may be slowing down the economy, but they are having the opposite effect on the country's efficiency. The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday that productivity in the United States economy, outside of farming, rose at a healthy 2.4 percent clip last summer, the first gain in a year and the fastest pace since the summer of 1988.
Economists, who cautioned that the gain could later be revised away, greeted the report as a hopeful sign. "The economic environment is tough," said Stephen S. Roach of Morgan Stanley, "but the silver lining is productivity." 
 The spurt in efficiency may partly be a product of efforts -- some begun years ago -- by service companies to automate, streamline operations and squeeze overhead. "New technology has allowed us to grow without adding people," said Kenneth A. Macke, chairman and chief executive of the Dayton Hudson Corporation, a Minneapolis-based retailer with 750 stores around the country. "It's allowed us to work faster and smarter."
Productivity almost always revives in the wake of a recession, as businesses hold off on adding new hands and employees work harder. The question is whether productivity will perform equally well in the fourth quarter, when economists expect growth in the gross national product to slow to a 1.5 percent rate or less compared with G.N.P. growth of nearly 2.5 percent in the summer.
"We've seen signs that the economy turned quite sluggish in September and October," said Edwin R. Dean, associate commissioner at the bureau, "and we don't know what that portends for productivity."
But Mark J. Lasky, senior economist at DRI/McGraw Hill, a consulting firm in Lexington, Mass., thinks business will keep aggressively pruning costs and paring work hours; he expects productivity will advance at an even faster 2.9 percent rate this fall.
Last summer's rise in output for each hour worked reflected the fact that non-farm business output increased at a solid 3 percent rate while hours worked inched up at just a six-tenths of 1 percent pace. "Business is producing more, but it isn't using more workers to do it," Mr. Lasky said.
The increase in productivity, typical in the early stages of a recovery, augurs well for inflation, profit margins and, eventually, pay. "It's a good sign for the cost picture generally," Mr. Dean said. "Labor costs are increasing very slowly over all."
The rise in labor costs for each dollar of output, an important determinant of profit margins and prices, slowed sharply in the summer. Unit labor costs actually fell in manufacturing at a seven-tenths of 1 percent rate. In services, where costs had been rising at a runaway 6 percent rate, the increase slowed to a 2 percent pace.
In any case, hourly output in the nation's factories soared at a 4 percent annual rate last summer for the second consecutive quarter.
"You ain't seen nothing yet," said Adrian T. Dillon, vice president for planning at the Eaton Corporation, a Cleveland-based manufacturer. "The restructuring efforts we made at the beginning of the year show that business is taking a hard-nose look at costs in order to make sure that we can make money even in this dreadful economic environment."
 
Gain in Service Sector
 An even more encouraging note of improvement was struck in the sprawling service sector, where productivity has stagnated for more than a decade and efforts to cut overhead have brought an unusual stream of white-collar layoffs. According to unpublished data from the bureau, non-farm, non-manufacturing productivity rose at a respectable 1.5 percent annual rate after declining at more than that pace last spring.
"We're seeing all this white-collar restructuring," said Mr. Roach of Morgan Stanley, who recently published an article in the Harvard Business Review on productivity in the service sector."This will be a very unique recovery, driven primarily by efficiency rather than new hiring."
One corner of the service sector that has seen more than its share of restructuring is commercial banking. "We're re-engineering the industry," said Michael R. Zucchini, executive vice president at the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group, based in Providence, R.I., which earlier this year acquired the failed Bank of New England. "From the back end to the front end, we're looking at new ways to reduce expenses and improve quality, and we're doing this primarily through consolidation." Fleet/Norstar has been pruning branches and, more important, merging back-office operations.

HEADLINE: An Enormous Empire With Debts to Match

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Robert Maxwell died just as his grip on his global publishing empire seemed to be slipping.
His empire -- and investor confidence -- had been shaken by turnovers in management, the burden of billions of dollars in debts incurred from acquisitions made in the 1980's, and depressed business conditions in the United States and Britain. It also has had to absorb losses from The Daily News in New York, which Mr. Maxwell acquired last spring, and from The European, an English-language pan-European weekly newspaper he introduced in May. 
 As a result of the problems, he has had to sell all or parts of significant holdings. This year alone, divestitures have totaled more than $1.9 billion.
 
Two Sons Take Positions
 Mr. Maxwell's two sons stepped into the void today by assuming control of his two flagship companies.
Ian R. Maxwell, 35 years old, was named acting chairman of Mirror Group Newspapers P.L.C., one of Britain's leading newspaper companies. He had been executive director.
And Kevin F. H. Maxwell, 32, was named acting chairman of the Maxwell Communication Corporation, whose operations include Macmillan book publishers, Berlitz language products and the Official Airline Guides. He had become chief executive in July.
"The vacuum left is obviously a very big vacuum because Maxwell is so personally identified with the running of the companies," said Neil Blackley, an analyst at James Capel & Company in London.
Mr. Maxwell presided over the finances of his empire, including the dizzying pace of buying and selling businesses and shifting assets among an array of private and public holding companies and trusts. Onlookers were often left unsure of which entity owned what. The interests of the Maxwell family's private companies also included a market-research company, soccer teams and papers in Israel and Hungary.
With Mr. Maxwell gone, some analysts wondered whether his successors would have the patience to wait for businesses like The European and The Daily News to become profitable.
In an article published last month, The Independent, a British newspaper, said it calculated that Mr. Maxwell's private companies have a debt of about 1 billion ($1.77 billion).
Given Mr. Maxwell's domination of his empire, some analysts speculated that his death must be sending shivers through the banks and financial firms that have lent him money.
It is known that Mr. Maxwell pledged sizable stakes in some of his companies as collateral for loans from banks and investment firms, reportedly including Goldman, Sachs & Company and Midland Bank of Britain.
Mr. Maxwell had already been scrambling to sell assets to reduce debt. Deals this year have included the 446 million sale of Pergamon Press, the scientific and academic publisher that was one of the empire's jewels.
In May, he offered for sale to the public 49 percent of Mirror Group, his British newspaper operation, for 245.5 million.
And in July he announced his intention to sell shares in the North American operations of Maxwell Communication, the company that accounts for the vast majority of the assets and operating profits of his holdings.
The article in The Independent concluded that the debts of Maxwell Communication may exceed the value of its assets by almost 400 million ($708 million).
"Maxwell Communication is obviously in a financially delicate situation," Mr. Blackley said. In the year that ended March 31, Maxwell Communication's earnings before taxes and extraordinary items dropped 15.6 percent, to 145.5 million on sales of 996.9 million. But the vast majority of those earnings came from things like foreign-exchange profits and one-time gains.
When trading in the company's stock was suspended today in London after losing 12.9 percent of its value, its price was 1.21 ($2.14). That was down from a 1991 high of 2.41.
Mr. Blackley added that the Mirror Group, with a net debt of about 350 million ($619.2 million) "is fine" financially. Its British newspapers include five tabloids led by The Daily Mirror and Sunday Mirror, Britain's second-largest daily and Sunday papers, with average daily circulations in September of about 2.9 million each.
But investor jitters, which analysts have attributed to the recession in Britain and the sluggish American economy, nervousness about the Maxwell empire's finances and second thoughts about the true value of the company, have caused Mirror's stock price to plunge. It was 77.5 pence ($1.37) when trading in the shares was suspended in London today. That was down from 78 pence on Monday and from a 1991 peak of 1.27 reached shortly after the offering of shares.

HEADLINE: Banking Overhaul's Fate;
Bush Never Pulled All the Political Stops And a Top Domestic Priority Unraveled

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
The competing interests of powerful lobbies could not be reconciled. Many lawmakers, without really addressing the merits, smelled a rerun of the savings-and-loan disaster. And President Bush never pulled out all the stops politically.
So legislation to revamp the nation's anachronistic banking system, which at the beginning of the year the President called his top domestic priority, has come unraveled. 
 Before the year is out, Congress will probably give the Administration a $70 billion loan from the taxpayers to shore up the bank insurance fund. And Congress may agree to lift the age-old restrictions on banks' opening branches nationwide, although the Administration will have to play its cards exactly right to get even that relatively modest change.
 
Fate of Other Proposals
 But Mr. Bush's more ambitious proposals to permit banks to sell insurance and stocks and underwrite bonds and to allow commercial enterprises like retail chains and even automobile companies to buy banks are almost certainly dead.
On Monday night, the House of Representatives voted down comprehensive changes in the nation's banking laws. The Bush Administration actually worked against the bill in the House because it had become so filled with bank restrictions the President opposed. The Senate today found itself unable, at least for the time being, to begin debating a similar measure. [Page D6.]
No one doubts that banking laws are outmoded. They were written mostly during the Great Depression, long before the advent of money-market mutual funds, commercial paper, bank credit cards, computer transfers of funds, automated teller machines and countless other mainstays of modern banking and financial life.
And no one doubts that the banking system is deeply troubled. Many of the nation's most prominent banks like Citibank and the Bank of Boston are in financial straits, scores of banks are expected to fail in the next couple of years, and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is close to insolvency.
But no consensus exists on whether modernizing the system would avert a more serious banking crisis, and few experts believe it would make any short-term difference.
The Administration argued that over the long run its measure would have allowed banks to diversify, attract more capital and theoretically become more profitable. But opponents maintained that banks had made enough mistakes managing their own affairs and that letting them get into stocks, bonds and insurance policies, hardly profitable businesses anyway nowadays, would risk another expensive taxpayer bailout.
The division did not start out as a partisan one. Republicans and Democrats were on both sides.
In the end, though, Mr. Bush and some Republicans may reap some benefit from the collapse of his legislation. To some degree, it ties the hands of Democrats who might try during next year's campaign to pin on the President the miserable condition of the banking industry. Now, true or not, Mr. Bush can turn the tables and blame the Democratic Congress for the banks' problems.
 
Disinterest of Voters
 From the beginning, the banking legislation faced enormous obstacles. The biggest one, probably, is that voters for the most part do not care much about banking laws, about whether, say, commercial and investment banks are allowed to compete with one another.
But influential lobbies -- the major money-center banks, small-town banks, securities dealers, investment bankers, insurance companies, real estate agents and dozens of others -- care a great deal. Not since the Tax Reform Act of 1986 had there been so much arm-twisting.
So lawmakers, feeling no pressure from ordinary constituents, saw their job as one of refereeing among competing interests. Since so many interests were involved, any single change in the law was likely to antagonize more lobbyists than it pleased.
A second obstacle is the specter of the savings-and-loan mess. In 1982, savings-and-loan associations were allowed to move into new lines of business. Now, in the biggest scandal in public finance in American history, the failure of many of these institutions is costing taxpayers hundreds of billions of dollars.
 
Distinctions Get Fuzzy
 The truth of what happened to the savings-and-loan industry is more complicated than that, and banks, as Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady keeps saying, are much more secure than were the savings institutions. But in the public's eye and that of many lawmakers, the distinctions are hard to draw.
For instance, even though every responsible legislator understands that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation must be given more money (otherwise, blameless depositors will not be reimbursed when their banks fail next year), 75 to 100 Representatives are prepared to vote against any bill that provides the funds. That is because they know that their opponent in the next election will take advantage of the public's dismay over the savings-and-loan bailout and blast a vote for more money for bank insurance.
The final big obstacle that blocked a thorough overhaul of the banking system was the President's failure to throw his full weight behind the measure.
Treasury Secretary Brady pushed hard for the bill. His Under Secretary, Robert R. Glauber, one of the country's foremost authorities on finance, worked night and day and even relinquished his position as a tenured professor at Harvard Business School to press the fight.
 
Bush at Arms Length
 But Mr. Bush kept at arm's length, making few if any calls to round up votes and certainly not wasting any political capital on the matter. That is in sharp contrast to the way President Reagan took the unusual step of going to Capitol Hill himself to lobby for his tax bill in 1985. And it is a far cry from the way the President fought this year for authority to go to war against Iraq, to block the civil rights bill and to win confirmation of the nominations of Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court and Robert M. Gates to be Director of Central Intelligence.
Chances are, a bill will be enacted this fall containing the $70 billion for the bank insurance fund and requiring Federal authorities to intervene sooner when a bank failure looks likely. Whether that measure permits interstate banking is largely a matter of legislative tactics.
Before killing the overall bank bill Monday night, the House voted 366 to 4 in favor of a section allowing interstate banking. The bill approved by the Senate Banking Committee has a similar provision. Many experts like Robert E. Litan, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, argue this is the most important way of strengthening the banking system because it would make banks less vulnerable to regional economic distress.

HEADLINE: Daily News to Continue, Its New Publisher Says

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
One of the sons of Robert Maxwell pledged yesterday that his family was "completely committed" to the continued operation of The Daily News, despite continuing doubts within the industry about the newspaper's future.
"My father was tremendously excited by The News and its prospects," said the son, Kevin Maxwell, who was named publisher yesterday. "We are completely committed to continuing the marvelous comeback of the newspaper by providing the support it needs to prosper in the years ahead." 
 But newspaper executives and industry analysts said yesterday that the long-term prospects for The Daily News, a paper Mr. Maxwell rescued from almost certain death earlier this year, were greatly worsened by his drowning yesterday.
"The Maxwell commitment to The Daily News was more personal than corporate, more an ego trip than an investment," said John Morton, a newspaper analyst for Lynch, Jones & Ryan in Washington. "It may be his sons were infected with his enthusiasm and will carry on, but I think the likelihood of finding another Maxwell is very slender."
 
Still Unprofitable
 Despite recent growth, the paper is unprofitable and continues to suffer from a combination of recession, a strike earlier this year, and longstanding competition with two other tabloid newspapers: The New York Post and New York Newsday.
What happens to The News will have a huge impact on the city's continuing newspaper war.
The News's recent recovery suggested that the city's three tabloids would continue to slug it out for dominance for a long time to come.
But should The News leave the field, the principal beneficiary would probably be New York Newsday, which has a Sunday paper and showed significant gains during The News strike.
The New York Times has welcomed the revival of The News as a buffer that prevented New York Newsday from making a head-on assault on The Times, which would be very likely should The News cease publication.
 
Strong Circulation Recovery
 Mr. Maxwell acquired the paper six months ago after a disastrous strike that cost most of its circulation and advertising, and, through a combination of nonstop promotion and reader loyalty, had recovered more than half of The News's lost circulation and much of its advertising.
Mr. Maxwell's passionate interest in the paper was considered to be its greatest asset, and the removal of that interest has created a void of monumental proportions.
"With him, it seemed to be a crusade," said Douglas LaChance, president of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers' Union of New York and Vicinity, which represents the paper's drivers.
While Mr. Maxwell was known for taking a strong hand in the management of all his enterprises, he went even further at The News by effectively making himself the paper's day-to-day operating head. Ten vice presidents at the paper, with responsibilities ranging from news to circulation, reported to Mr. Maxwell even as he traveled the globe.
When word that Mr. Maxwell was missing began to circulate yesterday, the assumption at The News was that James P. Willse, the editor, was in charge because he was the only senior vice president.
Mr. Maxwell had indicated that there was a limit to his willingness to underwrite the paper's losses. He frequently said that he expected the paper to be profitable by next spring, which would have been the first anniversary of his ownership and that he would close the paper if it did not show signs that a sustained profit was possible.
In a recent interview, Mr. Maxwell said the paper had seen its first profitable week of operation under him just before Columbus Day, with advertising revenues exceeding $3 million. John Campi, a spokesman for The News, said that since then there had been two more weeks with similar revenues, and that Mr. Maxwell had been optimistic that his profitability standard would be met.
But some newspaper executives remained skeptical that The News could become profitable on a sustained basis, because expenses remained quite high and because of the overall advertising recession, which has hit New York particularly hard.
"In today's environment, I doubt it," said W. Dean Singleton, chief executive officer of Media News Group Inc., a newspaper group based in Houston, assessing The News's prospects of becoming profitable.
Indeed, an executive at a rival paper who spoke on condition of anonymity said that an analysis by that paper's executives concluded that The News was losing more than $1 million each week. Mr. Campi, however, said such a weekly loss figure was greatly exaggerated but would not give specifics.
Should Mr. Maxwell's heirs decide to try selling The News, they would probably face formidable difficulties.
Mr. Singleton, who is familiar with The News's operation from earlier efforts to sell it to him, said he was "frankly impressed" by the paper's success in rebuilding its circulation. Even so, he said he would not consider buying the paper because, like virtually all other newspaper organizations, his own is concentrating on weathering the recession.
Mr. Singleton said that he would be surprised if any newspaper company would be willing to acquire The News.
Peter S. Kalikow, a real estate developer now in Chapter 11 bankruptcy, acquired The New York Post in 1988 from Rupert Murdoch when the paper seemed about to close.
Mr. Murdoch would ordinarily be considered a prospective buyer of last resort for The News, but he could not acquire it because he signed an agreement not to compete with Mr. Kalikow through 1994.
In one sense, the poor market for newspapers could encourage the Maxwell heirs to continue operating The News in hopes that an economic recovery would make the paper profitable and also encourage a prospective buyer. And news executives said it was conceivable that Mr. Maxwell's heirs would manage his empire in a more orderly and efficient manner.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

MAXWELL'S DEATH
Robert Maxwell's body was found floating off the coast of Africa. The British publisher whose global empire includes The Daily News in New York, vanished suddenly from his yacht while cruising off the Canary Islands. [Page A1.]
Maxwell fled the collapse of Czechoslovakia in 1939 to become one of the world's most powerful publishers, presiding over a multi-billion dollar empire he assembled with brass and bravura over forty years. [Obituary, D23.] 
 The 68-year-old publisher died as his grip on his empire seemed to be slipping. His two sons took control of the two flagship companies, which are burdened by billions of dollars in debt. [D22.]
Kevin Maxwell, the new publisher of The Daily News, pledged that the family was "completely committed" to the continued operation of the newspaper. [D22.] For journalists and executives of The Daily News, Maxwell and his purchase of the paper earlier this year was virtually the only recent bright spot. [D22.]
 
THE ECONOMY
No consensus exists on whether modernizing the nation's banks would avert a more serious crisis, and few experts think it would make any short-term difference. News Analysis. [A1.]
A day after the House rejected banking legislation, the leadership of the Senate was unable to muster the votes even to begin debate on a similar measure. [D6.] The defeat of the banking measure capped months of wars of persuasion by various lobby groups. [D6.]
Productivity rose 2.4 percent last summer, the first gain in a year, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said. [D1.] Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks fell 8 percent in late October. [D1.]
The Postal Service rejected a proposed one-cent increase in the price of a first-class letter, to 30 cents. [A18.]
President Bush warned that any action to lower taxes could prove counterproductive by pushing interest rates up. [D6.]
 
MARKETS

The Dow fell 14.31 points, to 3,031.31, with a decline for Walt Disney accounting for more than half of the loss. [D8.]
The dollar was little changed as lower interest rates were expected. [D16.] Grain and soybean futures prices fell. [D16.]
 
COMPANIES
Compaq outlined a new business strategy based on lower operating costs and a new line of inexpensive personal computers. [D1.]
Compucom Systems will leave the consumer retail market by consolidating and selling its 14 Computer Factory stores. [D4.]

TECHNOLOGY
Optical fibers are finding new applications in the sensing devices used to monitor manufacturing processes. [D7.]

TODAY'S COLUMNS
An analysis of the credit shortage hypothesis confirms that a scarcity of bank capital has indeed affected the supply of loans. But the study says the full weight has been felt only in the Northeast. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Value Health and Preferred Health Care are benefiting as a growing number of large employers are hiring specialty companies to try to slow the steep rise in health-care costs. Market Place. [D8.]
