HEADLINE: THE 1991 ELECTION;
Mississippi's Governor Beaten by a Newcomer

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
An apparent casualty of voters' antipathy toward incumbents, Gov. Ray Mabus of Mississippi lost yesterday to a political newcomer, Kirk Fordice, a conservative Republican who stressed his opposition to racial quotas. Mr. Fordice will be the state's first Republican governor since Reconstruction.
Mr. Mabus, a Democrat, was attempting to become the state's first governor to win back-to-back terms. The state dropped a prohibition against successive terms four years ago. 
 In a bitterly fought campaign, Mr. Fordice, a 57-year-old construction company president from Vicksburg, called the incumbent a liberal in the Kennedy tradition and charged that he had bloated the state's payroll while neglecting its economy. It was Mr. Fordice's first bid for public office.
At the last minute, Shawn O'Hara, an independent, threw his support to Mr. Fordice, but Mr. O'Hara's name remained on the ballot.
With 99 percent of the state's precincts reporting, the vote was:
 
Fordice . . . 356,250 (51%)
Mabus . . . 330,347 (47%)
O'Hara . . . 11,674 (2%)
In Kentucky, where governors cannot succeed themselves, Lieut. Gov. Brereton C. Jones, a Democrat, was easily elected governor over a seven-term Republican Congressman, Larry J. Hopkins.
 
Hurt by Bad Checks
 Mr. Hopkins received campaign help from President Bush but was hurt when it was recently revealed that he was among the lawmakers who wrote bad checks on the House of Representatives bank.
Mr. Jones's victory extended the Democrats' 24-year hold on the governor's office. He will succeed Gov. Wallace G. Wilkinson.
With 99 percent of the precincts reporting, the vote was:
 
Jones . . . 2,471 (65%)
Hopkins . . . 288,471 (35%)
Voters in the District of Columbia approved a measure aimed at holding the makers and sellers of some assault weapons liable for the injuries and damage those weapons cause.
Unofficial returns from all precincts in the capital showed 77 percent in favor of the measure and 23 percent opposed. The measure was believed to be the first of its kind in the country to receive voter approval.
As of Monday, 409 homicides had been reported in the nation's capital this year. A record 483 homicides occurred in 1990.
A similar measure was passed by the District of Columbia Council in December. But Mayor Sharon Pratt Dixon, who took office in January, persuaded the Council to repeal it after some Congressmen hinted that the measure could block a $100 million aid package for the city.
 
Whitmire Loses in Houston
 In Texas, voters endorsed a constitutional amendment to lift a 146-year-old ban on lotteries. Voters in that state also backed a $1.1 billion prison bond and up to $300 million in bonds to finance college loans, both by 2-to-1 margins.
Control of City Hall was at stake in 10 big cities from Boston to San Francisco.
In Houston, Kathryn J. Whitmire's record 10-year reign as mayor ended when a developer, Bob Lanier, and State Representative Sylvester Turner finished first and second in a three-way race. The two top vote-getters will face each other in a runoff Dec. 3.
With 79 percent of the vote counted, Mr. Lanier had 43 percent of the votes. Mr. Turner, who is trying to become Houston's first black mayor, had 36 percent. Mrs. Whitmire had 21 percent.
Mrs. Whitmire, 45, had been elected to five consecutive two-year terms beginning in 1982, but she came under fire this year because of rising crime and her support of an unpopular $1 billion monorail project.
In Dallas, Steve Bartlett, a Republican who resigned from Congress to run for mayor, topped 58 other candidates in the nonpartisan race to succeed Mayor Annette Strauss. With all votes counted, Mr. Bartlett won 54 percent, while his closest challenger, Kathryn Cain, a lawyer, took 27 percent.
In Boston, Mayor Raymond L. Flynn, 52,entered the race a strong contender for a third term after taking 67 percent of the votes in the three-way preliminary race. Edwin Doherty, 47, ran a half-hearted campaign against Mayor Flynn, who is president of the United States Conference of Mayors.
In Philadelphia, Edward Rendell, a Democrat and former District Attorney, was voted the city's 127th Mayor. This spring Mr. Rendell, who is white, won the Democratic nomination by defeating three black opponents. He attacked Mr. Goode's mismanagement of City Hall as the main cause of a financial crisis that has taken the nation's fifth-largest city to the brink of bankruptcy.
In Baltimore, Mayor Kurt Schmoke, a Democrat, fended off a challenge from Samuel Culotta, a Republican.
In Indianapolis, Stephen Goldsmith, a Republican and former prosecutor, defeated Louis Mahern, a Democrat. Mr. Goldsmith will succeed the retiring four-term Mayor William Hudnut 3d.
In Salt Lake City, Deedee Corradini was elected the first woman Mayor of Utah's capital, foiling Dave Buhler's attempt to become the first Republican leading City Hall in 16 years.
Republicans and Democrats split the contests for the two open Congressional seats. In Charlottesville, Va., a Republican state lawmaker, George F. Allen, beat Katherine E. (Kay) Slaughter, a Democrat, for the seat being vacated by her cousin, Representative D. French Slaughter Jr., a Republican. Mr. French resigned because of ill health.
In Philadelphia, the former City Councilman Lucien Blackwell, 60, the Democratic Party's endorsed candidate, won the seat vacated by the surprise resignation of Representative William H. Gray 3d.

HEADLINE: THE 1991 ELECTION;
Outsider Campaign Works for Insider

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
Harris L. Wofford has the sort of dream resume that makes a hardened liberal swoon: he studied civil disobedience with Gandhi's followers, marched with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., served under President John F. Kennedy and helped found the Peace Corps.
Yet when he was appointed in May to fill the vacancy created by the death of Senator H. John Heinz 3d, Mr. Wofford was widely considered too inexperienced, too unknown and too liberal to have a realistic chance of re-election in a state that had not elected a Democrat to the Senate since 1962. 
The 65-year-old Mr. Wofford, who despite a background in politics had never held elective office, turned his inexperience to his advantage. A consumate political insider, he ran an outsider's campaign, and handed a stunning defeat to Dick Thornburgh, President Bush's former Attorney General who had been a popular two-term Governor.
 
A Scarsdale Youth
 Born in New York City in 1926, Mr. Wofford spent his early childhood in Johnson City, Tenn., and spent his teen-age years in Scarsdale, N.Y.
After graduating from the University of Chicago and studying Gandhi's work in India, he became one of the first white students at Howard University School of Law -- an experience that sparked his interest in civil rights. He earned a second law degree at Yale University and later taught at Howard and the University of Notre Dame before joining President Kennedy's staff as a special assistant for civil rights.
He helped R. Sargent Shriver start the Peace Corps and served as its associate director until 1966, when he became president of the State University of New York College at Old Westbury, L.I. In 1970 he became the first male president of Bryn Mawr College since its inception in 1861.
After leaving Bryn Mawr in 1978, he quietly practiced law in Philadelphia, slipping into an obscurity that was never too far removed from the Democratic Party. He was appointed state party chairman in 1986, and a year later Gov. Robert P. Casey made him his Secretary of Labor and Industry.
When Governor Casey named him interim Senator, after two other candidates turned down the offer, Republicans reacted with glee and political analysts predicted he had little chance to win.
"People will say, 'Harris who?' " said Michael L. Young, an associate professor of politics at the Pennsylvania State University branch at Harrisburg.
An incumbent for only six months, Senator Wofford had to stage a remarkable comeback against the high-profile Mr. Thornburgh -- and he did, closing a 40-point gap in the polls.
Assailing what he saw as the ingrained corruption and ineffectiveness of Washington, he ran an aggressive populist campaign. He repeatedly hammered Mr. Thornburgh on issues like health care and the economy. On Oct. 11, just as Mr. Wofford's comeback was peaking, President Bush handed him another club, vetoing a bill to extend unemployment benefits, which would have aided some 170,000 of Pennsylvania's 400,000 unemployed workers.
Mr. Wofford's campaign, and his stunning comeback, suddenly turned the despair of Democratic political analysts to hope, offering the party campaign themes it will no doubt turn to in 1992.

HEADLINE: Amid Criticism, Bush Drops Plans for 2-Week Asia Trip

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
President Bush tonight canceled plans for a two-week tour of the Far East as he faced mounting economic pressure to speed the end of the recession and political pressure to demonstrate his concern about domestic issues.
Marlin Fitzwater, the President's spokesman, issued a written statement that expressed the President's regrets and cited "uncertainty over the Congressional calendar" as the official reason for the cancellation. The trip was to have started on Thanksgiving or the day before and ended on Dec. 7 in Honolulu for the 50th anniversary of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. Mr. Fitzwater said the President had not decided whether to attend the commemoration and held open the possibility that another Far East trip could be scheduled soon. 
 But most members of Congress have long been expecting to adjourn by Thanksgiving in any case, and the President's move seemed motivated as much by the sudden shift in political focus from his achievements overseas to his problems at home.
The decision to cancel the trip came today, as Dick Thornburgh, a former Attorney General, met defeat in the Senate race in Pennsylvania. White House officials were reluctant to discuss the politics of the decision, but it seemed clearly linked to the slippage in Republican campaign prospects.
 
More Overt Political Role
 Mr. Bush has acknowledged that the recession is not ending as fast as he had hoped and that economics -- not the new world order -- is going to define the political debate for his re-election bid in 1992.
He seems increasingly at a loss over how to respond to Democratic assertions that he is not paying enough attention to domestic problems, and his advisers have been giving him conflicting advice about what economic and political steps he should take. The debate has forced Mr. Bush, who has yet to formally announce his candidacy, to take on a more overt campaign role earlier than he had planned.
Reflecting these political currents, the decision to cancel the trip, announced after NBC News reported earlier this evening that such a move was under consideration, was coupled with an announcement that Mr. Bush was summoning reporters to the White House at dawn Wednesday to hear him read a statement on today's elections and other domestic questions.
Mr. Bush seems to have seized on the technique of the hastily called news conference to give him a platform from which to respond to the Democrats. He did just that 10 days ago, before he went to Madrid to meet with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union and attend the opening of the Middle East peace conference.
Immediately afterward, Mr. Bush planned to leave for Rome for a two-day conference of the leaders of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Just a year ago, such a trip would have given Mr. Bush a welcome platform for his diplomatic prowess. But NATO's mission to defend against a Soviet threat has been virtually eliminated.
With public opinion polls showing that many Americans say Mr. Bush should travel less abroad, Democrats in Congress seized on the trip to Rome as a way of keeping pressure on the President as the struggle between the Republican White House and the Democratic Congress increasingly took on the tones of a political campaign.
 
Democratic T-Shirts
 The Democratic National Committee distributed T-shirts lampooning Mr. Bush's globe-trotting Presidency, and the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee issued a news release with 11 cities in the United States named Rome and the unemployment rate for each.
Asked about Democratic criticism at a White House news conference today, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, Mr. Bush's former campaign manager, replied testily: "It would only be valid if there were a failure on his part to address domestic concerns. I don't think there has been a failure. In the absence of that, I think it's quite inappropriate."
One official said of the delay: "There was this whole spate of stories about domestic issues and the concern that the way Congress is behaving, they might try to take advantage. Better to have the President here so he can continue to hold their feet to the fire."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Decision Dismays Japan
 TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 6 -- Japanese leaders reacted with surprise and dismay this morning over President Bush's sudden cancellation of his trip, and Foreign Ministry officials sought to assure Japanese journalists that the decision did not represent a snub.
Less than 24 hours after taking office, Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa was seen as having to deal with an extremely embarrassing setback, especially since Mr. Bush also canceled a visit here at the last moment in February, because of the war against Iraq.

HEADLINE: For Bush, NATO Talks May Test His Strategy

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
For President Bush, the meeting in Rome of the Atlantic alliance this week will be yet another exercise in trying to hold together an institution shaken by the very new world order that he has been so eager to help create.
As was the case with Mr. Bush's meeting in Madrid last week with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the summit meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization on Thursday and Friday promises to be more symbol than substance. Administration officials said they do not view the meeting as a forum for major policy advances, apart from an already agreed-upon effort to bring the former Warsaw Pact countries into a liaison role with NATO. 
 Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d announced here today that the East European countries, the Baltic states and the Soviet Union would be invited to send representatives to a NATO foreign ministers' meeting in Brussels on Dec. 20.
But American officials are keenly aware that relations within NATO are so unsettled that basic questions, like the future security structure of Europe, are best papered over for now. Officials here have set their goals at a minimum: a reaffirmation of NATO's role as the central military institution in Europe.
 
The Stakes Are Higher
 But, where it was Mr. Gorbachev who stood to gain the most from the Madrid meeting, the stakes in Rome are higher for Mr. Bush, who senior officials said views NATO as America's only hope to retain its political influence in Europe as the Continent grows increasingly integrated.
"We think it's still very important to maintain our commitment to the security of Europe" through NATO, Mr. Baker said today, adding, "It is very important that it continue and it will continue."
American officials have deliberately combined the NATO trip with a visit to The Hague for meetings with officials of the European Community, a symbolic gesture that they hope will underscore the overlap in membership of the two organizations. Of the 12 members of the community, only Ireland is not a NATO member.
"The only institutional link we have to Europe is NATO as an organization," an American official said. "In NATO, we play a leading role and can exploit the overlap, we hope, with the E.C. membership to keep an institutional link in their economic zone."
In Rome, since much of what the NATO summit will produce has already been worked out, American officials are concentrating harder on the sideshow of individual meetings with European leaders than on the main event.
"The summit will be more like a political convention, where they come together in a big room with a common platform, but the real action takes place on the outskirts, where they dicker and the problems are aired," an official said. "This is the first NATO summit where the importance will be in the bilaterals."
American officials said Mr. Bush hoped to head off a call by President Francois Mitterrand of France for a four-power meeting on nuclear disarmament, a process that Mr. Bush prefers to keep within his own control, as he did with his most recent initiative, or in the context of Soviet-American relations.
The President also will seek assurances from Mr. Mitterrand and from Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany that a recent Franco-German statement on joint defense policies is not intended to replace NATO as Europe's primary security apparatus.
With Mr. Kohl, Administration officials said the President would press for concessions in the current round of international talks aimed at lifting barriers to free trade. Officials here said Mr. Kohl had promised the United States he would press for progress on lifting protections for European farmers after his last round of elections but has since been dragging his feet.
 
Meeting in the Hague
 Mr. Baker said those trade talks will be at the top of Mr. Bush's agenda in the Hague when he meets on Friday with Jaques Delors, the European Community's chief executive, and Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers of the Netherlands, which holds its rotating presidency.
Stitched throughout all these talks will be the Soviet Union, which has been a central subject for every NATO summit meeting but will be discussed by the alliance's leaders this week in an entirely different context than before.
The last time the NATO allies met at this level was in London in July 1990, and the goal was to make progress in reducing conventional armed forces in Europe and on the strategic arms reduction treaty.
"But that was before the Soviet Union fell apart," an Administration official said. "The Rome meetings will be the first opportunity for the President to brief the allies in person on his meeting in Madrid last week. What are we going to do about the fact that Gorbachev seems increasingly irrelevant?"
 
Principles for Soviets
 Mr. Baker said today that the President would urge his allies to adopt a specific set of principles for judging democratic reform in the Soviet Union, including respect for international conventions on human rights and strict control of Soviet nuclear weapons.
In an oblique criticism of the Ukraine's effort to use the presence of nuclear weapons on its territory as a bargaining chip with Moscow, Mr. Baker said, "Soviet nuclear weapons should not become the object of political bargaining of any kind."
As Mr. Baker did today during his news conference, American officials said Mr. Bush would use the uncertain political future of NATO's former adversary to bolster his argument to keep the Atlantic alliance intact, to protect its members against unexpected threats, like the Persian Gulf war earlier this year, and to provide a source of stability for Eastern Europe.
"The President will make a pitch that we have to be careful with this euphoria," one official said, adding: "After World War II, everybody disarmed and went home, then we had to come back and create NATO. So the argument now is to keep it strong. Its role has changed and the President will say, 'I'm the first to recognize that, but let's be realistic about the world around us at this stage.' "

HEADLINE: Cultural Links With Chinese Are Eroding

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Throughout the 1980's, Chinese-American relations flourished across the cultural bridges built by scholars, artists and business executives who established exchange programs and advisory councils to help bring the two nations closer.
Now, these bridges are slowly deteriorating, not so much because China is closing its doors, but rather because American bitterness over human rights abuses in China has dried up interest. Many of these programs are fighting for survival, and their struggle underscores the difficulties that the Chinese-American relationship is likely to face in the future. 
 "It's all part of the tremendous mood swings people suffered, going from the exaggerated rosy picture of China that Americans have from time to time to the exaggerated, depressed picture that they have from time to time, and now we're in the bottom of the swing," said Jerome A. Cohen, a specialist in Chinese law at New York University. "The whole picture is a very serious and sad picture."
 
Students and Tourists Still Come
 To be sure, many American students still come to China on exchange programs and American tourists still flood the Forbidden City. And the trip later this month by Secretary of State James A. Baker, the first by such a high-level official since the Tiananmen Square crackdown in 1989, is expected to have some impact on relations with China. But several prominent links between the two countries are now in trouble because of disgruntlement at the political repression in China -- even though those associated with the programs insist that they help foster a more democratic culture there.
These people worry that if the trend develops, it could create a gap in understanding that may make bilateral problems more difficult to resolve.
"The great impetus for Americans to give is a missionary impetus -- wanting China to change -- and there's a frustration that China hasn't changed the way we wanted it to," said Anthony J. Kane, co-director of the Center for Chinese and American Studies, a program sponsored by Johns Hopkins University and Nanjing University. "It's going to end up hurting Sino-American relations in a number of ways. Obviously, it closes a window."
The six-year-old center, in the eastern city of Nanjing, is one of those that is struggling. It has enough money to make it through this year, but may not be able to operate next academic year. The program, which has 31 American students and 46 Chinese students this year, exposes the Chinese to American teaching methods and materials.
 
Students Turned Away
 A second major exchange, a business school program for Chinese students at the Dalian University of Technology in the northeastern city of Dalian, did not take students this academic year because it did not have enough money. The United States Department of Commerce, which had sponsored the program by contributing $400,000, used the money elsewhere. Organizers are trying to arrange private financing to keep the program alive.
The United States-China Business Council, which represents the interests of American businesses in China, has lost about one-fourth of its membership in the last two years. The Council's president, Donald M. Anderson, says that raising money has been difficult for a variety of reasons, including the poor economy in the United States.
Most of the money from foundations is going elsewhere -- often to the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. Only a few of the large foundations, like the Ford Foundation, which has an office in Beijing, continue to finance projects in China on a steady basis.
To raise money, programs sometimes need to be packaged as part of an Asiawide effort so that China is not singled out. Some centers are scaling down their programs, while others are rethinking their strategies.
 
Arts Exchange Is Silent
 For example, the Center for U.S.-China Arts Exchange, which brought Arthur Miller's play "Death of a Salesman" to China in the early 1980's, currently has no programs. For the last two years, it has been revising its focus and approach. Now, it hopes to translate and distribute works about prominent Western composers. Chou Wen-chung, the center's director, also said that it plans to focus exchanges but on smaller cities and counties.
Organizers say that for the near future, they do not foresee changes in the American perception of China, which many believe is unduly negative. They are confident a change in attitude will come about, but none could say when they expected that to happen.
"It is important for Americans to actually go over and see what is happening," Jan C. Berris, vice president of the National Committee on United States-China Relations, one of the organizations not in difficulty. "Until the number of Americans who have the opportunity to go increases, I am concerned that these impressions that are now prevalent in the country are going to remain."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Dozens of Peruvians Killed In Wave of Political Violence

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Dozens of Peruvians have been killed in new political violence around the country.
Five suspected leftist guerrillas fired rocket-propelled grenades at Peru's presidential palace this morning, wounding two police officers and a merchant when the devices exploded in the vicinity of the palace, the police said. 
 Initial reports said the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement was responsible for the attacks and for explosions on Monday night at several banks, the state-owned water company and an Ecuadorean airline office, the last apparently connected with a border dispute with Ecuador.
The attacks came as Lima residents were still in shock from a massacre in a poor neighborhood in the city center on Sunday night, in which 16 people were killed and 4 wounded at a chicken barbecue.
 
Investigation Promised
 Attorney General Pedro Mendez called the crime, the deadliest attack in the capital in a decade of guerrilla violence that has taken thousands of lives, "inconceivable to the human conscience," and he promised an exhaustive investigation.
The killings came three days after a human rights team from the Organization of American States expressed concern over the impunity with which Peru's security forces deal with guerrillas.
Informers close to Mr. Mendez's office said that statements by witnesses to the killings on Sunday pointed to a paramilitary group because the people who organized the barbecue were suspected of having links to the Shining Path guerrillas, a Maoist group that advocates the overthrow of the government and creation of an agrarian Marxist new order.
In Ayacucho, 240 miles southeast of Lima, the police said that about 100 Shining Path militants raided the remote Andean village of Santo Tomas de Pata late Sunday, killing 37 members of peasant self-defense militias.
Shining Path has stepped up attacks in recent weeks on the militias, calling them traitors for collaborating with the army in its counterinsurgency war in the countryside.
The new violence has led to renewed calls for a change in the Cabinet of President Alberto Fujimori a week after Prime Minister Carlos Torres y Torres Lara surprised the nation by saying he would resign in mid-November.
 
Inquiry by Peru's Senate
 Mr. Fujimori has been meeting with Cabinet ministers for six days, looking at Cabinet changes and putting final touches on decrees before special powers to legislate in areas of investment and pacification run out.
Late Monday, Peru's Senate summoned the Defense Minister, Jorge Torres Aciego, and the Interior Minister, Gen. Victor Malca Villanueva, to render their account of the killings in the heart of the capital.
Sen. Raul Ferrerro Acosta, speaking on television today, called for their resignations and urged Mr. Fujimori to forge a strategy to defeat the guerrillas.
"The Government must make the war its highest priority, not its third or fourth," Mr. Ferrerro Acosta said. "This is not just a military problem but a political and economic problem."
He was referring to Mr. Fujimori's heavy emphasis on seeking foreign investment for Peru's stalled economy.

HEADLINE: Bridgeport Mayor Falls, but No Wide Anti-Incumbent Trend Is Seen

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Mayor Mary C. Moran of Bridgeport, whose decision to file for municipal bankruptcy earlier this year made Connecticut's largest city a symbol of the nation's urban struggles, was defeated in her bid for re-election tonight after one fiery term. She conceded about an hour after the polls closed to Joseph P. Ganim, a 32-year-old Democrat who has never served in public office.
"This is not our loss -- it's Bridgeport's loss," she told supporters. "They said that filing for bankruptcy was against the odds, but I knew it was the right thing to do." 
 Across the state, as Connecticut residents went to the polls in 158 towns and cities to vote on offices from zoning boards to school boards, results were equally quick and decisive, but the message was mixed. The supposedly angry electorate, concerned about the recession and incensed about the state's new income tax, took out its frustration on many incumbents but not on others.
In Waterbury, voters dismissed the three-term Republican incumbent, Mayor Joseph J. Santopietro, who was indicted earlier this year on Federal corruption charges but chose to run for re-election anyway. He came in last in a three-way race, trailing even an independent candidate who had never before run for public office, losing to Edward D. Bergin, a Democrat who was Waterbury's mayor from 1976 until 1985. Mr. Bergin was under a cloud as well -- he cleared his name of bribery charges only this spring.
But in New Haven, the Democratic Mayor, John C. Daniels, that city's first black chief executive, successfully fought off a challenge from a Republican Alderman, Jonathan J. Einhorn, and won another two years in office. And in Stamford, a Republican candidate, Stanley J. Esposito, who had been endorsed by the current Mayor, Thom Serrani, a Democrat, won handily over the Democrat, Sandra Goldstein.
In Hartford, the state's second-largest city, Mayor Carrie Saxon Perry, a Democrat, was unopposed.
Democrats, who accounted for the majority of legislators' votes for the income tax, generally fared well, picking up town hall control in 22 communities, including Bridgeport, previously controlled by Republicans and losing 10, for a net gain of 12. Republicans who opposed the income tax also lost in West Haven and East Haven.
Ms. Moran, a Republican who battled her way to the top office in a city long dominated by Democrats, lost by about 4,000 votes out of about 20,000 votes cast, according to the unofficial count. Mr. Ganim will become the second-youngest mayor ever in Bridgeport, and Ms. Moran becomes the only mayor since Fred Atwater in 1923 to be denied a second term in office. Mr. Ganim melded a law-and order appeal with a repeated message that Ms. Moran's combativeness had only made Bridgeport's problems worse.
 
Prosecutors Blamed
 In Waterbury, Mr. Santopietro, the mayor since 1985, received only 6,635 votes with all 32 precincts reporting, compared with 14,075 votes for Mr. Bergin, a Democrat, and 11,786 votes for Josephine Mills, an independent candidate making her first bid for public office.
"The Federal prosecutors have won their first election," Mr. Santopietro told about 200 of his supporters gathered at the Pontelandolfo Community Club. Mr. Santopietro has pleaded not guilty to all the charges against him.
The state Democratic Party chairman, John F. Droney Jr., said the party's gains in many areas across the state were in part a result of the "failure of the Republican strategy to superimpose the income tax on local candidates" but also of what Mr. Droney said was the party's tradition of being the one people turn to in bad times.
"When times are tough, just as it was with Roosevelt, people go with the Democrats," he said.
Mr. Droney's counterpart, the state Republican Party chairman, Richard Foley Jr., conceded that some of the losses hurt, but that Democrats had also suffered, losing control of several mid-sized communities including Middletown, Norwalk, and Litchfield, in addition to Stamford, the state's fifth-largest city.
 
Clear and Ambivalent
 But other numbers were indisputable. The Democrats now control town halls in the four largest cities, and some small communities that have traditionally been Republican strongholds, like Eastford, a small town in the northeast corner of the state that was thought never to have ceded control of the local government to Democrats until tonight.
But any grandiose claims were tempered by the hesitation that many voters also expressed. In New Haven, in particular, where Mr. Daniels won by more than 7,000 votes in 1989, his margin of victory was cut nearly in half. With 29 of the 30 precincts reporting, Mr. Daniels had 15,827 votes to 11,655 votes for Mr. Einhorn, the Republican. Registered Democrats outnumber Republicans by about 9-to-1 in New Haven.
"This is no mandate for John Daniels," Mr. Einhorn said in a speech to his supporters. "It's not even a slap on the back -- he's lost a substantial part of his own constituency."
In Stamford, where the city's once sterling image as a gleaming center of white-collar corporate power has been pulled down by the recession and a large glut in commercial office space, Mr. Esposito said in his victory speech that the vote for a Republican mayor was a vote for "open and fiscally responsible government."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor John C. Daniels, who was re-elected in New Haven, at victory party. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: FIRST-CLASS MAIL STAYS AT 29 CENTS

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
The United States Postal Service refused today to raise the price of mailing a first-class letter by a penny, with opponents of an increase contending that the timing was poor because of the shaky economy.
Six of the service's nine governors favored the increase, to 30 cents, but the motion was defeated because a unanimous vote was required. The increase was intended to insure sufficient funds until 1995. 
 Norma Pace, the board chairman, who supported the increase, said it was opposed by three governors who thought an increase unwise in "a period of economic stagnation."
Richard M. Kessel, executive director of the New York State Consumer Protection Board, said the increase would have been "a severe setback to the already fragile U.S. economy."
 
Disappointment Expressed
 Postmaster General Anthony Frank said, "If we could have had a 30-cent first-class stamp, we would have needed only one more rate change this decade." He predicted increases in 1994 and 1997 or 1998.
Mr. Frank predicted a surplus for fiscal 1992 of about $600 million, but he predicted that "as our costs go up and our prices stay steady, why we'll start to lose money."
The Postal Service governors oversee the operation of the Postal Service. The Postmaster General, himself a governor, reports to the Board of Governors, which proposes changes in postal rates to the independent Postal Rate Commission.
The commission studies the proposals, invites comments and then makes its recommendation to the governors, who can either accept or reject the recommendations. Once a recommendation is accepted, however, the governors can only change the rate by a unanimous vote.
The service estimates a $1.5 billion deficit in fiscal 1991, which ended Sept. 30, after an $874 million deficit in 1990.
The Postal Service asked for a 5-cent increase, to a 30-cent first-class rate in March 1990. Ten months later, the Postal Rate Commission recommended a 4-cent increase, to 29 cents. The increase took effect last February.

HEADLINE: Two Years of Trouble;
With Legislature Going Republican, Florio Faces Confrontations Into '93

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Irate about taxes, New Jersey voters set the stage today for what promises to be two years of confrontational politics between Gov. Jim Florio and a new a Republican legislative majority.
The voters, who turned out in numbers far larger than expected, wrested control of the Senate and the Assembly from Mr. Florio's Democratic Party and for the first time in 20 years made the Republicans dominant in both houses. 
 The anger was over Mr. Florio's $2.8 billion tax package and the speed with which a Democratic Legislature had pushed it through. Last year that public displeasure almost cost Bill Bradley his seat in the United States Senate. Today voters clearly showed that their anger has not abated. And the off-year election that proved as much was certainly being watched in Connecticut, where a new income tax is meeting with strong opposition, and in states around the country, where voters are clamoring to tell officials how angry they are.
 
A Republican View
 Many Republicans believe that Mr. Florio's sudden entry into the campaign in the last two weeks, when he said Democratic candidates should "get off their knees" and start defending the tax program, was calculated to shield himself from blame if Democrats did poorly.
"He was innoculating himself against disaster," said Assemblyman Robert D. Franks of New Providence, the State Republican Chairman. "Now he can stand up after the election and say that what happened was not a rejection of his policies, because nobody defended them, and he'll promise to make his case to the voters over the next two years."
Mr. Franks added, "Some would argue that the election was an absolute rejection of the Governor's entire program and that it was time to go back to the drawing board." But he said he does not expect Republicans to reject all of Mr. Florio's programs out of hand.
In the days before the election Mr. Florio had said he would work with the new legislative leadership, regardless of which party prevailed. But Republicans are skeptical. Jeff Michaels, the executive director of the Republican State Committee, said that if Mr. Florio was sincere about reducing public anger over his tax policies, "he could have turned it around after the last election by admitting he made a mistake."
It is more than Mr. Florio's tax and school aid programs that are likely to come up for revision, and it could be more than Republicans who try to do the revising. The National Rifle Association put about $200,000 into the campaigns of candidates likely to support their drive to weaken Mr. Florio's ban on automatic weapons. Mr. Florio has vetoed one attempt to weaken the law without inspiring a serious effort to override his decision. He may have a tougher time when the issue comes up again.
In addition to the Republicans, the Democrats who won today will also be on the ballot in 1993, and they will have to assess their re-election chances in 1993. Some political consultants say Mr. Florio may have as much trouble retaining his party's support as he will dealing with a Republican majority.
Jay Severin, the chairman of Severin/Aviles, a New York-based campaign consulting company that works for Republican clients, including the New Jersey party organization, said voters in New Jersey had "a clear target" in Mr. Florio.
"People don't turn out in large numbers to defend anybody," Mr. Severin said. "They turn out to spit in somebody's eye."
The voters had personalized their anger and focused it on Mr. Florio early on. "Impeach Florio" bumper stickers could be seen everywhere and grass-roots antitax groups bloomed overnight.
The Governor's lack of popularity was a problem for Democratic campaign strategists, and it prompted many Democratic candidates to run without mentioning their party and to try to distance themselves from their support for the Governor's program.
Mr. Florio's problems at midterm contrasted with the experience of his predecessor, Thomas H. Kean, in 1981. Mr. Kean, a Republican, also promised not to raise taxes during his campaign and then signed increases in both the sales and income taxes to meet a budget deficit caused by a recession. Two years later Mr. Kean had become one of the most popular governors in state history.
Mr. Kean was helped by an economic turnaround, something that has not shown up to help Mr. Florio. But there have been other differences between the two. Stephen A. Salmore, a professor of political science at Rutgers and a Republican consultant, recalled that Mr. Kean initially supported a 5-cent increase in the gasoline tax, and that when the measure cleared only one house of the Democratic-controlled Legislature, Mr. Kean told the lawmakers to come up with their own solution. When Mr. Kean signed the sales and income-tax increase, he criticized the tax bills and "held his nose" as he signed them, Mr. Salmore said.
By contrast, Mr. Florio and Democratic leaders rejoiced after enacting the tax package, and this is what turned the public against him, Mr. Salmore said.
"People didn't go against Florio because he lied or raised taxes; people expect politicians to lie, and they accept tax increases if they're prepared for them," Mr. Salmore said. "What Florio did was raise taxes and smile, and it was the smile that got him."
